Good location. Average service at check in. Overall was good stay for the price you paid. Rooms are quite small but it’s normal for hotels in Tokyo. Comfortable bed though. Friendly service at the bar.

I had mixed feelings of this hotel. The location is well located and the hotel is recently refurbished. The rooms are small - as expected in Tokyo - but nicely furnished and up-to-date.However the breakfast room is absolutely outdated and the breakfast is reasonable but not great.

Really enjoyed our 5 night stay here. Room spacious by Japanese standards also very quiet. Bed firm but comfortable. Great buffet breakfast. Location was really convenient, subway station outside and lots of restaurants nearby. Seven eleven also very close. Easy access to fish markets and walkable to JR station.

Hotel is located near Ginza Station (Metro Ginza Line) and Ginza-itchōme Station (Metro Yurakucho Line). Reception provided good service. Room is not quite big but still comfort. this hotel don't have fitness or pool but some fitness is located near hotel.

Hotel and rooms very clean, staff courteous, professional and very helpful. Breakfast choices were numerous and food fresh and of good quality. Room amenities were excellent and the use of a smart phone very helpful.

I’ve stayed at several Mercure hotels in Europe and always been pleased, so I was looking forward to a weekend in Ginza. The location is great and the hotel is in good condition but I expected a lot more. The room was tiny, there was no desk to work at and there was almost no storage space. The high price may have been due to the Tokyo marathon, but even allowing for that you don’t get a lot for your money.

The hotel is really easy to get to from the station and has a quirkiness about the lobby which is fun. For the price we expected a bigger room - we had a lot of luggage and one small wardrobe with one shelf - and tiny drawers by the bedside - meant that during our stay we spent our time moving bags around so we could get to the bed, the chair (singular), the kettle.It was clean and welcoming though.Originally my husband booked then we decided I would go along too. We were told he was entitled to a breakfast included but not me, that would be extra (something like $20 per day). We therefore asked them for no breakfast one day, 2 the next. After a bit of hesitation they agreed. Frankly, the breakfast is certainly not value though it ws pleasant enough.

I have stayed here more than once. Good location in Ginza with friendly staff and helpful staff in the restaurant and very clean rooms. Reception is efficient and checks in and out quickly. I would stay here again.

walk to subway is very convenience just take lift to B1 and walk for 3 minutes and boom, subway is there, very easy.Many Restaurant around the area include Lawson just around the cornerNice Breakfast, staff in cafe is very helpful, work much more than his payment.Room is OK, space is ok, clean, we have nice stay there.Concierge were helpful, we appreciated so much.

The hotel is easily accessed and is superbly situated. The rooms are extremely well presented and designed for ease of use for all age groups. The staff were extremely helpful and were friendly and humorous when dealing with our family group. Breakfasts were beautifully presented and offered a great range of European and Japanese food. I would certainly stay there in the future and recommend it to others.

First time staying in Ginza and wanted a hotel that was also close to where I had my business meetings. Great location close to shops as well as great places to eat. Rooms were a decent size and comfortable

The hotel only 15-20 minutes on walk from Tokyo Station. It also near (there was a pathway from the hotel basement) from Ginza-itchome station for Yurakucho Line. Another great thing was a McDonalds next to carpark entrance. Also 1 minute from the convenience store. The room was great with a handy mobile phone that can take outside the hotel (it was free). Reasonable price for family stay.

The hotel is in a prime location. However, the rooms are very small. Only 1 lift was working. There’s no gym. I am not sure with the price, is this worth it? I would rather go to another hotel. Breakfast buffet is very small too.

Tokyo Mercure Ginza is situated at the famous shopping area Ginza. It is in the central area in Tokyo near the Tokyo Railway Station. The Ginza Metro Station is also around. It is also convenient for people in particular from the Heneda Airport by Monorail followed by JR lines to Ginza. Mercure Ginza is not a big and grand hotel. However, in Japanese standard, its rooms which have recently been renovated are really spacious, clean and well designed providing very good sleeping quality. I could have sweet dreams each and every night throughout my 5-night stay. Over the past couple of years, I had stayed with Mercure Ginza for 3 times excluding this one. I met again my good friend Romain who worked in the Bar and the Guest Relation Manager Jae. Taking this opportunity, I would like to extend my sincere gratitude for their job well done. I am really happy with their service and warm hospitality. My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed our stay with the hotel. I should appreciate it if the Hotel Management would convey to them our thanks and regards. We will definitely be back on our next visit to Tokyo. Certainly, I also highly recommend this hotel to my friends.

Anyone who wants to go to Tokyo should have this very nice hotel in their minds. I was truly amazed. As of November 2018 the hotel undergone renovations and it is wonderful. Everything is new, shiny and clean. Common areas as reception and aisles are beautifully decorated, and very modern. Modernity does not mean poor taste or coldness. I really liked it. Rooms are impeccable, with new furniture and nice amenities. I was even given a cell-phone with 4G connectivity to use during my stay!!I want to thank all the staff for their kindness. The employees at the reception and the waiters at the bar were awesome. Breakfast is very good, I recommend paying for it. You’ll find all the western options and some local flavors as well.I stayed for 17 nights; a very long stay and was assigned room 1008. During a stay that long it would be easy to have any sort of issue, but in this case my stay has been so great!! People make a great contribution to a client experience, and in this case I have nothing to complain about.In terms of location, it is very good!! Just a couple of blocks from the Ginza Avenue, just a few blocks from the Wako building (use it as a reference) The metro line Yurakucho, at the Ginza-itchome station, in the exit 11 has a direct entrance to the Hotel, it is convenient and useful, especially in bad weather.I loved this city and I want to get back. Japan is a beautiful country, with great people and services. I loved this hotel, it has been very rewarding to stay there.Had I the chance of coming back to Tokyo, this hotel will be my only option.

The location is very close with sub way station, near lawson and family mart.. in the heart of Ginza.. the room is small, clean enough and nice hospitality.. need deposit when check in.. the staff was good and nice.. just 1 elevator working while the other one was out of service.. Thank you..

Hotel is conveniently located in the heart of Ginza. Took the Narita express bus to Ginza station. It’s about 10-15walk from ginza bus station. Easy access if you have luggage with you as there’s no need to carry up any stairs. It’s just behind LV. There is a Lawson and Mc Donald nearby. Main entrance is located in the smaller street. It doesn’t have a grand entrance. Room was good. Got upgraded as an Accor Plus Gold Member and they gave me a late checkout as well. Room doesn’t have a view but a good size for Tokyo standard. There’s lotsa good food nearby so don’t need to worry much about getting hungry. The popular Bills restaurant is about 5 mins away as well.

The location of the Ginza Mercure is so handy to shopping and transport hubs. This was the 3rd time we have stayed at this hotel and it keeps getting better. Staff are super helpful and the rooms are good.Very spacious bed and a comfortable stay. Highly recommended

We arriving at 7.30am with 4 kids and 1 infant . I ask hotel staff politely if they can help with this situation. The staff answered they would do the best with 2 room cleaning services. Amazingly , 2 connecting room available at 11 am !!! What a service !!! With those kind of services, mercure ginza other services looks perfect ! Hahaha

We love the location of Mercure Ginza, it’s very easy to get to subway stations. Standard rooms are small compared to deluxe room we stayed in previously, however not much time spent there. Breakfast buffet is OK and all staff are always friendly and helpful. Hotel renovated and would recommend and stay again.

The hotel is located in Ginza area which is central location for those who love to do shopping in Ginza. There are many department stores, restaurants, and coffeehouses in the area. Travel to the hotel from Narita Airport is easy. I took the Keisei Skyliner from Narita Airport to Ueno Station, then transfer to Ginza subway line, and alight at Ginza Station. The exit A13 is closed during my visit, so I use the another nearby exit instead to the Matsuya Ginza Department Store, and I walk from the Matsuya to the hotel in few minutes. There are a Lawson, 7-11, and Family Mart convenience store nearby. McDonald's is just downstairs. The hotel reception is located on the second floor. The lobby is very small. The staff was helpful during my stay. They also have a Ginza map to help you with travelling around the area.The check-in was fast, however the staff still asked me to get my credit card swiped as a security deposit which I did not find such process in other Mercure hotels. The room size was decent for Japanese standard. It was clean with basic room facilities. Wi-Fi Internet was okay with fair speed.They serve breakfast in a restaurant on second floor, opposite the lobby. The breakfast was okay, but boring with limited choices.The hotel also provided the complimentary handy 4G smartphone in the room. You can bring and use it outside hotel. The Internet is unlimited with some city guides and free call.They were renovating the hotel during my visit, and one of the elevators are closed. There was only one elevator to serve the entire hotel which was annoying, because the wait time was usually long than usual.Mercure Tokyo Ginza is a centrally located hotel in Ginza area. The room was small, but clean. Breakfast was average. The staff service was okay. When it comes to the price, I think I can find better value-for-money alternatives in the area.

I was pleasantly surprised with the location of the hotel. It was close to everything: grocery stores (Lawson, Family Mart), restaurants (both fast food and Japanese cuisines), coffee shops (Doutour, Starbucks), and Ginza shopping. Felt like everything is within walking distance. We walked around and managed to visit Tsukiji and Ginza area during our really short stay.They provided late check out for us (which is great) since our flight out was in the early evening, so we could maximize our walking around time on the last day. All in all, love the hotel and definitely will try to stay here again next time.

staff language issues in speaking English. well not so much speaking but knowing how to explain things. IE the dining area turns in to a bar at night but they do serve breakfast in the AM. the PM staff said no restaurant Bar only....There were other issues too. I will not stay here again even if there is direct access to the trains underneath the hotel. hmm is that safe...must be in this earthquake proof nation.

Dear Mercure hotel, We must tell you that how disappointed it is to know that our booking can’t earn points due to staffs rate, not to mention the price is not cheap, and the fridge was not cold at all, we brought expensive food and it turn bad :(Accor program has great reputation and after this time, it make you second thought about trying to book anything with Accor again,Thank you for your follow up.

The hotel is perfectly located. There is a metro subway under the hotel Basement one, it connects to Ginza station and Tokyo station and many more. The hotel has descent size rooms each room has a GPS handy device which includes free international phone calls. It also allows to use all features. Including maps, internet and restaurants, events etc. the toilets are Japanese so for the flush button it’s located at the back on the right hand side (hard to find) The bar in the hotel has a variety of drinks and great place to relax before dinner. The restaurant in the hotel is only open at this stage for breakfast. The food is great. Also near the hotel there is kit Kat chocolate place if you have a sweet tooth. Great to visit. There is plenty of restaurants and cafes close to the hotel.

If you don't mind the absence of a grand foyer (the check-in counter is one floor above via 2 elevators), everything else exceeded our expectations, including large rooms recently refurbished, a smartphone with free usage and its central location to Ginza and beyond, thanks to a basement passageway to the Tokyo metro. The main Tokyo station is a 7min ride away by taxi, where one can connect to Narita Airport either by train, or nonstop bus express (US 10).A little pricey, but really average for Tokyo. Will gladly return. A little pricey, but really average for Tokyo

Location in Ginza..place for luxury brand shopping..Hotel 3 minutes walk from train station and next to Mc Donald and supermarket just arround the corner..Room is not too big just enough..Staff very friendly

A wonderful location and room a good size staff exceptional so helpfulRoom was spotless and loved the free smart phone with a walking GPSThe Ginz, restaurants, and railway all within easy walking distance If you don’t care for Japanese food there is a McDonalds about 100metres up the road and also a seven 11 not far. A wonderful stay

I like the area very much as well as the hotel. Lots of brands are in Ginza main street. Very near with many stations and the night don't sleep till midnight. Clubs and bars are opened till 2 to 4 am in the morning. The staffs are very helpful and fluent in many languages. I overheard some guests saying the staffs are very nice and I couldn't agree more on the fact. Overall, loved it.

We found this hotel to be excellently located for our first visit to Tokyo. The staff was friendly and helpful. For its grading our room was comfortable and for Japan roomy. We were able to get over our jet-lag in a quiet well appointed room and take advantage of the numerous attractions within walking distance of the hotel. We would definitely stay here on any subsequent visit.

Not too bad, but not too great either. The location is decent, with easy walking distance to most things in Ginza, shopping, eating, etc, but the hotel is average at best. Staff were nice and helpful (they even offered us a drink after the restaurant had closed, as there was no bar), but that's the best aspect. The carpark was too small for our car, so we had to park somewhere offsite (a 10-`15 min walk away), and the hotel was undergoing renovations, which was a pain. Lifts were very slow and dirty, and the rooms seemed from an age gone by, so I'm not sure what was being renovated. Certainly not my floor! The room was tiny, and was oddly laid out, but in a bad way. There were odd nooks and areas that weren't much use, and not a lot of space to put my things, and certainly barely any space to work. The window was also tiny! Furnishings were okay ,and at least the room was clean. I'm not sure I'd stay again...

Reasonable place to stay in Tokyo for two weeks. European style (with some japanese plates) breakfast was more than enough to the travelers like me. Good location in Ginza. Only 20 minutes to the Tsukizi fish market, the same foot distance to the Emperor gardens. Tokyo station is also in steps distance from the hotel. Underground station is just beneath the hotel building.

Stayed here for three nightsFantastic location in Ginza extremely close to the subway. Loads of restaurants and bars nearby and short walk to the shopping heart of Ginza. Taxis easy to get on the neighbouring streets and connivence stores, fast food, coffee shops and speciality stores nearby too. Rooms were very modern but very small. Tokyo hotel rooms are obviously small as space as a premium but we had a cot in our room too which was a struggle! Bathroom was a bit dated but find. Make sure you pack light and for those of you who like to spread out- might not be for you as very tight. We were able to check in early which was fabulous. Wifi was good and free wifi device in room is available to be used which was also very handy. We were travelling with a baby and they were very happy to provide a cot for us which was great

My husband and I stayed here for a week this Oct/Nov for our trip to Tokyo and found it was perfectly comfortable but for a week stay perhaps not ideal. Only reason I say this is because to unpack there really isn't anywhere to put your clothes if staying any longer than a weekend. A few hanger but nothing else, also the line you need on the subway is quite some walking to and from which again is fine if your prepared for it! Other than this it was clean, comfortable and well priced!!Just a side note: the restaurant only serves food at breakfast.... wasn't an issue for us but possibly for others.

I stayed at Mercure Tokyo Ginza for 3 nights with my family and we had a great time. The hotel has a convenient location to different subway lines, and a passage to the Ginza-Itchome station on the Yurakucho lines is accessible directly from the hotel basement, however you have to walk perhaps 400 meters. You can also easily reach the Higashi-Ginza station on the Hibiya line and Ginza station where you will find the Ginza, Hibiya and Marunouchi lines, by foot. The breakfast is OK, but a bit strange, like they can't decide if it should be a japanese or western style but the coffee was great. Our room was spacious and very fresh and modern, and we were offered an early check in without any additional charge, which was great because we could get a few ours of sleep before we started to explore Tokyo.

My third visit to this hotel. Nearly all I wrote in my previous review still stands except the minibar is no longer stocked and the entrance area and reception have been overhauled. The major plus on this visit was the outstandingly helpful Yumi on reception who went to great lengths to ensure we found tickets for the recent Australia/New Zealand rugby match. Certainly way and beyond service and thank you again.The one disappointment was the poor directions given to get to Haneda Airport via subway. Yes it is on the Toei Asakusa (red) line from Higashi Ginza station (not Asakusa station as one member of reception insisted (I knew she was wrong because we visited the shrine and station of the same name). The two important pieces of information that were omitted were that the two Higashi Ginza platforms can only be reached above ground. We had to climb back up a long flight of stairs with our suitcases and cross the busy main road to access the correct platform. The second important piece of information is to look for the train with Haneda on the headboard as not all trains go to that airport.

The Mercure hotel is a typical European style business hotel centrally placed in the Ginza area - relatively close to Tokyo Station. Staff is friendly and helpful. They have closed down their restaurant, but then Ginza is full of them.

Stayed here two nights after a cruise. The location is terrific, just two blocks off the main shopping street of the Ginza. They were just finishing renovations so the lobby was closed off. However, all rooms were finished and noise was not an issue at all. Check in was easy and they held our bags for us until check in time. The staff was quite friendly and helpful. The room was exactly as you would expect in Japan--small, expensive (about $300 per night) but certainly more than adequate. We choose to have our suitcases on the floor since there was really no other place for them. There is a room safe, refrigerator, TV, nice sized bath including a super duper toilet with all the Japanese gadgets. But nicest of all, the room had a free smart phone that you could take with you while you toured the city. It also offered completely free calls to various countries including the US. It was a terrific touch especially since our older version phones did not work on the Japanese cell phone frequencies. We made sure to opt for the room package that included breakfast. Breakfast is on the second floor, is buffet style, and includes both Eastern and Western style breakfast items. The coffee was quite tasty out of their large custom coffee machine. We extended our check out by two hours--one they gave us free and one we paid an extra 1000 Yen (about $10). Your bill will also show an additional 400 Yen local tax which most likely was not already figured into your room rate.In terms of airport transportation, here's the deal. To Narita, where most international flights are, would be about $250 by taxi so not a good choice. There is bus service but the stop is not within easy walking distance with luggage. So, have the hotel call a taxi for you (tell them how much luggage you have so they call the right size) and take it to the Tokyo Station Yaesu South Entrance which will cost about 1000 Yen ($10). They can't enter the bus area but can drop you off about 50 yards south. Find bus platform #7 for The Access Narita bus which runs frequently and costs a mere 1000 Yen. They will take your bags and mark which airline you're flying so they unload them at the right stop. We used this on a holiday Monday so our driving time to Narita was a fast 55 minutes. Terminal 2 is where most of the flights are and it has 2 entrance doors so ask which stop is for your airline. American Airlines, for example, uses the first stop which is door 2. Overall between the hotel and the bus, we would definitely do this again.

We were upgraded to a Privilege room with free soft drinks and snacks everyday plus a free 4G mobile to take out of the hotel for maps etc. Saved us a fortune on using our own mobiles and renting a SIM. A good stay.

This hotel is situated near the heart of Ginza near a subway station. So location is very good. Staff are friendly and efficient. The room we stayed in was quite spacious by Tokyo standard. However, there is no security to speak of. Anyone can come up the lift to your room. The restaurant on site only serves breakfast. Fortunately, there are plenty of eateries nearby. It is apparently still under renovation. Should be a nicer hotel when renovation is completed.

I stayed here for my business trip from Monday to Friday. I’m a platinum member and consider that this is the by far the worst AccorHotels.1) Check In was way too long. I booked my 5 days trip on the app. The receptionist had to use my credit card three times. Firstly they charged me only for four days. Then they had to use my Visa card again as they forgot to charge me for breakfast. Then they checked and realised I booked five days. The whole process took me 40 minutes.2) forgot to give me vouchers - I went to the Resturant for my breakfast before my big meeting. I went to the Resturant and was asked to present voucher. Needless to say, they never gave me any. I had to do all that after work to get my breakfast vouchers.3) most hotel stamped the validity date of their breakfast vouchers for your entire stay. No, not this hotel. You have to check the day of your voucher. Each voucher is valid on a specific date. On my second day, I used my fifth day voucher. The second Day voucher expired on my last day! This is just stupid... I ended up buying breakfast elsewhere as I’m sick and tired of dealing with this hotel again!

This wasn’t value for money as we paid close to $300 a night. There was construction going on which was quite disruptive with a tiny reception area and minimal food options. Room service only had breakfast. It was so inconvenient to get to the reception on the first floor. The rooms were tiny as well. Very conveniently located though and close to everything which was the only positive. Rooms were clean but tiny

Perfect location, excellent amenities, and very helpful staff. We had a weekend in Tokyo and wanted to use Ginza as a base to get around the city. The hotel has an access to the subway under the building that you can access from the hotel elevator: now that's service. Check-in was a breeze, and in a very un-Japanese manner, they let us check in before 3pm. You can't go wrong with this place.

A Great Hotel staff are excellent and very Helpfull, food is really good and the Hotel is in a good location there are two Metro stations within a 10min walk that can get you anywhere in Tokyo, rooms are large and well appointed

The hotel is in a great location close to the Tokyo Station and several metro stations. The room was comfortable, clean and tidy. The hotel is currently undergoing renovations. With only one elevator working and the hotel restaurant closed for dinner. We were disappointed that we weren’t advised of the renovations prior to check-in.

Good hotel with nice friendly helpful staffThis was our second visit Last stayed in 2013 and we were happy to return A little surprised our room was tired this time round but renovation was happening on higher floors in the hotel On the last day of our trip we opened our room door in the morning to find the carpet and hallways covered in plastic and workmen everywhere We were the only guests on the floor, every other room was stripped We had a late checkout in the afternoon and the work made our last day uncomfortable This could have been avoided completely if we’d been warned or advised. Really disappointed in the final experience on our last day of our trip It was very hot and we were tired but not able to relax due to the work outside the room

Been staying at this hotel because of its location. It has been sweltering in Tokyo with temperatures reaching 37 degrees. We asked for some water to fill our bottles (refraining from using PET bottles), first 2 days were fine but on the 3rd day we were informed that it was not permitted. Huh? Where’s the consistency in that? We were just asking for tap water. Never been refused water until now. Almost seems ridiculous.

The hotel is perfectly located, close to the train station and many metro lines. It is a great spot to start visiting Tokyo. The rooms are not very big, but comfortable and rather quiet. The only thing was that we booked for two adults and a child of 5, and we got a room with two beds. We would have to pay on top for a roll away bed. The breakfast was ok, nothing special, rather continental than Japanese.

The hotel was located in the lovely area of Ginza and hosted our first ever trip to Tokyo for a holiday. We found that the location was great and we used the subway system to get around the tourist hotspots with ease. The room in the hotel was recently renovated and had everything that we needed for our stay. As expected the room was quite small but adequate nonetheless. The front desk team were helpful and very welcoming. I would recommend this hotel. If travelling from Narita Airport, the Access Narita is the quickest and cheapest direct option and stopped very close to the hotel.

This is a basic tourist hotel if one wish to stay in Ginza area whereby everything is within walking distance.The drawback is that it is under renovation and one can go straight up to your hotel floor without any hotel card. Any stranger can go up and down as they wish for the moment.Service wise, it is within expectation.

The hotel is ideally situated in the Ginza district, close to all the luxury shops and interesting stores. The Tsukiji market is at a walking distance, the Tokyo rail station is close. Overall the hotel is great, the only problem is the room size: the rooms have a "Japanese size" (ie they are tiny...)

Stayed at Mercure during 4 day visit to Tokio last year. Small hotel with friendly service, close to Metro. Asked reception for teppanyaki and shabu shabu restaurants and good excellent recommendations nearby. Would stay again!

We used to use this hotel as our business hotel, but I fear we must say this is no longer a good choice as a business hotel. Although the floors saw some renovation, the rooms are as small as they ever were (sure, that's natural), however there is no more desk available in the room. This used to be below the window, which was quite practical, nowadays there is no such desk anymore in those rooms. Prices also went up quite significantly. The breakfast is "french", so it does not comply with German business standards at al.

I am so happy I booked this hotel on my first visit to Tokyo. We had a clean and tidy hotel room with two queen beds and a desk inside. The location of the hotel was perfect we were close to the station to take you to all the major tourist attractions and straight back to the airport. Ginza itself is a beautiful area of Tokyo with good shopping and amazing restaurants. We could walk everywhere staying at this hotel. I would highly recommend a stay at the Mercure when visiting Tokyo, you won’t be disappointed.

So happy to have booked this hotel for our first trip to Tokyo!! First of all, its location is unbeatable. Easy to travel here from Narita via the Access Narita bus -- it costs only 1000 yen and drops you off at Sukiyabashi crossing in Ginza, some 550 meters away from the hotel. Sidewalks in Ginza are EXTREMELY clean and well maintained so you won't have any problem lugging your luggages. (The Access Narita bus has a very user friendly website that shows their bus stops at Narita, Tokyo station, and Ginza. Also, no need to buy tickets, just pay cash direct to driver.)Hotel is close to both Ginza station (with access to 3 Tokyo subway lines), around 5 mins walk away, and Ginza-itchome station, which has an exit at the hotel basement. From there, it was so easy for us to travel to the different tourist spots in Tokyo. The hotel is in a lovely quiet neighborhood and is just a stone's throw away from the main shopping highway. There are loads of designer names but also several middle-end stores like Uniqlo, Gu, Loft, Muji, Itoya stationery, ABC Mart (for sneakers), Hakuhinkan Toy Park, and a 24 hour Don Quixote. I was able to walk to Don Q at midnight, and felt very safe!! We also loved that there were a few Lawsons and a Family Mart nearby as well as a 24 hr McDonald's, for the late night munchies!!The hotel room was very clean, beds were firm and comfortable, and space was sufficient. Room came with a writing desk, ref and closet, as well as a spacious bathroom (and I believe this is exceptional for Tokyo hotel standards). Bathroom was pristine. My only gripe was the carpeting, which looked like it could use a good shampooing, and the aircon which took a long time to cool and felt warm at times. Hopefully they fix this with the current renovations.Staff were warm and pleasant and made us feel welcome. Regards to Estelita Kai who helped us during check out. All in all, a super pleasant stay!

Mecure Ginza is in a great location, so much so that this was our second stay there. The room this time, like last is of an adequate size for start and end of days. The breakfast restaurant is very good (buffet) which our daughter thought was great.Very close to many attractions and importantly very close to the subway. Well recommended.

Friendly and helpful staff who went out of their way to help. At the end they helped call our next place we were staying in to speak to them in Japanese as they didn’t speak English and we needed to confirm our arrival. Rooms were small but enough room to have suitcases. Bathroom was clean. Would stay again

Stayed here for 3 nights. Location was great right in the heart of Ginza.. metro at the end of the street. Breakfast was ok not much selection but certainly ok. No facilities for dining for dinner or lunch but many choices in Ginza so not a major issue. Reception was great v organised and efficient. Hotel rooms were fine bathroom ok with a great toilet! I didn’t find the rooms too small for Tokyo pretty good. I would return here for a stay hopefully more dining facilities by then. Some renovating going on but heard nothing! Accor membership gives you discount on breakfast as well. Could do with more fresh fruit for breakfast there was only one plate of sliced fruit. All up a good stay and will return.

Perfect, perfect and more perfect. Easy quick check in, polite fast and efficient customer service, room was very clean, bathroom with deep bath, quality shower, generous supply and replenishment of toiletries, helpful tourist information, handy to Ginza metro, main shopping area and lots of bars, cafes, restaurants and small supermarkets. We really enjoyed our stay here and will definitely consider staying again if we return to Tokyo.

This hotel has so much potential. Great spot, would accommodate an extra bed in the room. However, it really lets itself down. Air con did not work, breakfast was poor (packet scrambled eggs), reception was slow.

On our first arrival in Japan, the hotel became a sanctuary welcoming us back every time we ventured out into the streets of Tokyo. Rooms very clean, modern and trouble-free.The bar was poorly utilised by guests, which may have been the reason why the barman was a tad surly. But the Japanese staff were very attentive and informative, and the breakfasts were good quality. Location is perfect for seeing the sights: within walking distance of the famous fish markets. A handy tip: the hotel has an exclusive entrance to the subway in the basement, and is easily the best way of getting further afield.

The room is what you would expect, it was small, mostly clean. The problem mainly was that the room was hot when we entered so we put our room key in the hard holder to turn on electricity and turn down the ac. Hours later, it did not get much cooler so we had a technician come in to fix. It seemed to work, however a few hours later it become hot again. Then we asked to change rooms which we did. The next room had working ac. It was mainly an ordeal that we should not have dealt with when paying for the basics of a clean room with a working air conditioner.

We arrived at the hotel around 7:30am from Australia. Our room was not ready as we hadn't arranged the extra night in Advance. Estelita Kai on the desk did everything she could to get us a room. The other girls in reception were fantastic as well. The room was small, but we were warned about that before we left Australia. It was clean and comfortable. There is an added bonus of the mobile phone for use whilst staying there. All in all I would stay there again if visiting Tokyo.

We had enjoyed our stay at Mercure Tokyo Ginza in 2016 but unfortunately we didn't do so this time. The room we had was smaller than the last visit (even though it was the same price/category) and we had ongoing problems with the air conditioning. I barely slept the first night because the a/c kept switching off and the room became unbearably stuffy. We complained the next morning and it was much better the second night but again barely worked on the third and last night of our stay by which time there was no point in complaining again. We stayed at the hotel both times mainly because I am an Accor member but I will probably look for other accommodation the next time we are in Tokyo.

An ideal base from exploring Ginza with good access to other parts of central Tokyo.Well positioned to access Haneda, using Asakusa Line / Keikyu Line from HIgashi-Ginza.Rooms are excellent and should be further improved when the current refurbishment is complete.

I have Accor Platinum status. The only reason I stay in this hotel is because of the location and the early check-in and late check-out associated to my Accor Loyalty card.The hotel is under renovation - which is 5 years overdue. The elevators are jammed by construction workers. The lower floors are not disturbed by the construction.The reception area is very small, totally run down and puts you back in the 70’s, the staff seems to be equally depressed by the condition of the hotel. The rooms are of course run down too, beds, linnen, shower are acceptable. Room 321 is like a tight, tiny, dark shoebox. I made a U-turn and requested a change. Room 307 is larger but still that small that the TV doesn’t fit on the wall at the end of the bed. The worst had to come. The Breakfast is a shame. I can’t recall any hotel in Japan (or any other Accor Hotel inclusive Ibis) having the guts providing such mediocre quality. Our 3 children asked me « papa, there is nothing to eat ». Everything was cold and had been there for hours. It took 15 minutes to get a piece of bread (they don’t replenish). The staff is totally helpless, doesn’t know what to do and of course doesn’t speak English. The breakfast is provided by and external company which is only interested in cashing the vouchers.Obviously management doesn’t care about its current customers. Getting the hotel ready for Tokyo 2020 and keeping on cashing in is their only focus.This Mercure experience is being sold for 250usd per night.

We enjoyed our stay at Mercure Ginza. We took a train from Skinjuku station to Ginza and it is only about 500 meters from there. You will need to have some map navigation to find it from the station though. The hotel is in a great location, currently it is being renovated. We booked a Deluxe room, which was a reasonable size. there is step up to get into the bathroom which was a bit odd, but no problem, shower is over the bath which seems to be a common theme in Japan. The staff were great and inviting, we were disappointed to learn that the restaurant has closed and is only open for breakfast's, but there are lots of local restaurants around. location is great, and happy to recommend the hotel.

The Mercure is in an excellent location in the upmarket area of Ginza. The rooms are generous in size for Japan. The staff were friendly and helpful but a English speaking concierge would be good. It was disappointing to find out, after we had arrived that there is no longer a functioning restaurant there and NO room service. After travelling for 15 hours we were not happy at having to go out and find food. The hotels website still lists a restaurant as a part of their services. I would not have booked there if I had know that. There are a lot of reviews on there site about how great their restaurant is so I feel that this is very misleading and quite deceitful.

Good price when similar hotel options had increased significantly. Currently being refurbished, upper floors first. Expect workers in the lifts for the foreseeable future. Not an issue for me, Japanese politeness prevailed. My room was a little bit tired, but clean and quiet. Slightly tight for space, but not unreasonable for Tokyo. Good location, short walk to Ginza shops. Would stay again.

My wife and I spent 2 nights in the Mercure Ginza recently prior to joining a cruise ship. This is the 3rd time I have used the Mercure and on each occasion I have been fully satisfied with the hotel and the service provided by the excellent staff. The hotel is very clean and although the rooms are relatively small as is the normal in Japan, they are very comfortable. The buffet breakfast is good and there are numerous coffee shops and eating places within a very short walk.It is located within 10 minutes walking distance of the main Tokyo railway station.

The hotel is a short taxi ride from Tokyo Sta. and a block away from Ginza shopping district. Although our room was starting to show its age, it was still very comfortable, clean, efficient, and decent sized. The front desk staff were all very courteous and helpful. As a bonus, we were allowed to store some luggage at the hotel for a few days while we were travelling other parts of Japan. The breakfast buffet was very good, albeit the service was chaotic. The Imperial Palace and Fish Market are a 20 to 30 minutes stroll away.

Very friendly staff and good rooms. A great central location in Ginza with multiple dining options very close as well as several metro stations within a short walking distance.The room came with a free "smartphone" with the opportunity to use google map and search functions as we explored the city.

We arrived at Tokyo main train terminal at about 9.00p.m. and grabbed a taxi to the hotel which cost us about $12.00. Very happy at that time of night. The hotel is in the best location with so much surrounding the hotel. Staff were wonderful and the morning breakfast was a treat so a great way to start our day. You walk to the Palace, to the Fish markets - you must go there. To Ginza shopping. If you have cash to spend and if not there are subway stations all around. The rooms were good in size and modern. We really liked this hotel and such an excellent location.

The hotel is centrally located in Ginza, close to 3 metro stations, various restaurants and a convenience store. The twin room was not very spacious, but the average rooms in some other hotels in the area are much smaller. Anyhow, there was enough space for 2 big suitcases, only the passage by beds was too narrow, obstructed by a LCD TV set.The beds were comfortable and sleeping quality was high (no noise or other disturbances). The bathroom was fully functional, but the cold water pressure was a bit low and there was an unpleasant odour in the bathroom occasionally.Breakfast was very good, with limited variety of dishes, appropriate for the hotel size and price. Availability of toast was not satisfactory, one of the two toasters should be replaced. The tongs for toast should't have plastic handles!The hotel staff was friendly and helpful. Have in mind, that from May to September 2018, the hotel is undergoing some renovation, which will definitely enhance guests' experience.

Mercure Ginza - TokyoI have to be honest and say that this hotel was disappointing. On the positive side , the staff were lovely, friendly, helpful and spoke good English and the breakfast was very good.However the bed and pillows were so uncomfortable that I was not able to sleep. I requested different pillows but hotel could not provide any that were different. All you want from a room is a good night’s sleep and this hotel did not provide that. - My advice to anyone thinking of booking is DON’T.

Room was ok, beds comfy and bathrooms beautiful and modern with plenty of space.The room itself was a bit cramped but adequate, the room needed a good paint and the carpet a good clean or replaced. Staff were very helpful. Interconnecting rooms were a pain as the doors got in the way, poorly designed and not very functional.
user_name:
Peter Julia B
Queenstown, New Zealand

review_body: Hotel lobby and room look pretty old although well maintained and clean. Room size is decent. Check-in and check-out process were very smooth. Main point of this hotel is its strategic location at the center of Ginza. You can walk for about 7 - 8 minutes from hotel to Yurakucho area where you can find Yurakucho station, MUJI, and other shops in that area. If you are willing to walk longer for about 15 minutes you can go to Don Donki Ginza shop that is opened for 24 hours.

We stayed for 5 days in this hotel in May17. Location is good as it is right in Ginza, if you have the money to shop that is. There are many restaurants in the area, but some do not welcome children. We have to try several restaurants until one accept a child. The hotel is spacious, bathroom is very clean, however, the chair, walls and carpet have a lot of stained. Our bed linens were not changed for the duration of our 5 days stay. We have one child and she left a chocolate stained on the bed sheets which did not get changed. We went out everyday and coming late at night, we kept on hoping that cleaning staff will notice and change for us the following day. I would not stay in Ginza again as it is only a minor station, I prefer to use the JR line in Tokyo.

The hotel is in a great location the staff are extremely helpful and give assistance to what to see. The rest is excellent great food and reasonably priced. The rooms are comfortable but a little small. We will stay again in this hotel because of the location and service.

First of all let me start off with the positives.We arrived early from a cruise and as expected, our rooms were not yet ready. The staff took our bags and gave us a receipt and this was handled very well. The reception staff are friendly and helpful. The hotel is very well situated in the heart of the Ginza district close to some very expensive and some not so expensive shops. There are plenty of eating places around to suit every budget.Now for the negatives. The reception area is tiny and when we returned to check in it was jam packed with several tours and we had to queue for ages. Just bad timing I guess. Our room was adequate but as has been mentioned before by others, the bed was a little hard for us. There is no lounge for guests to sit in. The bar is practically non existent and extremely expensive. We paid the best part of £20 for a gin and tonic, 2 small beers and a small bottle of water. The dining room is small and the breakfast very basic with items running out several times. Tables are not cleared until the meal is finished. All in all. liked the area but would choose a different hotel next time.

I have never paid so much before to stay at a Mercure Hotel, but I gather hotels are expensive in Tokyo and the rooms are generally small. However, I was completely satisfied with my stay at Mercure Ginza and two aspects really stood out. Firstly, my overnight flight from Sydney got in at 5am which meant I got to the hotel at 7am. I am an Accor Platinum member (which entitles you to early check-in) but I thought getting into a room at that time was probably unlikely. However, it was absolutely fine and I was also upgraded into the larger room type.Secondly the free mobile phone available in the room is really invaluable for getting around Tokyo and navigating. I could not have managed without it. Brilliant idea! I also found the staff lovely and helpful, the room very quiet, and the location really ideal - a very central spot for exploring the various districts of Tokyo. The room's decor is a little tired but it proved to be a very functional space and everything I needed for a long stay (6 nights) was provided.I guess the test of any hotel is whether you would stay there again and I certainly would. I was very satisfied.

This is a very quiet hotel and it was perfect to rest after my exploration of Tokyo, it's within walking distance from main Ginza shops and points of interest, the best part is that transportation is easily accessible, as an example, there's a metro station downstairs, and there are stations for different lines within walking distance.I had no complaints, my stay was just as I expected, ample room (compared to Japanese standards), nice beds and everything was clean.I'll definitely stay here next time I visit Tokyo

Staff friendly, comfortable bed and a good breakfast, easy to get around being a good location. they also give you a mobile phone that you can take out of the hotel and use for the duration of your stay we found that really useful instead for paint for your own phone use

It takes a 10 minute walk to the train station and a quick turn out from the small road and it was the main shopping street. Hotel is relatively close to fish market, and there's a lot of shopping nearby. Macdonalds' is just downstairs in an adjacent building. We walked to the nearest train station to take the airport shuttle (was going to Narita). It's quite convenient. You take a coach first to a central bus station, and then switch to another coach straight to Narita. It was a breeze nd very reasonable rates.

Location wise it is right there in Ginza. Room size as with most Tokyo hotels is on the small size. The plus thing is we can book for inter connecting rooms in advance, unlike others with availability when check in excuses. I think the best thing about this hotel is customer service that start from the front office. They also have storage room for luggage that come in handy when you arrive early. When I was there they help me to reserve a restaurant, communicate with delivery man etc. Nothing seemed to much trouble for them. Oh and they return my email communication promptly.

Hotel is located in a perfect location in Ginza with direct subway line underneath and 7 mins short walk the Ginza main line.Many food options nearby and very safe to walk even at night.We chose for bigger size of room and we found out that room size is very adequate. 2 very comfortable queen beds and can fit 4 people inside.Breakfast not so good and overpriced.The front desk is very accomodating, they provided me with nice birthday cake by exchanging my Accor birthday cake certificate.Free one bottle of sake also being provided in the room.My only complaint is the housekeeping was too eager to “clean up” and ended up threw away my facial cleanser. I made complained but they can only apologized and gave me some “bath soap”!! Quite disappointing.However , i will return if the price is reasonable.

We stayed here because: (a) we wanted to be in Ginza; and (b) finding connecting hotel rooms in Tokyo for a family was difficult. The first rooms the hotel provided were not acceptable -- they were on what was formerly the smoking floor. That smells still permeates everything. So they moved us to another floor, which was a hassle but at least we got moved. The rooms are small and banged-up. Then again, at this price point in Tokyo I probably should have expected that.The gem of this hotel is the location. So close to all Ginza had to offer. The hotel is not terribly convenient to a useful subway station, but we walked everywhere we wanted to go. (There is a subway station next to the hotel, but it was not a useful subway line for our purposes.) Nearby convenience stores (2 of them) were exceptionally handy -- particularly when time zone changes left us awake at odd hours.We slept well here. Given the location and the price, I would stay here again.

The hotel is very basic - not bad, not great- just getting by on the basics. Rooms are tiny - and not all that clean - which is unusual for Japan. Unfortunately all that can be commended in the rooms are the mattress quality ... And .. the multi functional toilet seat ! The corridors, reception areas and restraurant are drab. Staff are friendly and pleasant but with very limited English. Breakfast is chaotic: a wide but odd choice of food ( spaghetti and meatballs!) - which is often cold as it isn't replaced fast enough by the understaffed service. In fact I had the impression that the hotel - which is very popular with international visitors - is staffing at the bare minimum.The general management is French with the staff a mix of Japanese and some European. I got they were doing their best on a constrained budget. There are no staff to assist with bags for example and the reception is in the second floor.So it's the location - in the heart of the Ginza and at the centre of great transport links that sells. The hotel is in a side street so is very quiet despite the location - and there are no views beyond looking into the windows of offices.In summary - a mediocre hotel in a great location. Think: holiday inn express on 5th avenue or premier inn on bond Street .

An unbeatable location in Ginza. Friendly English speaking front staff. Adequate buffet breakfast.Steps away from Itoya the stationery haven. Mitsukoshi Department store worth an exploration of its basement supermarket. Or a one act performance at the Kabuki Theatre. Tsukiji market is a 15 minute stroll away. So is the 24 hour Don Quixote. Subways and JR Yamanote Yurakucho adds to the convenience.

We stayed at the Mercure Ginza for 4 nights and were happy with the standard of room and staff. The location is perfect with east access to rail stations, shopping and tourist attractions. The only disappointment was the bar and restaurant was closed on a Monday night and as it was cold and wet we had to go out.

As an Accor Plus member, I will always choose Accor hotels for my accomodation. Apparently in Tokyo there are only Mercure and Ibis.This hotel is centrally located in Ginza area, where you can have boutiques, department store as well as restaurant. Room are small, typical hotel in Tokyo, however why bother if you will spend most of day outside the hotel. For sure will comeback to this hotel dor my next stay in Tokyo.

My partner and I stayed here for a week and thoroughly enjoyed it. It's a great base.for exploring Tokyo; it's close to train stations and ginza itself is pretty cool too.We only ate at the restaurant for breakfast but found them to have a really good selection; my partner and I are both vegetarian and found plenty of vairety at the breakfast buffet.The room and bed were also very comfortable.

Very centrally located in Ginza with the large department stores, convenient stores and food joints within walking distance. The room was larger than most Japanese hotels and stocked with all the necessary amenities. Service staff were helpful which is expected of most Japanese hotels. Will return if I’m heading to Ginza for another visit.

This hotel is in the heart of Ginza surrounded by good restaurants and quality Japanese department stores. I ran the Tokyo Marathon and this hotel is near the finish line which makes it very convenient. The rooms well appointed and big for Japanese standards. Service from the staff was very good and they were very helpful in answering questions. Subway is very near the hotel which makes it easy to go around Tokyo.I would stay in this hotel again.

A good location for Ginza and conveniently located on top of a subway station but the positives end there. This place has seen better days. It’s typical Tokyo to an extent... small rooms that smell of stale tobacco, but more noticeably, the carpet in the room was stained all over, with the bed linen and towels competing for the title of the most tired-looking hotel room I’ve seen in a long while.

This hotel was perfect for our stay. The property is in an excellent location, the room was extremely quiet, and the staff were very helpful and kind. They gave us very good restaurant recommendations in the area and gave us a very nice complimentary late check out as our flight was very late in the evening. Thank you so much.

Good hotel well located in the Ginza. Good amenities and the sleep comfort is good. Nice touch to provide a phone which was used for its map function and making local calls. reception staff were very friendly as well as restaurant staff.

We stayed five nights here and would definitely stay again if in Tokyo. The hotel is located in the hub of Ginza, a short walking distance to various metro stations and the major shopping and food areas. It's about a 10 to 15 minute walk to Tokyo station and easy access to and from Haneda airport. The staff, from Reception, Restaurant and Housekeeping are all friendly, polite and professionally efficient. We chose a superior room (allocated on the sixth floor) and were pleasantly surprised with the amount of space and the size of the bathroom compared to other hotels we stayed in. Spotlessly clean and very comfortable for sleeping. No views - but we didn't come to Tokyo to look out the bedroom window. Breakfast was more than adequate and catered well for both Western and Asian tastes. We ate dinner in the restaurant on two occasions and were treated to excellent French cuisine and personal attention. Even if you haven't come to Japan to eat French food, try this at least once. Be aware that you may need to book as it seems they don't take too many diners in one sitting. We did experience a problem with someone smoking on our floor which seems to be a bit of a problem although the hotel has a strictly no-smoking policy.

When we checked in the booking had 3 instead of 2 . The hotel wanted us to call American Express to ask why. Someone goofed up and it put the front desk off. Our first room had a previous heavy smoker. They let us change. The next room was all beat up. The chairs are damaged, huge stain on the luggage upholstered stand and the wall covering was just dirty and damaged. They gave us 1 regular coffee for the Nespresso machine day one. I had to go to the front desk and had to beg for another one the second day. WIFI works however it is very slow. Corridor carpet is loose and luggage wheels don't want to roll on them so easy. We didn't try the restaurant. For +- $350 US a day, this hotel is very disappointing. It doesn't matter how many do-dads they place in the rooms, when they miss on the basics the experience go well. This might be the worst Internationally franchised I have every stayed in.

The hotel was very clean and staff was super friendly. Also the location is great and near to subway stations. We also have been positively surprised as we received a mobile city guide device called „handy“ which is connected to 4G and can be used as a mobile hotspot. Only negative point was the reliance of the internet which sometimes stops working for some minutes. In case you find this disturbing, you can ask for a pocket wifi at the reception to resolve the problem. Overall we would definitely recommend this hotel as a place to spend some days in Tokyo.

First time i stayed in Mercure Tokyo Ginza, i enjoyed staying in Mercure Tokyo Ginza, The staff were friendly, kind and warm, the room was clean, location near with ginza shopping, also near with train station.

Stayed for 3 days and coming from 5 days osaka stay. It’s a relief here, rooms are bigger compare to ibis osaka, it’s like twice the size. Beds and room are well kept. Housekeeping are doin a good job. Breakfast has more variety and they have different selection everyday which is good. Fast check in and check out being an accor member.Estellita the receptionist is nice and accommodating, she explained in detail and even gave maps and list of things to do and recommended restaurant around the area.Location is perfect, hotel basement is connected to the subway. There’s lawson in the corner and 24hrs mcdonald’s beside the hotel. It very convenient. Plus factor is the handheld gadget that you can bring around to help you tour the area, you can use it also for unlimited calls.Will surely visit this place again with my kids.

I'm in Tokyo at least once a year for business. Usually I’ll stay in Shibuya for work. As an Accorhotel member I decided that I’d give the Mercure Ginza a try. I was expecting a small & cramped room but I was pleasantly surprised by the size of the room and the standard of the service. I was in the delux room for 2 adults. I arrived at the hotel via taxi from Haneda airport - costing about US$70.00. The reception is located on level 2. The breakfast spread was nice but I would have preferred more Japanese food. Housekeeping was very tidy & clean. The service at the front desk was very good, they spoke good English & was able to help with directions & arranging for taxi services. The fish market - Tsujiki is only about 10-15 mins away, a good brunch option before the day begins. The train station below the hotel connects you to all destinations. While I was there I found google map to be very useful. There’s a Family Mart, 2 Lawson & a medical & beauty shop just outside the hotel. McDonald’s is just a stone throw away for a quick bite. This is an excellent hotel with a good location. I recommend it to all 1st timers arriving in Tokyo.

We stayed four nights a family of 5 ... 3 kids aged 14, 12 and 9. Rooms were small and dark and the beds were like rocks . When we arrived they had the rooms on different floors which meant we would be separated from our kids ... we stood firm and they finally found us two rooms on same floor . They provide a free iPhone to navigate the city which was welcomed but the connection kept dropping out so often we were left to navigate streets of Tokyo which made it interesting . Ginza is more of an upmarket area selling brand names but the hotel is centrally located to rail network and downstairs is a 24 hr McDonalds ( not saying that a bonus but for the kids sometimes it's a welcome alternative ) . We didn't have any meals in the hotel as they were quite expensive and you can find a cheaper alternative in the side streets of Ginza in fact the hotel will give you a list of best eats in Ginza and a map of the Metro system . Your best to buy a Suica Rail card which is a card that you top up to pay for trips it's more cost effective and when you finish with it you get a refund of the small deposit . Back to the hotel the staff were knowledgeable but not super friendly and of course the language barrier didn't help . Reception is on level two and there is no baggage service so be prepared to be the bellboy or girl not a fun experience if you have a lot of bags . So in summary Pros centrally located , iPhone to navigate CONS hard access. Expensive , small rooms , hard beds , wifi intermittent , staff semi friendly , not really a family friendly hotel , no pool ..... families are. Better off staying in Shibuya where you get more bang for your buck .

My wife and I have stayed at this hotel a number of times in recent years and is your preferred hotel in Tokyo. Its location is excellent - a 15 minute stroll to Tokyo Station, a Metro station entrance directly below the hotel and just around the corner from the upmarket Ginza shopping district. As always, all staff we dealt with were very courteous, helpful and professional. In particular the reception staff were outstanding. The recent addition of handy phones to all rooms was innovative and very useful. The WiFi is much improved since our last stay.
Small hotel with fantastic restaurant. Metro rail line is directly below hotel and can be accessed from the hotel.Rooms were small and really only big enough for two people.Rooms were clean and tidy

Compared with my last stay and review published in January 2017 WiFi has improved very much. Because the positive topics - spacy room, access to subway, location overall - are still the same, I can increase my former rating from 1 to 4 stars. This time I can only complain many tourist groups from US and western europe who don’t behave like Japanese people, so the breakfast room was always crowded and noisy.

On our first trip to Tokyo we chose to stay at the Mercure as we were an accor member..Heard about Japan hotel having small rooms but not here. big enough and comfortable.. Its a hotel value for money.. good breakfast hall and the location was excellent.. will surely return when we are back in Tokyo..

Nicely placed in the middle of’Tokyo within walking distance of all attractions in downtown, this is a good choice for tourists.Nothing is fancy but everything is ok. The rooms are nice.This has the smallest lobby I have seen in a long time which may be annoying if you have to wait.The European breakfast is welcome if you are European.Very good price value relationship

Have to move Hotels between stays in Tokyo as previous Hotel have maintenance, lucky for us an aap was open just 2 weeks before the stay, check-in is fast n easy, received our welcome amenities and reception counter explain what benefit for us, also received a small cigarette ash bin after asking if there is a smoking area in this hotel.Room and bed is quite small but expected as it was clearly stated in room description, towels need a bit upgrade as it seems very old, check out is fast and easy.:D

Rooms nice & comfortable beds. Small but big enough for 2 people (we booked 2 rooms & they were happy to give us adjoining rooms but we emailed prior to arrival) Bath good for me (5”2”), heated toilet seat & fancy toilet. No view but excellent location in the middle of Ginza & walking distance to all transport. I’m an Accor plus member so good value & 2 kids (12&13) ate free buffet breakfast. B’fast selection was great because it inc. western & Japanese. Scrambled eggs perfect, bacon, cereal, pastries, tea/coffee...everything to give you a hearty start to the day & keep you going till lunch. Free wifi & in room portable mobile. You could take it out & about (we didn’t-I was too scared of losing it) staff were very friendly & helpful. I enquired how to get to Disneysea & it was quiet complicated using JR pass. Lovely girl at reception knocked on my door 10 minutes later & had written out clear instructions in English-very kind. Also, because there were 4 + luggage, they ordered us mini van taxi & gave driver instructions for us so he dropped us off at correct entrance for Tokyo station. Also, being Accor plus-received free gift at check in (cookies) Lawson’s, family mart & 7/11 all within walking distance. I’ve stayed at Mecures in Australia & this is very typical & meet our expectations. Ideal as a base (we were out exploring all day)

Location is very good. Just 10mins walk from the train station. Room is clean and of good size. Good location for shopping and food too. Staffs are friendly and helpful. Overall a pleasant stay! Thumbs up

Spacious room, great service, good breakfast variety and good connectivity to all parts of Tokyo.Only downside is that not many local eateries nearby open till late night.Will definitely stay here again if in Tokyo.

The location is perfect and the neighbourhood is nice. The hotel is close to good Japanese restaurants and great shopping stores. The short distance from Tokyo station to the hotel make it a very appropriate base to explore other parts of Japanese by rail. The room is cosy and the size is somewhat bigger than others of the same class; good value for money. Although the breakfast is not a big feast, it is very reasonable and food is “refilled” quite promptly. Enjoying all the benefits of an Accor member, I have no complaints.

I stayed at this hotel from 19th November until 23rd November this year. The location was excellent, right near the Ginza shopping strip and near three train stations. The staff were friendly and extremely helpful, though English was limited, but understandable. The room was clean, not too small and had a room safe. I would definitely stay there again. We had our bags forwarded to Nagoya and a mix-up in communication at reception meant that the bags were transported on the day they should have arrived. The staff took full responsibility for their mistake - which in my book is great. I wouldn't bother with breakfast in the restaurant, it was a tad ordinary - there are much cheaper and great cafes nearby that have suitable breakfast food. And its always nice to mix with the locals.

An average hotel with convenient location to get to Tokyo station. Very friendly and helpful staff. Room size was typically "Japanese" standard. As an Accor member, my rate included breakfast which was good with no complaint.

We have stayed at the Mecure Tokyo Ginza many times. The first time it was rather a shock as the room was so small. We do not travel light, especially during the winter months. We now stay in the same Deluxe large 2 bedroom. Quite comfortable. Always request extra soft pillows. Sleep well. Rooms a little tired but being renovated this year. Lunch and Dinner in the Bistro, truly delicious. also excellent wines. All the staff in the Bistro are hard working and very polite. Management in all departments very good. Hotel located in a great position. Would recommend.

Was heading to Tokyo for 4 nights and wanted to be in Ginza, thus Mercure Tokyo Ginza was the perefect hotel to suit my criteria. Although the hotel was abit dated and had some prior complaints, I consulted with a few friends and fellow travellers to see if I should try it out. Thus, I decided to give it a go.Arrived around 11am on a Monday morning and was greeted by very friendly lobby staff. Although one small complain I will say is that they have no doorman to help you with your luggage when you arrived on the 1st floor. However that was nitpicking considering the 3 star ranking.Yumi behind the desk shared with us they are quite full this week and told us to give them awhile to see if they could push us for an upgrade. After awhile, indeed she found 1 room that we could be upgraded to however she shared with us that the room would be on the 3rd floor and that on my preferences, we preferred rooms on a high floor. That made me impressed to be honest as that shows the hotel actually take a look at your preferences when that check you in. Thank you so much Yumi!-Room-Our room was located on the 3rd floor (Room 318) and it was a Deluxe Room Twin Bed. The room size was okay in a sense that we were in Tokyo and hotel rooms in Tokyo aren't famous for being spacious. Yes, the rooms are dated with the old carpets and dated furniture. However to be fair they maintain them well as carpets are old but clean, furniture are dated but kept in good condition. Bath amenities are by Omnisens. Thus, no major complains there but of course new is always better. I understand that the hotel will be doing renovation soon. Thus, that will improve the situation they are in. -Dining-I had dinner at the hotel once and I must say, the food was E-X-C-E-L-L-E-N-T. The 4 Course dinner I had was absolutely. The ingredients used was fresh and the smell of the food was amazing. Would definitely recommend a meal here once if you have the time to do so. Thank you to Florent and Chris from the restaurant for being so helpful and welcoming to us while we were having our dinner.Breakfast buffet was small but food was generally delicious. No major complains here since breakfast was included in our rate and this wasn't the worst Mercure brekafast I had. No egg station though but the kitchen staff makes a good scrablmed eggs for the buffet line.-Location-Location was amazing though, just a 1-2 minute walk to the main street of Ginza. Thre are 3 Subway station surrounding the hotel. The closest one which has direct acces to the hotel is Ginza Itchome Station and the other two station are about 5 mins walk away are Ginza Station and Higashi Ginza Station. I cannot recollect which station it is but one of those station has a direct train to Haneda Airport.-Overall-Overall my stay was above average. Yes the rooms are old but they maintain them well. The price I paid per night was competitive but I understand at certain periods of time, the hotel can be expensive and overpriced in my opinion.Thus if you get the hotel room rate you want at the correct price, I believe its a good deal. Although not the best Mercure I have been to, niether is it the worst. It slots right in the middle and I would return to this hotel if I come back to Tokyo and want to stay at Accor.

I have rated this 4, because there was nothing really wrong with it, if you are judging it as a 3* hotel for tourists, which in my opinion is what it is, and it does that job pretty well. I was travelling for business, and I am used to 4-5* more luxurious business hotels - if that is what you are looking for, then this is not it, and I would have rated it lower on that basis.Location is pretty good - I took a bus from Narita when I arrived, and it stops only about 10 mins away walking. The Ginza subway is literally just around the corner (2 min walk), and when I left I took a taxi to Tokyo main station to catch the Narita Express, and I would say it was only about 20mins to the station by taxi (also to the main business district, which is where my meeting was).Bedroom was OK size, quiet and reasonably clean, with decent wifi, but otherwise a bi shabby.Staff and breakfast buffet both excellent

I must say very friendly staffs. Room condition is about a 2-3 star hotel. The floor is filthy and house keeping didnt throw away the rubbish of left over food the night before. Shower mixer is unstable; hot and cold. It can be just nice and then next it can be very hot. Pressure is also on the low end. The pillows had alot of beans in them and the bed were not comfy enough.Definitely not a value four star.

very centrally located, friendly staff. Breakfast soso, the room is not quite big. Of course not too cheap, but i guess that is Tokio ? There is a metro station under the hotel, which is convenient. All kind of shops in the area

This hotel is (at least on freqhented days) quite expensive, but it is in a very convenient Location: Not far from Yurakucho Station (5 minutes), Tokyo Station (10 minutes), and also the Ginza Shopping Malls as well as Tsukiji Market.

We stayed for three days here, though the location is fantastic, it desperately needs an upgrade in all areas to be reflective for the price and area it's located in.We found it easy to walk everywhere from here including to the Imperial Gardens (an easy 15 minute stroll)We dined in the in house French restaurant 2 nights and the food was superb, comparable to any we've had in France! Service good but the letdown was the restaurants decor, desperately needs an upgrade.Breakfast was okay but basic, unable to get English breakfast tea. I asked for some cheese but was told they only had the cream cheese portions.The room we had was very small with a 70's decor, the bathroom had a high step up with nothing to hold on to which made it cumbersome for my husband as he's had both knees replaced. We found overall the highlight of our stay was the food in the restaurant, if we ever go back to Tokyo we wouldn't stay here but would dine in the restaurant.

Stayed for 4 nights Nov 20th to 24th.We arrived from.another city in Japan and as Platimun members we were upgraded to a bigger room (nothing fancy just bigger ). Having stayed at many Accor hotels, the welcome amenity could be improve.The service staff did not "wow" but they were not rude as well. Breakfast not bad ... the croissants and danish pastries were excellent. As mentioned by previous guests, you can access the subway directly from the basement (a long walk to the fare gates) but at least you are sheltered. Higashi Ginza subway was nearby and from there you are able to take direct trains to Haneda. One point to note, when going to Haneda airport, you must use the entrance on the opposite side from where you came from (i wish the hotel staff had shared this with us).There are several nice food outlets near the hotel ... one being a Ramen Place and there is a also a Tendon place (believe its part of a chain). McDonalds is just beside the hotel (24hrs) and Starbucks round the corner. There are also convenience stores around.Main Ginza is less than 5 mins walk away.Tsukiji market no more than 15mins walk.Tip - if you are intending to stay in Tokyo itself you can consider purchasing the subway pass ... we bought the 72 hrs pass for JPY1500 which in my opinion was good value as you can hop off and on if you are tired of walking. Load the Tokyo subway app on your mobile for convenience.Overall - hotel is dated but its clean. The service of the staff can improve - not all are friendly but would I stay there again ... possibly YES for the location.

I just left from this hotel several days ago with booking number FJCSBSQZ. In the past, I always though that Japanese people and Japanese company has everything perfect such as about timing, behavior or anything from Japanese. But, now I can realized that, it is not true and I can not believe that it is very stupid and terrible that I have met before. Below, I will dedicated the topic for each issue that I have found.- ServiceThe service of this hotel is very poor. I have had snack in minibar everyday but they not fill and everyday snack in minibar is not the same. So, they don't know what I have consumed or still not listed of price in the menu yet. There are also many dust at the shelve and housekeeper not kept back my towel.- Accor's member benefit. (Strongly not recommended to stay this hotel)In this hotel, you will not get the good benefit such as room upgrade. If compare with Thailand. They will always guaranteed upgrade at least one step but mostly if platinum member they will always two steps upgraded.- RoomRoom is quite old, not beautiful and the cost per night is opposite than its quality. If I have to pay with my own money I will not book this hotel for sure. There are a lot of good hotels in that area and absolutely not to choose here.- Restaurant.I had one meal in lunch time of France restaurant in this hotel. The tall guy in the restaurant gave very stupid service and he looks like don't care Thai people. Breakfast also stupid as everyday foods almost the same and bad quality.- Check out performance.According to I have very early flight and I had a lot of snacks and beverages in minibar. They invoice me very cheap and they really don't know what I have eat from the minibar and the staff did everything not very professional about this then I have to told and shown from my list that what I have had from minibar.Finally, I would like to invite the management to come to Thailand as internship or try to stay just only one night in Thailand hotel. You will see that the performance and quality of hotel in Thailand is perfectly and Japan can not beatable. It is like a 10 years past of the service quality away from Thailand. You should learn a lot from Thailand hotels especially AccorHotels in Thailand.This stay of me is free of charge I still very felt bad to chose here. So, how much I will feel bad if I must to pay for this suck hotel.THIS HOTEL IS NOT RECOMMENDED FOR ANY ACCOR MEMBERS especially for Gold and Platinum status.Thank you.

I am a platinum Le Accor member and stay in Novotel / Mercure / ... about once a week. Overall, I am very pleased with the hotel chain.  Mercure Ginza: Positive: 1) Staff very good and friendly - very helpful. International staff (mostly French) excel with their language skills (French, Japanese, impeccable english). Japanese staff do their best to speak english but sometimes very difficult to understand. But again, extremely helpful. 2) location is very good in Ginza3: good breakfastTo be improved: 1) hotel has really NO facilities besides the restaurant (which also is the breakfast room / bar).2) no gym, ...3) price / quality is really not OK taking into account this is a hotel without facilities. 4) very small room (the smallest of my 4 hotels during my stay in Japan). Room is really worn out. 5) opening hours bar (last entrance was 9.30pm on a Friday) - why do you have a bar if you only accept clients till 9.30PM.... I will not go again to this hotel - better alternatives nearby.

Fantastic welcome from Vivien, we got our room upgraded, we received really nice attentions during the whole stay. We really felt home. The room is spacious. The location is perfect to visit Tokyo, this is very convenient. We will come back

This was a typical Mercure Hotel with everything provided, clean and adequate size and breakfast provided. We stayed here for 2 nights at the end of our trip. The king sized mattress was probably the most comfortable we had in Japan. The staff were very helpful. The location was good for Starbucks and about a 500 metre walk to the Airport bus at Ginza station.
