We returned to Tokyo from Osaka by Shinkensen and the taxi fare from the Tokyo station was about 2500yen. Good area for high end shopping and department stores. About 20 minute fast walk to Ramen street at Tokyo station. However, we far preferred our 4 night stay in Shinjuku at the beginning of our trip due to easy access to the fun entertainment and cheap and cheerful cafes. If Ginza is your area of choice to stay then this hotel would suit you perfectly.

Hotel is conveniently located. Considering overall japanese way the room sizes are just optimum.the breakfast spread at the restaurant is good enough and sufficient.all the shopping places are closeby.tokyo station is close by metro,taxi or even a walk of 10min.be aware that the early check is at charge unless you are Accor member and lucky.

I stayed with the Mercure Tokyo Ginza for 6-nights between 31 October and 6 November this year. This hotel is in the very convenient location with almost all the international shops of famous brands including big Japanese Department Store there. The Ginza Itchome Metro Station of the Yurokucho Line connects with the basement of the hotel while the Ginza Station is just 5-minute walk from the hotel. It takes you less than 45 minutes from the Heneda International Airport by Monorail (680 Yen) to the Hamamatsucho Station and then by JR (2 stops Hamamatsucho/Shimbashi/Yurokucho). After getting off at the Yurokucho Station, you walk straight for about 3 minutes across 2 traffic lights and see the big Japanese Department Store - Matsuya Ginza. Going further for about another 2 minutes, you will find the Mercure. As far as the hotel service is concerned, I enjoyed my stay with the Mercure. The Reception staff were nice and professional. They were efficient so that checking in and our were smooth and quick. I would like to mention in particular the French Restaurant. I had my dinner there for 4 times during my stay. Not only was the quality food very fresh and delicious but also the excellent service of the staff. Taking this opportunity, I would like to thank the Managers, Romain and Chris as well the Attendant Mr. Florent for taking care of our meals. On the other hand, I hadn't had my breakfast in the hotel restaurant because the size of the restuarant was relatively small so that it was always full after 8 a.m. It was too crowded ! Overall speaking, I am satified with the service of the hotel staff and its location but would like to remind the other ACCOR members in particular the Gold and Platinum Member that you should not expectto receive the Member's benefit as much as the Accor hotels in other countries and as promised by Accor. What you may have is just the welcome drink, late check-out up to 2 p.m. and free internet. No room up-grade like other Accor hotels should be expected. Over the almost 3-year Platinum Membership, this is my only experience.

The great location of this hotel is a double edged sword in that it is almost always occupied to full capacity, yet in need of a total refit. We had the misfortune of having to endure 4 room changes in 5 days because of a number of issues including not getting the room type we had booked, extremely bad room odours, smoking in a non smoking floor etc. The staff are extremely sympathetic to the problems of the hotel and can't wait for the renovations to start. From what I hear, staff morale is quite low because they are in the front line of dealing with guests complaints and can only "fix" things as best they can.Wi Fi is hopeless, with frequent interruptions to service, and the trick photography used to "show off" the restaurant area is outstanding.I have been an Accor member for over 30 years and I hate writing a bad review- perhaps we were just unlucky, but for those high ranking Accor executives, please help the kind, sympathetic and caring staff at this incredibly well located hotel of yours.They deserve better and so do your guests.

Love the location of this hotel...just off The Ginza...fantastic. The rooms are small but quiet & comfortable. The Bathtubs are deep & lovely. The staff friendly, & helpful. BUT, the wifi is terrible. It is strong at times then drops out readily. This has occured on my last 2 trips to this Mercure hotel. Unfortunately the staff seem unable to rectify the situation and the only way to get a stable connection is to sit in the 2nd floor foyer to use wifi. This is at the suggestion of the staff. If you need to Skype or make any wifi call for business, privacy is unavailable. Such a disappointment for a usually well appointed hotel brand as Accor and such inefficiency is really suprizing in Japan.

A great base for a 3 night stay in Tokyo within easy walking distance of Tokyo Station. Underground is also accessible at basement level without the need to go outside if it’s raining and the highlights of Ginza are just 2 minutes walk away. Appreciated the help and advice in advance of our arrival and were pleased to be able to checkin during the morning after an overnight flight. Room was ideal for our needs, comfortable spotless and with everything we needed - ample tea and coffee, a fridge and a bathroom, although small, well stocked with toiletries. I believe renovations have now begun on some of the rooms and this will only add to the attraction of staying here. Rates were good and we enjoyed the wide selection on offer at breakfast.Service offered by reception team was very helpful and friendly, great tips on easiest way to visit some Shrines for example.Worth noting you can download a map on the hotel website to hand to a taxi driver to easily get you back to the hotel if language causes any problems.

We booked two rooms in mid October as part of a 3 night stay in Tokyo, ahead of a family cruise from Yokohama. It was our first time in Japan and we booked this hotel on advice from our travel agent (and checking reviews here on TripAdvisor ).The hotel more than exceeded our expectations. All of the staff we met were extremely friendly and helpful. They ensured we had adjacent rooms, took time to provide good advice on places to eat and visit, booked us taxis etc. Everything was done with a smile and a genuine desire to make our visit a pleasure. The rooms we had were a good size (around 200 square feet I believe ) and very clean. Bathroom toiletries were refreshed every day, along with tea and coffee making facilities. We had an all inclusive breakfast which we found very good. As others have reported, there is a good variety of western and Japanese items to choose from. The hotel is in a great location, in a fairly quiet street, just 2 minutes from the main shopping street and only minutes from local metro or the main Tokyo rail station for Japan Rail.This was one our best hotel stays in recent years and we would definitely stay again.

Not many affordable hotel in Ginza, the most expensive area in Tokyo, but Mercure is one of the best! Service and location are superb! Prior to my arrival, the Hotel sent me emails and gave a clear direction to the hotel. I took the Access Narita bus from Narita Airport which stops at Ginza station which cost only 1000 JPY per person. Thanks to Ms. Johanna, the Guest Coordinator which was very kind & helpful. I also got a free early check-in (probably because I'm an Accor member), which was very rare to get, especially in Tokyo. The room is quite spacious for Tokyo hotel. You can walk to Ginza street and shop till you drop!

Pros : The location, just beside Ginza-Itchome, It is a Tokyo Subway station, and near Yurakucho Station, that's a JR Station.Being in the centre of Ginza, if you want to make Ginza as your main destination, the hotel is for you, And being near two different station, 1 JR, and 1 Subway, of course it is a big plus.The room : Typical Mercure Hotel, Spacious if you compare with another hotel with the same price range. Amenities quite basic, but we're annoyed with Mercure standard [read : soap], because in other hotel we stayed while in Tokyo, the shower gel / soap were very abundant, and being Mercure, the soap, shampoo, and conditioner're being kept in a small tube, and they only provide two. After we call, they bring it to our room, alright, but it's a bit annoyingStaff : They're very helpful, help with my itinerary at 3:00... and when we checking in, they gave a small gift, ginger biscuits, quite tasty.Being member of their chain, they gave me a late check out, which I appreciate very much. Cons :Public Bath : being in Japan, we really hoped there's public bath, with a mix of western style, but in Mercure, they didn't have any..Cons of Ginza-Itchome station, it is not luggage friendly, many stairs, without elevators or lift.

The hotel is located in a nice area of Ginza and is close to many eating places. There is a subway connected so easy to get onto the subway circuit. Really was impressed with the staff as they checked us in early for a small fee as we just got off a 10 hour flight.The restaurant is high quality and the waygu beef steak is yummy. Recommended for people to stay

Third or fourth time here, i cannot recall. This hotel had always my appreciation for the services, the spacious for Tokyo rooms and the great location in Ginza heart. The low, value for money fare and the italian restaurant on 2nd floor with the inspired chef.But this time i would say i am quite dissapointed and annoyed. I have left in the morning my shirts for laundry. Putting them in laundry bag, filling the laundry check list and placing both on the bed as usual. To my surprise when i returned in the evening, instead of clean ironed shirts, i have found the laundry bag as i left it and a printed note saying: We have seen your laundry but we have not taken it because you have not called number 9 to notify for laundry service (something like this).Come on!!! What is this? Should i read all the room user's handbook to get my shirts washed? Isn't it common sense that since you see a full laundry bag with the application filled, these clothes have to be washed??? What is going on with people? Cannot judge anymore? Only regulations, endless rules and penalties?So my punishment for not following the housekeeper law, is to go on tomorrow business meetings with dirty, fried squid palm oil smelling shirt. Great!!

This was my first time staying at an accord hotel and I was quite disappointed.Firstly the wifi was slow, at times not working. This came not only from me but from my co worker who stayed here too. Thankfully I had a SIM card, but he didn't. Room- for the price paid, I expected a better furnished room. Compared to a Japanese business hotel room which I usually put up in, I wasn't impressed at all.Toiletries- was disappointed at the tiny shower gel and shampoo provided. Despite publishing that you are trying to save the environment, it didn't translate into the toiletries, except the usual hang up the towel to be re used scheme. Why not consider to install quality Japanese liquid soap and ditch the tiny tubes of made in china products?I'd definitely not come back again. It just didn't work out for me.

We would definitely stay here again. The room was compact but very comfortable. The location was great and the front desk staff very helpful. It is on the metro line and there are some good little cafes just around the corner. Centre of shopping just 3 blocks away. Overall an excellent value!

Great location, clean and comfortable, wonderful service and enjoyable food. We used this as a home base during a recent visit to Japan and it was a great success. The elevator goes to the subway (Exit 11 of a local line, which easily connects to the main lines) but if you want to walk, the nearby streets are safe, clean and fascinating. The Ginza area has fantastic up market shopping coupled with authentic local shops and food nearby. It is only a 15 minute walk to the main Tokyo rail station for access to both airports (Narita is an hour away but it wasn't a problem getting the express train).A great place to stay :-)

A mid range hotel, nice and clean and in the heart of ginza. Can be reached via Ginza itchome subway station. This is not the same JR line as tokyo station.The door from station linking the hotel is closed between 2200 to 700 hours. But you can take other approach via the main road.The rooms are decent and clean, hotel is nice with friendly staff. Didnt try the food there though.I liked the stay and the staff was helpful, hotel is walkable from ginza district and with many good resturants around.

The Ginza area is superb. The hotel is in need of a refurbishment as it is looking quite tired The location is fabulous, one block is way from the main boulevard lined with fabulous shops. A few good restaurants nearby that have a good local feel. The breakfast is good with a wide range of food choices.

It was cherry blossom season so hotel rates in Japan were extra high and we were lucky to get a good deal with Mercure as Accor members. Location is the best selling point for this hotel. Right in the middle of Ginza, full of note-worthy establishments and a shopping paradise. Also very close to 2 train stations so it was the perfect base for exploring. The room itself is clean and functional, nothing exceptional until you stay at other places in Japan and you realise it was actually quite a good-sized room. We didn't eat at the hotel due to the many restaurants nearby- also it was kind of lacking in ambiance so was not tempted to dine there at all. We were able to check in early which we appreciated. Also plus points for being able to borrow umbrellas and an electric plug/converter. Would recommend and would happily stay again next time we're in Tokyo.

My family enjoyed staying in Hotel Mercure Ginza Tokyo because of location , value for money and getting assured quality at fair Price. The Hotel was close to many restaurants. Tokyo Station & other Stations were in walking distance from the Hotel.

This Mercure is right in the heart of the nicest high end shopping area in Tokyo. Breakfast and service are good. In the future, my wife and I will stay in an Ibis further out of town near Shibuya for half the price because we liked that part of town best because of it's wonderful parks and nightlife.

Very comfortable, great breakfasts with cappuccino, super location with many excellent eateries hidden on higher floors in the office buildings surrounding the hotel. Highly recommended. Very helpful staff.

We have just spent 5 nights at the Mercure, Ginza, Tokyo. Unless you are paying £300 per night, hotel rooms in Tokyo are not large and our room was no exception to this rule. However, on arrival we were offered an upgrade at no extra cosy but we choose to stay in the room we had been allocated. It was cosy but had a very comfortable queen size bed and ample wardrobe space for two people. There was a stocked mini bar and tea or coffee making facilities. The ensuite was small but adequate, with bath, shower fitting, the over functional Japanese wc and wash basin. There was also an endless supply of good quality toiletriesWe were invited to the managers regular Wednesday drinks reception, with complimentary drinks and canapés. The Mercure is well located in Ginza, close to shops, restaurants and entertainments. There are two metro stations close by, providing quick and easy access to all the places of interest in Tokyo and beyond. The breakfast is plentifhl and varied, offering Japanese and European style breakfasts. The French bread and pastries were as good as from the a local patisserie.

I have stayed at a few hotels in Tokyo / Ginza and this one is my favourite. The location is perfect, the rooms are large and the in house French restaurant is amazing. You need to check the rates on various sites, my last trip I booked direct on Accor for the first few nights and then got a better rate for my next stay on a different site.I would certainly stay again

I have been at many hotels during 30 years of business - but this is not ok !!! The room is not clearn and the breakfest is poor. The hotel is on a good lokation neer to Ginza but the price is not ok !!!SORRY- but I will not come again !!!

Hotel was very clean, quiet and roomy - we asked for a superior room with twin beds to get the maximum size and were happy with our choice. Hotel is 15-20min walk to Tokyo Station which was a bit further than we'd liked in hot weather carting suitcases - I'd recommend catching a taxi. Staff were very friendly and helped us find our way around and booked a cab to the station with a smile! The area around the hotel has a great range of restaurants and is in the posh end of town for shopping (Tiffany, Louis Vuitton etc). We didn't try the hotel restaurant as it was a bit pricey.

Great location. Room is small but comfortable. Breakfast can use a bit upgrades. Nice and reasonably priced Sushi Belt and Ramen noodle bar within 5 mins walk. Also there is a street full of little posh restaurants about 15 mins walk.There is no 'view' so to speak.

We stayed here for 6 nights in August 2017 and returned for a further 2 nights after travelling Japan. The hotel is perfectly situated in the lovely area of Ginza. It's a 5 minute walk from both metro stations and we arrived into Higashi-Ginza which has a direct link from Haneda airport. Exit 1 or 2 which has an elevator and walk for 4 mins, when you see McDonalds keep walking for 25m and the entrance in on your left. Reception is on level 2 and the check in staff were amazing. The rooms were larger than I expected and came with 2 bottles of free water. The beds were firm and comfortable, clean bathroom and powerful shower. Complimentary shower gels and the typical hi-tec Japanese toilet with heated seat and jet spray. Wifi is very fast and we found the signal stronger on our first stay on the 8th floor and not as fast when we returned to the 12th floor, but suitable for browsing.We didn't use the restaurant as we booked via a hotel online site and secured a very good room rate without breakfast. Ginza is truly spectacular and offers restaurants to suit all your tastes. Obviously McDonalds is handy for a snack or icecream, we found a cheap Japanese noodle bar near Higashi-Ginza called Ippudo. Also Rump Cap just around the corner from the hotel serves steak and lovely food with a 400 yen cover charge. This hotel is extremely well located for all your travels into central Tokyo and a Pasmo card is well worth the money to save buying tickets every day. It's approx 200yen and 20 minutes to all of the main sights, depending on which metro line you take. The local shops are fantastic and all within minutes from the hotel. We contacted the manager by email in advance as we bought a BMobile 5gig 21day sim card for data only from the UK. The hotel replied the next day and said they were happy to receive the package and all 3 were handed to us at check in. This meant we had data for our phones and more importantly google maps and the best app - Tokyo Subway for IOS. It details the subway stops and is a must for the metro.We travelled using a Japan Rail card and the hotel kindly held onto one of our suitcases until we returned which was very helpful. Tokyo rail station is 10minutes in a taxi and cost 600 yen which was brilliant value, we hailed one right outside the hotel if you turn right and walk to the family mart small supermarket. We intend to holiday in Japan in 2 years time as it;s the cleanest, friendliest safest place I have ever experienced. Try and learn a few basic phrases as it goes well with the locals who appreciate the effort. Thankyou Mercure Ginza and see you 2019.

We always stay in this hotel for our sales mission great hotel near metro station shopping center restaurant and bars. Convenience to move around room size rather small like city hotel in Ginza. However it's clean and full set of amenities. Very good service staff at front desk had been ask for email problem she is really helpful.

The Ginza area is not considered the best touristic location for Tokyo but it has some advantages.Value per money you get a modern and reasonable size rooms.The underground is 10 minutes walk there is an underground station beneath the hotel but it is hardly relevant to any tourist destination.In addition, good selection on none sophisticated restaurants on the surrounding streets at very modest pricing.The rooms are very well maintained and clean.

The Hotel is centrally located with high-tech rooms. Good value for money. excellent service.Restaurant is run by French chefs with french and Japanese cuisine.Staff speak good English and very pleasant and polite.

The hotel was very clean, there was a mistake at first with the booking as the picture on the booking we made with Qantas did not reflect the room they tried to give us but to there credit they remedied it immediately.The room was very clean and spacious and the staff were incredibly helpful.The breakfast was excellent , however we did dine in one night and found the food lacking to be honest and not worth the money.Overall I would gladly stay there again and as for location to Ginza and the Metro it was excellent.

I spent 3 nghts at your hotel. The best experience of my stay was your pillows. It had a top layer filled with little plastic pipes. My wife and I both have neck and back issues and are very sensitve to beds and pillows other than those at home. However, the hotel pillows were magical and both of us had well rested sleep and were able to enjoy our stay in Tokyo. Would definitely return to stay again, just for the pillows. Would love to bring one home!!! Could you advise the what are these pillows called in Japan and where i can buy them.

Great location for getting in and around Tokyo. Easy walk to several railway stations, restaurants, and those shops. Breakfast had good selection of east/west food, and the staff were always helpful. Try the cafe/cake shop just round the corner

Chose this Hotel as it was a reasonable price and seemed like a good location. For Tokyo is was excellent value and you are right near the subway and the main Ginza area. There are restaurants nearby and we particularly liked Nelsons Bar around the corner. The staff were very friendly, the hotel was clean and the breakfast fine. We took a Deluxe room which was a good size. There is no outlook even though we had a 11th floor room.

The hotel was easy to find and in a good location- everything in the centre within walking distance. However our bedroom was very small, only just space for a double bed. The air con was very effective which was definitely needed in the summer heat! We liked the complimentary bottles of water for every day of our stay. Hotel bar and restaurant small and disappointing but plenty of places to eat and drink in the neighbourhood.

Good situated hotel on a 15min walking distance from tokyo Station. There's a metro station connected to the hotel. The staff is verry friendly and helpfull. On the breakfast you can choose from a western part or a Japanese part. The rooms are Japanese standard . You have all the comfort but they are a little bit smaller than european rooms. But that's Japan ?! Best service I ever had !!!

This hotel was chosen to met with a former exchange student after a break i n Guam to attend a basketball tournament in which our son played for Australia. This hotel was very central and close to all amenites including shopping and restaurants. Our former student played travel guide and we visited local temples and the Tokyo tower. The reception staff were awesome and checked us in early (over 2 hours) which was gratefully accepted. They were pleasant and helpful. Room was small but acceptable given we were in a major city. Bedding and bathroom were good. Our room rate included breakfast which was ok and standard for a major hotel. Overall I would return. Staff were a big plus here.

We are a daily of two adults and two teenage boys. We stayed here recently for four nights in interconnecting rooms. Rooms were roomy and comfortable. The buffet breakfast had a large variety of options. We didn't use the restaurant for lunch or dinner as we were our but we did pop in for an evening drink at the bar. Staff were always friendly and helpful. This location is perfect for exploring Tokyo and surrounds. Highly recommend this hotel.

My wife and I stayed at this hotel about two years ago and thought it was good then. with this review I will first give the minuses and then the pluses.Minuses.The rooms are a little small by Australian and North American standards but are still adequate, meticulously clean and comfortable. The bath rooms are clean and well stocked.The pillows could be a little bigger.The bar needs redesigning and kept opened past 9pm.PlusesThe hotel is very close to the Ginza and a short walk from both great stores, restaurants, the Imperial Palace and Tokyo Station.The hotel is one of the cleanest I have been in and the cleaning staff should be congratulated.We have been informed that the hotel will go through a refurbishment in 2018. We, ourselves believe, using the great Holmes on Homes saying it only requires some lipstick and mascara as the bones of the hotel are excellent.The outstanding quality of this hotel is its staff. We would particularly like to thank the following staff and their staff for making our stay so pleasurableJohanna (Guest Coordinator) well done JohannaCoquet (Front Office Shift Leader) thanks for sight seeing suggestions and making the bookings especially the dinner cruise of Tokyo Harbour Chris and Romain and their staff from the restaurant for friendly banter and excellent service. (The snails are the best I have ever eaten)We would highly recommend this hotel to anyone either transiting or using as a base whilst in Tokyo.

Excellent stay in this OUTSTANDING hotel!Spotlessly clean with exceptional service in every aspect.Particular mention must go to the wonderful in-house restaurant! Not only are the friendly staff attentive to your every request but the cuisine is delicious!! Compliments to the Chef and everyone involved.Very convenient location in the Ginza

This has been one the best experiences I have had with the Mercure Ginza. My flight arrived at 6 am and by 8 am I arrived at the hotel. I made an initial request for early checkin when booking via the accor website and to my surprise I was able to get the room immediately! This was a great bonus as I had some important errands to do at 11 am and it enabled me to take a quick shower before going to my meeting location.The 2nd bonus was the late checkout which enabled my to slowly go and take the airport shuttle without having to wait with all my luggage. A truly memorable experience and I will definitely come back

We had 3 rooms for 7 people in early July, staying 6 nights. My expectations were pretty low, but this hotel was surprisingly good, a solid 3.5 star property that could improve to 4 stars with a few tweaks and staff training.Positive:- Location in Ginza is very nice. Lots of high class shops, nice backstreets to explore. It is a great area. Hotel has a direct link to railway station. - Rooms are bigger than expected and have everything you need. It felt quite comfortable. Good shower, comfy bed, adjustable AC. Needs Improvement:- the breakfast buffet is pretty bad for western taste. Most annoying was that they cut each slice of bread in half, and only put out about 5 slices, 10 pieces at a time. It was constantly empty and we were asking for more bread every 5 minutes. One day they ran out and said no more. Really??? Adding to the annoyance factor was that because the bread was cut in half it would get lost in the toaster and would pop up. You were constantly trying to dig it out of a hot toaster. We were not the only people getting annoyed each morning!- we ate at the restaurant one night, too tired from a day of sightseeing to venture out. The service was pretty amateur, the waiter couldn't remember the specials, the wrong deserts were served. The food was OK, but not overly memorable.

I gave staying this hotel to my family, wife and son. They were glad to stay. Hotel staff kindly talked to my son. So he could get relax. Room is clean. Location is good. And room was upgraded. About trip and staying, they talked to me smile. Thank you for take my family comfortable staying.

We stayed here for three nights at the start of our holiday and a further two at the end of it. The hotel is a Yen800 ($10) taxi ride from Tokyo station and there are three metro stations less than 10 mins walk from the hotel so very convenient. Heaps of eating places and up market shops all within ten min walk from hotel. The first three nights we had a room on the third floor with two double beds for the three of us and it was a bit tight. The two night stay was on the 6th floor and was much roomier with same bed configuration so rooms described as being the same can be different!. No views to be had except building across the street! Reception staff very friendly and helpful. Included breakfast was quite good and our ten year old grandson averaged four to five plates each morning! We did not have dinner in the restaurant as cheaper options outside but did utilise the bar one night and enjoyed the wine. Free wifi worked well. We were here two years ago and have no hesitation in recommending the Mercure Tokyo Ginza.

Hotel is located a short walking distance from main subway station Ginza. Rooms are a bit outdated, but fair size and well equiped and free wifi. close to a large number of shops and walking distance to Tsukiji Fishmarket (in case you want to get there early in the morning, while the subway is not yet running).Breakfast buffet was included in our deal and worth it (eggs, bacon, sausages, panncakes, waffles, croisants and so forth).Friendly staff, was very helpful in arranging restaurant reservations.

We stayed a week in a Deluxe room which was spacious & well-appointed. The breakfast buffet was quite satisfactory. The location is very convenient. The WiFi was not as seamless as expected.All in all, decent value for money.

These is my little milestone where i have stayed 10X at these same hotel during i come to Tokyo. & Mercure Ginza give me surprise where i got double upgrade room. i booked superior room & they put me in Mercure suite!! its really awesome & they also give me a bottle of red wine where make me like really VIP. After 10X came to Tokyo & these time i have a chance going to Fuji Mountain & these hotel at one of the best location where i just walk to Ginza subway station & no need change train again to Shinjuku station. At shinjuku Station i took bus going to Fuji Mountain. Its comfortable & access to anywhere around Tokyo also convenient. Going to Tsukiji fish market its only 2 subway station away from Ginza.When back to Tokyo also drop off by bus at Shinjuku & take subway back to Ginza also easy.The staff also very welcome for every guest & i felt back to Mercure Ginza are back to my 2nd home.Once again thanks for yr hospitality, invite me for cocktail party & treat me like VIP. I Hope can come to my 2nd home soon

good location, near tokyo station, shopping area, restaurant, not far from tsukiji fish market any shasimi and sushi restaurantgood service, staff hospitalityrooms are quite big, clean, modern stylehotel very recomended

We chose this hotel to stay at partly because of the location, within walking distance of the railway station and access to shopping and restaurants. It wasn't hard to find and the choice of eating places around the hotel was excellent. Price was comparable if not better than other nearby hotels @24000 Yen for one night. The French restaurant attached to the hotel looked a bit dead so we didn't bother with that one. The room was small but more than adequate for one night. As an Accor Le Club member I was offered a 3pm checkout at no extra charge which was perfect for us. Staff were friendly and helpful. I'd probably stay again if it was for one night.

We stayed at this hotel for 5 nights in June. We flew into Narita airport and caught the n'ex to Tokyo station and then a short taxi ride to the hotel (worth having the address in Japanese ! ) The hotel is clean and the room was bigger than expected. It was also very quiet throughout the night which was a god send when trying to sleep through the jet lag! The daily complementary water was an added bonus when returning from a long day in the Tokyo heat! The room was a little bit basic but why would you need an amazing room when you are in one of the most amazing cities in the world! The location is definitely the best thing about this hotel. Only a 15 minute walk to the main Tokyo station where you will find the bullet trains and around a 10 minute walk to the ginza subway line which can get you to pretty much anywhere in the city ! There is a station directly under the hotel but wasn't the best for the sights of Tokyo! The shopping district of ginza is literally around the corner where you will find all the designer shops and hundreds of restaurants ! (The difficulty is picking one ! ) and there is a mc Donald's attached the same building as the hotel which is particularly handy on a late flight when you are jet lagged and starving !!! There is also a supermarket around the corner too! A little hint - don't change any currency at the hotel !! They completely rip you off ! We where desperate so changed £100 but instantly regretted it when finding a much much higher rate outside (122 offered by the hotel - 141 outside ) ! There are a lot of exchange places around the shinjuku and shibuya area ! 5 nights definitely wasn't long enough and we will definitely be returning to this hotel and to Japan in the near future!

Great location in Ginza, 15 mins from central station and near the Ginza subway stations, and main shopping street.Rooms were clean however on the first day they did not make up our room. When we called to request at least fresh towels and water I was told that they did not make up the room as the 'do not disturb' sign was on our door. It hadn't been but she wasn't willing to apologise, but we did get some towels and water in the end.Breakfast was a disappointing selection of pastries, tinned fruit, a few fresh grapes if you're lucky and some of the worst coffeee I've had. So don't pay for breakfast and grab some nearby.Reception aren't particularly helpful - a restaurant reservation felt like a big inconvenience. When asked for a cup to use the water jugs at reception we were told there were no more and the water taken away. Asked for a bottle of water which was handed over as if it was worth as much as a bar of gold.No transfer service to Haneda airport but they arranged a taxi for us which arrived within 5 mins which was appreciated.Overall, good location and clean rooms for a basic hotel. Just don't expect great service or breakfast as this took the shine off the stay.

We were traveling as a family of four and a baby and stayed at this hotel for 2 nights on the way back from Hokkaido. It's worth staying, the services, the staffs and the rooms were quite good. We had been traveling in Japan for 13 days, so , we came across many hotels which were good and some were not so good. For Mercure Ginza I would recommend you to stay. Good location, near to Fish market and many interest places.Staffs were helpful and can speak English.! It's to our family satisfaction.

I stayed last year in June as well. This time round being better acquainted with the hotel and its surrounding area I definately had a better stay! Check in was smooth and we had to bring our own bags to our room - as with previous reviews there is bell boy but one trick to aviod lugging your bags up to reception is to have them couriered from the previous hotel. Security is tight in Tokyo and was asked by reception if they could take copies of our passports- apparently its a law in tokyo so do not be alarmed! ( We were in Osaka before and were not asked / told of such ) so we were abit perplexed! Deluxe room will fit 3 persons easily with luggage. Rooms are abit tired but I am told they are refurbishing. There is free bottled water now but there were 3 of us in the room and only 2 bottles were given? Its the little things that count. As with housekeeping all over Japan, room is very clean and good toiletries provided. AC provided relief from the heat outside. The star of this hotel is the location! Close to almost all major subway lines and smack in the heart of Ginza. Staff are helpful and speak good english so there is no lack of communication here! We will be back after refurbishment! Decent price for location and services!

The hotel is in a convenient location, walking distance from the Metro station. Many shopping areas nearby. Tsujiki market is a 15 mins walk from here. Some notable staff who made my stay memorable are Estelita who helped us receive our pocket wifi from the courier, Sylvian who did my check in and Yumi who checked us out and arranged our taxi.

We stayed here 8 nights as part of our holiday in japan recently.The hotel is part of the Accor chain which we used for the majority of our hotels.Located in a quiet street 2 back from the main Ginza Street. It has a subway station (Ginza Itchrome) underneath the hotel, however that particular line is not one that we found useful. To stay at the Mercure you are approx 5-7 minutes walk from Ginza Subway (3 lines) , Higashi-Ginza Subway (2 lines), you will find these a better option or with Tokyo main station (terminus for all Bullet Trains) approx 15 minutes easy walk away . Note that the Mercure is located on the Yaesu side of Tokyo Station all the Bullet Trains and buses use that side, very handy. Reception is on 2nd floor (note that in Japan they don't have ground floors that is called 1st floor). Check in was quick and informative, a large % of the staff are European both in the restaurant and in reception so languages are not an issue.We had booked a Superior double room, which when allocated was on the 10th floor. The rooms are not large but manageable, we had 2 large suitcases plus a plane locker bag and we worked around them very well. The beds where comfortable and all the amenities first rate. Breakfast has a good spreed of western food and you can order eggs as you want them from a waiter. We used the Accor card which gave us 50% discount on breakfast. Convenience stores are located both sides of the hotel entrance, turn right walk past McDonald's and you have a Lawson s Store, turn left over the road and there is a 7/11. If you kept going past the 7/11 till the street ends in a T junction turn left and you will find an Indian restaurant ( upstairs)which is good food at a reasonable price. There is a service in Japan in that hotels will on forward your luggage, we sent our bags (2) to our next hotel in Kyoto the day before we checked out, packed a travel bag to kept us going and when we arrived at our new hotel our bags where waiting for us, no lugging them around stations. Check at reception for this service, cost around AUD$30.Overall an excellent stay in a well run hotel, staff where always first rate whether reception or the house.Would stay again in need

Everything was perfect. The air conditioning was not freezing but just right. The staff was lovely and helpful. The bed comfortable and very large. The rooms are quiet even in the centre of Tokyo. The restaurant was great and the price very reasonable. The breakfast was high quality and had a choice for the West and for the Far East!!

We stayed at the Mercure Tokyo Ginza. It was hard to find at the start however the train line is connected to the hotel in the basement so that was very handy for us.The room itself is quite dated and small. TV only had one channel in English however other hotels in Japan we noticed had more.Beds were comfortable. Bathroom was good size with shower/bath comboRooms need an upgrade and a clean as lots of scuff marks on the wall.One thing I found odd was there was no room service availableUnsure if would return in future

Stayed here for six nights on holiday. Staff were attentive and professional at reception, restaurant and throughout. Stayed in a deluxe room which was by comparison with other hotels we stayed at in Japan of a good size. Well located near public transport and Ginza shopping area. We definitely wish to stay here again and would highly recommend to others.

We stayed 7 nights in a superior twin bed room. Our room was very quiet and the staff were all friendly and efficient ( like almost everywhere in Japan )The room was a bit old fashioned. We didn't like the look of the dirty looking carpet and the bed sheets should be changed more often.Express breakfast: yoghurt, croissant, buns, coffee and tea 690 YenFull breakfast: 2200 YenThe Hotel is directly above Ginza itchome station exit 11 on the Yarakucho line and is an easy 10 minute walk to Ginza station exit 13 on the Ginza line.There are 3 or 4 convenience stores next to the Hotel.We would consider staying again the next time we are in Tokyo but we would also look at other alternatives.

This hotel was our base for a week of visiting Tokyo. We had two rooms at a reasonable price and a great Ginza location. It doesn't get more central than this. Rooms are ok in size, and clean. Better than finding an airbnb. Service was excellent. every staff person could speak English, Japanese, or French.

The location is excellent with 3 stations within easy reach, including the Yamanote line.Breakfast had a good selection, but the hot food was only warm and this is a general hotel problem I guess. The rooms do really need a spruce up, with the paint beginning to look a bit used and old.Best part of the room was the bathroom...large and plentiful supply of requirements.The size of the room was satisfactory, considering it is Tokyo.Have stayed there twice now, but did notice the need for a re paint etc.

I think Mercure Hotel Ginza is one of the most convenient hotel to travel in Tokyo.You can directly get to Ginza from Haneda airport within 30minutes.And the hotel elevator is linked to subway station, so you can move very easily.Around the hotel are lots of shopping area, dining places and more than 100years of time-honored shops such as Kimuraya bakery. Like other hotels in Japan, the hotel also has very cramped rooms but clean and the staff were usually kind and polite and they seem to be a real multi-national company.

The waiters at the hotel's dining room is so disrespectful. Asked for a piece of tissue and he just did a disrespectful gesture by himself, like he didn't want to get a piece of tissue for me. I only asked for a piece of bread as I already paid for the breakfast.

I know Tokyo hotels are expensive and this one wasn't too bad but the hotel had little character and rooms were dated and dingy. Beds were reasonably comfortable and staff were helpful. Quite a trek from the main tube station. Probably wouldn't return.

We stayed here for two nights prior to a tour. We expected a good standard from the Mercure brand and we were not disappointed. Visualise a city centre business hotel and you won't be far wrong. As others have mentioned, the reception is not on the ground floor so you have to negotiate the lifts and other guests with your suitcases when checking in and out.One observation (ok, criticism) is that the restaurant is small and eye-wateringly expensive. I would recommend the continental breakfast (650Y) rather than the buffet (2200Y) which seemed to just add fruit juice and an egg.

We had a bit of a job finding the hotel but a very kind Japanese lady stopped to help us. She then went out of her way to take us there - the Japanese people are lovely. The hotel is very welcoming and friendly and is about a 10 min walk from yukarucha station. The room was lovely and the bed comfortable. The room had everything you needed including free WiFi. Very clean hotel and we were happy to stay there. We were going to Narita airport early in the morning (leaving at 5.30am) and found the a coach goes direct from outside the station for 1000y. It was perfect. You can get to Haneda easily using the train. A good hotel to stay at for the airport.

We stayed in the hotel for 3 nights. We had a superior room in the ladysection (don't worry, it's only an extra door). The room was clean and nice. But small if you have any form of luggage. The bathroom is very nice as well. You get a good hot shower, japanse toilet with a warm seat and any toiletry available. And you get a watercooker, tea and coffee and a fridge.We didn't have breakfast but near the hotel are pleanty of coffee shops(starbucks is 2 min walk)Only thing, there is no great entrance on the streetlevel. Only an elavator. The reception is on the second floor.

The good: 1) The location (heart of Ginza + easy access to Metro)2) The Franco-Ukranian relationship manager who went out of his way to help us with transportation, gave us complimentary champagne and macaroons, checked in with us during breakfast. The bad: 1) Housekeeping didn't clear out old dishes and sheets from the day before (it lay where it was). We were with kids so the sheets had food stains which weren't replaced. I will upload photos shortly. 2) We got free drinks coupons for the bar and were told it was open till 10pm. On arriving at 9:40pm, the person at the bar told my husband rudely, that he could not serve us. The front desk gave us bottled wine as a compensation. Not cool! 3) The 'grand' breakfast: cold scrambled eggs. No mention of a live egg station. One kind of bread? DO NOT BE FOOLED INTO BUYING THIS. Plenty of cute cafes around the hotel! 4) Reception is on the first floor. And luggage is self-serve, so no luggage trolleys on the ground floor- which means if you're with a big group ie 10 people (10 bags) it is very difficult! 5) The elevator DOES NOT DETECT your hand etc when closing. Be careful!The ugly: 1) Being Platinum club Accor members (I had my wedding at Sofitel L'Imperial in Mauritius), our room wasn't ready until 5:30pm on the day of check in! We lost an entire afternoon in Tokyo! 2) Centrally-controlled energy saving air conditioning timings which went off in the middle of the night, much to the chagrin of my parents, both of whom suffer heart problems and claustrophobia. The thermostat is a placebo! They also had to stay in a room with double beds because of the lack of availability.

My entire family (almost 10 of us) decided to celebrate my father's 60th birthday in Tokyo from the 16th-19th of May. 4 members of my family, including myself, are platinum members with LeClub Accor. We've had an otherwise great experience dealing with other Accor hotels, having celebrated my sister's wedding at the Sofitel L'Imperial in Mauritius, and have frequented other Accor brands in and around India. We stayed in four rooms (2 queen bed and 2 twin bed non smoking rooms). I was shocked to hear when we reached the hotel that our rooms were yet not ready for us to move. Forget the fact that we had platinum membership and all the privileges the membership has to bestow upon its members, we had 3 children, as well as we had a lot of bags and had departed from Kyoto early that morning. We were finally able to move in at 530 pm! Yes our entire day got wasted just hopelessly waiting in the lobby. Additionally we were told by the Club Accor representatives on the helpline, before we reached, that we would get upgraded as we were platinum members, but the hotel said they were "fully booked" (although booking.com and other websites clearly showed there were rooms available, and in fact we booked our fourth room at the hotel itself). It's definitely a business hotel and don't expect any bell-boys to transfer luggage to your room as it's self-service. Even when we went to the bar to avail of the free welcome drinks given to us as Platinum members, we were rudely turned away as the bar shut at 10 pm (we reached at 9:30 pm). We alerted the front desk, and they hurriedly rescued the situation and sent wine bottles to our room. The thermostat in the rooms were a bit messed up, and the air-conditioners were definitely not working. It kept randomly switching off in the middle of the night, which made it uncomfortable. When alerted the problem to the Front desk, they put an "air-purifier" in the room saying this is all they had. As retribution for all the mess ups, the hotel decided to give us free full breakfast for one day, which we kind of regretted taking, as it was quite bland, and there are some real nice cafetarias near the hotel. Apart from all the above mishaps, the hotel is located in probably the best location in Tokyo- the centre of the hustling and bustling Ginza area, & all the biggest shops/stores are a stones-throw away. Their customer/quality manager Mr. Nikita Dimitriev is indeed a gem of person, and tried his best to salvage the situation we were in. He personally came with us to the Ginza station and helped us to book our daily metro tickets. He was very understanding, although he could not do much. The complimentary celebratory wine and champagne was much appreciated by all of us. Really the only bright spark in our entire stay unfortunately. Hopefully this hotel repairs it's image and makes it more comfortable to other travellers and tourists. As a Platinum LeClub member was thoroughly disappointed that we had a stay with quite a few hiccups.

Stayed two nights, we had a deluxe twin, on the 6th floor. Spacious room and bathroom (step up into the bathroom). Complimentary toiletries, bottled water, tea and coffee making facilities. We paid extra for buffet breakfast which had small hot western selection and good continental choices, fresh bread rolls, pastries etc. It also doubles up as a French restaurant in the evening, menu looked ok. Top tip, there's a McDonalds restaurant on the corner if you want that sort of food. We couldn't find this hotel upon our return one night, it's not well sign posted. However use McDonalds as your marker (the hotel has a large red canopy on the street, hence my reference to hidden). On a quiet street.

Choose this hotel again as it is centrally located in Ginza and close to metro stations. Lawson is close by and this provides your basic needs while in Tokyo. Brought my family this time round and they enjoyed their stay there as well. Check in was smooth and straight forward being an Accorplus Platinum member. Room upgraded as usual. We had breakfast this time round in the hotel and its very basic (came with the room), limited dishes but will certainly get you through the morning if you're in a rush. Lots of nearby restaurants / convenient stores, so you might want to give those a try. Heading back to Narita airport, we took a taxi (which is what I would suggest) to Tokyo central station and the NEX (Narita Express) to Narita airport. This is probably the most convenient way to that airport. Rooms clean and basic as per my previous review. Price is always high...(you're in Tokyo). Will certainly come back again!

Clearly value for money hotel, considering prices you can pay in Tokyo. Location could not better. In the middle of Ginza, full of places to walk around, shops, restaurants and bars. Walking distance from Princess Park.Room pretty clean and decent size (for Tokyo standards!) and a simple but good quality breakfast. As said, value for money!

Location is simply perfect but the hotel has this old feeling of the 80's. Expect nothing much. Rated as 4 stars but not worth more than 3.Bathrooms are old fashioned, you hardly see anyone from the hotel except upon check in and check out (are we disturbing them??). Room was not properly ready when I arrived even though I clearly indicated my arrival time 2 days before arrival. Even though I am a platinum member of Accor this place would be off the list for any further visit in Tokyo.

Mercure Ginza you were so disappointing! From me having to argue with Reception on arrival that I do receive discounts as I am a AccorPlus member. When having dinner in the flood lit restaurant with absolutely no atmosphere then being told it was a limited menu as the chef had a disaster in the kitchen! Breakfast was so mediocre that we ate out the rest of the time. The hotel is 'tired', very impersonal & desperately needs a makeover or knockdown. The front desk is really disinterested & totally unfriendly except for one Frenchman. Mercure Mercure pick up your act - I would rate you 2 stars.

Comfortable hotel, very close to all the retail opportunities available in Ginza. Shop till you drop then 50 metres to the hotel. Very easy to find your way around from this hotel and a subway station located underneath. Clean and comfortable, great nights sleep, although the curtains don't go quite to the edge due to the wide windows so we found the early morning light a bit of a distraction. All in all a very enjoyable stay in a beautiful city.

This hotel is located within Ginza, walking distance from Tokyo Station.Friendly staff with excellent english. While waiting in reception I observed them help various guests with tours etc. very helpful.Good location in a swanky shopping area, and is just a few minutes walk from excellent bars/ restaurants and cafes.The hotel has a small bar at the back of it's adjacent restaurant, which is fine for a quick night cap.The room is quite large for Japan, much bigger than other hotels I stayed in.

The Hotel has many things (AIRcondition ...) explained in english, while many other hotels are japanese only. Reception speaks good englisch. Rooms are small, windows cannot be opened. But this seems to be standard in Japan.

The hotel is located in Shopping district of Ginza which is a shoppers paradise. The rooms are really small for 2 people, but the price is good.Limited options for Vegetarians, though there is Nataraj Restaurant which is pure veg located about 900 meters walk from the restaurant which is excellent. The restaurant is located next to famous Uniqlo store in ginza which everybody knows on the 7th floor. The indian food that you get is one of the best that you can taste in Japan. There lunch buffet is price at 1100 Yen is reasonable and eat as much as you want. Coming back to Mecure you can either take a cab from tokyo station for about 650 Yen (The base price for the first kms is reduced to 410 yen, which makes taxi a very attractive option) and move to any place that you want.Else if you have the card can travel subway or bus. Overall can stay in Mercure for the location.

Room is a little small, perhaps due to Japanese typical lifestyle. Very friendly staff. Very clean, however carpet is kind of old and slightly smelly (fresh spray provided), also there is no bathroom fan. Overall, It is a very nice hotel to stay with fabulous streets of Ginza, Tokyo. Highly recommend.

The location of this hotel is fantastic. It has an entry to Ginza-itchome station in the basement, and it's an easy walk to Tokyo, Ginza, Higashi-Ginza, Yurakucho, and Hibiya stations, which meant we could easily get a direct train to and from the hotel (changing lines can mean long walks). The latest we were out and about was probably about 10:30pm, and we always felt safe getting back to the hotel, and we really liked the area it's in. There is a 7-11 with an ATM that accepts foreign cards nearby (it doesn't show up on Google maps, and they only sometimes left a sign on the corner, but it's about a minute walk - turn left out of the hotel, left at the first intersection, right at the next intersection, and it's about half way up the block, on the right hand side). The bed's were comfy, the shower water pressure was very good, good supply of toiletries, and the step up to the bathroom was very Japanese.I'd happily stay here again.

This hotel has an amazing location, next to theFabulous streets of Ginza.The staff is warm and welcoming and they doA great job assisting the guests with suggestions on all the options Tokyo has to offer.The hotel is in desperate need of an update.The rooms are very small, and not clean byThe Accore hotel standard. The pillows wereOld and smelled foul.Not a pleasant experience at all.This could be a great hotel after a seriousUpdate and cleaning.

near to metro station exit. just behind ginza shopping street. 15mins walking distance to Tsukiji market. close to Itoya where they have specialized theme for every floor for you to shop around. convenience store is very near and there is a fast food restaurant just 1minute walk from the hotel entrance.

The location is ideal. There are plenty of options for transportation with metro lines and the JR Rail Loop close by. There is a lovely Starbucks a very short distance away. You can walk to the Tsukiji Fish Markets. We even walked to Hamarikyu Gardens from the hotel.The rooms are in need of an up-date which I believe is happening shortly.

You cannot beat the location, just off Ginza (the main shopping street). But what's even more impressive, is the price. Admittedly I got this stay on sale, but my Japanese colleagues could not believe what I paid to stay in the Ginza area.The rooms are a reasonable size for Japan, a bit dated and the breakfast is ho hum, but again, you won't find a better location and price. I'd definitely stay here again.

Location:Great location, it's about 3 minutes walking to famous Ginza Shopping mall and some 15 minutes of walk to Tokyo Station which can connect you to virtually any major place in Japan. There's subway/metro station accessing from the hotel which is fantastic. Room: Room is quite small but rather comfortable. It would be nice if you can open the window to let in some fresh air especially in my room the AC does not seem to cool enough. Bed is quite comfortable especially the pillows (two soft and two with beads which I find very therapeutically relaxing). Bathroom is great with plenty of amenities - i liked especially the combs. Restaurant/Breakfast: Breakfast is excellent with plenty of selections. Their porridge and miso soup was great to start with.

Perfect location, close to the subway and restaurants, shops etc... in Ginza The staff was very helpful and multilingual both in French and English. The only drawback is the size of the rooms but I guess that Tokyo-wide. Altogether, a very positive stay.

This hotel is in a perfect location for sightseeing with easy access to the subway. Yet, the rooms were silent at night, which was perfect for a great night's sleep after a busy day discovering wonderful Tokyo. We had two interconnecting rooms, one for the children and one for my husband and myself, which pushed the price of our stay up but was ideal in terms of space and being able to put the children to bed early. The Mercure was one of very few hotels to offer this. Breakfast was fresh and had plenty of options such as croissants, bread, eggs, bacon, sausages, fruit and yoghurt. Check in was easy and we appreciated the mini green tea kit kats we were given to welcome us. Check out was also easy and we are grateful to the reception staff for having booked us into a restaurant in Osaka after we had gone, as they'd promised to do.

Everything was perfect during my stay at Mercure Ginza: 1- Location: just 7min walk to Access Narita bus stop, 7min walk to Ginza Metro Station, a metro station under the building, in the middle of Ginza (a fenomenous shopping district) but in a quiet quarter; 2-Building: quite new and easy access by foot (sidewalks in excellent condition to one pulls heavy luggage) or car/taxi. 3-Staff: very professional, friendly, skilled and attentive at reception desk and at the restaurant as well;4-Rooms: spacious enough to arrage ones luggage. Perfect amenities, cleanliness and soundproofing. Very comfortable. 5-Breakfast: many options of bred, fruit, dairy, cereals, juice, etc. Eat as much as you can! 6- Costs-benefits: excellet option for middle or high budget travellers; Highly recommended.

This hotel is in a fabulous location - a step away from the Metro and five minutes from the JR Line. There are convenience stores a minute away and a 24 hour Mc Donald's on the same block. The staff are friendly. The bathrooms are clean and there is a small bathtub. For those with mobility issues or knee or hip problems the step up into the bathroom may be a concern.BUT the rooms are in serious need of a massive up-grade. The carpets are stained and the walls are badly marked.

The place is in a good location for the Ginza experience just walk, it has a subway under it, handy once you get a hang of the rail (good luck,its complicated). The staff very helpful & friendly. Found this of all the Japanese people, must say it makes your beautiful country a memorable place to visit. Only one shadow was the man who served the free drink at the restaurant (accor member privilege ) came over as arrogant feel, with "what do you expect for a free drink "when asking about the drinks available, was the juice fresh & the type of wine with a shrug of the shoulder. No, he wasn't Japanese.

Stayed here 7 nights and never had a bad experience. They were very hospital, friendly and professional. The room was always clean and well kept. the bath was a little dated but overall, very nice. Sits on top of Ginza-itchome station but within a 5 minute walk you can get to Ginza and Higashi-Ginza which are much more convenient to getting around town. This is right in the middle of high end shopping mecca so Louis Vuitton and Tiffany's will love you that much more. It's very close to lots of 24hr shops that have just about everything you could need in an emergency. McD's and S-bucks is also less than a block away.
user_name:
photodoug
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: This hotel is perfect for first time visitors to Japan/Tokyo. Hotel staff all speak perfect English which makes check in/out and any inquiries a breeze.Location is brilliant - in the heart of Ginza - easy stroll to shops, restaurants and underground stations. A couple of really good convenience stores are across the road (Hello Natural Lawson!) Twin room was spacious and very clean. Bathroom was good - lots of amenities and bench space to spread out.

as a gold member, I am automatically upgraded to deluxe room, which is very spacious considering Tokyo is an expensive city. It has complete amenities with a good bedding quality.In overall, I enjoyed my stay here, it has a very good location, direct access to Japan Metro station, very close to Ginza shopping strip, easy to find good coffee shop, fast food restaurant.

What a great hotel. Nothing was too much for them. They were very helpful, gave great advise on travel tips. Hotel rooms are a great size and loved the hotel amenities.. The rooms were very clean and we loved the toilet.. Best location in Ginza, close to the stations and so safe. Try the restaurants under the train tracks that are only walking distance away. Do yourself a favour.

The room is normal with basic itens to have a good stay.The localization is fantastic. It has a Metro entrance/exit in the underground of the building and a couple of meter of the Ginza's main street.The price is a little high but at the end it is a good choice to stay in Tokyo.

Conveniently located. Easy access to major train lines (as well as direct line from Haneda and Narita) all within 10 mins walking - Line beside the hotel was useless to places I wanted to go though. Many choices of restaurants, cafes and shops to suit different budgets and tastes all in a few mins of walking or round the corner. There's also McDonalds and Lawsons next door. Never needed the hotel restaurant or breakfast. Area is also not packed like Shinjuku. Will likely stay there again if price is reasonable.Rooms are clean but small. Bed and pillows surprisingly comfortable and not hard. Aircon was good - I'm Glad they don't have centrally controlled aircon/heaters. You may want to note that bathroom/toilet is on a stupidly high platform.Stayed 8 nights in two rooms. Would have been perfect if they had washing machines like some hotels.

The hotel is in a great location, easy access to metro and subway and surrounded by restaurants and café. There are more rooms for improvement for staff, especially Europeans at reception need to put some smiles like locals.

Accor Plat Dec 16 StayStayed 2 nights. Two reasons - location and my Accor Membership.Price for my stay was within my budget. (Was going to stay again in March 17 but the rate was over USD$400 as hotel was 99.9% full)Quiet back street Ginza location with "in-building" subway access. The line that I needed was only a five minute walk away. Fast food close, and some great little restaurants nearby. Hotel restaurant is small and adequate for breakfast and serves a good priced "fixed" lunch. Did not dine at night.Rooms are small, functional - immaculately clean but a little tired. Limited TV choices and a good selection of amenities.Front desk staff - "ok" - nothing more.Love the area, will stay again but only at a reasonable price. Accor needs more 4 - 5 star Japan properties. Especially in Tokyo.

Excellent location, easily accessible with a small walk. The hotel is not easy to be fond as the entrance is in a small road and signs can be unseen.Rooms are bigger than the normal standard in Japan and enough for all you need to do in a room. Space is enough to open 2 bags leaving a slight space for walking. Cozy bedroom (but hard pillow, next time I need to ask for a softer one) and bedroom. Missing a common bath as usually found in Japan. Breakfast is really good and reception always available and friendly.

We stayed in the Mercure Ginza for 3 nights. Hotel is excellently located, near subway and Ginza shopping district. Large clean rooms, great local knowledge in front desk people and located amongst numerous restaurants.

First, a disclaimer: for the last 5 years when staying in hotels in Asia I have always booked a Sofitel. Oddly, in Tokyo the highest level Accor property is a Mercure so my comments need to be read in that light (as well as a Platinum members.Positive points: Ginza location; cleanliness; welcoming staff; quite large rooms by Tokyo standards.Negative points: very small public areas for relaxing; an even smaller bar; limited Platinum privileges.

My friend and I stayed at the hotel when we first arrived in Tokyo from Narita Airport. It is located in the Ginza Shopping District about 7 blocks from Yarachuco Station which is one stop west on the Yamonote Line in Tokyo Station. We had very little difficulty finding it when we began looking up instead of across because many buildings are tall!Right beside this hotel is a 24 hour McDonalds which comes in handy if you an early riser and a Starbucks diagonally across the street- very handy for coffee!The hotel itself has a French flavor as some of the staff are French and the restaurant has a French Air about it as well. The rooms were comfortable but nothing out of the ordinary and we did need help with how the lights worked at first!The staff were agreeable and eager to make us comfortable but we did make a mistake regarding the date line and they were very strict adhering to policy! A shuttle would also be helpful from the station so we did not have to haul our luggage.All in all we would highly recommend this hotel as a place to stay in Tokyo!

Stayed here for 3 days ... Simple room. Clean and full amenities .. Location is good too . Plenty of cafe around . Near to subway and a stones throw away from Ginza shopping belt .. Members benefit given ...

The hotel is adequate and well priced for Tokyo BUT it is in need of upgrading the rooms and specifically the bathrooms. The rooms are comfortable and clean and the nespresso machine a nice touch. the internet connection is also very good and fast. The hotel is quiet and that's good in Tokyo Ginza as its very commercial. It is close to the metro and shopping district. What makes the hotel though is the staff. They are VERY VERY helpful and as a foreigner in Japan it is highly appreciated. Specially late at night when you are jet lag and disorientated. I did not eat there so I could not comment on the restaurant. there are plenty of local japanese places around to try. This was a business trip for me and I have stayed in much more high end hotels in Tokyo (and MUCH more expensive) that did not have the customer service this hotel has so that's why i would recomend it.

Arrived in Japan for a week stay. Two days ago me and my family was in Bangkok and also stayed in a Mercure Hotel. My main comment then was that Mercure Siam Bangkok was a simple no frills hotel with a great location. I would also same the same thing about Mercure Ginza that the location was really great which was reasonably priced. Our room which had two double beds was bigger than the other rooms as I managed to peek in one the rooms beside ours.

It's not the first time I'm staying in an Accor hotel, however this one is definitely the best!The staff is friendly and warm - service is really good. Mattress and pillows are good and breakfast is top!I will come back to Mercure Tokyo Ginza for sure!

A very convenient location in the main shopping area of the city with easy access to the underground. The hotel staff were friendly and helpful and the hotel provided a buffet breakfast and a restaurant in the evening.

My husband and I were here for 3 days. As we're on holiday, we found the location was really great for us, e.g. we walked to the Fish Market, ate at local restaurants at the alleys, and shopped along the main street in Ginza. The best bit is the close proximity to a subway station that has a direct train to Haneda Airport.

I'm often travelling to Tokyo,for business, and eventually found out this hotel which I find convenient , quite and clean.i enjoy fresh baguette and croissants at breakfast, which I prefer to traditional soup, fish and rice, sorry for being so desperately French (-:

I was Staying on this hotel due to business trip to Japan. Hotel is placed close to Ginza the main shopping street in Tokyo. We had only breakfast here. But this was OK. room was good and clean. The personal here is friendly

My husband and I stayed here with our baby for 8 nights in February and were quite pleased with the experience.First, the location of Mercure Tokyo Ginza is fantastic. It's a (very) short walk to the main shopping street, and just across are a Lawson's, a Starbucks, and a some good places to eat. There's a good ramen place just down the street, as well as a good soba place. The subway was quite near too. Traveling with a baby, and this being our first trip to Tokyo, we had a relatively easy time. It was in a good location so we could just walk around then go back to our room anytime we needed to. I've heard that rooms in Tokyo tend to be small and, although we had a bit of luggage with us, the room was comfortable enough. Plus, the service of Mercure was great so we're very happy with our stay. I would definitely recommend staying here.

The central location on top of Ginza Metro station with access directly from Hotel basement was perfect.Easy access to Tokyo Station and Shinkansen trains all over Japan.Walking distance to many famous spots.

My wife and I stayed here for two nights. Location to Ginza station a plus as we were able to walk 15minto hotel. Lobby busy but front desk staff very efficient and we were quickly check in . Rooms are in need of upgrading and was told by staff that this is scheduled. Area around hotel you may shop til you drop !Food choices are abundant and Tokyo Station is within walking distance.Would like to stay again after remodeling , but for this stay the location and staff were the stars!

This was a comfortable hotel for our four night stay. The standard room was the biggest we experienced in Japan. The hotel is very conveniently located near multiple metro and JR lines. I would say the only downfall was the expensive breakfast. The service was excellent, but the food was only ok for the price you pay. Having said that, I would highly recommend this hotel.

Staff are friendly and helpful. Room is spacious and clean. Has a bath too! Restaurant is reasonably priced for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Wifi great. Location near public transport, shops and restaurants.

The hotel is located in Ginza, which is superb neighborhood. Rooms are small, as in most hotels in Tokyo. If you do not want to pay for breakfast the ¥ 1800 per per person/day, there is a starbucks just 1 block away or a cafe just around the corner. Very close to shops, transport, restaurants, metro station, bus and train main station, and all other activities.What surprised me most, specially for the lovely people in Japan, was the reception staff, which was not very polite and friendly, may be because some of them are not Japanese.

Stayed for just a night, but every thing was great.1. enough room space - even 2 adults and 2 kids,2. great locatoin - waking distance from subway stations. just next to the ginza-itchome station, 15 minutes from Tokyo station, 8 minutes from Ginza.3. friendly staffs.BUTIt was not easy to find The hotel!!

Stayed for three nights. Took 15 minutes to walk from Tokyo Station to hotel. If you do not want to eat at the hotel for breakfast, there is a Macdonald downstairs. Great location with lots of shopping and food joints.

This hotel is very well situated for exploring the Ginza area; very close to shops, transport and other activities. However, the quality of the room we had was very poor for this chain of hotels which usually provide accommodation of a higher standard. Whilst the corridors were clean and being pumped with scented air, the room itself was small, hot and smelly with a filthy carpet and scuffed/stained walls. Storage was poor, with us having to put one of our suitcases on the desk. There were no drawers and only a tiny wardrobe. I complained, but reception staff said the hotel was full and could only move us the next day but with no guarantee that the new room would be any better. Must do better.

It's always a challenge finding a room in a good space to accommodate family of 2 adults and 2 kids in Tokyo. I know to pay more or get two separate rooms can solve. Two twins room at Mercure Ginza was quite nice space for us as our kids are at age 6 and 9 only. The location is good, attaching to Metro. Even though we need to leave quite early on next day, we still like our stay very much.

Stayed at the Mercure Ginza for 7 nights in February 2017. This hotel is perfect as a base for a sight seeing holiday in Tokyo. Spotlessly clean and well located in Ginza. Attached to a subway station and only a short walk to Yurakucho station on the yamonote line. Rooms aren't huge but perfectly fine for two people. Would have no hesitations in staying here again.

I stayed at the Mercure Ginza for one night as a LeClub Gold while transiting in Tokyo. I reached out to the property beforehand and was notified that renovations have yet to begin. I decided to give the property a try anyway. I was upgraded to a Queen Deluxe room. I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and facilities of the hotel. The location was also exceptional, a short 3 minute walk from exit A13 of Ginza station.All LeClub amenities were provided without having to ask (welcome drink, room upgrade, additional amenities in room- mini bottles of drinks and macaroons). Even before the refresh, the rooms were well-furnished and had good facilities. Staff were friendly and helped facilitate a reservation at Kyubey without issue. Overall a great stay. I look forward to returning when the renovations have been completed.

My wife and I stayed here during a visit to Tokyo last month. I kept hearing about tight hotel rooms in the city unless you paid the big bucks, so I was concerned. This hotel was just fantastic. Very easy to find if you're walking, as we were, from Tokyo Station after taking the NEX from Narita. About a 10 minute walk at the most. The room was spacious with many amenities provided, including all toiletries (even toothbrushes and toothpaste, and razors and shaving gel), robes, slippers, etc. More than enough space to stretch out.Breakfast was very good with wide selection. Traditional "Western" offerings as well as more local selections. Everything was fresh and delicious. We also tried the restaurant for dinner one night and it was excellent as well. Prices are unbelievably reasonable for Tokyo.Location can't be beat with subway station in the same building and an easy walk to the larger Ginza station. Close to shopping, restaurants and even McDonald's and a Family Mart within a minute walk. Friendly staff. Impeccably clean rooms and hallways. Convenient location. Great value. Will definitely stay here again when we go back. Highly recommend.

The staff made us feel very welcome. They helped us with everything required to make our stay relaxed and natural. The location of the hotel was excellent; close to transport, restaurants and really cool cafes. The room was comfortable and clean. The restaurant within the hotel provided first class French cuisine; extremely enjoyable environment.

I love this hotel when on business in Tokyo. It is in a great location and very easy to go out and walk around and find good places for food and shoping. Rooms are a great size, always very clean with good facilities. Wi-Fi is free and it works very well.

I booked through internet, and extended my stay by calling worldwide reservations. They extended my stay but decided to change it (to prepaid and charged my credit card). When they realised that they had made a mistake, they claimed that Accor will contact me anytime regarding the refund. Unfortunately there wasn't any communication back to me. I kept on calling, but they just gave me false hope. Nobody got back to me. Being an Accor member and was feeling quite stuck, I called on customer care. The first person told me to document my case and promised to call back within 3 hours, alas after 3 hours there wasn't any news. I called back and he has already left home. The second one who picked up the phone apparently wasn't from ACCOR paid member customer care, said that he wasn't actually supposed to help, but went out of his way to help - so I should feel fortunate for his assistance.In the end it wasn't sorted out really, but since I was able to travel, I didn't need the refund from the prepaid mistake. The customer care person didn't want to apologise for all the inconveniences I have gone through. He quite arrogantly made the point that it is not his mistake, and told me to settle down and focus on the holiday...There was a total breakdown in both communication, and the whole corporate image/strategy.

Stayed for 1 week. The hotel is well located and reasonably priced for central Tokyo. It is conveniently located with good quality bars and restaurants that are not too expensive nearby. The staff are very competent, friendly and speak good English. The rooms are a reasonable size but in need of an update. Overall well recommended.

Affordable hotel in Ginza. It is located near to main department stores in Ginza as well as the infamous Tsukiji Fish Market. You can explore the city straight from your hotel room as you can access the Ginza-itchōme subway station straight from the hotel's basement.

Appropriate rooms size, cleanliness, calm and quiet atmosphere, silent air conditioner but a bit too warm and thermostat control panel didn't work, firm mattress…It was a very pleasant stay and I had a warm welcome from the staff. In this regard, special mention should be given to Vivien, competent multilingual receptionist, with a strong professional sense of hospitality.
