This hotel is very well located, just 200m from upscale shopping district of Ginza. There are many luxury shops and near the most important train hub in Japan (Tokyo Station).The room was big as per Tokyo standards and had a modern coffee machine and amenities.The hotel manager was very kind and the front desk team shared city tips and arranged restaurant bookings for me. The breakfast is complete (very good as an European breakfast).As Tokyo is a pricey city for accommodation, this is a very good option comparing price/quality/location.I traveled solo, but coming back in a couple with my wife and daughter. Didn't have any doubt to coming back to this Mercure hotel.

I stayed four nights in this hotel in mid January. The staff service is good. The location is excellent. There are many luxury shops nearby such as LV, Chanel and Bulgari. The room size is normal. Not very big but clean.

Three of us (parent & 2 teenagers) stayed for three comfortable nights.Extra (good-sized) single bed added to room with two large singles (maybe even doubles).There was enough room to be comfortable for the three of us plus luggage.Decor as you'd expect from the Mercure chain.The bathroom was very clean and functional.The breakfast buffet had enough variety to cater for different tastes and food intolerances.The staff were a mixture of Japanese and European so English is not problem. They were courteous and helpful. A pleasant comfortable stay without any incident.I'd stay here again!

The Mercure hotel is located excellent in the city of Tokyo within the shopping district Ginza. Just 1 station subway plus one station local train to Tokyo main station, the hotel provides a seperate entrance to the subway station. You don't have to leave the hotel and use the street which is pretty useful at rainy days.The room is spacy in comparison to other Tokyo hotels, it's quiete and the AC/heating system works very well. You receive to bottles of water each day.The breakfast buffet is good (not excellent) but it's worth the moderate price (2200 Yen only).Without the following drawback I would rate the hotel with 4 to 5 stars. Unfortunately the WiFi provides the worst user experience I made ever in Japan. It's extremely slow, many websites actually don't open due to server time outs. My speedtest app didn't work due to the low speed. If you depend on WiFi because of your business iPad and iPhone you have lost. I spent my evenings at the nearby Starbucks to write E-mails with attachments and to prepare powerpoint files.If you are just on vacation, this hotel could be a good option, but if you need WiFi for your business you should definitely choose another hotel. By the way, I spent 5 nights, the terrible WiFi speed didn't improve at any day. Because for my purpose (business trip with heavy usage of iPad) the hotel was a bad option, I can rate 1 star only.

The Mercure Tokyo Ginza is an ideal base to explore Tokyo just off the main shopping streets of Ginza and just a short walk away from the Ginza Itchome metro station. I stayed in room 307 which is quite spacious for a hotel in central Tokyo, very clean with standard hotel furnishings, comfortable double bed and very good Wi-Fi. Bathroom small but fine, view straight across the road to offices.Reception staff very friendly and helpful, ate only once in the restaurant okay but not a great selection charge of JPY2200. Lovely Starbucks just a few minutes walk away with a little McDonalds in between.

Location is good! Close to many attractions - dining, shopping and entertainment. The staff were very helpful, they provided us all of information about Tokyo. Breakfast was reasonable. Wifi speed is fast enough. I stayed here for 8 nights and happy with our choice.

Don't get me wrong, the place is nice. We enjoyed staying there based on the location, price and cleanliness. However we had a terrible experience with the staffs while we were there.We stayed there 24-26 December and 30 December - 01 January 2017.On 25 December, we decided that we would be having breakfast at the restaurant. Breakfast was not included but because we were accor member, we were told that the we would be given a buy one get one free.While we were eating, the restaurant staff asked how we would like to pay. My dad decided to pay cash to to the waiter. We gave him 4,400 YEN for the four of us.The next day, we left very early (5.30 AM) because we had to catch the 6AM Shinkansen to Nagano. We tried to check out and were held by the receptionist. She said that we haven't paid for the breakfast. We tried explaining and the lady understood and since we had another booking for the 30th, we said that we can continue this then as we were in a hurry. And we couldn't be late because we've booked a day tour in Nagano which we have paid full and unrefundable.Thanks to that, we almost missed our train. We got to the track just 7 minutes before departure.On 30 December, we returned to Tokyo to stay at the same hotel. The receptionist lady (a different one) told us we haven't paid for breakfast. We explained to her and she said she will confirm with the waiter and erase the bill from their system. We though that everything was OK.01 January, we were checking out and needed to catch a train to Narita airport for our flight. GUESS WHAT? We were billed again for the breakfast.We tried explaining to the receptionist and he wouldn't listen and understand. He kept saying not according to the system, it's not in the system, the system said bla bla bla. Sick of it, we asked him to bring out the waiter from the restaurant.The waiter came, and CONFIRMED OUR STORY. He said "yes indeed I remember receiving exactly 4,400 YEN from you. I remember because you had so many ACCOR cards and we made a joke about it."The receptionist still didn't want to hear any of it and kept going about how we couldn't leave until we settle the bill. We decided we had enough and said we are going and left him there with his jaw wide open.A few days later, we received an email billing us (AGAIN!) for the bloody breakfast.My dad asked me to write directly to the manager and accor explaining our situation and FINALLY the bill was written off along with apologies from the hotel.And of course, we made it to the train tracks just under 5 minutes before departure. Thanks to my dad's decision to leave the unreasonable receptionist behind. Thank God we weren't chased by security though!

The Mercure is interesting in it's location and entrance from the street of subway. Close to many attractions - dining, shopping and entertainment. The staff were very friendly and helpful, going out of their way to provide information. The triple room was well appointed and had plenty of room. Breakfast was reasonable.

Check in and checkout was fast and friendly. They used to charge for internet but am pleased that they have done away with that. Free in-room internet was fast. When we called for the unreplenished complimentary bottles of water, the receptionist was so apologetic and delivered to our room within minutes. Room tho small, typical of Japan, was tasteful and clean. Location was within easy access to shops, food, subway station.

A quiet hotel within the Ginza district that has well appointed rooms and comfortable beds. Complimentary water, high quality bathing products, selection of pillows for different types of sleepers. Very close to many restaurants and airport transportation. Very helpful English speaking staff and good breakfast offering. Very enjoyable toilets!!!

very happy with the location of the hotel, accessible to public transportation system, walking distance to tsukiji market. mix of western & local selection for breakfastgood range of toiletries, bathrobe

PROS (1) Location - close to Ginza Train, subway stations (2) close to shopping areas at the centre of Tokyo, Ginza, including famous department store (3) close to restaurants (4) complimentary mineral water (5) wifi speed is fast enough (6) Reception is very kind, in particular, Mr Kakeru Moriki was very kind and efficient. He provided me with very helpful information regarding the venues I was going to visit, including information regarding subway lines. (7) hotel is located in quiet block.CONS (1) buffet breakfast was poor, compared to the price.

Very well connected and centrally located in ginza shopping district. Offers nice complimentary continental breakfast. Ideal for business trips.Courteous staff to help you on ground transportation and locality.

This is my second visit (last one in the year 2006), and found this place is still the same. My complaint was only the room aircon. Not cold enough even though I have complained to the hotel staff. Despite the aircon, I like this hotel area, access to Ginza area and size of the room.Subway station can be reached from the basement and McDonald's restaurant is nearby.

Stayed at this hotel 2x during peak season. Love the location, just right behind main Ginza-dori, n directly above Ginza Itchome subway station. If you're a culinary enthusiast, this is a perfect base for Sushi and Tempura outings (tons of starred restaurants within walking distance). I usually used a shuttle bus from Narita airport to reach the hotel, only 1,000JPY per adult one way and it stops nearby the hotel (Access Narita bus). Room is very compact and rather old, but at least functional. My main problem is just that the 2nd time we stayed here, they ran out of non-smoking room despite our prior request. I ended up not able to sleep the whole night because my poor nose was so itchy due to the strong cigarette smell. Not sure I'll be back after that last episode.

The Mercure is ideally located in the Ginza region of Tokyo. It is close to major Department stores, railway stations and restaurants - all of which are within walking distance. The rooms, while small, are typical of what one generally finds in big cities in Japan. However, this is more than made up for by a friendly and efficient staff - not to mention a super breakfast. It is reasonably priced for a clean, well apointed and centrally located hotel in Tokyo. Free wifi of course. They kindly allowed us to leave major pieces of luggage when we went on side trips. As a precaution, be aware that laundry on public holidays is double priced. Take tea bags, if you like black tea - opposed to green. We would definitely return.

Stayed here for total 6 nights. Very nice location. Very close to the subway. Mc donalds and Starbucks are just around the corner. Before I arrived, I email them for direction from Haneda airport. There direction were very clear and easy to follow. Staff are very friendly and we even left our luggages when we went to Osaka and Kyoto. Again the hotel's location is just amazing. Is in the heart of shopping district of Ginza. Definitely would come back here.

We had an excellent stay at Mercure Tokyo Ginza! Very well located in the city, the staff were very helpful, kind and professional, and the room was big (we were three) and clean. I highly recommend it!

The Mercure Tokyo Ginza is only a moderately-priced 15 minutes taxi ride for Haneda International Airport, so is very accessible even though it sits in the heart of the Ginza area. The staff are warm and engaging and eager to assist in making your stay as comfortable and stress-free as possible. Access to 5 Tokyo subway lines can be gained with a maximum 5 minutes walk. Breakfast is available in the restaurant and an Express side-bar service is also provided for guests who are checking out early and on the run to meetings or the airport/Tokyo Central Rail Terminal. Ample Convenience stores surrounding the hotel, including a Family Mart and it pays to remember that Seven-Eleven stores accept foreign debt and credit cards, so all is well.

We stayed here for our first 3 nights in Japan so was unsure of what to expect after a 12 hour flight, lack of sleep and culture shock.There was no need to worry as it was almost embarrassingly easy to travel by train from Narita to here.The hotel is a 10 to 15 minute walk from the station and is simple to find and is in a great location for the shopping areas nearby.Our room was fine for our needs and everything required was provided.I do have to give extra praise for the reception staff (possibly Kumiko but my memory is fuzzy after travelling so much!) for arranging a booking at a nearby restaurant.Nothing was too much trouble and it was a lovely introduction to Tokyo and Japan in general.We only had breakfast in the hotel as there are lots of great places to eat nearby.

We stayed three nights and a full day here at the end of October 2016. We actually booked four nights so we could stay in our room until early evening – then take a 22:00 flight to Sydney.I only have basic loyalty status with Accor Hotels and so didn’t expect any special treatment. As it was we had a decent room (although not upgraded) and enjoyed our stay in what proved to be a good location.The hotel doesn’t have a reception at ground level, you need to take the elevator one floor up. One floor below is a metro line, but that line didn’t seem to be useful for getting anywhere and we usually walked to a nearby metro station on a different line.The entrance is down the side street to the right of hotel as seen in the picture below.The reception desk were helpful and spoke English. As we’d arrived late afternoon, our room was ready.It wasn’t anything special, but it was more than we expected after reading about small rooms in Japan. We were completely spoiled by our next room in the Hilton Osaka and so I’m glad we did this first.There was a safe, tea/coffee, kettle, really small tea cups and a mini bar, although I could see a miniature Jack Daniels whisky was 1200 Yen – the local convenience store was selling half bottles of Suntory whisky for 500 Yen so better to walk around the corner and pick one up from there. That local store was open 24 hours should you need anything.The bathroom was a decent size, shower over a bath, heated mirror and a Japanese electronic toilet. The shower feed was from two separate taps and not a mixer tap or shower control, something I thought was peculiar to England, so it was difficult to get the shower at the right temperature.The towels were always smelly after use and so we were always leaving them on the floor for replacement each day.The free Wi-Fi worked well as did the room air con.Breakfast was included in our rate. The small breakfast room is on the same floor as reception. We never had a problem getting a table and the staff were friendly. There was a good selection of both Western and Japanese food, plus some weird mixtures such as scrambled eggs next to spaghetti bolognaise.One reason for choosing this hotel was the location. It was great to be able to walk around the local area, luxury shopping streets, good local restaurants and not far from the famous fish market and easy to pick up a metro and go sightseeing.Checkout was smooth and the receptionist was also able to arrange for our large suitcase to be delivered to the Hilton Osaka for the equivalent of $60 which I think was pretty good value. I think most hotels in Japan will arrange this service for you, but you must have a reservation at your destination hotel in order to send.

Came to Tokyo on business and stayed in a few places but this was the best for the price and budget my company was working within. The location is superb and easy to walk to lots of things including great restaurants and the palace. Ginzi train station isn't far and neither is Tokyo train station again great for getting about I. Tokyo. Highly recommend this hotel for that type of trip

Hotel is located in the center of the shopping district, a 10-minute walk to the Tokyo Station and buses to the Narita airport. Check-in went quickly (we were late in the evening), check out slower because there were only 3 desks and we checked out in the morning rush hours. The front desk staff very helpful and obliging, there was no problem in dealing in various issues over the phone. The metro station is under the hotel. Near the small network grocery stores. Rooms clean, but as in Japan smaller than i.e. in Europe.

Great location -close to the Ginza main street, and reasonably priced places to eat. However, as mentioned in other reviews, the rooms are small (just good for 2 adults) and the hotel is needing refurbishment. The entrance is literally the elevator lobby, and guests are expected to take their bags to a cramped reception area on the second floor (shared with the hotel restaurant) . On average, there are only 2 personnel on duty at reception, and good luck to the other hotel guests who, with the language barrier, need simple but useful information like transport maps and directions or recommendations on nearby places to eat - no one will be able to assist if there is a large party checking in or out of the hotel. There is no concierge but only a desk run by a tour operator - weekday office hours only (closed on Sundays).The only saving grace turned out to be Mercure Tokyo Ginza's NIKITA DMITRIEV, Quality and Brand Coordinator, Accor Group, who saw us hovering near the tour desk, which was closed till 11am. Our family group of 11 was needing a large van or minibus to take us to Kamakura. He took it upon himself to make phone calls to Japanese tour operators/transport services and when none became available, recommended other scenic places in Tokyo that could be reached by taxi so we would not waste the last day of our trip. Due to his helpfulness, I would not hesitate to stay at this hotel again.

So first off I want to say the location is at a great and safe spot especially if you like luxury shopping! You will find all sorts of high end luxury shops just a few blocks away. Stores such as Louis Vuitton, Chanel, Tiffany & Co, Fendi etc.The hotel itself isn't really a 4 star. I would say maybe 3 star. We stayed in room 707 and the bathroom stunk like mold. I'm allergic to mold and dust so every time I came back to the hotel my nose would get stuffy and my eyes itchy. So I wud have to take Zyrtec just so I cud sleep. The bathroom didn't have any caulking around the tub so I think that's where all the mold was building up. The walls in the room were also all scuffed up from ppls luggages. Made it look very dirty. And the chair in our room was ripped on the edges (needs to be reupholstered) They always replaced the toiletries so that's a plus! But for some reason the maid service always left something extra in my room!?! Like a rag they wud wipe down things with, or extra bedsheets they were gonna change the bed with? It was just so random and maybe they really did forget but it was every other day and we stayed for 5 days lolThe breakfast was horrible, one of the worst I've ever had in a hotel. Eggs were super soggy, honestly only thing worth having was coffee and the mini crossaints they had. Oh and the tater tots they served every other day. I will say this, and this is why I gave them a 4 instead of a 3. The hotel staff are so nice and so helpful! Especially the reception desk! The staff really make this hotel great! They were so happy to answer any question i had and even help me ship some packages of souvenirs back home to the USA! I wish they would update the hotel maybe paint the walls in the room, fix the mold smell, re do the carpets and maybe reupholster the furniture and maybe it wudnt be so bad. Breakfast, meh, I cud go out and get breakfast else where (which we did anyways cuz it sucked).

One of the worst state Accor Hotels I have ever seen. I have been in four (Superior) rooms before I could select the one with the least smell and noise. The windows do not open, ventilation is not adequate, carpets are in a poor state. Noisy aircon. Left a day earlier than planned.On the only positive side, the staff are friendly and did their best to accommodate. The public areas are in better state than the rooms. Breakfast is good. The bedding is clean and mattress comfortable as one would expect from Accor group. Excellent location!

this hotel is centrally located in what it seems downtown or financial district of tokyo, a lot of high end western stores around, around 7/8 from JR train station, rooms were ok, not small not big just ok, the TV though ws very small, maybe like 25 inches, or 27 inches max, weird they didnt have a big tv like almost every other hotel, but overall is a nice place to stay.

Was pleasantly surprised with my stay at the Mercure in the Ginza. Located in a small street just behind the main shopping street, we were also handy to a railway station and eating places are everywhere.Even McDonalds was in the the same street. Nothing fancy about the room and although it was small it was comfortable and had all that you could expect. There was a full step up into the bathroom which may affect some with walking difficulties. Breakfast was nothing special but good enough. Friendly staff.

Reception was lovely and helpful. Hotel was well centralised to walk from different directions to shops, restaurants and train stations The hotel connected to the train station, which I loved. Defiantly booking there again. Thank you

Great location. Close to department stores and shops.Department stores have great food halls which is great if solo traveller.Staff very helpful and friendly Nice French restaurant located in hotel.Rooms a good size.This in my 2nd stay and I would definitely stay again.

I traveled to Tokyo with a group of sixteen. We all stayed at the Mercure Tokyo Ginza. I thought our room was adequate for our two night stay. We all had two twin beds and that request was honored by the hotel with one email. The front desk staff was very accommodating to our group and their many requests and questions. I have to thank Elisa at the front desk who helped me print out eight vouchers for a tour. Thanks so much. The buffet was excellent. Many choices and continually stocked during the breakfast hours. We were so pleased with the excellent location in the Ginza neighborhood. So many restaurants and shops nearby.

We stayed at the mercure for 3 nights before joining a cruise. It was in a good position for shops and a few bars and also easy to get to various metro lines. You can easily walk to the fish market etc.The staff were great from the moment we walked in, helping us to find the bar i wanted. The wi fi worked well, tea, coffee and safe in the room all worked as required.Breakfast was great, just what was required to start the day !One tip, get a taxi from the station, not worth trying to find it on foot in the heat of Tokyo !

I would highly recommend The Mercure Tokyo Ginza. The location was fantastic. It is very close to the station, Seven Eleven, Lawsons, Family mart, and McDonalds. The staff are very polite and accommodating to your every need. The breakfast is lovely, and the restaurant food is to die for! I would definitely return!

The front end staff were fantastic, they were patient, helpful and genuinely interested in weary travellers. The room was small but clean, a comfortable bed/pillows and it is central to Ginza shopping areas. The restaurant is French cuisine and we had a couple of snacks, one was an onion soup to die for, it was so delicious!. The hotel is close to the subway as well. On Saturday the main shopping area is closed to traffic, chairs/tables are set up in the middle of the road and it was SO busy! High end shops competed (?) with smaller shop, eateries etc. I would recommend this hotel to anyone travelling in the Ginza area.

In the ginza area it,s in great part of the city , the room was small but neat and tiny, the dining area very neat ,the staff were excellent helpful and polite, the food was very good and the variety catered well for all people,a short walk a great shopping area subway stations..

I had an enjoyable stay at this hotel.I found it to have clean spacious rooms and the staff helpful.I went to eat at the restaurant once but was very underwhelmed by the offering so decided to eat somewhere else.For me though the outstanding feature of this hotel was its location. It is situated in a very convenient location for catching the various rail lines and exploring Ginza. It would be nice if the hotel had a more convenient way to get to the airport as I used the train and as i speak no Japanese and had a lot of luggage this wasn't as convenient as hotels which offer shuttle services.

Excellent hotel, very comfortable room, good bedding and comfortable beds. The food in Bistro was superb we chose from set price for two course meal and it was exquisite. Easy and safe area to walk by foot the shops are extremely expensive but you have all the branded names you can wish for . Delightful window shopping.

Nice hotel in a very good location with good access to trains. By train :Haneda airport to Shimbashi Station ( ask at Info Counter or train master at gantry for platform no and exact departure time to take the right train as different trains on same platform) Fare : 530Yenat Shimbashi Station change to GINZA Line (subway called Metro) and take train towards Ginza (all in english so no worries). It is only one station from Shimbashi Station. 180yen. at Ginza Station take the Exit A13 and then turn left towards an alley. it is a 5 - 7 minute walk and best print out a map or ask along the way at major shops or boutiques. all are very friendly.

We chose the Mecure Ginza as we are Accor members and received a good deal for the hotel. It is located in a a lovely area of Tokyo although all the shops are quite highend so quite expensive. The station is quite close so easy to get around and there is a really good ramen restaurant not too far away which is delicious and reasonably priced.We were too early for check-in but the paper work was processed and our bags stored so that after we had had a walk around all we had to do was get our key and go to our room. Reception staff very helpful with maps, etc.Our room was small and we were glad we had sent our suitcases on to Kyoto and not had to try and fit them in the room. While the room was clean and the bathroom spotless the walls could do with a good scrub. I could understand the wall at the foot of the bed being scuffed as there really is not enough room to get suitcases in and they had obviously been rubbed against this wall for some time, however the wall next to the bed (which is about a foot away) was quite dirty, it looked as though someone had opened a can of drink and it had sprayed on the wall with drip marks all the way down and a lot of other random marks as well, so it did feel grubby especially as you were more than likely to come in contact with the wall when getting in and out of bed.The bathroom was extremely clean with all the amenities that you would need including razor and toothbrushes. Breakfast was good, not a huge range of food but enough to get you going for the day.Would stay here again.

We had an enjoyable three night stay in this well located hotel. Easy walk to shops and train stations. Staff were friendly and helpful. Our room was clean and functional however a paint job to freshen up the walls would enhance the ambience. Breakfast was good but once again a wider selection of foods eg. Whole grain bread and fresh fruit, healthy eating food. Overall very good.

Stayed 4 nights in this hotel for business trip in Tokyo. The room is clean with 2 twin beds. Though it is quite small which most hotels in Japan are. But we stayed quite comfortably. The bed is comfortable and it is very safe to leave your things around. The hotel is located at the center of Ginza and it is very convenient to go to various part of Tokyo. The subway station, Yuracho station is a short distant from the hotel and I can get to the station via the hotel basement. There is a French restaurant on the 2nd level. The Manager of the French restaurant still remembered me and my hubby when we were there 4 years ago. Felt very happy when people remembered you.

Our group of six arrived at around 1PM and one room was available so we put all our bags in there and went off to lunch. Upon our return, we were happy to see they arranged all three rooms close together so as to make moving the bags easier. If you are walking to this hotel it is not easy to find. There is no ground floor lobby, just a doorway off the street and an elevator to reception. There is a small sign on the sidewalk but you can easily miss it. Rooms are very small, views non existent. Breakfast buffet was not included in the room rate and upon inspection, was not worth the price. So we decided to go to the Starbucks just around the corner.It was clean and convenient. It's very close to the main shopping street in the Ginza neighborhood and walking distance to Tokyo Station. If you plan to be out and about all day this hotel is more than adequate.

This hotel is located in the Ginza area - close to the subway and lots of cafes, stores. The breakfast was great - manager cocktail party on Wednesday. Room was small - OK by Tokyo standards. Expensive - if going back, would look for more reasonable hotel.

Our Company HQ is located across the street so I am always booked at this hotel for training or sales meeting visits. This is like a home away from home for me. The staff is always very friendly and accommodating. On one trip I found out my flight is delayed for more than five hours and I was already checked out. Instead of sitting it out at the airport at 1 AM up {btw Haneda airport too} I asked them if I can take a room for an extra day so I don't have to sit it out in their lobby as well. The hotel does not have an actual "lobby" and Tokyo GInza slows down and businesses close at 10 PM.... The manager accommodated me with a room and charged me at the original price of my room during my stay. I thought that was really helpful to me!

From european point of view very small rooms. Comfortable bed, big enought for 2 people. I hate once windows cannot be open. Room qiute clean, just carpet should be changed. Bathroon OK, clean. TV just in japane language :-) We have had just breakfast, you can chose european (french) style or japanes, up to you. Personal was helpfull. Very expensive in comparison with all other countires I have visited.

Gosh - how quickly a month passes by in the Ginza! This year we stayed at the Mercure Ginza for our third consecutive year and must admit that you will not find a better base for a holiday in Tokyo. We have found that our holidays here are relaxed and we feel safe wandering around the area at any time, day or night - even walking to the Tsukiji Fish Markets at 2.30am.We have easily explored our way around Tokyo from here - our best advice, buy a Suica or Pasmo Card at the station when you arrive and use the subway. You won’t need to buy tickets - pay 500 yen deposit, top it up as you go and get the deposit & balance refunded at the end of your stay. You can hop on the subway at various stations near the Mercure, we favour Ginza (exit A13) and Yurakucho Stations. If you are a train spotter, sit on platform 4 at the latter to view a constant stream of Shinkensens passing by. It is an easy walk from the hotel to Tokyo Station where you can catch a Shinkensen, for trips out of the city.A regular route for us, to and from the hotel, was via the basement of the Matsuya store next to Ginza exit A13, to pick up food - you are so spoilt for choice here. For drinks, ice creams and snacks - when you exit the hotel - there is McDonalds and a Lawsons on the first corner to the right and then a Family Mart and a Lawons Natural on the first corner to the left. Tomod’s Pharmacy is close by and is very cheap for cold drinks.The hotel is right by Chuo Dori which has all of the major shops but … make sure you walk up and down the smaller parallel back streets. You will discover wonderful restaurants, cafes and amazing bakeries as well as countless boutique stores and ‘name brand’ stores - they are all waiting for you to find them.We were pleased to re-acquaint ourselves with the wonderful staff at the Mercure Ginza, they always provide you with great customer service. There is a new manager at the hotel this year so it will be interesting to see if this will be a change for the better … look out for our post around June next year as we have already booked to stay there for another month in 2017.We are happy to answer any questions you may have about the hotel and its surrounds – we know it well.

A few minutes walk to Ginza's elegant main strip. Underground access to hotel from subway. Plenty of restaurants and convenience stores within minutes walk. Good size rooms and bathroom. There's no day spa - caters for business travellers, flight crews and tourists on the go. And it was quiet at night for sleep. Perfect base for talking this side of Tokyo.

Right on top of Ginza-Itchome station, and 1 minute walk away fro Ginza station (This has many more subway connections).Nice sized rooms, comfortable, and cleanLots of places to eat and cafe's nearby, as well as convenience and food stores.Hotel went out of their way to help me recover an item I had left in a store 2 days earlier - they recovered it for me and arranged delivery with little stress on me, thank so so much

Excellent hotel and great vantage point to get out an about in Tokyo. Located in the beautiful Ginza area the hotel is ideally situated above the subway. The rooms are great size and the hotel has a lovely restaurant. The hotel is perfect for that sigh seeing holiday.

If you like a San Francisco way of life, choose this hotel. Small room, shaby tapestry, a bathroom as little as possible, a restaurant with a restricted menu, well this is your hotel.The best aspects are: very well located and very gentle personnel.

We have absolutely no knowledge of the Japanese language.Prior to leaving Aistralia we emailed the hotel to find out what exit would be the most appropriate to transfer from the Tokyo train station to the hotel.At a ticket counter we purchases tickets for the NEX (Narita express) to Tokyo. After a journey of approximately one hour we arrived at Tokyo central. There were signs in English showing the way to the taxi stand.Before leaving home we printed a sheet in English and Japanese asking to be taken to the hotel. This was handed to the driver and it was immediately apparent he could not understand the note. Next we showed him a photo of the hotel. This was still not helpful. Thankfully we had also printed a map of where the hotel was. At last we were getting somewhere.The driver was able to get us in the general area of the hotel but could not locate it. We had him stop outside another hotel and in the pouring rain I ran across the road to it. With the help of the reception staff I was able to get directions to our hotel.It shows with careful planning and a cool head you can always get to your destiination without knowing one word of the local language.Now the hotel:-We have stayed in many hotels in the Acoor chain (we once held shares on the company) but this one is dated and the rooms could be spruced up.The bed is very comfortable and each night we have slept through the whole night.The usual amenities are all provided with the free wifi being of an acceptable speed.The buffet breakfast is adequate.

Neat and tidy with good reception etc.Great location and thats the main draw really.i popped into the restaurant for a quick bite an hour before it was due to close.the 3 course option seemed tempting and there it was - a darn good French cuisine meal served up like lightening. Tokyo always amazes and it got the place 4 stars.

It's been 8 years since my last stay. The hotel is not as clean as before though still OK for a business trip. Convenience is still the advantage as it is located in Ginza and near the Tokyo Station.Breakfast is not bad. The chocolate croissant is delicious! Room size is also comfortable though the pillows are rather uncomfortable. Reception staff are friendly and helpful. Housekeeping has room for improvement as sometimes they replenish the toiletries but at times not. The carpet needs a major clean up as its old and stained.I will probably stay here again only due to its location being near to my office.

we never expected to stay a room this size in Ginza area. we used to stay in some Japanese hotels, the room size is only for sleep. but this room is quite spacious, really beyond our expectations. the breakfast is also good, meet both western and oriental needs. the hotel is in the heart of Ginza area, walking distance to the shopping malls. good place for shopping.

This is convenient for central Tokyo - near to the main station and handy for several underground lines.The hotel is comfortable, small rooms, but perfectly acceptable. Breakfast is good - with plenty of emphasis on Mercure's french connection.

We stayed at this hotel twice, at either end of a cruise around Japan. The hotel has an excellent location for enjoying the shopping and restaurants in the Ginza area, and for getting around Tokyo.The hotel itself is adequate, with only rooms and a restaurant/bar, but for most people that's all you need. What sets this hotel apart from the rest is the staff, every one of whom we met were friendly and very helpful. As soon as we returned for our second stay, we were recognised and greeted by several members of staff, who wanted to hear about our trip. The reception staff are very happy to give tourism and sightseeing advice, and they have a stock of useful maps and brochures. If the weather is rainy, reception will loan you umbrellas.The rooms tend to be on the small side, but are well equipped. The only thing which I feel is missing is the usual retractable laundry line over the bathtub for drying underwear etc. There is a shower rail, but wet laundry hung on this will drip on to the floor.Breakfasts in the hotel are at two levels, either 'express' or buffet. The express breakfast is perfectly adequate.If we return to Tokyo, then this hotel will be my automatic choice.

Great well priced hotel in a fantastic location in the shopping heart of Tokyo - Ginza. Rooms are smallish but are clean and well serviced. Very good value. Breakfast is fairly basic but it does the job. Great restaurants nearby though for lunch and dinner. Highly recommended hotel. Staff speak English and are great providing assistance with directions and things to do.

Spent a night with 3 female adults & 3 children with lots of big bags - it was an excellent experience. We were all impressed with the comfortable and neat rooms plus excellent service. The only problem we had was with the negative attitude of the resturant manager and his impatience with us & kids during breakfast. 5 out of 5 to Nikita & most staff members and 1/5 for the Resturant manager.

I was recommended the Mercure Ginza for a short stopover in Tokyo on the way to Okinawa. Relatively easy to find and in a very upmarket area we were pleasantly surprised by the size of the room and facilities. No cramped box room, our twin bedroom was roomy and comfortable. Breakfast was sublime and the best I have had in any hotel, all with a french twist thanks to the French manager. With the metro nearby and a bus stop to the airport 5 minutes away, it was the perfect location to explore Tokyo.The only gripe was the pillow which I found too hard and uncomfortable.

I've read many review here saying that the room is "small by international standards, but big by Tokyo standard". Our room was a deluxe twin (advertised as 24m2), and I was positively surprised, as it can easily beat some European capital hotel rooms.Japanese chains (Mitsui Garden or Tobu, not to mention) will offer a much much smaller room for not always a cheaper price.This said, two things are obvious :1) "Mercure" is an unknown brand. My japanese friend even mistook with Monterey Hotel next door ...2) Location is great if you need to be in the eastern part of Tokyo. Ginza, Yurakucho, Imperial garden are all within reasonable walking distance. Many subway stations are around, and even one of them is accessible directly from the hotel elevator.The building occupies one face of a small alley parallel to Ginza avenue, and therefore, all room face the opposite building 9m away. Don't expect a romantic view ;-)On the positive side, all rooms are very calm.Exterior entrance : Pay attention, as you can easily go past thinking that the discreet double door is a backdoor. (FYI, there is no doorman.)If ever you come by car, parking fee is 2500JPY per day (25USD, one entry) which is a steal in this neighborhood, but height is limited to 1m55.Front desk : The reception is accessed by elevator, and you really wonder if this is really a hotel entrance.There are three counters, and one small sofa with tea / coffee (self service). As the area is very small, it can't support many people at the same time.There always seems to be a non-japanese staff.Room :The deluxe room is spacious enough (but perception may differ).The decoration is quite modern though there were some scars / stains on the wall. The main pieces of furniture are :> 2 beds (1m20 x 2m) for twin rooms> 2 armchairs with stool and a small table> a closet (33cm width) and a wardrobe (55cm width), which should be enough for the majority of us staying no longer than a week in Tokyo.> 25' flat TV ; rather small, but OK.> work desk along the window (1m40 x 0m50) with a desk chair ; comfortable enough to work if you don't have too many documents spread around.Bathroom :That's the disappointing point.It is clearly a japanese "unit bath" (prefab bathroom module) disguised as a proper bathroom. But some signs are unmistakable : 1) same yellow plastic used for bathtub, ceiling, floor and walls, 2) raised floor for the pipes (inside height is therefore 2m00 ...), 3) cheap thick shower curtain.The advantage is that you can splash as much as you want, because the Japanese typically shower themselves out of the tub (the tub should remain clean).Some details try to elevate the perceived quality : ceramic tiled wall, ceramic basin (but cracked), wicker basket, marble designed table ...You may have fun with the "washlet" (shower toilet). That's one of most remarkable japanese inventions which can also be found in public places.Former room occupants clearly tried to peel off the instructions as a souvenir (but didn't succeed).Amenities :> japanese pajama (improperly called "kimono" by foreigners), large persons won't fit> branded shampoo and shower gel.> toothbrush (japanese size = very small brush)> 2 small bottles of waterEquipment :hair dryer, safe, minibar, tea stuffnespresso (probably not in all rooms)Breakfast :It is taken at the french restaurant at the same level as the reception. The room is quite small, but we didn't need to wait.You have a continental offer (with some good pain au chocolat) and simple japanese offer. It's not sophisticated and the choice is limited, so don't pay extra for it if it is not included in your rate. You have many choices in the vicinity : convenience stores, fast food, coffee shops, etc.Platinum members : can get the usual free beverage coupons and a mini-bottle of champagne. As this hotel has a french origin, we were positively surprised to get real stuff from the Champagne region, and not some fake lousy bubbly. On the negative side : it's not offered proactively ; you have to ask for it.Overall :> large room compared to similar priced japanese chains> extremely conveniently located> nice staff> "cheap" bathroomWe may regret the absence of a very convenient executive lounge, as, even similarly space scarce Hong-Kong is offering it (Novotel Nathan Road).Will we come back again ? Most likely.The room itself deserves a 4 points. But, considering competitors' offer, price and location, it is definitively an excellent choice.

Travelers: Family of 3 (2.5 year old)Room Selected: Room 915 - Deluxe Queen RoomCheck-in: We requested an early check-in time in advance of our reservation, understanding it could not be guaranteed. Unfortunately, we arrived later than expected at the standard check-in time of 2:00pm. Not only was our room not available at the standard check-in time, but we had to wait an additional 45 minutes in the lobby while the staff fumbled about trying to determine how to handle it. It was not a great start to our stay.Room: Leading up to the room, the hotel's halls looked old with bunched up carpet and older wall art. Our room was average. Despite the room type, we only had a view of the outside wall of a neighboring building. Everything was clean and orderly. The room comes with a safe and small refrigerator. The TV was one of the smallest I've seen in a room at this hotel's price point, but it worked fine. We upgraded to a deluxe room to have some additional space for my son to play. I'm glad we did because I don't think the superior room, if smaller, would have been a good choice for us. The bathroom was very nice and it came with premium toiletries. Location: The hotel's location is maybe it's best characteristic. It is located with easy access from the local metro line. Ginza's main shopping street and great restaurants are just a short stroll away. There are two Lawson convenience stores and a Starbucks within 100 feet of the entrance. It is perfectly suited for soaking up all that Ginza has to offer.Hotel Food:We booked our room rate with the included breakfast from the 2F restaurant. The breakfast buffet was good with Western and Japanese selections. There was cereal, yogurt, fruit, different breads, eggs, bacon, and sausage, among other selections. I was pleased with everything we were offered. Overall:I am an Accor hotel rewards member, so I would consider this hotel again, but not without checking to see what other options exist in the area. I found our overall stay to be average when comparing with my other Tokyo hotel experiences at this price point.

typical hotel rooms in Japan are really small. Even the bathrooms. Their bathrooms are elevated, so if you're with an elderly or someone on a wheelchair-this would not be an ideal hotel for them. Before booking with this hotel, we requested for a wheelchair accessible room. And even when we checked in, the hotel staff probably noticed we had an elderly. But they did not even bother to ask or even worry about her. They should have informed our travel agency beforehand that they do not have rooms intended for persons with disability to have an easy access to the bathroom. hotel location is two blocks from the Ginza main street. Since we were a large group, we hired a private bus (wheelchair accessible) The road in front of the hotel is not accessible to big bus, so we had to walk 2 blocks just to get on our bus, which was a little inconvenient at the time of our visit because it rained. the hotel is a non-smoking hotel. prior to our final booking, we made sure that we get 1 smoking room. they should have informed our travel agent that the hotel is non-smoking room. there are lots of restaurants around the area so eating is not a problem.since we were a large group, check in took very long. it took them 40 minutes to give us our 6 rooms. i really timed it. and the guy that handled our check-in was not so pleasant. we had 1 de luxe room booked, but what he saw was all superior room. when i said we have 1 de luxe room, he just said, show me confirmation. and i did! and my travel agent even called them to confirm my said booking.

I usually stay in Accor hotels as we have Platinum Membership. We got the usual Mercure attire, along with snacks, a bottle of wine, 4 bottles of water and a premium apple juice from France.That aside, the hotel was a little bit older. I didn't like how there weren't any power plugs near the bed (I like to have my phone charging next to me so when I wake up I can see my messages without getting out of bed). Other then that the hotel was great. Typical (but older) Japanese electric toilets. Decent room size. And I was surprised to find that they change their sheets on the bed everyday (which I like). Of course if you don't want them to change the sheets, all you have to do is leave the card on the bed that says you want to "save the planet"

Central location, very friendly and helpful staff. Eat in the Restaurant and although a very limited menu we were pleasantly surprised with the good food, and using our Accor 50% off dining, it proved a bargain for us.

The location in Ginza is very good: One can reach the hotel conveniently by public transportation, and there are many beautiful shops as well as cafes around.So it is perfect for exploring the area.The breakfast: The breakfast manager made an extra-ordinary effort to accommodate my gluten-free diet. So I believe that people with allergies are in good hands at the hotel - allergies are taken seriously. It is important to inform the hotel, however, in advance about any dietary requirements.The room: This is the weaker part at the hotel. We received a room on the highes floor as we requested, so the team was responsive to our requests which was very nice. The room was however old: Carpet with unremovable stains, walls with stains, strange smell in the bath room - probably from the toilet (I am not sure if it was the cleaning agents or the fact that it was old).In addition, we ordered a superior room, but it was small and there was hardly sufficient place to conveniently pack and unpack the suitcases. The beds were convenient.

Location is great. Just a 2 minute walk to the metro. Staff is extremely attentive and helpful. I will definitely stay here again the next time I come to Tokyo. The shuttle bus to the airport was kind enough to wait a few minutes for us, even though it was an inconvenience for them. The checkout person knew we were hurrying to catch the shuttle, so she had already checked us out and handed us our receipt before we even asked. Excellent service. The only downside was the hard, firmness of the beds. However, most places I have stayed in Asia have very firm beds, so this is just a personal preference.

Small room which is expected in Japan, but old and dirty which is very disappointing (scratches on walls, stains on bathroom floor, dust on bed lamps, even hairs on bed...).Do not recommend, go somewhere else closeby if you can like the Daiwa Roynet Ginza which is brand new and clean...

Never disappointed !!! Again and again - Very good location.This is the 1st place to think where to stay in Tokyo.SO comfy to stay and travel.The office counter service are very fluent in English.GREAT !!!

Excellent and really nice crew. This hotel is well placed close to subway or to the strategic Yamanote JR line. Room is fine bigger than in a Japanese hotel. Hotel is really quiet. I really recommend it.

We stayed at this hotel for 2 days, the rooms were small. The location of this hotel was perfect. The price are average. Food okey, nice thing are they gave us banana and bread before we go somewhere after breakfast, it likes they already knew if we would to travelling somewhere that day,,small thing but sweet , thanks for the attention. And if you stay at this hotel dont forget to try kobe steak at the back of the hotel, heijouen. Perfect meet, ever!

spacious, convenient, and close to main strait Ginza.Very close to Tokyo station as well, stay there on a sunday, the ginza main strait was open for pedestrian. alot of restaurants and shopping close by
user_name:
Pui Kin Y
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed for 3 nights in twin sharing room for holidays.Hotel Room: 2x super single bed. Considered spacious in downtown Japan. Toilet comes with a decent size bathtub. Super clean and efficient check in/out team that can speak English well.Location: 5mins walk from subway that links direct to haneda airport. So much cheaper than taxi. It's also fast and convenient. About 10mins walk to JR station.Food: didn't try the hotel food since there's plenty of restaurants around. Just beside is also a 24hrs macdonalds and small supermarket.Shopping: weekends, Ginza main shopping belt have their roads closed so it's a massive pedestrian walkway. It's great. They even setup tables and chairs for the tired ones. All brands can be found there.

Hotel located on a short walk from the metro station Itchome Ginza, very easy to reach from Narita and Haneda. The location is great, staff attentive and smiling, room spacious (for Tokyo standards) and comfortable, free wifi.Various restaurants and cafes near the hotel

Good location in Ginza, very accessible by public transport. Also lots of nice shops and restaurants nearby. Staff have very good maps with places of potential interest clearly marked and good recommendations. Staff also very good and patient at giving directions or checking things for you. Room was big for Tokyo, nicely appointed. Good housekeeping, very nice toiletries. Staff happy to provide adaptors.

It is situated in Ginza, the most expensive area in Tokyo. All famous brands are around, shopping malls, coffee shops, elegant restaurants and bars. It is close to Tokyo train station from where you can take Shinkasen fast train and metro to anywhere. The hotel itself is minimal, with a small reception, small but nice italian restaurant with excellent chef and personnel (they are funny and polite). Rooms are nothing special, narrow with low ceiling, but this is the case in most hotels in this area. At least they are very clean as everything in Japan. I will go again cause it is value for money (it is the best value hotel in Ginza), it is easy to move for business and pleasant to go around in free time.

My fourth time to this hotel and it is still by far the best!Hotel is located right in the heart of Ginza main shopping street! From the Haneda airport, take the bus to Tokyo station and hotel is around 15min walk. Alternatively, you can catch a taxi to the hotel for less than Yen 1000. Just 2 min walk you are in the main shopping street with many shops and eateries. Hotel is located right above the Yuracucho line subway with direct access to the hotel. For the other 3 subway lines, it is only 5mins away from the hotel. Accessibility is just too easy for this hotel.Hotel offers super fast internet speed and no buffering. Very pleased with the speed whilst staying there. The room size is very reasonable and very comfortable for 2 adults. Like all rooms in Japan, it is not very big but it is just nice for me. The rooms are very clean and still looking very new.Hotel serves a good range of food for breakfast. Nothing excessive but just nice. With McDonalds just underneath the hotel, Starbucks across the road and Lawsons around the corner, you have plenty of choices to go for.Highly recommended to everyone!

stayed for 3 nights in a tiny twin superior room - sufficient if you only need the room to sleep. - I recommend to take bigger room if you have more than 2 people. Buffet breakfast is very average - western food and small japanese corner I would recommend getting macdonalds or starbucks around the corner from hotel. It is a cheaper and better no frills option. Location wise this hotel is very convenient - right in the heart of ginza and good for shopping - there is no bell boy to help you with your bags so you will have ro bring the bags up to reception by yourself. Subway is Ginza station and easy access to most attractions in tokyo - a good 20 mins walk to fish market. Staff are friendly and helpful and provide good directions and information to various places and shopping - they will provide maps and clear instuctions. No bottle water provided but from what staff said - tap water is drinkable. As with Ginza price it is very expensive but acceptable for the location.

Great breakfast and coffee, very close to the Metrostation and to nicest Shopping area in Tokio. For Photo freaks The big Camera is not faraway (take care of the currency) and there Are a lot of delicious restsurants. The Most Bars are Teen minutes to go but Enjoy it

In doing my research for my Tokyo holiday, I knew my first preference would have been for an Accor property, preferably above the level of an Ibis. This hotel fit the bill perfectly. We arrived shortly after 10am and only had to wait 15 minutes before getting an available room. Thankfully early check-in is one of the benefits of Accor Platinum status. Our room, 1018 was on the 10th floor overlooking the street outside. The room was very well appointed and had all the modern day amenities one would come to expect. As I received a complimentary upgrade to a deluxe room, it was quite large. We had a Nespresso coffee machine, fridge, safe, two large beds, bathtub/shower combo, heated toilet with the butt-washing feature and a wide range of toiletries. The only item missing that we had to request was an iron an ironing board. Staff at front desk can speak both Japanese and English which was welcomed. Even in the restaurant, the level of English spoken by staff was fantastic. The WiFi network worked flawlessly throughout the property and we found the Lobby network which powers the reception area and restaurant was much faster. I clocked download speeds of 30MB and upload speeds of 22MB when on floor two.Breakfast wasn't included in our room rate and we only had breakfast twice in our five day stay. It isn't particularly cheap at ¥2200 per adult. The food was very good and had a good range of Western and Japanese options available both times we went. I would highly recommend this property in the trendy Ginza area of Tokyo as a nice base for a holiday. The nearest Metro station was Ginza and the nearest JR line station was Yuracucho on the Yamanote line. Getting here from the airport was very easy and straightforward. We bought Japan Rail Passes ahead of time and exchanged them at the ticket office at Haneda when we arrived. I would admit, the wait time there was almost an hour which wasn't ideal after coming off a 12 hour flight. Nonetheless, once we got them, we were onto the Monorail to Hamasutcho and then switched to the JR Line to Yuracucho and the walked 8-10 minutes to the hotel. While it's true that the Ginza station is closer to the hotel, the JR Rail Pass is non accepted on the metro. We bought a separate 72 hour metro pass for ¥1500 at the BIC Camera store for that made sure we got our money's worth. BIC is just outside Yuracucho if you're interested in getting one. You must present your passport to get it as they are only sold to tourists. Thank you Mercure for an excellent stay in Japan and you will be at the top of my list next time I return to Tokyo. Also, thank you for the bottle of wine delivered to my room as a welcome gift. It was most certainly appreciated.

Summary of stay in June 2016 - Hotel located in the heart of Ginza, a popular shopping area with plenty of bars and restaurants - Well connected to various metro lines (all within 10 to 15 minutes walk from the hotel) which in turn is connected to the airports - Supermarket, starbucks and 24 hours Mc Donalds at less than 2 minutes walk from the hotel - Efficient check in and check out but i must add that at check out a standard 'how was your stay etc' should be asked as per international standards especially at an Accor property - Deluxe room had twin beds, safe, TV, refrigerator and water heater for tea coffee Lastly, as a silver member of Accor, this was the 3rd Accor hotel i stayed at during my trip and i must thank the Accor team for the efficiency starting with checking in online through the Smartphone App, to the welcome glass of wine, upgrade to a better room and late check out.. Such gestures are really appreciated and look forward to staying at Accor hotels again as my first choice..

A quite spacious room with excellent amenities and a very good French restaurant in the lobby. In a terrific location in Ginza. Front desk staff speak good English. Because of the French management, the restaurant is well run and one of the best croissants ever anywhere.

Stayed here 3 times and will keep coming back. The staff are beyond fantastic and try to help any way they can. The rooms are a bit small, but reasonable size for Japan. This hotel fills up fast, so be sure to book well in advance to get a great deal.It has a railway station access in the basement, or a 15min walk away from Yurakucho Station (on the JR Yamanote Line). Also close to the Tokyo Imperial Palace and Hibiya Park.

This hotel has small rooms like any other hotels in tokyo. But this hotel has a very strategic location that allow us to explore tokyo easily. Below this hotel located ginza itchome train station that can take us anywhere in tokyo. Around this hotel we can find lots of convenient store and cafes (including starbucks )We stayed in two connecting room. The room and bathroom were always cleaned. The hotel staff were so nice and so helpful from replying our e-mail when we asked for connecting room until the day we left tokyo. Thank you Mercure Giza..Me and my family really had a nice stay there..Would be back again if had a chance to visit tokyo one day

I stayed there for 2 weeks in May for work. The location of this hotel is very good, near the subway and within ten minutes from Tokyo station. Rooms are tiny but conveniently arranged, with a nice bathroom and all the amenities you can dream of. However there was an unpleasant smell in the room, and the walls (and roof) are quite thin so do bring your earplugs if you want to spend a quiet night.Housekeeping is good but in the morning, cleaning carts with clean and dirty laundry are all over the place, all along the corridors and in the elevator area, which doesn't really give a good impression. The breakfast buffet is good but really overpriced for the choice there is. As an Accor gold member, I was given a bottle of wine as a welcome back gift, which was really nice. But as I was staying for 2 weeks, they were asking to settle the bill every 4 days, even though I have stayed with Accor hotels very often and have never defaulted payment, so that was a very strange thing, and quite unpleasant to be treated like a potential thief.

The stays very comfortable and the hotel is well appointed. Great breakfast buffet and Chris Puissant was a great and made the family feel very welcome. Most of the staff offer, but make sure you ask if it is possible for items and services to be charged in your preferred currency, as it saved me some fees from my financial institutions.Fast free wifi also.

We wanted a hotel that was handy to explore Ginza and the Mercure is ideal. It is within easy walking distance of the major shopping precincts and the Kubuki Theatre.Rooms are clean and comfortable and there is a full restaurant and bar service. There is a real European style to the hotel that is friendly and welcoming. The reception staff were knowledgeable and helpful, a big plus as it is not that easy following Japanese characters for directions.We would certainly recommend the Mercure to anyone wanting a boutique hotel experience in Tokyo.

This was everything you would expect from a 4-star hotel. The rooms were large for Tokyo and the location was great -- very central, just off one of the largest high-end shopping areas in Tokyo.The rooms were cleaned very well every day with fresh towels etc. The breakfast was great and had a good range of Japanese, Western and fruits/cereals.A member of the staff, whose name I missed, really helped us out and booked a return ticket to Fuji-Q Highland theme park. I explained that the website was down and he then without hesitation called up the ticket booking line and booked everything for us telling us how to pick up the tickets and where to leave from. I was really impressed and without his help it would've been near impossible to book over the phone.5-stars an all-round great stay.

We stayed at the Mercure Tokyo Ginza primarily because I am an Accor member and was able to use my free night here. I would usually stay in a less expensive hotel but there aren't many cheaper if you want to be in this part of the city. The hotel was close to shops and subway stations and only a ten minute walk from Tokyo Station which we did easily with our suitcases. It's also only a short walk from the fish markets. The room we had was spacious by Japanese standards. The bed was comfortable and the room was nicely decorated although the fittings and furniture were a little tired and need to be updated. The wifi was free and fast and we enjoyed the buffet breakfast. There are lots of eating places close by and a Lawsons just around the corner. If you can afford it, this is a great place to stay in Tokyo.

This was the first hotel we stayed in our long awaited Japan trip and it did not disappoint. Location is great in Ginza - around 15 mins by cab from the Tokyo main train station and located straight above one of the metro stations (which we did not use, as all our excursions were pre-planned). Many restaurants and convenience stores nearby in walking distance.We expected room sizes in Japan to be small, so was quite ok with the room - it was comfortable enough. Staff are friendly and helpful (common feature we experienced across Japan) and good breakfast spread. Overall a pleasant experience to stay here.

前に一度宿泊もしたことありますが、いつも、こちらのレストランが好きでよく利用します。レストランのみの口コミを書きます。ランチはフランスパン、スープ、サラダなどおいしいです。コーヒー、紅茶もお代わり自由です。メインディッシュも注文できます。夜も行ったことあります。ディナーもおいしかったです。スタッフも外国人が多く、親切です。I like the buffet style lunch and French cuisine. The prices are reasonable. The international staff are friendly and speak Japanese as a matter of of-course. It's spacious and always relaxing. They serve nice French food.

Location - lift in hotel lobby takes you straight to exit of metro line, however this exit closed at 10pm but its only a short walk from the other exits, in addition about 5 min walk is a another metro line. close to the hotels are starbucks, grocery shops and mcdonalds - all accept foreign credit cards. loads of departments stores and designer shops nearby also - perfect location.Breakfast - wonderful breakfast - it is was it is - buffet, not table service, but good selection of breads, pastries, breads cereals and hot e.g. hash brown, eggs, waffles, sausage (chicken or pork) and beans, breakfast was on till 10 which was useful.staff - were helpful, they did seem to confuse our booking on two occasions - we booked via BA and paid in full in advance, but the hotel called us the day before departure to request we leave, as they had us due to leave a day before (this was quickly rectified) plus on checkout, despite paying in full, we were asked to pay again. luckily this was quickly rectified but i was asked to sign a receipt in case they couldnt reconcile with BA.Room - was clean, wasnt too small (we had superior room) TV wasnt free, although this may just be the films. had free safe, hairdryer. in addition, mini bar wasnt excessive when compared to japans costs.

I stayed here for 2 single nights throughout a recent business trip. I've stayed at the hotel previously, back in 2012, and I was happy to return. The hotel is nothing especially spectacular, but its a good clean and budget friendly hotel in the centre of Tokyo. The hotel itself is above a Metro stop, and the reception is on the first floor. Staff are very friendly, and check in was quite smooth. There did seem to be some confusion between single bed, twin bed and queen bed, which caught me and some others off guard - referring to rooms as single rooms or twin rooms - but I'm not so sure that means the same as it does to an American or European.In any case, the rooms are very clean, small, but given the location not unexpected. Bathrooms are clean and well stocked. I stayed in a both a normal and deluxe room, and the only visible difference was complimentary water and better bathroom accessories - neither are that big a deal. Breakfast is where this hotel lets itself down though. There is a reasonable selection, but I think its an area that could be improved. Also from a business point of view it would be better is breakfast opened at 6am, not 6.30am. I ended up taking only 10 minutes for breakfast as I had to leave for my Shinkansen at 6.40am (and unlike in the UK, the trains leave to the second!) I would definitely return if fortunate enough to be staying in Tokyo again.

Mercure from Accor did not disappoint. Although the room is not really big and they did not provide complimentary water but overall the experience still not too bad. As I was Accor member and thus I had a very fast check-in and check-out services. I was able to request for an early check-in and late check-out. The staff was friendly. The decoration of the room quite nice but there is only one thing which I am unhappy about but of no fault of the hotel.There is a train station directly at the basement of the hotel but the line of this train does not get to places of interests and thus we usually have to walk about 7 minutes to the next station yet this hotel is close to 3 subway stations which is pretty cool. Located right in the heart of Ginza, there is this atas feeling :)

- This hotel is in a good location in Ginza - right in the heart of the action. Good access to 2 x subway stations and Tokyo main station an easy 10 min walk away. 7-11 type shops 1 min walk away as is McDonalds and Starbucks (if that's your thing).- Good English spoken at reception- Excellent food at the restaurant. Very good value fixed price 2 or 3 course lunch and dinners - menu changes every day. Staff also very friendly - especially the (Russian?) guy who's name I forgot - sorry.Only disappointment - I got charged Y2200 for breakfast when I didn't have it. I checked out at 5.45 am and restaurant isn't even open then but still got charged for it. Reception point blank refused to refund it - "hotel policy" they claimed. Rather annoying but I was not getting anywhere and had to get a flight. Just be aware.

We stayed in Mercure Tokyo Zinza for four days and were very impressed by the quality of the hotel, rooms, friendliness of the staff, service, location ( close to shopping, good restaurants ( Indian) , metros etc.

Hotel was good,staff was polite. We've got upgraded room at that time,so the room was more spacious than standard room. Yet,normal (standard) room was so small. The location is quite accessible,you can reach metro station from the hotel itself. So many shopping mall and restaurant nearby.

It was a nice stay, a bit small but clean room, accomodative service & staffs. Perfect location, just in the center of Ginza. So easy to find places to eat. Mc D is just next door, on the downstairs and Lawson, just across the street. Surely will be back here again.

i had stayed for 7 night in this hotel during the 'Golden Week' (early may) and find this hotel have an excellent service..special thank to alissa who made our registration effortless.. this hotel is ib the heart of Ginza and very close to all the major subway line.. quite at night but... that is when you need a rest... roppongi,shibuya,akihabara is only 5 to 20mins trains ride fron this hotel(without changing the train).. tokyo station where you can take shinkasen and narita express is less than 1km from this hotel.. last but not least it is at heart of ginza.. 5th avenue equavalent...

In Ginza with plenty of boutiques, Malls n restaurants. Ginza metro though has quite a few exits and underground walks may cause one to be lost. Room is big for Japanese standard. We had a twin bed room n staff speaks good English.Ours was booked together with a flight package n extremely worth it. 1 week post Golden Week, the crowd was lesser n weather absolutely fabulous!

Fantastic location, easy walk to Tokyo station with some great little restaurants just down the street. Walk to the fish markets and all four major departments stores. Rooms very large and generous bathroom amenities. We found it expensive as we were right int he middle of Golden Week but so was every other hotel at that time. Staff friendly, lots of french staff about. Restaurant okay, didn't bother with buffet expensive and average but Express breakfast is good value. Other than breakfast the restaurant/bar was deserted every single day.

The room was spacious, more so than I thought! The bathroom was excellent and the 'gadgets' on the loo made the stay even more interesting! The long bench and basket under the basin the bathroom gave you so much more room. Wi fi was fast and not restricted.....a blessing. The location was superb, so close to the main area of Ginza which was a quiet and up market shopping area. There are 4 maine train stations near by....the Yamanote line being approx. 500m walk. Ginza station is 200m walk. Breakfast was good...but a little expensive for what you get. The staff were all fantastic...esp the breakfast staff, very friendly.The room was always spotless when we returned each day. One lady even picked up the paper for my husband....she'd seen him get it yesterday from a table near the lift.

Spacious and clean rooms. Efficient and friendly staff, it's worth to note that some of the staff are non-Japanese (English, French...) which can be great when travelling in Japan! You have the possibility to have either the full breakfast or the express breakfast very reasonably priced at 540 yen which is an excellent alternative. I encourage Mercure to expand its "Express Breakfast" formula to other of its hotels.

the room was big as its an international standart, the location was perfect! in the B1 floor there's a connection to subway station ginza itchome, if u're coming from tokyo station, i suggest u to take taxi coz it's very near only spend about 800-900 yen. but if u have nothing to carry feel free to use subway - ginza itcome exit 12. if ur going to ginza shopping street go to b1 and out in exit 8, there u go! there's mcd within few steps, there's also lawson and natural lawson (lots of organic food).

We stayed 3 Nights and the Mercure Ginza is a great hotel base, we had breakfast every morning and ate at the restaurant every night and the food was really good quality and the service above expectations, would recommend the Mercure to all travellers.

Surprisingly large rooms for Japan. In a fantastic area surrounded by lots of good restaurants and shopping.All staff were so friendly and helpful.A lovely French restaurant attached.Close to the station and would thoroughly recommend it and will stay there again

Stayed here many times for business. The location is very good, connected to the yurakucho line subway from the under ground and 5 mins walk to the Ginza station. It is also just 10mins taxi ride from the Tokyo station. So if you are looking for a reasonable business hotel around Tokyo station, this is a good place to stay. There are a few Convenience stores within 1 min walk. The room is very modern, stylish and comfortable. And the hotel service is good. The only catch would be the reception and restaurant. They are located 2nd floor and nothing fancy at all. Hence, it is great for business as you are always out and do not go to the reception and hotel restaurant, but it might be a bit boring for holiday makers.

This is a good hotel if you wish to visit the fish market and other Tokyo attractions. Staff were very helpful and the restaurant was good. Rooms are small but this is typical in a country where land is scarce.

The hotel is located very close to main Ginza shopping street, about 2-3 min walk. However, it has a very small entrance facade with virtually non-existence sign that you would expect of a hotel. The entrance is smaller than a shop front with a miniature signboard that is only 1-foot square mounted on the side. You have to take the lift to level 2 where the lobby is located. The room is small but normal in Japan. We were given a room at the end of the property and wifi connection was non-working 90% of the time--we gave up. You can go to the lobby or restaurant where you can get a proper wifi connection. The bistro (only restaurant in the hotel) serves excellent French cuisine at very affordable price. A 2-course set lunch was JPY1800 with good portion and excellent standard comparable to a good French restaurant. Service was very good too.

I visited Japan again this year for leisure, and this time I stayed in Mercure Ginza twice. First is for 2-nights, and then the next is another 2-nights after I visited another city in Japan. Both stay have 4-days apart between them, and I experience different stay. For 1st stay, I arrived in the rainy days, wet at around 11AM. The room is not ready but the reception say our reservation is OK and I can come back at 2PM. I came back at 4PM and the shift have changed and the check-in procedure repeat from the beginning. However, it does not matter since they said they upgraded my room. I notice the room layout is strange (room number x17, forget the floor). The door is from the side and it has alley before reaching the room. The room is not spacious but adequate for Japan size. For the 2nd stay, I arrived at 4PM and the room is ready directly. The difference with the 1st stay is I get ordinary room layout, but I dont get mineral water and welcome drink coupon. I called reception and they just said the tap water is drinkable. I dont ask why I get mineral water in the previous stay, probably because the room is upgraded. In previous stay, the room is equipped with nespresso coffee machine, and this room is not. Another difference is on the bathroom. In the latter stay, we need to mix hot and cold water manually to get warm water, while in the 1st stay, there is rotary valve to determine temperature. In conclusion, we are lucky to get upgraded in the 1st stay although paying the same rates.Despite the differences, both stays are OK. The hotels provide good location. When we use JR-Pass, the JR Yurakucho station in JR line is near. When we use metro pass, nearest subway station is also convenient. Dragging luggage to Tokyo station is also possible when we use Shinkansen. In-room wifi internet is available free for Accor member and the speed is sufficient.

I must say that the mercure I have stayed in before were not as good as this one.Good size room, especially for Japan, safe in the room (not a mercure standard), staff helpful and friendly. One little negative point, dusty (bed side tables, lights in the bathroom...full of dust). Housekeeping can be improved but is anyway correct. One thing I don't understand is the towel policy.Like in every accor hotel, there is this "your towel plants a tree" board. I hanged my towels every morning so they won't get changed... They were changed anyway...quite common in Japan apparently. But all in all, excellent hotel, extremely well located !

The hotel was easy to find by taxi. And the location is very convenient with a MC Donalds and Grocery Store nearby. We always walk to metro ginza is on foot just about10 minutes away. The rooms and bathrooms are very clean and have everything you need for a great stay.The breakfast was delicious with a good selection . Check in was quick and easy and the staff friendly and nice . I can recommend this hotel for a nice stay in Tokyo.

We stayed here for 4 nights to end our two week stay in Japan. The situation of the hotel is in easy walk to the train station for use of the Japan rail pass as well as the metro. Easy walking distance to fish markets as well as as fabulous shopping. What impressed us most was the reasonably priced and outstanding food at the French bistro on the second floor. We will definitely stay here again .

We were a little surprised at where the hotel was when we first arrived but it turned out to be a great spot.
