The attitude of the reception and service personel is pretty disturbing. One late morning, before going out, we had some questions to ask, so we went to the reception. There were 5~6 people behind the small reception counter chatting happily. When we entered the area, no one greeted us,but instead the chatting kept on and we were havily stared. We felt like we were disturbing a little meeting or something and they acted like we were disturbing.2. This morning, we couldn't connect to Wi-Fi. My partner called up to the reception, but the girl who took the phone didn't understand a thing (or seem). She called us back a minute later said "You mean you can't get into the hotel?" Hello! she can see who's calling and besides, she was calling to the room!! 3. At the breakfast restaurant, the waiter were greeting people with a very loud voice, soundedlike a screaming match! Such a rude way in the early morning. Also, the place was a total chaos, servers were hectic, food buffet was a complete joke, a disaster for the tongue. When you go there notice the best times for a relaxed breakfast in the tiny restaurant, somewhere between 7 and 8 o' clock. Nothing really to eat and they are chugging 2200 yen per person for...nothing. French cuisine? Lough out loud! Bed, too soft. Bathroom, somewhat small. Shower toilet, older cheaper model and not well functioning.Again, this is a Mercure, lower middle class hotel in Europe. Don't be fooled by the game they play and: you are being treated as a foreigner not as guest!

I stayed here for a business trip and loved the location , very close to trains , easy walk to Ginza and all the restaurants and shopping . Restaurant a bit pricey and slow at breakfast , but Starbucks is around the corner and MacDonalds next door if you want to grab a quick bite in the AM. There is also a fabulous little Tempura place just around the corner. The rooms are a little small but well setup and very clean! The front desk staff was very helpful with directions to various places and information on taking the trains. Would come back here any time.
Hotel inside GinzaMultiple metro station at 5 minutess walking (metro and JR line)Breakfast ok5 stars Cleanliness5 stars servicesStarbuck at 2 minutesPerfect location for high end shopping in tokyo

We very much enjoyed our stay at Mercure Ginza. It was very easy to find our way from there and explore Tokyo, either on foot (gentle early morning walk to the fab fish market), on the metro, overland from Tokyo main station or monorail - all within easy reach. The hotel staff were extremely friendly and helpful, the rooms were great (interconnecting rooms so great for families) and the kids loved the buffet breakfast. And for 'quick and easy' dinners when the kids were shattered at the end of a busy day, the mini-mart at the end of the street, or department store basement food courts around the corner, made keeping them happy very easy.As a way of finding our feet on our first visit to Japan, this was perfect. We'd definetly stay here again!

The room had everything i needed. I love the furnishings and the Japanese design. The toilet is so advanced that you might want one in your own home. The bed had top quality fabric and pillows. I found it too hard for my liking but it seems to be an asian thing to have hard beds. The room was super functional for a single business traveller such as myself. The desk worked well for me and functioned far better than average for a hotel room workspace. The electrical plugs were all in the right spot.The wifi was top quality but that was to be expected in Japan.I did not eat in the hotel restaurant. There were just far too many dining choices for me all around the hotel location.This was a quick visit and I feel i barely scratched the surface of Tokyo thereby I do not feel qualified to make any recommendations with respect to accommodation. I can say this hotel fit the bill with respect to comfort and quality of hotel room.

It was one of my last stays in Tokyo. The staff was perfect as we came in the morning and we could check-in wright away ! The room was huge with a nice touch of decoration ! I really enjoyed staying at this Mercure, which is a peacefull hotel ... so confortable ! I know this hotel chain as it is French and well known in France. The hotel is well situated in Ginza with a lot of stations, restaurants and coffee shops near by.

We are staying here until tomorrow and have really enjoyed our stay. Although the room is small, there is still room to move. The Reception Staff have been very helpful and the Restaurant Staff have been great. This hotel is in a great spot in Ginza and easy access to Metro.

We had 6 nights in this hotel and used it as a base for Tokyo sight seeing. We had a deluxe room because we needed an extra bed for my daughter, breakfast was in the price, but is 2200 Yen if paid separately, bit expensive for what you got in my opinion.Location is excellent, a metro stop is attached to the hotel, with other stops within 5 minutes walking. Loads of places to eat nearby. Loads of shopping, Ginza is a bit upmarket, so its a nice and safe area to walk around.WIFI is free in the room and lobby and was always a strong signal. Staff were excellent and the room was always spotless. No issues at all.The hotel is 20 minutes from Tokyo station if you fancy a walk.I would stay here again, though I'm sure you could get better value else where in the city.Tip - buy a 3 day metro pass from the airport, once in Tokyo, you can only get 1 day passes.

We stayed five nights at the Mercure, while we visited Tokyo. The main attraction of the hotel has to be its location, which is right at the heart of Ginza and not far from Tokyo station so commuting to and from airport and other cities is a breeze. Room was of a decent size. Only hiccup: when I booked via Expedia, the booked room showed a twin bed room, despite having specified that there would be an adult and two children. No side bed could be fitted in the room and upgrading incurred a not negligeable additional cost. So we had to make do and fit all three in 2 beds... But apart from that, all facilities provided. One tip - dont have breakfast at the hotel unless you want to pay a lot and have to queue... There are many great coffee shops 2 minutes away from the hotel.

I stayed in Mercure Tokyo Ginza for 5 nights during my stay in Tokyo. The hotel is well located...within walking distance to 4 stations so easy to go anywhere in Tokyo. Staffs are helpfull and speak good English. Nothing less than what you would expect in any Accor hotels. The room was small if you compare to other Accor hotels in other countries but considering this is downtown Tokyo you can say that the room is big enough and cosy with good facilities... I came past midnight around 1.30 am due to late flight and they had my room ready for me without any problem at all. If I ever go back to Tokyo definitely I will stay here again.

Spacious rooms and friendly staff. Great location, 1 min walk from ginza with all the department stores. You can access directly to the metro from the hotel.The greatest surprise was the super big rooms - which is quite uncommon in Japan!

I may be biased , but Japan is definitely a quite unique place where level of service has reached a very very high position. And Japanese are always smiling , being overly courteous, and very helpful . We can learn a lot from them truly . I am stunned by how everything is so clean. So spotless, and I truly felt in love with their bathroom and toilet seats that plays music, are heated, and clean you with hot water as well :) .  Will come back

After a long flight from Europe the Mercure Ginza gave a friendly and quick check in.The service was first rate.In and out of Tokyo on business for a few days only I found the location convenient. 1 min walk to the underground! Importantly for business not expensive.Don't expect the trimmings it's a practical, clean, good value establishment with great service!

Mercure Ginza is ideally located in Ginza area (the Champs Elysees of Tokyo) at 200 meters from the Metro station.The rooms are pretty small but this is something common in Japan.Breakfast is made "French Style" with croissants and other french delicassy.

The hotel is extremely small and I booked it expecting the good quality that most accor hotels are. The staff at reception were lovely and they kindly gave us a bottle of wine as a honeymoon gift. However when we got to our room we were extremely disappointed. The room was so small there wasn't enough space to put our case down we had to move a chair and stack furniture. The bed was comfy but the hotel was so tired with marks all over the walls and huge stains on the carpet. The room also smelled rather stale. The bathroom was also small but clean. We cut our stay short and moved to a nicer hotel. Location is good handy located but I wouldn't rat this hotel any higher than 3 star at a stretch.

Working in Tokyo in June (yep rain season). Hotel is in good location for everything.Reception staff very welcoming and spoke excellent English which helped on arrival.Numerous metro stations few minutes walk away and main Ginza high street.Breakfast quite expensive but was ok - buffet style.Wifi worked well in room, note rooms are not very big but were fine.Handy 24hr Ronald Mc D next door if desparate need of a bite.

Had a nice stay here other than being awakened by tremors from an earthquake in the middle of the night. Excellent location within walking distance of so much....a few blocks from the Kabuki Theater. About a 15 min walk to the famous fish market. So many places to eat or grab a drink within a short walk.....and a short taxi ride away from everything else.....staff was great and very helpful with any question whether it be sightseeing or getting to the airport. Had breakfast included in room rate which was very nice also every morning. Would happily stay here again

Excellent option, well located near several metro stations, lots of restaurants nearby and food walking attractionsRoom was big, bathroom with amenities and breakfast good and moreover the service was really excellent – No five stars hotel would do better.Price moderate for Tokyo so I really recommend it

I have stayed several times at the Mercure Ginza and have always had a pleasant stay. The staff are very professional and helpful (Javier recommended the best transportation to Narita Airport, for example). The hotel is so convenient for a tourist wanting to visit Tsukiji Fish Market and all the shops and restaurants of Ginza. It is an excellent value for such a prime location!

This hotel is in a great location for both business and shopping. However I stayed recently and it was the little things that made me mad. First of all when I arrived they did not have my room ready - this was at 4:30pm. Secondly I requested a an ironing board to press my shirt for the next day, I was told yes. About 2 hours later I went to reception and was told we don't have any. This happend two day! I had read reviews about the wifi and they are correct, I struggled to connect any device - and each time it disconnected I was asked for the password. Real pain in the you know what. Lastly the room was just not clean, it had hairs in the bath and sinc. Next time I think I will go else

The main reason why I chose this hotel to stay in Tokyo is because of it's location. And it is proven that indeed this hotel is located right at the heart of Ginza. Arriving at the hotel I was actually a bit confused that the entrance is indeed small. You would've missed the entrance if you do not really look for it. I was slightly worried about the room when I stepped in. But it was all compensated with the friendly and efficient staffs that speak a good English. The room is standard (well it's Japan) but it is clean nevertheless. Bed is a bit hard but the pillows are comfortable. As of location? A minute walk to 24 hours Mc'Donald. 10 minutes walk to Ginza (where all major brands are located). 10 minutes walk to Yurakucho. The hotel is situated on top of a Metro, Ginza Itchome (serving Yurakucho line). Access to Metro is on Basement 1. Exit number 11 but it is open from 7am until 10 pm only. Otherwise take exit number 9 and walk about 5 minutes. The hotel provides a shuttle bus to Tokyo Haneda airport that cost Y 900/person. But if you wish to take a train you can take a direct line from Higashi Ginza (8 minutes walk) with Keikyu Line direct to Tokyo Haneda.

This centrally located business hotel is efficient and reasonable, located within walking distance to the Tokyo station, Ginza shopping area and imperial palace. More of a business hotel but acceptable for families, though rooms are small-medium sized. Rooms are clean, staff is pleasant and breakfast is acceptable.

The Mercure is a tiny hotel on a quiet lane in the middle of Tokyo's most expensive shopping district. Since I used British Air miles to pay for our rooms, I'm not sure how much it would have been and can't make a value call except to say that I assume the rooms are inexpensive based on their size and average quality. The staff speaks excellent English and are just lovely - Javier was wonderful. Breakfast was great and to us, a bargain at about $22 with both Japanese and Western buffet options. Although the rooms are tiny they're comfortable and importantly, very quiet so we slept well here. Right down the road are a number of charming little restaurants including a vending machine ramen place with amazing cold soba, and a bar that served fried rice pancakes topped with uni - sea urchin. My mother and I got excellent haircuts at the Fragrance salon down the street - incredibly cheap at 4200 yen. We were within very short walking distance of several department stores with the most incredible food halls in the world, and every high end boutique in existence. Don't drink and shop!
user_name:
AJLarkin
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Very warm welcome at check-in though perhaps too much focus on trying to get me enrolled in their loyalty scheme. Room was ok the tenth floor. No real view except of the building opposite. Walls are marked/scuffed quite badly and need painting. Very squashed even for Tokyo and almost claustrophobic at times. Sweet bathroom with decent shower. Nice traditional style sliding door. Very accommodating with our unusual tea requests. Good location about fifteen minutes from Tokyo main station. Acceptable. Not worth the price. Cheaper and better places available (see Hotel Niwa review)

This hotel is wonderfully situated to the Ginza shopping and entertainment area, it's locality to the rail network is perfect.All the staff but one could not do enough to assist, their greetings each morning at breakfast was heart felt and their offer to assist with any inquiry was very genuine.Sadly after a long day out at DisneySea we were met by the flashing light on the phone in the room, after speaking to someone who I believed may have been a shift manager telling us to do the hotel a favour and come down and settle the bill as he believed after 5 days the account was too large.I did go down and told the charming young Japanese gentleman at the desk that I was highly embarrassed by the manager with the French accent attitude and that I found his persona was both arrogant and abusive suggesting that I couldn't pay my bill.Also I mention all the Japanese staff at reception were deeply embarrassed by the event, when I suggested that like most hotels place a credit hold on the quoted tariff on check-in he started stating company policy, working in tourism industry for 28 years I know all about company policy garbage and that I have never been so offended so I promptly went back to the room and book a alternate hotel and checked out first thing in the morning.All the reception and restaurant staff on duty that morning when we were leaving were sincerely apologetic about the highly embarrassing situation and ask us to return next time we are in Tokyo, sadly I not total confident that I could ever go back and I will make sure the different organisation that I am currently involved with are made aware of the occurrence.What really upset me was the fact the hotel accepted my 7 day booking and they had access to 2 of my credit cards so why there was any suggestion that I couldn't pay, I have used the Mercure Chain of hotels for both Business and Pleasure in the past and never have been so insulted by a suggestion that I could not pay my account.I have put in complaints with both the Accor and Mercure organisations but as this was a family holiday I don't expect any responses that are adequate enough to rectify the damage one gentlemen with a French accent has caused.

Great location next to Ginza shopping district and metro stops. The rooms were good, and the breakfast was great. The wifi did not work during my entire stay, which was inconvenient; hence the 4 star. Good, not great.

Standard neatfully japanease service.Great location.Place very near to the first Starbucks cafe in Japan.Walking distance to the center of downtown.Very convinience to move around Tokyo.A five star lunch at very famous Kyobei Sushi in just 2 Kilometers on foot.The service, clean, and safety of hotel are touching the world wide japanese impressed style of warmingful service.Sleep tight when rest your life here.Piyawong Setthawong M.D., Ph.D.

Roughly 30-35 minutes by taxi from Haneda Airport to the hotel. There is a metro station right beneath/next to the hotel. Highly accessible hotel. Reason of staying here was to get to the Tsukiji fish market (one subway train away which operates from 5am). Then a short 3-5 minute walk. Concierge has a special map for all directions to nearby destinations. Nearby Lawson, family mart if you need a quick breakfast, water and basic supplies. 24-hour McDonalds just a few steps away. Shopping district is 2 blocks away (5 minutes walk)Check in was smooth. Staff fluent in English and they even hire non Japanese staff to help with directions. Rooms are clean and spacious for Japanese standards. Comfortable bed, room comes with safe, tv (Good range of channels and also pay TV), coffee making facilities. However, no ironing boards/iron in room (I did not request either). Service is typical of most Japanese hotels, excellent and makes every effort to satisfy the customer. Up to par for a mercure, will visit again.

Overall, this hotel is perfect. This hotel has a very good service, for instance, the front desk officers are friendly and the restaurant staffs are kind. All of the staffs are very helpful thus it makes guests like us feel comfortable to stay in. The room is comfortable and surrounded by wifi service.Furthermore, the breakfast is complete because it's provide general food especially Japan food itself. Although the variety is not many and the foods are quite simple, all the food can be eaten by tourists and it is delicious. The hotel location also support tourists accessibility because it is located above the subway station (Ginza Itchome Exit 11). However, this exit door is close by 10 pm. Thus, if you go back to the hotel above 10 pm, you won't be able to use this exit door and you should walk to the hotel by road, which is quite confusing for tourists.This hotel is highly recommended for tourists.

Nice small hotel a few minutes from main Ginza shopping area. Need to take elevator to 2nd floor to check-in. Reception staff speak English and are all politely friendly. There is a small grocery just down the street (take a right from hotel entrance passing the 24hr McDonald’s). Starbucks around the corner for those coffee addicts. It has a working air-con, mini frig and safe. Loved that they offered L’Occitane as their bath products. What made our experience exceptional with this hotel was that they were so responsive to my pre-booking email inquiries. One that stood out - as this was our first visit to Tokyo, I had asked for directions from Tokyo station to the hotel. They suggested taking a taxi (cost ¥700 and took 10 minutes) and advised that because many taxi drivers don’t speak English to give the driver the directional map that they emailed me that was in Japanese (also included their address and telephone number in English for my benefit). Sure enough using the map resulted in a quick, hassle-free trip from Tokyo station to the hotel. When in Tokyo again the Mercure Ginza will be our hotel choice.

Good location. Staff very helpful. Able to walk to fish market, palace, shopping and restaurants. Rooms small but comfortable. Subway station next to hotel. Price reasonable. Close to Tokyo station by cab and bus or train to Narita airport.

Enjoyed the stay here. Superior twin was decent size but no view due to narrow streets in Ginza.suggest asking for higher floor and non smoking floor if street noise (minimal anyhow) or smoke bother you. Nice breakfast spread but if they offer you per booking breakfast note it's only cheaper at check in time else full price applies. Was pleased that Mercure Ginza was just 10mins walk from Tokyo JR station and the Ginza Sukibiyashi Airport Express bus stop plus very close to Chuo Dori and the wealth of upmarket shopping there.After initially having difficulty locating this hotel, I thought I should mention its above Ginza Itchome metro station exit 11, just one block from McDonalds and Starbucks.Nearby Tofuro restaurant was a good find too.

Stayed 2 nights with family n kids there and we were really impressed by their staff's great services. Really try their very best to assist you in any queries with patience and a smile always.I've stayed in many hotels around the world and I can say even some staff in some 5star hotels do not provide that kind of genuine friendly services with a smile.

Tokyo visitors have a number of locations to choose from. Fortunately, most areas have easy access to the excellent (albeit potentially confusing) subway system. Thus, don't be deterred by a Ginza hotel unless you're looking for local night life - Shibuya or Shinjuku offer much more at night. The Ginza is a high end shopping area that some might find slightly sterile. However, walks along the side streets will lead you to some excellent and affordable restaurants.I was very pleased with the hotel - it was clean, quiet, and the staff excellent. I was even more impressed by the price given that Tokyo is among the most expensive cities and I paid less than I would for a mid-tier hotel in most major US cities.The hotel has a small reception area along with a breakfast area (too pricey for me at around $17 US) and a french restaurant that I assume is a homage to the hotel chain's roots.The rooms are small but not uncomfortably so. The bathroom was more than adequate. I especially enjoyed the shower which had incredible water pressure and a toilet fitted with a "shower," bidet and heated seat. For most of your electronics, you won't need a converter (Western plugs and a 100w current works for most laptops, phone chargers, etc.)I believe no room has a king size bed but check first - I could be wrong. The Mercure Ginza is located near the Yurakucho subway line; however, you more likely walk five minutes to access either the Hibaya or Ginza lines which provide easier access to popular districts and attractions. There are several convenience stores (think 7/11), fast food restaurants (including the very close and highly popular McDonald's plus good beef bowel, sushi, and tempura restaurants) and chain coffee shops near the hotel. The reception staff will provide maps and directions.If you're coming from the Narita airport, I found the easiest way of getting to the hotel is to take the express train (you'll find the counter to buy tickets just outside of customs) to Tokyo station and from there, grab a taxi for the short ride to the hotel. Since many taxi drivers do not read or speak English, you may want to bring the hotel name and address in Japanese.

The hotel is good but the room was to small, so if you expect the regular size, review that first and expect to pay much more because japan is very expensive. The hotel is very near (7 minutes by taxi) from the Tokyo City Air Terminal (known as T-CAT), an excelent way get from the aiport to the city by bus. The hotel is also close (5 minutes by taxi) to Tokyo Station in case you want to take the train from the airport.The staff is very friendly.

Like many things in Tokyo this hotel is compact. It was however clean, comfortable and close to public transport. Staff were helpful and overall the stay was excellent. The area is clean and safe and thankfully clear of Pachinko parlours. The Ginza shopping strip is only a few blocks away

Overall we had an average stay at Mercure Tokyo Ginza.Location was great, breakfast was good and service was good except on arrival. We arrived late at night and did not find the gentleman that checked us in to be very friendly or welcoming. He was not rude but just not pleasant.I am a Platinum member for Accor Le Club's and also an Advantage Plus member, I provided the membership cards on arrival. I did not get any recognition which I found was very disappointing and no benefits for being their highest level membership. All the receptionist did was photocopy the Accor platinum card which I did not understand.We just left the Ibis at Seoul, South Korea and they were overwhelmed on our arrival, they provided complimentary welcome drink vouchers, advised breakfast discounts at the restaurant for A plus members, and provided a very early check in and waived the fee as we were Platinum members. Our main issue was the bad smell in the room. When we entered the room it was just not a good smell it smelt like something died in the room, It was late at night and we wanted to sleep so I did not mention to front desk. We turned on the air conditioner to make the smell go away but it did not disappear. Everyday we had this pungent smell in the room we ended up buying some febreeze to deodorize the room.

We very much enjoyed staying at the Mecure Ginza. The staff were fantastic and their English was also great so easy to communicate.The room was small but expected when staying in Tokyo, great location and very close to a subway, McDonald's and Starbucks!!! They had a wide selection for breakfast including English favourites of toast, tea and cereal! Along with the Japanese rice dishes, and fruit selection.Would recommend this hotel for convenient access around Tokyo!

We stayed at the Mercure for a few nights after arriving in Tokyo. Perfect place to recover from jetlag. A block from shopping in Ginza, walk to the famous fish market and to several Metro stations, short taxi ride from Tokyo station, lots of restaurants and convenience stores in the neighborhood. The rooms have everything you need, but as you would expect in Japan they are really small. Javier at the front desk will help you with recommendations for dinner, sightseeing etc in perfect English or in Spanish. We were treated as friends rather than paying hotel guests and felt truly welcomed. Breakfast is expensive, but do splurge at least one day and enjoy both Asian as well as amazing croissants as well as other French treats.We plan to stay here on our next trip to Japan.
user_name:
Therese S
Chapel Hill, North Carolina

review_body: Location within walking distance to the train station and close to the pedestrian shopping street make this a good choice for a Ginza hotel, but the rooms are really tiny. So what, you aren't in your room much, right? Yeah, but it makes getting around another person in the room a really tight squeeze. The bathroom is nice with a Japanese type sliding door, but the step up/down for the bathroom can be awkward, especially in the night when you forget it is there in the dark.For my money, I would look elsewhere the next time, but if I can't find a better deal, yes I would stay here again. Hey, the place is still standing after we woken up by an early morning earthquake during our stay there.

Excellent quality for a medium priced hotel. Thanks to my fidelity card I got an upgrade to a deluxe queen room and that was spacious and had everything you need for your stay. Very good location for shopping and several metro stations to go anywhere in Tokyo quickly. Taxi from Tokyo station only takes about ten minutes. Very nice breakfast buffet and even though I normally wouldn't dine in a hotel, I had a surprisingly nice dinner there one night. The area is full of excellent restaurants but sometimes after a long day of sightseeing and shopping you need the easy and quick alternative and this place fits the bill. Service (as often in Tokyo) is outstanding. Everyone speaks good English and is very super friendly and professional. The reception manager (?) Javier especially makes the hotel feel like 5 star palace hotel. I don't think I've ever had such great service in a hotel. Will definitely stay here again.

Air conditioning didn't work, room small, couldn't put bag anywhere, so had to put it on the bed to take stuff out, then close and put against wall. Two people couldn't walk past the end of the beds. The hotel was very close to the shopping district which was a plus, but not enough for me to consider staying there again. Also it is about a 15 minute walk to the hotel from Tokyo train station, but there are three metro stations close by. If you are trying to find somewhere to eat western food, outside Tokyo train station take the underground walkway under the road and look for Bubby's Restaraunt, it was a life saver!

This Mercure hotel is surprisingly good for a medium price chain. The hotel offered very good value for money and was clean and tidy. The location is a major plus for the hotel with the main shopping area of Ginza with 5minutes walk and the main railway station 10minutes.
user_location: North York Moors National Park, United Kingdom
user_name:
Gran_G
North York Moors National Park, United Kingdom

review_body: The hotel was very comfortable and surprisingly roomy (for an Asian hotel). We had a Deluxe Twin room and they were very comfortable beds, good pillows, nice sized bathroom with a bath and a good shower (over the bath), a desk, comfy chairs with foot stools, a fridge and tea/coffee making facilities.Finding the door to Reception is tricky as it is on the first floor (Floor 2 in Japanese or American terms). The entrance to the street is marked with an awning which is easy enough to find but when you enter that there is nothing but a lift and stairs. Take the lift to Floor 2 and you will find Reception and the Restaurant.The location is good, just around the corner to the (expensive) shops of Ginza with their neon lights but only a short walk (or a subway ride) to other areas such as the Yurakucho station area where there are much cheaper shops and local food stalls. The hotel is above the Ginza-itchome subway station so if it is raining you don't even have to go outside, however it is only a short walk to the A13 exit of the Giza subway station which is on a more convenient train line as it will take you to Tokyo station or Shinjuku station without having to change trains. The subway is very easy to use and we used it all the time to explore the city and beyond.For getting little things or snacks there is a McDonalds right near the door and a Starbucks and a Family Mart around the corner. The hotel restaurant is very nice (French) and serves a good breakfast (though surprisingly they couldn't make a decent omelet). It's a little pricey for dinner but serves beautiful food. If you like Yakitori just walk to the local Yakitori stalls under the rail lines near the Yurakucho station (you can also just walk down into the Ginzo station and come back up via the C1 exit and you're nearly there). Beautiful local food at food stall prices.All-in-all a good hotel and the staff were great.

Our group of five adults stayed three nights in late February 2014 before heading skiing in Hokkaido. The location was great, the rooms were very clean and surprisingly spacious, there was a great variety of food at breakfast, and the staff were very professional. A special mention has to be made of Xavier, your English was excellent, you enthusiasm was like none other, and we felt like you couldn't do enough for us. Thank you so much Xavier! We will definitely remember you and the Mercure Ginza.There are a variety of restaurants within walking distance, the subway is underneath the hotel, and the shopping strip of Ginza is just around the corner. A great place to stay for shopping and sightseeing. Thank you for looking after us, we had a great time. We will definitely return.

This is a great hotel to see and experience Ginza. As a family of 4 with 2 small children the double twin room was plenty big for us. The beds we're comfy and the room was very clean. The hotels location is great as there is a train station just beneath the hotel and plenty of restaurants to include a McDonald's that's 24 hours or fine dinning as we'll. your a five minute walk from the heart of Ginza with all the high end shopping, kabuki theater and fish market. The price was very good compared to some of the other hotels we looked at in this area. Overall had a great stay and the staff was excellent!

I stayed here for 2 nights. The location was perfect. The staff were warm and professional. The rooms were large and spacious. And the included breakfast was pretty good. I would definitely stay here again.

Mercure Ginza is located approx. 25mins by taxi from Haneda downtown airport. From Narita, it would be about 1.5hrsI stayed at this wonderful property for 5 nights in May and let me state formally my thanks to the hotel general mgr, Mr. Kamel-san and his team. Firstly, due to a convention in TYO, many hotels were fully booked, Mercure itself were quite full, but upon writing to Kamel, he and his reservation team did their best to get me 2 rooms for my colleague and I. As a platinum member, I was allocated a deluxe room which by Japanese standards, it was spacious and very practical. In fact, I think it is larger by most Japanese standards. Room was clean and internet speed was fast. LCD TV was a bit small but manageable, most of the channels are in Japanese anyway. Lack of international channels like Fox or Star Movies but no issues for me as I spend most of my time away from the room.Breakfast was excellent with a mix of both Continental and Japanese fare, it was delicious and good way to start your day. Location wise, it is very accessible, 7min walk to JR Yamanote loop line and smack in the middle of Ginza shopping belt. Nearby are many small restaurants and noodles bars etc. Convenience marts like Lawson are also within walking distance.Overall a great stay and because of Kamel-san and his team, I will definitely come back to experience their great service!

It was a very pleasant stay in Japan for my recent trip at the Mercure Hotel in Ginza. it's only two blocks away from the elite shopping area of Ginza and few blocks away from the famous Japan Fish Market Tsukiji. If this is going to be your first trip to Japan, stay at this hotel and you will be happy. There's basement access to the subway from the hotel too. What else would you like from a hotel?

Very familiar and European feeling. Small-ish size rooms, good multi lingual staff.Breakfast was buffet style and excellent, the location to Ginza district and shopping was great, access to JR lines etc.Good value for money , would stay again.

A stroll to the Ginza, this hotel is as one expects of Mercure Hotels world wide. Excellent, friendly and helpful staff, multilingual too! Rooms comfortable, no outside noise to be heard, minibar, safe etc. Restaurant for breakfast, either continental or buffet. Bar available, and lunch and dinner. Recommend!

We arrived on an early morning flight and our room wasn't ready so we had to pay 3000 JYen to access another room, which I suppose, is average in any hotel! Our first impression was that the room was small and needed a bit of refurbishment but on speaking to other people from various locations around the world, we discovered the rooms in the Mercure are actually quite big compared to average Tokyo standards. However, the reception staff spoke good English and were extremely helpful, particularly Javier who couldn't do enough to help with any questions. We had free wifi in our room, a very comfortable bed, very clean bathroom with toiletries and free coffee/tea making facilities!We ate in the restaurant for breakfast on one occasion, one buffet lunch and two evening meals and found the food was very good and varied! There are also many cafes, restaurants, convenient stores etc near the hotel so its a great area for whatever you require. We stayed at the Mercure Ginza for 6 nights - it's very close to many subway stations, one of them we could access from under the hotel - there are also very many other places nearby and within easy walking distance! We would recommend a stay at the Mercure Ginza - great central hotel with easy access to every part of Tokyo should you have the time to visit them all!!

Located at the centre of Ginza it is the most conveniently located hotel in Tokyo. We stayed there for seven nights occupying two rooms in first week of April. There is a Metro station (Yurakucho Line) right at the bottom of the hotel where one can go using the hotels lift. It is only 10 minutes walking distance from Tokyo International Forum, 15 minutes from Tokyo station and 20 minutes from Imperial Hotel. It is very useful if somebody wants to join a meeting either at the Forum or Imperial Hotel - both being Tokyo's most common venue for international conferences/meetings. With Tokyo station in the vicinity and the Metro station in the underground Tokyo communications seems to be at your hand! The hotel rooms are far bigger than standard Tokyo hotel rooms with spacious bathroom with all the amenities, comfortable beds, clean and white linen, free WiFi and broadband internet, complimentary tea/coffee makes it's service unique. The staff are friendly and cooperative and there is money exchange facilities at the reception. The restaurant is useful and serves breakfast at 2100 JPY per person but is not cost effective, rather there is a Mc Donald's restaurant in ground floor of the same building serving Big Breakfast at 550 JPY is more attractive. There is also a convenience store within two minutes walking distance. The other thing that strikes me is their thrust for a green planet either in avoiding unnecessary washing of towels and bed linen or wasting soaps/shampoo etc. I shall strongly advocate future travelers to be the guest in this beautiful hotel.

We stayed in Mercure Ginza Last April in time for the Cherry Blossoms . It was peak season . We were three . Most of the rooms are only good for tOwo. They up graded our room to a bigger room and was charge $350 per day with Breakfast . The room was comfortable and much bigger. They gave as an extra bed .you can have Breakfast in bed if you want but you have to pay a little amount for room service. The service in the Hotel is very good .The staffs speak English . The restaurant serve international dishes. The food is very good . beside the Hotel is McDonalds and right across is Starbucks . Ginza is the best location .during weekend they close the streets .so everybody can just enjoy walking while shopping . We are seniors and we use walkers . We take a taxi most of the time , but because of the good location taxi fare is not so bad . we will definitely stay at Mercure Ginza next time we go back to Japan

My partner and I stayed here for 2 nights. After staying in Shinjuku for a few nights we wanted to stay in a different part of Tokyo and explore.Staff were friendly and rooms were a generous size. Location was great in terms of checking out the fashion district and public transport was close as well. Breakfast was really good and there were lots of choices. We enjoyed our stay!

I stayed in Mercure Ginza for two nights. I booked the rooms 3 months before using my Accor complimentary vouchers.Check in was easy as there were not too many people at that time. We were given canned juice as welcome drinks as we were on Accor Advantage silver membership. The lady in the reception was very friendly, spoke very good English and was very helpful.The room was not very big but spacious enough to fit two people. The bathroom was spotlessly clean and modern although the shower pressure could be better. The bed was OK to sleep in.The best part was the location as it was located in central Ginza and was even directly connected to the underground. We did not use that underground however as there wasn't so much direct connection to the places that we wanted to go. The next underground lines were very close and were about 5 - 10 minutes walk.My only complain was the check out as it was very full in the small lobby. I wanted help to book a cab as it was raining hard however they were too busy and it would have taken me a long time before I even reached the reception. However if you need a cab, there was a taxi stand a short walk to the left of the hotel.

If you want to stay in Ginza, Mercure Hotel is the catch The hotel rate cost $200 +. The staffs are english speaking and helpful. The best part is, the Basement 1 of the hotel is an access to subway, Yarakucho Line Ginza . Mercure Hotel is in the center of shopping district in Ginza. Everything is just a walk away, from the finest bar like Bvlgari Bar to the down to earth vendo meals! Mitsukoshi Department Store, Matsuya, MAC, Nishi Mall and Bic Camera! There's so many things to see. You must aleays ready your camera to take pictures of their awesome streets!

If you are looking for good hotel and in convenient location, this is your answer. It is located in Ginza area and closed to 3 major stations, Ginza station, Ginza Itchome station, and Higashi-Ginza station. So you can reach everywhere in few minutes. There are many cafe, restaurants, convenient stores, etc nearby the hotel. So you will be survived. Room is nice and comfortable thought a bit small. But this is standard size in Tokyo. Hotel is also nice and clean, staff are very friendly and helpful.

Located in the centre of Ginza, Mercure is a good choice for a business hotel. Among the positives are an efficient check in process, excellent breakfast - quality as well as variety, comfortable rooms and the proximity to JR/metro system...the metro station being right at the basement. Room size is small...this is Tokyo and that too Ginza; and the going up one level for check in and again for the rooms is a minor irritant. No language issues here...Had stayed five nights and was a comfortable stay...not much of views from the rooms...No gym...

Great hotel, location was very good in the heart of Ginza. Staff spoke excellent English and were very helpful. (Especially Javier). Breakfast at the restaurant was awesome. Super smooth check-in and very accommodating for letting us in early after our flight. Thanks Mercure ginza.

We recently stayed 5 nights at this excellent hotel. It is so well located in Tokyo. You can get anywhere using either the JR or the metro system. The staff are very friendly and helpful. Their English is good and always willing to assist in anyway. The rooms are a very Japanese size however 2 people 2 bags plus carry on fitted in well. Breakfast was included in our deal and it was a great way to start the day. For a great hotel centrally located in a great part of Tokyo you won't be disappointed

After several recommendations of friends at different hotels which were all booked, Im so glad I got a room at Mercure. I had to book it last minute and Im so glad to get the last room available. This has made our trip to Tokyo truly memorable. The hotel is conveniently located, right at the heart of Ginza where everything is there for eating and shopping. I just walked all over the area to find everything I needed in Japan. The rooms were very clean and big for what I had paid for. Most of all the staff were fantastic, would give them full 5 star for superb service. Japan is my second home and whenever I am in Tokyo I will definitely stay in this hotel again!

hotel very well located in the center of Ginza. Real "people hotel" where you are welcomed as a guest after 11 hours flight.The room are relatively big and very confortable compared to the standards in Tokyo.

Last night in Japan so we chose Ginza and a reasonable hotel suite. Not the easiest hotel to find as the main entrance is down a side-street. The hotel is well placed for Ginza shopping and central Tokyo.Rooms are spacious by Tokyo standards with good facilities. Very friendly staff although the restaurant is on the expensive side. It is an easy train ride to the Fish markets as an alternative.

We stayed 5 nights at the Mercure Ginza. We choose a the luxe room and it had space enough, the bed was very good and the bathroom also good. The wifi internet in the room could be better. The breakfast was good enough and we had twice the dinner at the restaurant and we had no claims. The hotel is very well located near Ginza, the subway or the JR railway station. The service in general was good specialy Javier with a warm reception and always very helpfull. The Mercure Ginza it is not a 5 stars hotel but in it class is very good. We recommend it.

You won’t find a three-star hotel in Tokyo with a better location than this. The basement level is connected to Ginza-itchōme Station; when it rains, you can take the underground passage to Ginza, Hibiya, International Forum or even Tokyo Station (15 minutes away on foot). The superior rooms are so small that they can barely fit two pieces of luggage; you will need to jump over them literally. Is it worth paying extra for a deluxe unit measuring three square metres more? You decide. Anyway there are only four hangers in each room; if you plan to catwalk in Roppongi, stay elsewhere. But the bathroom is of decent size and comes with all the amenities you would expect from an Accor property: razors, toothbrushes, a hairdryer, etc. The breakfast restaurant is packed at peak hours – 8.30 to 9.30 am – so it’s better to grab something from a McDonald's, a Starbucks or a Lawson convenience store, all within 200 metres from the hotel. Need we say again it’s centrally located?

This excellent hotel Because of : location, servis , staffe, management, employees It feels like coming homeNot unusual to find the hotel manager walk between the the guests at breakfast and all hotel ... interested and clarifying what more could please your stay. Feeling that they care about your needs

After a long journey, we received a wonderful warm welcome from manager Javier who was so friendly and helpful and eager to please.The hotel is small and the rooms but this is Japan standard and room was perfect for us...clean and breakfast fine for on the go.The area is beautiful and walking distance to ginza. I would definitely recommend

As usual, Accor hotels never fail us. We had some issues with our reservations but the GM Mr Kamel had been very helpful and accommodating. This is our 2nd time staying in Mercure Ginza. The best thing about staying here is the location, walking distance to few subway stations, within shopping district, mac donalds next door, many jap restaurants in the vicinity. Reception area is a little small but the staff is very polite and helpful. Western buffet breakfast is great. Rooms are clean n big. We will definitely be back again.

If others go the extra mile, Javier goes the extra thousand miles, and then some. He is an asset to the hotel. Fantastic service such as this makes you wonder why big hotel chains don't find people like Javier, so that all their talk about service from the heart doesn't just stay in their brochures. The hotel is well located in the upscale Ginza area (and offers pretty good value considering the location), close to Ginza line and a few minutes from Hibiya line. It's also close to some really good eateries. There's a soba place two minutes away that offers excellent noodles and tempura for less than 500 yen. To get there from Narita, you will have to get off at TCAT and take a taxi as airport limos doesn't go there. Fare should be around 1000 yen. The only downside: our fare included breakfast and since we were told it would be very crowded we ordered it in our room. When we went down the next day to have breakfast we found that 1) it was really a good spread, and 2) that the one we got in our room was limited. There were no eggs, pancakes or cereal. And it costs 300 yen per person, something we were not made aware of. You might want to keep that in mind. Other than that, very impressive.If you want to catch the Cherry Blossoms, go to Ueno, it was blooming two days ago. You can also go to Sugamo station from the Hibiya line and go to Rikuguen Park.

Unless you are on a high floor it's a bit dark (hey, it's Ginza, space is at a premium, and the next building is very close) and the room is comfy but functional. But a very nice bathroom all things considered.The staff as others have said are very very helpful and speak good English (and French, as you'd hope).This was a post flight stay before heading on to other parts of Japan - needing a good sleep job done, and despite the location in the heart of Tokyo it's quiet. You are very close to lots of great places to eat and things to do too.

Nothing special but everything is just the way is should be. The staff were really friendly and helped us with our skis (we send those a few days ahead from Hakuba, and they kept it for us). The hotel is really close to Tsukiji (walking distance), so it is a perfect location fro visiting the Fish market in the morning.

our experience was great per all kindness and attentions from Mercure Staff, specifically Mr. Javier Piqueres, very nice and attentive for us, since the beginning he shown a real interest in our stay per Tokyo, he made a thousand of recommendations for local attractions and place of interest.Many Thanks

The Mercure Ginza could be passed and not noticed in the heart of Ginza. This is a hotel that hides and the small lift lobby leads to a fantastic stay. The rooms are small but not cramped but what they lack in size is made up by its amazing staff. The bathrooms are large for Japan and a welcoming large bath awaits. Amenities abound. It boasts a French resturant and is within walking distance to shops and transport. A must see.

Although visited Tokyo so many times, I had never until now actually stayed in a hotel in Ginza. This was a solo visit to catch up with friends after skiing in the Japanese Alps. Room was very similar to another Mercure I'd used in Naha last year - adequate and comfortable. The reception staff were extremely pleasant and helpful, particularly the friendly amigo, Javier, who seems to have an ever lasting energy supply. Location for my visit was superb - I was meeting friends near Hibiya Park, in Marounouchi, and also in Nihonbashi; all were within walking distance, as was JR Yuracho station and Ginza subway (5 mins) and Tokyo Station itself (12 mins). My only criticism was breakfast and the availability of a buffet only. I much prefer A la Carte. Yes the hotel restaurant is small but this should not force guests into eating a buffet only. Thus I ate outside.

This Mercure is very nice in terms of location, 1 minute walk from Ginza Station and 15 minutes walk from Tokyo Central Station. There are many restaurants and fancy stores close to it (open late and close early). The apartments are small but comfortable for one person. And there is a floor just for woman!

The location is superb! It has access from the hotel to 1 metro station but 2 other stations are very very close by. It was great location for shopping as we could return to the hotel to drop our bags and continue shopping. :) The room was good. I hope they had more TV channels. There was a bath in the bathroom, which was excellent. No noise from the street. Overall a great experience!

The staff were extremely helpful and booked us in for the Robot Restaurant when we emailed them a week earlier then when we arrived we also received a 50% voucher to use. Javier was great and showed us which metro line to catch and more importantly which exits to use as it's quite easy to get lost. On our last day he even ran down the road in the rain to get us a taxi as we were going to walk down to the corner and he didn't want us to get wet (plus we didn't want to pay the booking fee)!The rooms are a good size for Japan and the twin beds we had were bigger than your normal singles so we liked them. Free Wi-Fi and great location make this a great place to stay in Tokyo.

Staff well versed in English. Hotel staff are very friendly and nice, always say hello to guests. Concierge is awesome! , Extremely helpful and lovely. Room is a bit small but still did the job perfectly well. Great value for money. Buffet breakfast is pretty good. $20 per head though. McDonald's is next to the hotel if you don't want to pay $20 for breakfast. Basement level of hotel lift is a Metro Station, very convenient for getting around Tokyo or Ginza Station is only a 5 minute walk from the hotel. Definitely will be staying here again and again =) Would highly recommended for anyone travelling to Tokyo.

Now, if you're expecting an Accor hotel like those in South East Asia, you'll be gravely dissapointed. In saying this, Mercure Ginza is well laid out with fantastic and authentic service.The hotel has direct assess to Inchome-Ginza line in the basement & is a 150m walk from exit A12 from Ginza line.Hotel has no pool or gym. Though rooms are larger then expected.Staff are extremely friendly and helpful. True to Japanese culture. All in all, location is central and hotel service is of the levels you'd receive at Sofitel, Pullmans etc

We stayed in a room with a big "planet 21" poster on the door (room 1221).This room needs an upgrade as the hot water system takes a while to respond and once responded was running very slow and intermittent so not a pleasant feeling in the shower at all :(... On top of this the big yellow stain on the floor lamp is what makes this room very unpleasant to stay in. The design and location of this room also means it is smaller compared to the other rooms (my friends and I paid the same $ but her room was much bigger (squarer) with a large window whilst this room had a big cut in at a corner hence loosing some space and a window of about 1/3 of the size for the same price. I'm glad I raised all these issues with hotel management before I left so hopefully they will consider upgrade it before putting the next guests in.

Mercure Tokyo Ginza is the excellence of the customer service worldwide.The Front Office department is lead by an excellent Spanish guy who is gonna solve your life in any kind of situation, best service I have received in my 20 years business trips around the world.The food at the restaurant is outstanding. The quality and taste is extraordinary as well as the amazing service there.The rooms are the hotel are the best you can find at the luxurious Ginza street.Mercure Ginza Tokyo deserves all my respect and admiration. Thanks guys for this unique experience

People was written it's a nice hotel and I stay there for 3 nights! I had gold level membership of accorhotels but I was regret of choosing the hotel! I preferred to stay in Tokyo courtyard ginza marriot and enjoy a lot of benefits of Marriott membership ! Marriott hotels if u r they gold member they will offer u free breakfast upgrade to the room u like ...! But mercury I was staying if u ask them breakfast they will laugh at u ! If u ask them for one more bottle of water they will bring you the one you should pay for it!the staff are rude in front desk cause if u tell them something they never believe you!If u have a welcome drink they don't make it like put in ur room to make your long way tired away when u arrive, they will give you coupon and ask you to go to restaurant to use(how can I go to restaurant now when I just arrive and tired)! Don't forget the rooms are too small! For me if I know those I never choose this hotel! If the location is important for u so choose the hotels in ginza but not his one!

The French connection in the heart of the brightly lit Ginza area in Tokyo. Close to the station with connections to Narita airport mans with its own metro station entrance, it's a good base for a first-time European visitor to Japan. Helpful staff with numerous languages and Beaujolais Nouveau on hand. The reception is not at street level, which is not so welcoming but doesn't affect the performance of the hotel.

A typical four-star business hotel in a high rise building with good size rooms. It's right in the heart of Ginza. From the airport, it's the first express train stop (Tokyo station) than a short taxi ride (710 Yen) to the hotel. Plenty of restaurants and shops within walking distance. Breakfast is very good with authentic French patisseries. Staff are excellent and nice, one of them recognised and greeted us on the street. They were flexible with early check in and late check out. Highly recommended for both business and leisure.

We stayed here on our last night in Japan and loved it's location. The room was big, clean and modern which was very relieving as we had just checked out of a hotel that had a tiny room. It is less than 5 minutes away from Ginza station and is located near a lot of shops. The staff were friendly and spoke fluent English. The only issue with the hotel was that we had spent more money to book the deluxe room for Agoda but it seems like we weren't provided with bottled water or better amnesties that were stated on the website. Nevertheless, we still enjoyed the stay and will probably stay here again when we come back to Tokyo.

Not far from Tokyo central station, and from Ginza subway station, a bit challenging to find by yourself - it's in some backyards, but if use as reference two big buildings of LV and bvlgari, it becomes easier. Hotel itself is very calm and personnel is helpful. Bad thing: there are no power sockets near the beds.

Booked this hotel on a Japanese website because of its location in Ginza....2min walk from Ginza metro station and everyone on the street knew where it was. Booked in with a friend 4 hrs early and was offered a 'ladies room'. This is a separated area of the hotel just for females with l'occitane amenities in the bathroom plus lots of other girlie goodies. Breaky was what you'd expect but the staff were fabulous.....great knowledge of the area and how to get to everything, good English and really friendly and helpfull staff...Xavier even offered to take our bags out and hail a taxi for us and Make was a delight in the restaurant. Would definately recommend this hotel.

The hotel is situated in center of Tokyo with a good walking distance to the famous Ginza district and to the imperial palace. Very close to the metro station and easy to get taxi. The hotel staffs are very helpful.

This hotel in the heart of Ginza is so well located and managed that I can't imagine staying anywhere else in Tokyo. The Staff all speak English and other languages (I assume), and are ready to help with any request no matter how small. The General Manager, Kamel Senhadji, adds another level of professionalism that extends to his personal handling of any special issue or concern quickly and efficiently. The breakfast was great with both Japanese and International choices that satisfy both adults and children. The self-serve espresso/cappuccino machine was a special treat for us each morning. We also had no problem getting seating even for our 4 adults and 4 children in the breakfast area. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Tokyo as it sets a new high standard in terms of value, location, cleanliness and management for any hotel in any big City anywhere. Even our Japanese Colleagues an friends could not believe we had found such a great hotel at the peak of a very busy holiday period in Japan. They are recommending it to their friends and Colleagues as well, now! I can't think of any better endorsement of a property in Tokyo.

Stayed at Mercure for the December holidays with family. Had booked 2 rooms in advance. Overall, we love the hotel and the rooms. Location is fantastic especially since we were on a 6 day vacation in Tokyo which also was our first time to japan. It is just 2 min away from the ginza itoco station. We had a blast using the subway to visit all the key attractions in japan. The staff were very friendly and the rooms were better than expected. However we had only one small negative; as we had 2 children with us, we had early request for connecting rooms. Upon checkin, unfortunately this was not to be. In the end, although we had 2 separate rooms, our kids squeezed with us. Other than the "packed" holidays, everything else was above expectation. Would recommend this to my friends.

This hotel has a very strategic position in Tokyo. Subway at 1mt, station at 5 min and the famous Ginza mani street at 1 min. so if you need to stay in the town for tourism or business is perfect. Rooms are very good, large (we were in a deluxe room) with very good standard.staff is nternational ( speaking english) and the breakfast is good too. Wifi is free of charge. Suggested

The room of Mercure is as expected. It is compact, have all the basic necessities for travelers. The twin superior room can accomadate 2 adults and 2 toddlers easily. The location is unbeatable, only 5 mins to Ginza. For food selection, visit Matsuya dept store Floor B1. The options are abundant. Mostly taste really good. Ginza is a heaven for crazy shoppers. It carries high end to mid end brands.
user_name:
Vivi W
Jakarta, Jakarta Raya, Indonesia

review_body: I would of given this hotel a much higher rating but all it takes is one staff member to spoil the party. Every morning at the buffet breakfast we ordered from the kitchen 2 fried eggs as we don't eat scrambled or boiled eggs which was the only egg options in the buffet. This was done with ease every morning free of charge, just like all other hotels around the world do. The 3 male waiters were extremely friendly every morning, until the last morning where a young waitress who will remain nameless, we'll call her Miss S, I asked her for the 2 fried eggs like every morning and was told very sternly 'No, you can not order that as it's the weekend and the kitchen is too busy' (it was a Friday btw and at that time was less busy then previous days) Instead of causing a scene I walked up to the young male waiter (who was in charge that day instead of the normal restaurant manager) this is the same waiter who the previous morning greeted us with '2 fried eggs again?' with a big smile. Well today he even changed his tune. As i asked him about the fried eggs, Miss S was shaking her head 'No' to him. Even though he was meant to be in charge he was taking orders from her and then informed us we must order the fried eggs off the A'la carte menu and pay for it. I asked to speak to the hotel manager, he made a phone call and then all of a sudden it was ok to get the fried eggs. This is a condensed version, this was actually a 15min saga before our fried egg request was approved.Silly things like this should not happen, you can't offer something for 3 days then say No on your 4th day. Lucky it was our last day there as it would of been very uncomfortable to go back. Both Miss S and the young waiter did apologise. Also on the last morning they had no bread for the toaster as the bread was not delivered?? They should send someone down to the closest supermarket and buy 20 loaves of bread. The pastries here are world class though. Just a little side note, we are also Gold Accor members so normally get treated with great hospitality from the Accor chain, unfortunately not this time. The checkin staff were lovely and upgraded us to a deluxe room and checked us in at 7am as we came off a 12hr flight from London, which was very accommodating.

The Mercure Ginza Tokyo, being part of the French group Accor hotels (Novotel, Sofitel and Ibis) has a little stint of French charm as you walk through the hotel entrance. But that as French as this place becomes. Once settled in the room, the decor and bathroom is a mix of continental/Japanese. I find the hotel to provide extremely good value for money, given it's excellent location near Tokyo central station and Ginza at it's doorsteps. Having said so, the rooms look very tired with an outdated decor, no comfy beds and are in serious need of renovation, at least in my eyes. In fact, the entire hotel could stand in for a major overhaul. I asked for a high floor room deluxe room and got it, thanks! However, I failed to ever understand the difference between superior and deluxe category rooms (except free bottle of water and wifi) and had expected something more of my deluxe room, even felt cheated. Browsing at the hotel website, the deluxe room appeared to look just the same like superior category. Again, given the Mercure's very ideal location, in an otherwise very expensive city, the price/value mix is reasonable, and thus the hotel is a great choice if you're on a budget, but nothing more. Front desk service is quick, efficient and with a smile. Overall, staff is very friendly and helpful at the Mercure Ginza, no faults there. Breakfast area was disappointing, but nearby Starbucks (just outside) and other small eateries easily made up for this shortfall. Sadly that the Mercure Ginza hotel is the only choice (apart from one Ibis) in this great city, offered by the Accor hotel chain, given this particular hotel's outdated state. Tokyo could easily do with a new modern Novotel!

This is a nice hotel conveniently located. It is just a 5 minute walk into the main shopping area of Ginza. We had a twin deluxe room which was clean, comfortable and had plenty of space. Staff were excellent. We would be quite happy to stay here again.

We stayed in a Deluxe Twin room for 2 nights inclusive of breakfast. The room fitted my family of 2 children quite comfortably. The bed was comfortable & the breakfast was buffet with quite a nice spread of western & Japanese.The basement of the hotel is directly linked to the subway but I won't suggest travellers with big luggage to use that way as there are some steps up & down.We took a taxi from the hotel to Tokyo station (Marunouchi side) which only cost about ¥700. You have to catch a taxi by walking to the main road, about 50m, but the reception at the hotel was kind enough to offer to write the instruction for the taxi driver in Japanese for us.

My husband and I stayed here for our honeymoon, and had a lovely time. It is well located and close to train stations and restaurants. The staff were friendly and helpful. The rooms were teeny-tiny, even our upgraded room, but as we didn't spend much time there it was not a problem. They contained everything we needed for our stay.

This hotel is in a good location. Indeed I got lost whilst shopping but because the sign of the hotel is so easy to see I was able to find my way back. The hotel is complicated to find your way round in. The reception is on the first floor. The street is narrow so if you are unloading you feel under pressure to hurry lugging your suitcases quickly. Then take the lift to the first floor and check in. It seems that every possible space has been utilized which whilst admirable is not always very practical. But still the hotel has been laid out attractively.The restaurant serves a very French breakfast. Some people rave about it because they have real croissants but being in Tokyo I prefer a taste of real Japanese. There were some signs in the lift explaining when would be the ideal time to have breakfast ie when there was less likely to be queues. That seemed useful.

We arrived to a warm welcome on the 20 th dec and left today morning for Singapore We had chosen this hotel based on its location which indeed turned out to be a very wise decision Being in the heart of ginza gives you amazing options of shopping and eating The ever helpful hotel staff guide you to the restraints of the cuisine you desireAnd if its really late in the night their is a McDonald two mts away which remains open twenty four hoursThe hotel rooms are adequate ,the toilet is fairly large with good toiletries providedThe main restrurant cum coffe shop serves a good wholesome breakfastBut what takes cake is the most hospitable staff that I have come across for a long timeI am sure the hotel would be getting repeat visits from their guests .i for one would love to go back

I booked this hotel for my Tokyo stay as I'm an Accor member. As I usually prefer to stay at the Sofitel brand, I found the room quite small, even for one person., but apparently this is usual for Tokyo . However it had everything I needed. I had issues connecting my Ipad to the free wifi, but it was quickly sorted out by a technician who came to my room. I felt the instructions could have been clearer re step 2 for novices like myself.I found all of the staff very friendly and helpful and was impressed with the number of languages they spoke and the level of English. I particularly enjoyed the food in the restaurant, for both breakfast and dinner. At times the service was poor, for example one evening when I was one of only two people dining, I waited for a long time before having to ask for a dessert menu. But then they surpassed themselves by providing a fresh fruit plate that was not on the menu. Also at breakfast, it seemed that every time I went to get something, it was in need of replenishment. Maybe more staff are needed at busy times. The pastries were delicious and tasted almost as good as those in France! The other comment I want to make is about the company policy of asking guests to leave their towels hanging on the hook if they want to help the environment and not have them replaced. Every morning I did this, but my towels were still replaced. Also, after a 4 night stay, I had 14 bottles of shampoo/conditioner in my bathroom! If it hasn't been used, then don't leave more every day!! It seems that staff need further training on how to comply with company policy and to respect guests' wishes in this regard.The location of this hotel was fantastic, close to great shopping, several railway stations and beautiful Christmas illuminations. I would return to this hotel if visiting Tokyo in the future due to its great value for money, staff and good food, but hope that the beds are a little softer in the future.

We were surprised that the reception area was on the 2nd floor, but check-in was quick and staff were nice (spoke good English). Room was nice and clean, which is very important and a big plus. The room was also small, but not as small as some other hotels we've stayed at in the past. The superior room was perfect for us as a couple, but it will definitely be way too small for more than 2 people. Fantastic and convenient location. Not far from Tokyo Station (about a 15 min walk) and easy access to the Ginza Metro Station. There's a McDonald's right next to the hotel and a Starbucks around the corner. Close to the main street (Ginza) where all the shops are at. Highly recommend this hotel!

Reception is one level above the entrance.The staff speaks perfect English and very quick and smooth check-in.Rooms were small but the average Tokyo room size. Space is precious there!We were given welcome drinks since we are Accor Members.Breakfast however was quite a disappointment going by Mercure standards.The variety was certainly lacking. There was a good sized salad bar. The cereals were sufficient but very few beverage options. And definitely very little cooked food and breads! So while it was good to taste, it was not filling!The staff was running and on their toes. It is good but a bit interfering due to lack of space. Elbows everywhere!However, no complaints otherwise. Wouldn't mind visiting again. I would probably pick a bigger room though.

The location of the hotel is very good for a mixture of subway stations and the posh shops such as Louis Vitton etc. The hotel itself is rather disappointing having stayed in many Mercure hotels in the past. I see the Mercure brand as something that is not a budget brand but not the luxury brand either. This hotel however seemed to be to be in the budget category. The hotel seems very dated. You arrive in a very small and darkly decorated lobby area and are greeted with two lifts and some stairs. After a while you work out that you need to get into one of the lifts to get to reception. Unfortunately you have to magic your heavy suitcases and yourself into the lift within a few split seconds before the doors shut on you. When you arrive upstairs to the reception floor, again, it seems like a rather dark, dated decor. You check in and as I was checking in with the receptionist, the reception area was suddenly inundated with what seemed like a coach party of people talking loudly and virtually stampeding their way around you at all angles. We found our way through these people to go to our room, the dreaded lift again which took off before I had time to insert my card and select the floor. We arrived to the floor and again were greeted by some dark decor with no daylight, a long narrow corridor down to our room. The room was tiny and that was when I was thinking, this was meant to be a Superior Room. Bear in mind we had 3 weeks away from home so we had three weeks worth of luggage. There wasn't enough space to open up our two cases, so essentially we had to keep our clothes in our two cases and open them up one at a time on the bed everytime we wanted something out of them. The wardrobe was pretty small anyway with not enough space to hang up one persons clothes never mind two. We then decided to head down for dinner in the restaurant. We arrived down to the restaurant and looked and it looked very much like a roadside diner to us. I apprehensively walked in thinking we are going to have a bad dinner in here. That's when I started to think, this is more like an Ibis hotel, Ibis being a brand I class as low budget. However after experiencing the food and service in the restaurant I was pleasantly surprised, both the service and food were very good. This I class as the highlight of this hotel. The breakfasts in the morning where rather disappointing. You had to ask for cutlery, the milk had run out, so we had to ask for that and the bread rolls seemed as though they had been around for many days. There wasn't really anything inspiring or appetizing about the breakfast, to the point where we just didn't bother with it on our last day. Altogether a rather disappointing experience, the hotel needs an upgrade of decor and a more friendly greeting in the lobby area, rather than arriving and feeling completely disorientated and not knowing where reception is. In the lobby area my initial thought was, have we actually arrived in a hotel or have we walked through the wrong doorway and into an office block. It also needs bigger rooms because to me the room that we were in was certainly far from Superior.

My wife and I stayed at the Mercure Ginza with our young son for a total of 6 nights in November. This is our favourite place to stay in Ginza. We arrived after a long journey from the US to find the room waiting for us and the little guy's crib already in the room and made up with sheets and blanket. The service is very welcoming and efficient and the staff speak good English (I am sure French too....). The room was one of their deluxe rooms, which are slightly bigger (needed for the crib and all the luggage). For Japan, the room was very spacious.Breakfast was included in our room rate and had a good selection of Japanese and Western food. The coffee was especially good and much needed when adjusting to the new time zone. We also had welcome drinks in the bistro (benefits of being a Sofitel/Accor card holder....) The location of the hotel is fabulous. Ginza was very festive with many shops decorated for the holiday season and Tokyo station is close by. We enjoyed walking over to Hibiya park to let our son burn some energy. The hotel is also about a 30 min walk to Tsukiji fish market, so when we could not sleep at 4 am we took a walk to wander around the market and have sashimi for breakfast.Altogether another very good stay

Stayed here for 5 nights in November 2013. Staff at the reception was extremely helpful and welcoming. They helped us making a reservation and helped us with our lost luggage. The rooms are very clean and convenient. The location is very good, walking distance from Tokyo station and the Ginza district.

During my holiday to japan we stayed in several places. This hotel 's staff were amazing. We speak no japanese and they even supplied maps with directions to nearby places,both restaurantsand shops. We didn't have any meals at the hotel but the bar was clean and relaxing. Having a subway station under the hotel also made our travel easy.
user_name:
Deanna M
Perth, Western Australia, Australia

review_body: The lobby is small and the breakfast choices are few but the room is ok for a Japanese Hotel that is located in Ginza street. Bed can accomodate up to 2 adults and 2 kids if you stay in twin beds room.(small kids only) Location is good and transportation is easy in this hotel. Stay in this hotel if you have lots of money because there is shopping,shopping,and still shopping everywhere around this hotel.

Super location close to Yurakucho JR station. Several breakfast options closeby. Lots of restaurants in the immediate neighbourhood. Our favourite was ITAMAE (in the street almost right across the main entrance of the hotel). Excellent beds (superior room). Spacy room for Japanese standards. Immaculately clean. No noise at all, either from outside or from inside. Knowledge of English at reception desk varied but service was always perfectly friendly and helpful. We got excellent information on Kabuki Theatre and Sumo wrestler trainings. Airco functioning perfectly (and noiselessly). The only "negative" (rather: strange) fact: every hotel we stayed in in Japan advertised eco friendly rules but when you oblige, they just ignore your eco-friendliness and go ahead and change all the towels and bathrobes daily anyway. I guess they just feel they have to oblige the guests in any way they can, regardless :-). Japan is heaven for tourists (exept for the fact that few people speak any English at all but we managed with sign language anyway). Loved it!

This is a very nice hotel. The room was clean and modern. It was the most up to date room we stayed in while in Japan. The only downside to the room was that it was very small. It was very hard to find space for two pieces of luggage. The bathroom was reasonable sized, but not large either. Overall we enjoyed our stayed here, and would absolutely stay here again. It was nice being able to walk to Starbucks in the morning, as it was very close to the hotel. The only downside with the location was that it wasn't close to the large train station, but we could have taken the subway to get to the train station, for an additional cost (we purchased Japan Rail Passes and they were only able to be used at the train station). The staff was polite and helpful. We did not go to the swimming pool or fitness center (does this location have either one?).
