We booked this hotel for 2-nights twice separated by 7 days back in August and couldn't have imagined our stay at this Ginza hotel any better.I agree with many reviewers here that the hotel is perfectly situated in Ginza. It is a short walking from the Yurakucho Station and the walking is very very enjoyable because you are literally walking thru one of the busiest streets in Ginza. The central Tokyo Station is a little far away but still within walking distance. The property itself is a little bit off the street, which is a nice thing to keep you away from noise. One subway station is accessible from the underground pass during the day. And the hotel elevator directly takes you to the pass. The lobby is on the second floor and I like it! Being separated from the outside gives you a cozy and quiet feeling which wouldn't be the case if it was on the first floor.On the second two-day stay, we had breakfast there. The French chef always welcomed us with smiles and elegance. The food was typical continental style added with many Japanese breakfast varieties. Choices were abundant and every one of us loved it. After the first 2-day stay we needed to travel to Nagoya and Osaka so we asked the concierge if we could leave one of our baggage we didn't need to carry at the hotel. They gladly stored it away. When we came back it was already put into our room. talking about small details!As usual, Mercure hotel room was clean. I had expected a larger room since I was a Platinum mumber at Accor. The room of our second stay was larger than the first. I think they would give you an upgrade if available.The rates were affordable and right on the money considering the fact that it was Ginza! I haven't had the chance to stay in other Ginza hotels but I can tell you that this one should rank on the top of the list.

"Reasonable price" and "Ginza" are two words seldom used in the same sentence, but given the excellent location, I think that it would be fair to say that Mercure Tokyo Ginza IS reasonably priced.My impression is that this hotel is a good business-style hotel in an the heart of Ginza. McDonalds occupies a part of the bottom level (although not with a shared entrance), and there are convenience stores and Starbucks very nearby, making it a great location for someone that needs to be in Ginza for more practical purposes than flushing away large quantities of cash on designer labels. I just wish I could have found a few more affordable restaurants in the area.The hotel's subway entrance could use a bit of a renovation. The original sight of the subway entrance foyer put some doubt in my mind about the quality of the hotel, however this was soon relieved when I entered the main part of the hotel.The staff were very courteous, and many of them had adequate English communication skills. The hotel staff also provided me with an iron and ironing board at my request, and without charge, and they accommodated my mother by permitting her to check-out an hour later than usual at no extra cost.These small courtesies go a long way to building goodwill, and I appreciate this kindness very much.

Stayed in a Superior queen room. Arrived at 11am, the staff who spoke excellent English told us our room will be ready at 1pm and offered to send the bags to the room directly. Refreshing as I seldom come across Japanese hotels who would allow to check in before the official check in time.Size of the room is large for Tokyo standard. Especially the bathroom. It was enough space for 2 to use the wash basin and the hair dryer and still feel spacious. Location is good, close to either the Ginza Stn or the Ginza3Chrome stn (where the basement of the hotel leads directly to the exit). There is a starbucks and McDonald's within 1-2 min walk from the hotel, along with huge huge departmental stores in Ginza. It is walk-able to Tokyo stn but we took a taxi as we had bags. The taxi only cost 710 yen, which is the minimum fare. It is easy to flag a taxi around the hotel as well. An excellent choice made for this Ginza hotel.

The Mercure Ginza is a short taxi ride from Tokyo Station. (Too far to walk with luggage but easily walkable without.) It is next to a Metro (subway) station, near a Family Mart and lots of cafes.The rooms are compact of course but beautifully appointed and every centimetre of space has been cleverly used. We were in a standard room and it had a nice bathroom with great toiletries.There are signs in the lifts warning of queues for breakfast so you would do much better to eat at a cafe.We would definitely stay here again.

Excellent location: Starbucks and Lawson are 2 minutes away, about 15 minutes walk to Tokyo station. Very close to Ginza and department stores, Itoya, subway. All very short walking distance.Good value for money too and free wifi.Forget about having breakfast there: restaurant is too small and long queue. Better to walk to Starbucks down the corner, usually quiet in the morning.Room and bathroom could be cleaner: many spots on the carpet and I also found some hair in the shower, that was gross. Stayed at the Marriott Courtyard several times in the past and it is cleaner as well as has a bigger room. The Mercure room is a bit small.Tradeoff: location and price, or bigger room and not as good location?

The location of the hotel allows you to get on the metro quickly (under the hotel), walking distance to Tokyo train station and the imperial palace (+ the running course around the imperial palace), and the fish market. The rooms are fairly large with Japan standards and are clean etc. The only drawback is the potential waiting for breakfast which the hotel warns about in the elevators. Starbucks on every corner, McDonald's downstairs and a little convenient store close by too.

We have just stayed at the Mercure Ginza with our two children (9 & 13) and another family with two children. We each had interconnecting rooms (which we were advised were not available at the time of booking - but were upon check in, so we were pleasantly surprised). We were very impressed with the whole hotel. The rooms are small, but comfortable. The beds comfortable, air conditioning works well, no street noise, good amenities. Unfortunately our friends rooms smelt of cigarettes, even though it was a non smoking room. I believe the staff tried to address the issue (offered them a room change, provided deodorisers etc). We found the staff very helpful and all spoke English. My daughter dropped her ipod down the elevator shaft - and they shut the whole thing down and sent people in to look for it. The hotel is in a great location. The convenience store nearby was very useful. The breakfast buffet was very good (the kids were free and they gave us coupons, so I think it was about 4000 yen per family per day - well worth it). We ate dinner one night in their French restaurant which we all enjoyed (pasta was al dente, not too much sauce and their bread is as good as anywhere in France!) We are probably coffee snobs - and all the adults were very impressed with the coffee. Loved the free internet throughout the hotel - every morning we planned our day over breakfast using our ipads. We would all stay at the Mercure Ginza again. There is a fantastic Japanese, kid friendly restaurant called Tartufo or Tarufo near the hotel (come out the front door and head left). Its in the basement, and the photos on their sign do not do it justice. The decor is more than you could hope for with ponds, chefs cooking on hotplates, individual rooms with paper walls, little bridges etc. They have an English menu, it was not expensive and the food was delicious.

Stayed 2 nights. The hotel is just a short walk to Ginza, considered as one of the most luxurious shopping districts in the world. It's also connected to Tokyo Metro Ginza 1 Chome station and just walking distance to Ginza Station and Yurakucho Station. The room is a bit old but at least Wifi is available inside the room. Room service is excellent. Our room was cleaned diligently. I also love the organic toiletries provided. Restaurant have Filipino staff. They were very helpful in providing info on which trains to take to get to tourist spots around Tokyo. McDonald's and Starbucks are close by. So if you feel like getting familiar food and drink, it's just outside the hotel. Breakfast buffet was quite good. Food selection was reasonable. Over all I had a great stay. Will definitely recommend to family and friends.

Being a member of Accor, there was an opportunity to stay at Mercure Ginza. Getting to the hotel was rather easy. Coming out of Ginza Icchome station and the hotel was just there! Checking in was easy as the staff could speak English. The room was rather small, though but the bathroom was rather cosy, instead! The front desk gave us coupon for welcome drink which was really a nice gesture!There were a few convenience stores and eateries near the hotel and also a 24hour MacDonald's right next door! Also, it is walking distance to the famous Tsukiji market! Just a few blocks away, you are on the main streets with many branded stores! Everyday, we would make use of the Ginza Icchome station to connect to the various destinations within Tokyo. It was really easy to move around!Would I stay here again when I visit Tokyo again? Most definitely!

I was at the hotel 2 weeks ago, it has really a great location in Ginza, just a 2 minutes from the main shopping street away. So for a shopmaniac is it a perfect location. But well Ginza was not an area for me, there are nice shopping places, but I don't really need Gucci, Armani-stuff etcThe staff's english was ok, not perfect, but fine enough to communicate. We arrived during the typhoon, so they gave us free umbrellas. The hotel has free internet which is really uncommun for Mercure Hotels in Europe. So this is really a plus for the hotel.He rooms were quite big, and really clean. You have one op those japanese hightech toilets, which are fun if you see one like for the first time. And to be honest I really miss those heated seats XDI haven't tried the breakfast in the hotel, I was to stingy to pay 20 $ so we took our breakfast next door at the 24/7 Mc Donald's, which was fine for me and it cost you only 3 dollar 80 for the cheapest menu with coffee and juice ;)But yes I would recommend this hotel, Accor Hotels are mostly all fine, and you can book this place without hesitation.

We stayed here in the first leg of our honeymoon. The location is fantastic. We caught a taxi from the Tokyo city air terminal and it was no problem at all. The Ginza area is really lovely with fantastic restaurants all around. The train station below the hotel is great and so easy to access and use. The staff were amazingly helpful and gave great advice. The breakfast was wonderful, plenty of options and all well cooked. The hotel room is small when compared to elsewhere we stayed in Asia but comfortable. We booked through flight centre so the rates were very expensive. But in future I will book directly through the hotel website the rates seem a lot better.

Located in Ginza, the middle of everywhere! Just a short walk or train ride to find a good feed or a ridiculously large shopping centre. There's a subway station directly underneath the hotel to make life even easier. 24-hour reception, so late check-ins are not a problem.The staff are tremendously helpful with no request too difficult. They can speak Japanese, English and French at the very least.Tidy, comfortable rooms. Decent breakfast. All the amenities worked.My only gripe was that it was a little difficult to find the hotel, but fatigue may have made things harder for me at the time.

The best thing about this hotel is the location. Located in the Ginza Area... this hotel is best if you come to Tokyo for shopping and also business traveller. The Tokyo Metro Ginza station is just walking distance can be assessed from the basement of the hotels. While Tokyo station is just few stations away from Ginza Station.Check in is very efficient, staffs generally are helpful and friendly. The Room can be little bit small, but for Tokyo standard is acceptable. Rooms are clean as well and mattress are comfortable. Breakfast choices are not much, however the quality is superb. This is much better than some hotels which provides lots of variety of foods but at sub-standard quality.The hotel can be a bit expensive about USD200 per night on average, however considering its location in central Tokyo, it is still acceptable.

The hotel in the hurt of the Ginza Area. Very comftebal by all mains. Good transportions to/from. The subway has a station at the underpart of the building. The breakfast more then far. The statof Maine of the stafe is to give good service.The G. manger is from France and looking for "solotins" to give the guests. Very friendly hust

I just completed my third stay in this hotel within a year. It has good location in the center of Ginza but rooms are small and breakfast a bit limited. But OK value for center of Tokyo. This time I had an afternoon flight and a lunch appointment nearby so needed to extend my checkout a little. I was surprised to find that checkout time is 11am and they are very reluctant to extend it. After some talk they were willing to give until 12 noon, which is standard checkout time in all of Asia but in this case useless to me. To get past that even to 1pm was very difficult. I have a gold card but they flatly said I get no benefit with that. Most other hotel groups, also in Tokyo, give easily until 2pm and usually with a gold card until 4pm as long as they are not fully booked. And I only needed until 1pm this time. They wanted to charge 1000 yen for that extra hour, so clearly they had space, just wanted to be difficult and greedy. It is the small things that push customers away. I will try another hotel on my next stay. For a thousand yen greed they can lose hundreds of thousands in return business.

Small rooms, but very good value. Location is excellent for business and pleasure, close to 5 metro stations and in the center of Ginza. Service is friendly and efficient. Food quality is good. Free wifi. The small size of the building means a lot of time is saved. Have stayed there multiple times and will do so again without hesitation.

- Perfect location especially it is so near to my office and also good walking distance to anywhere around Ginza. - Room: Clean and standard. In my opinion, this is fine for around 1 week stay. If the room size and TV is bigger and if it comes with complimentary water then it will be perfect!- Breakfast: Standard and not much options- Check-in/ out experience: Staff is friendly and can speak English fairly wellGenerally, this hotel is value for money and I do hope that they will keep improving further. Will definitely come back to stay here for either business or holiday with my wife.

We stayed for 9 nights And after the initial confusion over our booking we couldn't have had a better time. All the staff were willing to help with any queries we had, the room had all that was needed and the breakfast was superb. I would definetly recommend staying Mercure Tokyo Ginza.

The Mercure Hotel Ginza is extremely well located in the Ginza area of Tokyo. It is a few minutes from the main shopping area of Ginza and very convenient to the busy, but effective Tokyo underground. The Hotel staff are friendly and helpful and the rooms are well serviced. The breakfast is adequate, however should you be adventurous there are plenty of food choices for all meals of the day a close walk away. There are however a number of issues intending guests need to be aware of including that many taxi drivers do not know the Hotel so you will to come prepared with a map/card in Japanese, avoid the Hotel (Tokyo generally) in the heat of summer as the rooms get extremely hot and close and the air conditioning can't cope. There is virtually no Business Centre if you are expecting to do a lot of computing and WiFi access is limited. The room rate is reasonable value and it will be a pleasant place to stay outside the hot months. Japan (Tokyo) is a great place to visit.

Its located in a great & famous shopping area of Tokyo which is considered one of the finest area. The subway is just 10 mins walk. Room is small but comfortable and makes it convenient to do business as well as shopping. The hotel has many international eateries at walking distance.

enjoyed our stay . the reception staff were helpful .the hotel very central to all transport .the room was small but comfortable and very clean. the meals ok. they close of the streets on the week ends in the ginza which made good to visit all the shops . found the locals very friendly .would like to visit again ....

The hotel is in a great location for shopping and getting around with a subway station under or a 10 minutes walk to Ginza station. It's a bit hidden away on a side street but easy to find when you know where. The entrance is fairly basic with the lobby on the 1st floor. The staff there were fantastic and had good English and it was nice to see them always smiling and willing to help with any request (such as directions, tours etc.) The rooms are smaller compared to other hotels (having been to Japan before I expected it but my partner didn't) but bigger than most in Japan and was comfortable and clean. The bathroom was quite large with the normal amenities and a bonus heated toilet seat. It was easy to sleep there as the room was very quiet and dark with no noise from the street or hallways but I am still not sure about the pillow with some sort of beads in it. Breakfast was fairly basic but overall acceptable but make sure you check the hours as it turns into continental breakfast only after a certain time. Checkout was easy (a late check out incurs extra charges) and again all with a big smile and making sure we enjoyed our stay. It's a good hotel in a good location but don't expect big rooms that you get in other countries.

the room is quite small for a mid-scale hotel, but the cleanliness is very good, the location of the hotel to subway is very very near. and yes it is just a walk away to ginza shops. the hospitality is also very good, though it is typical for most of the Japanese.

We arrived into HND airport and transferred onto the Limo Bus service to Tokyo station and took the underground to Ginza, easy accessible from HND airport. Ginza is an upmarket and fashionable shopping district packed with your must-haves (Bulgari, Prada, Louis Vuitton, Tiffany, department stores, a multitude of bars, cafes, restaurants). Upon arrival, there is a lift to take you up to the Front Desk on the First Floor, not Ground Floor, or a stair case. We were lucky to get a room before official check in time. Housekeeping had not emptied the bin from the previous guest but apart from that (it was emptied without any questions apologies for) no issues. Asked for an ironing board and an iron to sort out travel outfits to go to NRT - a short walk to Hibiya line and transfer to the NEX at JR Tokyo Station, allow some 80-90 mins door to door). Well sized rooms (XL compared to Japanese style hotels). Great location.

This was probably the first time that I stayed at a Mercure hotel. I am not an Accor fan, though some stock of Avios points, made me decide to stay at this hotel. And it was a very positive surprise !The hotel is very close to Tokyo station (we arrived per Shinkansen from Kyoto and took the Narita express the next day to the airport). You can walk from the station (1.2 km). At the same time, it is at the heart of Ginza and also very close to the imperial palace garden and to the Metro. Excellent location.CHeck in was smooth and efficient and the lady told us that we are upgraded (they always tell you that in Japan). We had a very nice room (818) on the 8th floor with a sittting corner, Ipod docking, nice bathroom and fast, wireless internet (for free). All good.Check out was as efficient as check in. Overall : a very positive surprise

Mercure Ginza is very close with Ginza (shopping district area) . Good for business hotel too.The Loby is on 2nd floor and they dont have a troly boy. The concierge could speak english very well. Their breakfast is standart. So i prefer go to Lawson 24h mini market just turn right 2 minute from hotel. Room is standart, not too small. We got 2 queen beds, so thats big enough for my hubby and kid. Japanese channel tv only, others we need to pay (acctually i dont really understand their information for using a remote). I love the bathroom & all the compliments ^.^ . So japanese. Simple but beutiful.Easy to get taxi.Near to 24h Lawson , starbuck , bookstore close at 8pm , Ginza Shopping District. Its also near to Kabuki building."Sutekina ky?jitsu o motte iru."Have a nice holiday.

We, group of four check-in at Mercure Ginza in two twin rooms,last July 29 to Aug 3,2013 for 5 nights. I personally has good praises for the front desk staff. They can speak straight good English,We did not encounter language problem.They can teach how to get to your destination to the best possible route. THe staff are so accomodating that they will personally check on your aircon or wi-fi connection. Also very accesible to Main Chuo Dori with Matsuya Ginza and Mitsukosh dept. store with lots of cooked food to buy.I will definitely,stay on this hotel the next time I visit Tokyo, Ginza.

I stayed this hotel many many years ago and it is always my choice at Tokyo because of the location and room size.In fact, I just given another good remarks some three months ago but I was REALLy disappointed this time. I checked in likes usual, with lot of smiles and greetings on late July. This time, I added a trip to Osaka as I found out there was a budget flight from tokyo to osaka leaving narita at seven in the morning. I then asked counter in that afternoon if there was any public transport at 5 am. The counter simply answered she did not know and was not willing to help at all. I of course kept asking and finally she said I might go by a early JR train. I then asked for a copy but she said it was in Japanese. I insisted and then a copy was finally providedand it was in English. I further requested for a taxi leaving hotel to that station at 4 something. She was not happy. I was sad not because she did not know, but it was her attitude and unwilling to go further. She could simply check for customer those transfer details in Japanese. Obviously, she just did not do it.What was more, I kept thinking that there must have some sorts of transport or how local could get those morning flight. I later found out after surfing 30 mins in room and noted there was regularly coach leaving tokyo station. I then went to counter later than evening. This time, the trainee told they had nothing details but only one from TCAT. It was not responding to my needs but only lips service of what he had. Again, he was just not planning to help. I then further asked him to call the phone of the coach bus with my iPad as I won't speak Japanese. He refused and said it was a bit little as it was almost ten. As I got no choice but insisted, he finally called and confirmed that I could go there by 5-6. He was not happy then but I was really upset by their attitude.I think the mgt need to address this as it was Not a single issue/personal problem. I am now consider to report this to Accor and stop staying if it is not improved.

We still very much prefer this hotel! It's so close to department stores, shops and famous restaurants. The room is on the small side but is clean, got good wifi signal for my work, got good facilities and amenities which made our stay a pleasant one.We've asked the concierge to help book some restaurants and did not disappoint. The reception ladies (and gents) are extremely nice and helpful also.

Not such an easy location for those who travel with public transportation but a very good location to scan around the Ginza area and the fish market is also on walking distance. The rooms where clean but the decoration was for sure not my cup of tea. One good point is that this was the only hotel on our trip with soft matrasses. The staff was friendly and proffesional

I have stayed just 1 night at this hotel and I would stay again if I have the opportunity to visit Tokyo in the future. The location is amazing, really in the heart of Ginza, close to the main malls and train / metro station. I requested a late check out and they offered me to stay untill 6 PM paying US$10,00 per aditional hour, which was very convenient for me. I have not tried the breakfast, since there are 2 starbucks very close to the hotel. The cost was not high, specially considering the prices in Tokyo. Strongly recommend.

This hotel is just good value for money. I'd say it's no frills for a Japanese hotel but you need everything that you need.Pros:1. Location2. Amenities - complete, basics are there.3. CleanCons:1. Strict with check-ins and check-outs.2. TV channels - basically there's not much choice.So just value for money, yea.

A nice hotel, clean and tidy, and with close proximity to JR and subways, making travel around the city a breeze. As mentioned the staff speak good English and were very helpful. The wifi was very good, so good that video streaming was not a problem. Only reason it did not get the full marks, was the limited range of food for breakfast, but that is usual for Tokyo hotel.

Two elevators that are always full, the wifi range in our room couldn't even reach the bed (had to sit against the front door).The rooms are mostly on one side, the building across the street is grey. That's your view.Upon finding pubic hair in the bed and the bath, we opted to change hotels (the room wasn't great anyway). We were at the hotel for 30 minutes of a three day stay. They refused to refund the amount we had paid.Went to the Hyatt in Shinjuku instead. 10x better (more expensive though).

It's value for money given its location (close to subway & Ginza district) despite its small size (typical of Tokyo anyway, especially rate in this range). Unfortunately, no flexibility given for early check-in. This hotel is not easy to find too.For short business trips, it is quite a good value for money.Recommend to take cab to Tokyo main station (Narita) or JR Hamamatsucho (Haneda) if you have big luggage to carry. Fare about Yen1000. Otherwise, subway is a breeze.

This property is located in a very convenient location in the shopping district of Ginza and very close to metro stations and lot of food outlets around.Only one glich in our whole stay of 2 nights was though we had given our flight details, we were given a room only after 12 noon. I could make out that the room was vacant while enetering the room as the room was quiet warm and the aircon took sometime to cool the room.Though the rooms are very small but couldnt expect better in one of the most expensive cities in the world. The service was fast and prompt in the rooms but had bad experiences with the reception staff at the time of checkin.Overall I would rate this property as good for its service and basic amenities. When you travel in Japan, I found it common to see hardly one or two TV channels in english. VOD is available at a cost.I may try a different property for my next visit.

The Mercure Ginza is a hotel located in the centre of Ginza making it an excellent choice for staying in Tokyo. There is a railway station entrance (19) right next to it's door making travelling to and from the hotel a breeze, even with luggage. The hotel staff speak very good english so check-in and other queries should be hassle free.Both the room itself and the bathroom are larger than most hotel rooms in Tokyo which is a definite plus. There is plenty of storage space and a large work desk, making it very convenient for the business traveller and longer stays. The rooms are also very quiet, hearing no corridor traffic or noise from adjacent rooms. The beds are comfortable, and a little softer than the usual hard Japanese beds. The in-room free internet is fast and reliable.Breakfast is what you typically get at Tokyo hotels, with an additional selection of pastries. There are limited choices for breakfast nearby the hotel otherwise. On the other hand there's a wide variety of excellent restaurants for dinner or lunch nearby. The only real downside to the hotel is the lack of a fitness centre.If you're looking for a hotel with a great location that is good value and reliable, Mercure Tokyo Ginza should be on the shortlist.

Stayed here for 3 nights with option for breakfast at 1900 JPY Good selection but wish they could offer a real sausage instead of a hot dog type sausage as I saw a selection of wurst style sausages in the food courts . They also offered a late check out up to 6pm for JPY 1000 per hour past the normal check out which was great for me as my flight was leaving from Haneda at 1am but as I was checking out on a Friday they would not give me that late a check out and would only give me till 4pm When I checked in they were going to give me a room on the 3rd floor which was above the restaurant and lobby which were on the second floor so I asked for a room higher up and was accommodated no problem which also was upgraded from a single to a queen bed Beware the toilet seat ! room was warm upon check in as the air had not been on (need to put the room key in to a slot for power so ask for 2 keys ) Went to sit on the toilet and the seat was hot ! Only comes in hot or warm no way to turn it to cool . Good range of bathroom products including toothbrush razor Hotel is right by Ginza ithcome ? subway but its not on a main line . The Ginza subway is only 200 yards along the road and gets you nonstop to Roppongi and Ueno Took the train from Narita to Tokyo station and cab was only 710 yen Going to Haneda took cab to TCAT (Tokyo City Airline Terminal) for JPY 1000 and bus to Haneda for JPY 800

The hotel is rather small. The lobby is on the 1st floor, so the first impression was a bit uncertain, when I dragged my suitcases into the small lift. The check in went fine, and the hotel staff were very kind and happy. The whole hotel looks a bit old, and smells a bit funny. But the room is big according to the Tokyo standard. The bathroom is very nice.To use my time efficiently, after checking in, I went out ( at 11pm). The famous Ginza street is just there around the corner! The next days when I stayed, I returned my room a few times to leave the shopping bags, having a rest, etc. The location is the best, and the other elements are fine, even not the best. I will stay at this hotel again!

The hotel is central to Tokyos expansive railway system. Convenient for those wanting to shop. There is an abundance of fantastic local restaurants in the area.The rooms were basic but had everything you needed and were clean. Breakfast was very basic and service a bit hit and miss. Reception staff very helpful.
user_name:
HappyExpatSaigon
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: after our long roundtrip, we went for the last few days into this mercure hotel and it was directly in the shopping area and perfect (especially for my wife). they did offered a friendly service there and our standard room was pretty comfortable and room was very clean.

We like that Mercure Hotel in Tokyo, because it does have a very good Location and many Attractions are just beside. Friendly Service at the Reception and all was very clean there. Although in Middle of the City, it was pretty calm there.

Within easy walking distance from the station .Had a lovely surprise walking to the hotel ! All the designer shops are close by . The food at the hotel was very good , and the staff very friendly .Our room was the biggest that we stayed in during our stay in Japan . As with all the people we met in Japan nothing is too much trouble for them .

The best thing about this hotel was the location. The staff were very friendly and helpful, the breakfast was good and our room was small but clean and perfectly acceptable for one night in Tokyo. We hadn't realised we were just around the corner from the Knightsbridge of Tokyo with all the beautiful shops. We found a lovely local restaurant near the hotel where you cooked your own food on a griddle with a half brick to cover it. Ideal hotel, not far from the main Tokyo station and so many helpful people when we couldn't find where we were going!Would definitely recommend this hotel for a centralized short stay. We did have a rather active couple in the room next door who we could hear very clearly but that was the only down point.

in the heart of giza. expensive but worth the money for shopping and dinning. walkable to tsunkiji fish mkt as well. you got to be at the mkt at 4am if you want to see the tuna!!hotel's staff is extremly helpfull and upgraded us to a family room. great place to be for shopping and enjoying the tokyo heart beat!

The Mercure Ginza is reasonably priced for this part of Tokyo. The staff are exceptional, as we came to expect in Japan. Desk staff had at least passable English to very good English, so communication was never a problem. Rooms were on the small side but if you want large rooms in this part of Tokyo, you will pay a lot more. The rooms were well enough appointed, spotlessly clean and beautifully cleaned daily. The free wi-fi is also excellent. The rooms at the Ginza were also exceptionally well insulated and we heard no street or inter-room noise at all. The Mercure is not a huge building and can be a little difficult to spot the first time but it is only 5 minutes walk from Exit 13 of Ginza Station and another subway station is right outside but on a different line to Tokyo's main station, requiring one train change. This is simple enough after a couple of days but might challenge some on their first night. We only ate in the restaurant once and whilst the staff were again excellent, the food was only average. There are so many local eating options, that this is not an issue. We are happy to recommend the Mercure Ginza to anyone, although we are unsure if they have family sized rooms.

an good place to stay if you want to be in the ginza district of tokyo. the rooms are a little small (per american standards) but probably big or average for japanese standards. the location is excellent, within easy walking distance to subways and the ginza shopping district. I did not try the restaurant, but my family did and they said the food was good. the service was excellent, the front desk (english speaking) was helpful in providing directions to the tsukiji fish market. we asked for and received adjoining rooms which was very helpful for our family of 5.

Loved the Mecure - was chosen by our travel agent but excellent location in Ginza, we had two different rooms for different parts of our trip - one was quite large the other quite small. It is clean, modern and comfortable. Weird pillows though - soft one side, hard beans the other? don't know what that was about. This hotel is all about location location location - it's a couple of streets behind the main drag in Ginza - check out the food court in the bottom of the Mitzukoshi department store - close to the Ginza metro station giving you access to the Ginza, Marounchi, and Hibaya lines and quite a good place to base yourself from. Our deal included buffet breakfast which was good. There is a train line access through the bottom of the building but not a major line. Lots of good restaurants close by - ask the reception staff for a map.

This mecure is am above average Mecure . The rooms are a good size for tokyo hotels and the price we had (Dec) was good for the time of year. Its handy to several tokyo metro lines especially Hibiya line. JR yurackcho line is a easy 10 mins away. Many good (value) japanese restaurants nearby and because this is a buisness tourist area most have a english menu. Starbucks is 2mins walk away!. Hotel room is a room size, rooms are clean and efficient BUT not good english TV if you care about that (I don't). Staff are extremely helpful and their English quite good. Ive stayed all over Tokyo and recomend this for a buisness person or esp a traveller. Close to Tokyo station for shinkansen trips and easy access to Narita or Haneda airports. Close to shopping , eating and transport..Thumbs up!

This would be the last leg of our 2 week trip to Japan and what a disappointing end!!Mercure Tokyo Ginza was a complete let down especially after a fantastic 4 day stay at Keio Plaza Shinjuku where the service,room size,cleanliness etc were almost perfect.Here at the Mercure,you can hardly swing a cat be it along the aisle, room,reception area entrance etc.The room is so tiny and congested with our luggage on top of it, we virtually had to make our coffee in the bathroom.Most tourists would have a Japan Rail Pass and if I were to do it again, would most certainly stay in a hotel in an outer ward like Shinjuku, or Shibuya, and commute to the Ginza.Oh we'll, you learn from your experience!!!

Unless you speak Japanese, staying in the local hotels can be tough. At the Mercure you can get by quite well with English, so that’s a big plus. The rooms are adequate in size, and large by Japanese standards, very comfortable with all the necessary amenities. The staff are extremely courteous and accommodating, which seems to be the norm in Japan anyway.The Mercure is right in the middle of Ginza, one of the premier shopping precincts in Tokyo. You’re close to the subway system and overland trains, and literally surrounded by hundreds of dining options. If you like upmarket retail then this area is a “must visit”.This hotel is excellent value for money given its location and standards.

We enjoyed our visit to tokyo and stayed @ mercure ginza.they upgraded our reservation.room had enough space.hotel location was very good.we used yurakucho line and ginza line.very easy for looking food and shop till you dropped @ ginza road.The staffs were so helpful especially h.enimoto (if i didn't mistake mention her name).hopefully we can travel to tokyo again.surely, i recommend this hotel.

The Mercure is located in the prime shopping and dining area of Tokyo and is a sensibly priced hotel for a tourist visit. Some other hotels I have used in Tokyo are palatial and are fine for expense account visits on business, but for a self financed tourist visit the Mercure is my preferred option. Major department stores and designer stores are all nearby. The breakfast menu had plenty of choice, and the dinner was fine too but I expect most visitors prefer a nearby authentic Japanese experience for dinner.The hotel has several subway stations within 5 minutes walk which makes its location ideal for accessing other parts of the city. There is free WiFi but we preferred the LAN ethernet cable for the laptop which was a very fast broadband speed. The iPhones didn't work anywhere in Japan which I now find is due to a compatability problem. A special package is needed for phones.

Good location near the high end shopping district. Very quiet rooms and of a good size. Japan is pretty expensive but this was good value for money all things considered. For a westerner the heated toilet seats with spray and bidet options were pretty funny.

Having never visited Toyko previously chosing the hotel was a real punt that fortunately paid off. My preference is for Sofitel, but there is none in Tokyo so we opted to try the Mercure brand from the Accor range, which proved to be an excellent decision. The location is superb, right in the heart of one of Toyko's finest designer shopping districts, Ginza - all the labels are within a few minutes walk of the hotel as are both the JR station and nearest Metro.The hotel itself is a western style facility, being clean, comfortable and from what I understand about Tokyo accomodation quite roomy, albeit somewhat more 'cosy' than we are used to...!! Still it served us well for the 6 nights that we stayed there as most of the time we were out sightseeing.The staff were very welcoming and helpful throught our stay. The only incident we had was with the 'space age' toilet/wc that we discovered are a 'feature' in Japan. You need a pilots license for these Japanese loos and one night ours would not stop continuous flushing, with me getting a full bidet spray in the face when I tried to fix it in the middle of the night, much to my wife's amusement. Aanyway I called reception who sent someone to fix it within minutes, with no problems thereafter...I recommend this hotel to anyone on a limited budget who wants to stay right in the heart of the shopping action - mind you if you're on a limited budget then you won't be shopping much here, the designer prices in Ginza require a mortgage extension..!!

Location is really the best quality of this hotel for the price offered! Absolutely superb ginza shopping area with the famous designers buildings! Metro stations very close, loads of restaurants that you can choose from, breakfast in the hotel is decent, not amazing.

As per hotel's information, it is actually 1 min from one of the Metro station. However, the information does not tell it also only takes 8 minutes from JR Station if you know how to walk. It is also good if you plan to join the Tsukiji market (around 13 min walk).Counter staff was polite as always and spoke Excellent English.

I stayed for four nights and my thoughts are the same as I had on my first visit in December 2012. The location is very good as the hotel is a few blocks away from the main Ginza area. The room itself is conformable but a bit tired but the cleaning staff does an excellent job at servicing the room. The wi-fi is available but very slow. Only BBC news channel and a few French channels and the rest is in Japanese so if your jet lag and want to watch a movie in English, you need to buy a VPOD voucher next to the elevator to do so. The staff are very polite and a big plus for the hotel. I would return in the future as all in all it's a good place to stay with plenty of restaurants in the neighborhood.

My family and I spent some days in Tokyo and decided to stay at the Mercure in the heart of the city: Ginza. It was February, very cold but from the hotel building without going out you can walk directly to the train station: it was really confortable. 2 minutes walking to Ginza Street and to the other train stations. It was easy to reach all points of interests even though we don't speak Japanese as we follow the direction provided by the always kind and professional staff at the reception desk. The room are little but fully equipped with all kind of stuff you may need in an hotel. We strongly suggest this hotel for both tourists and business travellers.

Stayed here for 2 nights and were so happy how this hotel is very convenient! The front desk staff are very fluent in English and also very helpful.The rooms are clean and modern,also spacious enough.Breakfast buffet is just okay,not so plenty to choose from.The hotel is walking distance from the main shopping area. Also a lot of convenience stores,restaurants nearby. Mcdo is 24 hrs and a less than 5 min walk from the hotel if you're craving for fast food. If you want to change your money to yen, there's a exchange bank in Ginza core ( you'll walk past Mitsukoshi,cross the street and you'll see the building) For pinoys,they don't accept peso,only dollars and other currencies.Yurakucho station is 10 mins walk and travel time from Tokyo station to Narita is 1 hour.

Had stayed with my wife for about a week at the hotel, in 2 stays. The hotel is in a good location for shopping and eating and from there, you can take the subway to a lot of attractions easily. Special mention must be given to Ms Kunugi and Ms Fukushima of the front desk. Since check-in, both of them had patiently assisted us with the direction around Ginza and to some of the attractions. They were always so helpful and cheerful. Will stay with the hotel again.

This hotel offers very reasonable accommodation at a fair price in the wonderful Ginza district. It is only a 720 yen fare by taxi from Tokyo station and a pleasant walk to the Tsujiki fish markets. The subway is accessible from the hotel basement. The room was a reasonable size for Tokyo but obviously smaller than USA or Australia. The bed was comfortable, not too hard which some hotels can be in Japan. There was wi-fi available and a movie card could be purchased for 1,000 yen each 24 hours.

I arrived before the check-in time, so I just follow check-in procedure and ask concierge to store our luggage. When come back at the evening, the check-in officer require more than 10 minutes to fix something in the system about my assigned room. It seems the room assigned to me is changed. It is OK anyway since the room meet my expectation. Quite roomy for Tokyo standard, enough amenity, ice-cube machine available not far from my room. WIFI in the room is fast and very useful, can be used for multiple gadget + laptop. Safe deposit box is available.The location is good, right above Ginza-1chome metro station. Within walking distance, there is Highashi-GInza and Ginza-station. You can go anywhere in Tokyo starting from this hotel. McD is in the ground floor, and starbuck and convenience store is next to the hotel. Upon check-out, the coincerge is happy to store our luggage. They are also willing to give one-hour extra for check-out without any charge.

Nicely located in Ginza very close to all the action. Rooms are small but remember you are in Tokyo. They have interconnecting rooms for families. Good value for money. Starbucks 2 minutes walk from hotel so no need to pay breakfast at the hotel. Many convenient stores around and also basements of department stores great places to buy sushi and take it to your room for dinner, specially convenient when you have small kids and they are too tired to go out for dinner. Would definitely come back

An excellent alternative to 5* hotels if you are budget constrained but need more space than cheap business hotels generally provide in Japan. Very well located close to the Ginza line with direct access to Shibuya and Asakusa. You can walk from Tokyo station in 15'. Most important for us: twin bed deluxe room is spacious enough for 2 adults and 2 children. Good general feeling: new, clean, quiet. Good quality mattresses. Even in Ginza, there are plenty of delicious local noodle restaurants. Overall, a very pleasant experience and we warmly recommend it.

Great hotel in Ginza. Well located, near the metro, shops and ginza pedestrian street. Mcdonald and Seven Eleven is located besides the hotel.The room is quite big considering the Japan standard. The twin bed is 120cm ... compare to 90cm in other hotels. Comfortable bed.Highly recommended !

I have to say so many many thanks for the staff at Mercure Tokyo Ginza because of my careless when I stayed there at March 21-23, 2013. I slipped some money worth JPY 40000 or USD 400 in leaflet/brochure. When I checkout from the hotel, I throw that brochure to the garbage bin, and we go... For a couple hours I remember the money in that brochure. I backed to the hotel and the room has already cleaned up. The receiption called the cleaning service and the money back to me in less then 15 minutes. I amazed the honesty of the staffs and the Japanesse generally.fteAfter all I like the hotel because of its location at the luxury of Ginza area especially in spring season where all pedistrian were planted of colorfull flower, the room size, and it attached to the mrt station at the basement.I highly recommended this hotel. Two thumbs for Mercure Tokyo Ginza.

I stayed here as a family of four and without a doubt, this hotel has given us a good memorable experience. The front desk reception was friendly and helpful. The room we ordered was a twin bed and it was large enough beds and very comfortable bedding to accomodate two adults and 2 children age 8 and 4. The facility in the room is also very good, the bathroom also one of the best we found in our stay in Japan in term of size, design and functionality. Heated toilet seat with full electronic water control, its a standard almost in every hotel in Japan. There are plenty of nice cafe and restaurants all within 5-10 minutes walk however if you want something closer and convenient, there is a McDonald just a few metres from the hotel. There is also a subway entrance/exit at the basement of this hotel just in case you didnt know. Ginza experience is unique in Japan, it reminds me of New York Fifth Avenue with the big walkways and giant sized buildings, all the big luxury brand and shopping centers and big roads, truly unique.. This hotel didnt fail to deliver my expectation of its hotel chain standard and I'm a frequent Accor hotel traveller as well. Also dont forget if you travel for a few weeks in Japan with lots of suitcases or rather large ones and you dont want to be carrying it around the train stations/airports or catch two taxis, you can get the hotel to arrange the delivery of the suitcases to your next hotel at a very reasonable price.. (ie 1500-1600 yen per large suitcase from Tokyo to Osaka), it'll work out about the same or cheaper less the pain of moving those suitcases).

This time around, I'd like to stay in Ginza so I searched for a decent hotel that I could afford since Ginza is very very expensive. Mercure seemed to be the best choice.Location - 2 small blocks from main Ginza Street, opposite Channel with LV at the corner. Ginza subway is about 7-10 minute walk. From there, it is easy to get to anywhere in Tokyo. 2 Lawson ( convenient store) on both ends of the hotel. 24 hr. Mc is on ground floor. Access from and to the airport is not very convenient if you have a big luggage. You either take the NEX then taxi or airport bus to Marriott Courtyard then taxi.Hotel - small access from ground floor to the small 2nd floor lobby. Ok decor.Room - small but not tiny, big for the price in Ginza. I booked a double for single use and I felt comfortable in the room. Since it is in the center so there's no nice view even from my room on the top floor, just the wall of the opposite side building. Nice decor, very functional with everything you need, very clean, the safe is big enough for iPad. Free wifi.Staff - polite and willing to help as all in the Japanese hotels I've been to, no problem using English, they booked my friends and me (5) a cheaper taxi to Narita than the one in the internet. I would recommend this hotel highly.

this hotel is located in a great location of Tokyo, surrounded by high end shops and department stores - great if you even want to just window shop! There are also lots of local cafes to enjoy an affordable breakfast and grab a good coffee. It is also within walking distance of the subway. Staff were really nice and helpful in providing maps and things to see in this great city. We will definetely staff here again.

I stayed here to meet up with an old university friend for a blokes weekend. The hotel is relatively close to tokyo station (short cab ride) and is located in a nice area of the city. The hotel is close to many bars and restaurants and was safe at night walking around the area. It's also fairly close to a number of metro stations i.e. a 5 minute walk. The room was nice with a pleasant Japanese feel to the decor and I had a decent nights sleep. Rooms were comparatively spacious from the others I experienced in Japan. The hotel did not have room service but did have a European buffet in the bar area. The buffet is not too bad but best for when you don't want to venture too far, otherwise venture out into Tokyo. Staff were characteristically lovely and welcoming.Overall the hotel is good and I would recommend it, however its worth noting that Ginza is a very experience part of Tokyo and we rapidly found that bar bills of £100 for a couple of rounds of drinks (couple of pints, couple of shots) was pretty standard (pints in the £15 each or so). So be prepared to travel to other areas or have a dent in your bank account.

Booked 4 nights with Accor and used the card for breakfasts. A little hotel on a corner. The room was a good size had a desk and armchair. Bathroom was large and well equiped. It felt homely and it was extremely quiet never heard anyone. Free wifi in the rooms (essential) It has a French restaurant serving outstanding food. The breakfasts were excellent and of high quality. The staff were patient and accommodating they sent out luggage to the airport for us. So happy to have selected this hotel, the location was amazing most beautiful stores and streets. We will definately be returning.

I love the location of this hotel. It is just two blocks away from the main Ginza shopping strip but, very peaceful and quiet in this area. There are several convenient stores that sells almost everything that you will need for your stay including food. What is nice about the area are the local restaurants that serve tempura sets, udon and soba noodles, curry, tonkatsu and yakitori at very reasonable prices. If you are tired of eating all these Japanese food, there is a Mc Donald's store right beside the hotel. The rooms are well maintained and clean. The size of the room is comfortable considering that the rooms in Tokyo are generally smaller. Close to the train stations, a few blocks away from the JR line and the Tokyo station.

Nice sized rooms with good Beds. Make sure you don't get on a floor above a smoking floor, it leaks through the place and stinks. Ginza is a great location to be in for the buzz of Tokyo and easy access to everywhere. Lacks a good variety of restaurants though.

This hotel is hidden in a back street, the room are quite large for Tokyo and very well maintain. We spend 5 nights, the service each day was perfect and all the staff very friendly.The breakfast room has limited seats, best to go early if you do not want to wait.

Every time I visit Tokyo I stay at the Mercure Ginza. I just love the location. With a subway station down in the basement, Ginza shopping a few meters away and Tokyo station not far...perfect location.

I visited Tokyo in Dec 2012 and Feb 2013 and stayed at the Mercure Tokyo Ginza both times. This hotel is conveniently located in the heart of Ginza and within walking distance of several major subway stations including the Ginza Station. In addition, the friendly staff at the hotel will provide help giving you directions to the subway stations as well as tourists attractions within the area, which of course includes the Tsukiji Fish Market.Most of the staff speaks English. So, if you can't converse in Japanese, language is definitely not an issue when staying at this hotel.The rooms are small but comfortable. Housekeeping is good and everything in the room is clean and functional. Complimentary free wifi is provided at the lobby for guests. Also, complimentary copies of the International Herald Tribune and the Asahi Shimbun newspapers are provided at every floor on a daily basis while stocks last!If you are looking for a good and centrally located hotel in Tokyo at a reasonable price, pick the Mercure Tokyo Ginza. You can't go wrong with this choice.

I have stayed at the Mercure Tokyo Ginza hotel three times. Once on a previous trip, and twice on the last one. It is very close to the Ginza district and within walking distance of Tokyo Station, which means that it is also accessible by the Keisi Sky Liner to and from Narita Airport. The Mercure hotel chain is owned by a French multinational corporation, Accor, and this influence is apparent in the hotel restaurant for breakfast and dinner - both of which are quite good. The rooms are decent sized for accommodations in Japan, but they vary a bit with the price. Naturally, the price also varies with the day of the week and the season, so try to stay in mid-week and away from holidays. The hotel seems to cater to western clientele. The desk staff speak English well and can be quite helpful.

If you want to be in the heart of Tokyo then the Mercure Ginza is the place to be. Great access to the Subway and within easy walking distance to every thing else. While the rooms are on the small size by west standards they are clean and tidy with a good bathroom.  The staff are excellent and food in the restaurant is more than acceptable.In short we enjoyed our stay so much we have booked to return in May.

Although not the newest hotel around, this hotel's convenient location is what will bring me back. If you want to shop & eat at Ginza and do not have the money for the 5 star hotels near Yurakocho Station, then this hotel is recommended. I walked there from Tokyo Station & it only took about 15-20 minutes. The hotel is also right next to a subway station with two excellent convenience stores directly across the street. Department stores and literally hundreds of good restaurants are within 5 minutes stroll (Henri Charpentier's salon du the & Joe's Shanghai Dumplings are within 20 meters!). Check-in was fast & efficient. The room, while compact, was clean & comfortable. The old elevators with their analog indicators were really charming!

Well the hotel rate is high compare to what you get. The rooms are small and the bathroom is too tiny.Besides the staff was friendly which help to keep the experience above average. However, I will not consider it should I come back to Tokyo.

A great hotel in a great location. We stayed for 3 nights in December and the staff are very friendly and helpful. The rooms are a good size compared to some other hotels in Japan and are good value for money. We found the subway under the hotel very handy. The Manager must be complimented for his hands on attitude. On this occasion and on one of our earlier stays he took time out of his busy schedule to enquire if we had enjoyed our stay. Also, he informed us that the free wifi available in the lobby will be availabe in the rooms soon which wil make this hotel even better. This was our 4th visit and will definetly stay at this hotel next time we go to Tokyo.

Stayed for 2 nights during business and leisure trip. Mercure Ginza was a great base for my time in japan. The concierge was super helpful with bookings of restaurants and activities. The rooms are spacious compared to other rooms in Tokyo. And the bathroom is great! The rooms have excellent ammonites and pretty much everything u need. There's a direct connection to the metro station in the basement. But I usually walk to the main Ginza station to grab the trains. The area around the hotel has convenience stores and very nice and quaint breakfast spots. There is also a Macdonald (24hours) located around the corner. Although it says that free wifi is only available in the lobby, I was able to get a signal on the 11th floor, they probally installed access points on each floor. Great hotel, worth reviewing and worth going back!

We travelled with our 7 year old daughter to Tokyo in November. We chose this hotel because we have stayed at other Accor Hotels in Europe. The hotel is in a fantastic location in the heart of Ginza. Easy access to subway station and main shopping in Ginza is just around the corner.The hotel is very clean and the staff is wonderful. The rooms are small but this is Japan. The only complaint I have is that there is no WIFI in the rooms. To use WIFI you have to go down into the lobby area. We tried the breakfast on our last day and it was fantastic. We should have taken advantage of it throughout our entire stay. Great location, great value!! I would definitely return!!

We normally stay at the Park Hotel, Shimabshi in Tokyo but decided to stay right in Ginza for four nights on this recent visit.First, we must say that the staff at the Mercure Ginza were excellent - obliging and helpful at all times. And, the location of this hotel in Ginza is very good.The problem was the room. The Mercure Ginza's website shows two different rooms and offers two room choices - superior (standard) or deluxe. The room photos did not offer any other information to identify the room types. It is reasonable to assume that the photos were of these two types. I chose a deluxe room and paid the additional fee for it (bringing the cost to around AUD$300 a night). However, on arrival, we were shown to a tiny, totally unappealling room. I returned to reception and was advised that the photo of the better room on the website was actually the suite, of which there is only one in the hotel, not offered to foreigners, and was not available. So, why are the room photos of it on the website??? If the photos of the lesser room were the 'deluxe' room, than the website was not showing any photos of the standard 'superior' rooms.We were moved to another marginally bigger and better laid out room but it was still subfar below expectation. As far as I can tell, the superior and deluxe rooms are not different (other than some nominal differences one expects due to floor layouts). The extra charge for a "deluxe" room is for wifi (which should be free anyway and fell out constantly) and for the inclusion of an acceptable but mediocre breakfast. The promise on the website of international TV channels (BBC, CNN, and TV5) turned out to only be a not very clear BBC World. No CNN, no TV5.I again reitierate that the staff were wonderful. The hotel was clean, the bed comfortable, and would ahve been acceptable if one was expecting a standard 3 star hotel. My gripe is the totally deceptive marketing.

We stayed for 3 nights. Mecure is located near 3 subway stations. Coming from Haneda Int'l Airport, we alighted at Higashi-Ginza which is just about 5 mins walk away even with luggages. (We took Keikyu Line and it was a direct train I remember- the train staff will tell you when the direct train arrives or you can check online). The Ginzaitchome Line to Disneyland /Sea is even easier. Go to the basement of the hotel and walk to the station. To the Ginza station (near Matsuya shopping mall) its about 7 mins walk- if not distracted by all the malls and shops)- the various lines bring you to all parts of Tokyo. McDonalds is located below the hotel which is convenient for a quick bite. We upgraded ourselves to a Deluxe Twin (2A & 2C) with free breakfast Y4400/night paid together with our Accor free nights, which is worth it. The hotel staff is also polite and helpful. We left 2 luggages for 6 days before coming back to retrieve them and they didn't say a word. Highly recommend this hotel!

My friend and I stayed at Mercure Ginza during your trip in Tokyo in November. The hotel has a great location in Ginza, close to Matsuya shopping mall, Louis Vuitton, Chanel and Apple Store (it has free WiFi). I love shopping so I did enjoy walking from my hotel to those malls, even further to the world's largest Uniqlo, Dover Street Market where they sell Comme des Garcons, and Hankyu Men (near Yurakucho JR station) where they only sell chic men fashion items. The hotel is around five to seven minute walk from Ginza metro station (exit 13 if I remember it right), so you can get around Tokyo easily on Ginza Line. There's a metro station (can't remember the name, should be Ginza Itchome or something) underneath the hotel, too, but that train line goes to lesser known places you don't normally travel to. A bit useless. The room was comfy yet compact, but that's normal for Tokyo where everything is crazily expensive. Everything was on hand. We got a queensize bed with clean sheet, tv, air condition (and heater), a desk, a daybed, a proper wardrobe and boiler. The bathroom is compact but comfy. Of course we got a bathtub and a japanese style washlet. One thing I love very much about the bathroom is that they alway warm the mirror so it doesn't get fogged after you take a hot shower - small detail but really impressed.There's one restaurant on the second floor, opposite the lobby. There's one McDonald's on the first floor of the building too. It opens 24 hours. There are two Lawson convenient stores nearby. You won't be left starving, of course.Too bad the free WiFi is available at lobby only, with one laptop (connected to internet) for hotel guests.

Yes the hotel is expansive but that is Tokyo. Also keep in mind that Ginza is the most known and expansive shopping area. So I think it is still worth the money you pay. Overall the hotel has nicer rooms than the normal Mercure hotels. My room had even two king size beds - which gives you a lot of space for a japanese Hotel. Free and fast (cable) internet. The entry is a bit hidden, follow the instruction which are posted on the Internet or at most travel guide books. For sure a top pick.Hotel has direct access to tube station within the basement. Staff is helpful, very good english.

A decent hotel near a number of shops. Entrance is not on the main street, so it might be a little tricky to find at first. Check-in was efficient with english speaking staff. Room was a little small, but not unusual in Tokyo. Hotel offered complimentary wifi at the lobby on level 2 and in room wired internet.

Stayed here for 3 nights while in Tokyo for a business trip. Great location, clean and nice (small, as everything in Tokyo!) rooms with all necessary amenities as well as a good free internet (cable) connection. Expereinced some problems setting up the airco/heating as display was only in Japanese, but once I sorted it out, it worked fine.As fara as I am concerned: an excellent price/value ratio!

Stayed at the Mercure hotel for 4 nights while in Tokyo for business. Stayed at this hotel because the Marriott Courtyard was sold out. Overall, the hotel was fine - clean, modern rooms and good location. But if you like more space, stay elsewhere. From what I understand, this is a little bigger than a standard room in Tokyo, but not much. And watch that step up into the bathroom - it really hurts to trip on it in the middle of the night when you forget it is there, trust me! Oh, and if you want to watch TV during your downtime, forget it....2 channels in English and neither one was an American station.....everything else in Japanese. Also, no fitness center. The staff were friendly and helpful with everything, so definitely a point for that. Would likely stay there again, but only for a short stay and only if the Courtyard is not available.

We picked a hotel in tokyo based on location, and were very pleased with the mercure hotel.The location was indeed good: close to ginza brand street, a lot of restaurants closeby, basement connection to the subway or 5 minute walk to another line, and 20 minute walk to tokyo train station. The welcome was smooth, friendly and efficient. Any request for directions or recommendations was done very well, in perfect english. Breakfast buffet was good, with a larger then usual western selection, which we though was good. we did not try the restaurant, so I cannot comment on that part. The rooms were clean, and well kept and for a business user large enough. there was wired internet connection in the room and wifi in the lobby. I personnaly preffer wifi in room as well, as with many smartphones/ipad, wifi connection to connect to home is convenient and a wire just doesn't cut it then. that was the only thing I could find to improve on the rooms. There is no fitness/pool, but I guess taht is rare is a town where place is costly.Overall I enjoyed my stay in the mercure hotel in ginza and was glad I selected it

I travelled to Tokyo for a couple of time. Most of the time I stayed at a hotel in Shinjuku area. This time, I stayed at Mercure Hotel Ginza Tokyo in mid November 2012. This stay made me feel better than any time.From Narita airport, I traveled using NEX train to Tokyo station and walked to the hotel. It was okey to do so and took about 20 mins to reach the hotel. The hotel receptionist was helpful. The check-in time was at 14:00 but we could kept a luggage(s) at the hotel with no problem.The location of the hotel is very close to the main shopping street at Ginza area. Also one of the metro line is located at the hotel ground floor. Alternatively, we could walk through the main street, enjoy sight-seeing and reached at Ginza station within 10-15 mins. This was enjoyable. Nearby the hotel, a lot of Japanese restuarants, convenient stores and fastfood restuarant are located within 5 mins walking distance. This was impressed me.The room size was standard compare to the same room rate hotels and typical for Tokyo area. The room was clean without any bad smell. Hotel's amenities were reasonable. Free coffee & tea were available in the room. An ice maker was located one on each floor.Breakfast was in a standard range compare to other hotels at the same price range in Tokyo area. I could enjoy the breakfast with no complaint. For the same room rate, this hotel is recommended.Overall, I would definitely come back and stay at this hotel again in the future. Ginza area is one of my best favourite area in Tokyo.
user_name:
Anucha T
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed five nights at the Mercure Ginza. The hotel is located in the heart of Ginza and all the hustle and bustle of Ginza and shopping only a short stroll away. The area is also well covered with 24h corner shops which will provide you with all the essentials.Check in was delayed as my room was not ready at midday. The deluxe room I had booked was large with a small seating area and a desk for working and a mini bar and tea/coffee facilities. The bathroom was clean and tidy and featured all the typical amenities. WiFi was free but service was slow and unreliable. The hotel uses a very strange room deodoriser which is way too strong and takes quite some time getting used to.Breakfast was decent and varied (western and japanese). Staff were friendly throughout. As is typical at Mercure there was zero recognition for Le Club Accorhotels Platinum members, which is a shame and an opportunity missed.Room rates are on the high side for Mercure. Would I return? Yes

very modern, clean and polite staff.there is a good french restaurant in there, dont, miss it.it,s near to every were, easy acces to the metro.the price is high, as every thing in Tokyo, we choose a good hotel to feel safe.

We 2 adults 2 children age 10(twins!) stayed for two nights. 2 rooms. Very comfortable, clean, contemporary yet still sympathetic to Japanese style. Complementary toiletries and slippers/gown. Rooms quite spacious considering the comments other reviewers have made about hotel rooms in Tokyo being small...Easy to find-just look up as well HUGE purple mercure on side of building. Really excellent selection at breakfast. Tasted like "real" scrambled eggs!! Downside wifi only in reception and breakfast. But I managed to hook into a ramdom one ? We actually just walked from train station to the hotel- we were in no rush and arrived at commuter time so felt it was probably easier to meander along rather than sit in a taxi in traffic. We also got up at 330am and went to the tuna auction. Again this was just a 15 minute walk and easy to find. Saw the first auction, then back for breakfast then bed again!!!! I was delighted at choosing this hotel. It provided a very very comfortable base to explore Tokyo from, either on foot or by metro.

We chose this hotel for our last night in Tokyo becuase of the location. The hotel is about $10 AUD from Tokyo station by taxi so very affordable. The hotel is within walking distance of all the glitz of the Ginza district main streets - so much to see, do and shopping is great. The staff are very focused on customer service and were able to help direct me to a particular store which I had to visit - being a non Japanese speaking person, this request turned out to be easier than I thougth. Very helpful staff. The breakfast was good and the room and bathroom both were a decent size. Our room didnt have a good view, but we were only there for 1 night and not focused on the view.

We stayed here for 3 nights in a superior twin room. The room was fairly spacious by Japanese standards and the beds are softer than most. The bathroom is also quite spacious, though a little dated, it was very clean. Because it's a French run hotel, it didn't have green tea or slippers like Japanese run hotels, but there was coffee and robes instead. Location is close to busy shopping area of Ginza but not so close that it's noisy, it's actually fairly quiet and we slept well. Very close to subways, the hotel is actually above a station.

very good service, nice staff very close to the metro lines also interesting, just around the corner a belgian beer pub FAVORIgood facilities , free internet in the roommy next trip to Tokyo, i will stay again in this hotel

I stayed for a business trip and also took few days for personal trip to see the city . The location is very good at the heart of business district -it actually has metro station underneath the hotel , and many stations near by, so it's very easy to get anywhere in Tokyo.The room are spacious very clean and nicely decorated - I loved the bathroom!Good breakfast, very nice staff , free Wi-Fi available only in Lobby (cable in room also free).

This hotel is in a very central location in Ginza. Although the hotel can be quite hard to find down side streets. Slightly larger rooms than usual in Japan. Clean and modern with a good breakfast selection. Our room was on a lower floor so we got the WI FI from the lobby in our room. Would stay here again.

Great location in the Ginza area, excellent service, yummy breakfast buffet, rooms that are a little larger than the traditional Japanese accomodations. European decor and style. The staff members all seemed to speak English, which was helpful for us!

If you don't need to impress your customers or your partner (girlfriend or boyfriend ) , if you don't care about the hotel lobby size or to the view from your room than this is the perfect hotel for you.Rooms are big size for Japanese standards , the breakfast buffet is good and the location of the hotel is one of the best in Tokyo ( few meters away from Ginza) . The hotel is priced reasonably (about 170 euro) it is clean and the staff is helpful. I didn't give 4 stars due to the lack of WiFi in the rooms ( but available for free in the restaurant and lobby.If you like jogging, the hotel is about 1.5 km from the imperial palace , where there is a 5.5 km running trail.

We recently stayed here with our family of five in two separate rooms. We booked this last minute and couldn't get interconnecting rooms but they are available. The rooms are really small but clean and tidy. The reception staff were really helpful and spoke great English. We were there in July and it was extremely hot (35 degrees every day and very humid). We decided to go to a waterpark but all websites were in Japanese and the reception staff were great at translating these for us. The location of this hotel is fantastic - it is very near the main Tokyo train station, so it is very easy to get to from the airport. You can walk to the Fish Market and the Imperial Palace Gardens, and catch subway trains to anywhere else. The Ginza area is gorgeous - extremely expensive with upmarket boutiques (Tokyo's 5th Avenue equivalent) - Harry Winstons/Tiffanys/Chanel etc. The side streets are tree-lined with lots of restaurants and convenience stores. It is immaculately clean and feels very safe. "Lawson" were great convenience stores with some English labelled food and you could find bananas, yoghurt, milk etc.I would definitely stay in this hotel again and would highly recommend staying in Ginza.

Very good hotel in the Ginza shopping district. Lovely rooms, free wifi, good breakfastThe staff were exceptionally helpful and the service was very good. The staff did all they could to make the stay enjoyableWould definitely stay there again

Fantastic location only 1 block back from the main block of Ginza. Hotel Is surrounded by bars, shops and restaurants. Rooms are adequate, breakfast is good. Staff most professional. Rooms are a little tired and the lack of wireless Internet and English television programs was disappointing.

Hotel i regular quality but in an excellent location comparing with the cost.You can enter subway directly from hotel elevator!Ginza street, the most fancy shopping in Tokyo is 2 min. away by walk.Staff speaks decent English.Breakfast is both Japanese and western so fitting to everyone's taste.Recommendation: try restaurant called Tapas & Tapas which serves very good food and has fast acting and smiling personnel. Just get out of the hotel, turn right and then right again.Prices are moderate and quality is great. Went there with my family and kids every day!

We scored this room for just over a hundred bucks a night and it was a great base to explore Tokyo after more traditional and tiny accommodation in other cities. We were initially looking for the Tokyo central station area but hotels are all expensive there - Ginza isn't a bad consolation prize.It's known for its pricey department stores - and even though we had little interest in those, we still found it a great location. Staff were polite, as you'd expect at this level of hotel.Sightseeing/Attractions Tip: Careful that the nearest subway station does not take you to Tokyo central or even the main Ginza station, but Ginza itchome. It's the only drawback to the location, which otherwise was great - very close to the JR Yurakcho station (which is just one from Tokyo Central).

Ginza is one of my most favorite areas in Tokyo and Mercure (mare-cu-ray in Japanese pronunciation) Ginza is perfect for me.The staffs are very nice and helpful. Although there's one thing i didn't really like about this hotel is the guest room and bathroom interior. I could see that they did some touch-ups to it recently but red isn't my cup of tea. I sure will consider staying here again in my next trip.

After months of exhausting research and trawling through TA forums, I finally found this hotel (actually through a Google search of hotels with connecting rooms). We have a 7 year old and we didn't want to be sleeping in a small Tokyo hotel room, all over each other. But he's too small to have his own room, so connecting rooms were perfect! And the price was affordable (for Tokyo). They connect a queen with a twin room, so you get a good sized double bed in one room and two large singles in the other. You could accommodate a family of four comfortably. The hotel is in a great neighbourhood. Just on the cusp of posh Ginza, so great shopping (or window shopping) abounds. We took the airport limousine, which dropped us off at Tokyo Station, about a 5 minute walk away. But we got a wee bit lost getting there because streets have no names!! Thank goodness for the smart-phone GPS. It's a business hotel really, but you won't feel out of place because lots of people have cottoned on to it as a nicely located, affordable hotel. The reception staff were very nice and spoke English well. The rooms were really good. Small by international standards, but well designed. Take compact luggage to Japan, it's easier to store and to move around. Having two rooms meant we could wedge the door open and voila! A mini apartment! The bathrooms had a touch of Japan about them; screen door, spray toilet, deep bath, baskets for clothes; but all well designed and as always - efficient. The decor was nice - but it's a shame the wall paper is an English country scene when it could be Japan! But never mind, it was scrupulously clean, with just a few scuff marks on the walls.
