Each room had a mini fridge (with a few snacks you could buy), hot water kettle, a few tea sachets, glasses and cups/saucers. No microwave, which would have been good. Your room includes breakfast, but we were getting up early and wanted to eat brekkie in our PJ's so we bought delicious croissants every evening from the Lawsons across the road, along with mini- jams and butter, and ate them with a cuppa tea at our desk/table in comfort every morning! We ate dinner in the neighborhood, or at Tokyo Station - all the stations in Tokyo have fabulous restaurants in them. One night we walked the streets, on a gorgeous balmy evening, going down all the side streets in Ginza looking for a restaurant, and for some reason we couldn't find one that suited. We turned left down a tiny street, then right, then took two lefts and were thoroughly (but happily) lost when we found a cheap and cheerful noodle house, with champon and chanton (bowls of noodles with veges and meat if you want). We had a great meal, and then left, fully expecting to use the GPS to get home to the hotel, and what did we find? The Mercure was just a few metres down the road!! One more thing about the room. We were there for 4 nights. When we left, I stuffed a bag of bathroom toiletries in my luggage to take home. When I weighed it at home, it was nearly 2kg! Have fun.

It is a functional hotel at a very location! Travelling to the Airport in the morning was fine. We had stayed at the ANA a previous time, which although a much better hotel, the location was not great.The location has plenty of places to eat breakfast etc.

My son and I had to attend a seminar at a site on theYurakucho subway line so we looked for a hotel on the same subway line. We chose the Mercure Ginza and were not dissapointed. Our room was a deluxe twin and was quite large. certainly spacious enough for a week's stay. While the price was mid range, it was still less than what we have paid in lesser hotels. The facilities and room appointment were clean and comfortable. The breakfast selection was very good with both hot and cold as well as western and Japaneses choices. The rooms have small minibars but there is sufficient space in the refrigerator to store your own stuff. Despite being the middle of summer, the airconditioning was very effective.The location was very convenient with major Department stores only a short walk away. Despite the location, there are a number of comvenience stores close to the hotel allowing you to dine on the cheap if you want. Fast food outlets including Macdonalds and Starbucks are within a stone's throw of the hotel as well as a huge variety of restaurants.It is easy to get around as it is close to the subway. To reach the hotel from Tokyo station, just take the Yamanote line one stop to YurakuchoJR station then follow the signs to the Yurakucho subway station on the Yurakuchu line. Catch the subway one stop to Ginza Ichachome then follow the signs to exit 11. There you will see a door leading into the Mercure without having to go up onto the street. A word of warning though. Make sure your luggage is easily portable as there are a number of steps you need to go up and down.

We had two rooms in the Mecure Ginza to accomodate our family and used the hotel as a base for several days as we explored Tokyo. It's in a great location in Ginza, with a wide array of restaurants and convenience stores nearby, and some fast food options close too. It's literally around the corner from the main Ginza shopping street where you'll find stores like Tiffany & Co, Chanel, Prada etc along with several Japanese Department stores. The food halls in these Department stores are well worth a look as they seem to offer everything from simple (but outstanding) sushi to amazing cakes and sweets.As other reviewers have stated there is a subway station accessible under the hotel but it only provides access to the Yurakucho line which is of limited value to tourists unless you want to visit the Imperial Palace. For better subway options a short walk to either the Ginza station where you can access 3 different and very useful subway lines or the Higashi-Ginza station where you can access 2 lines including the Asakusa line are better options.The facilities in the Mercure are fairly basic for a hotel of this price bracket. There is no gym or pool, nor a business centre. It does have a small but functional reception area and a restaurant & bar. Wired internet access is provided in each room with wi-fi only available in the reception and surrounding area. (We rented a portable 4g Wifi device for our stay in Japan and this proved to be very convenient and useful.) There are ice machines located on each floor.The rooms we had were small, with one slightly larger than the other, but with space at such a premium in Tokyo we were not surprised. The rooms provided all that we needed with a small mini-bar fridge, desk, television and nice bathroom. They were spotlessly clean and the staff at the Mercure kept them that way throughout our stay.The reception staff were excellent, and the ones that we encountered all spoke good English. They were helpful and efficient, providing good advice and directions when needed. They were happy to store luggage upon arrival and leaving, and to arrange taxis for transit to the T-CAT terminal.Overall the Mercure Ginza provides a very good base to explore Tokyo, with it's location and convenient access to restaurants, shops and the subway standing out.

Good hotel in Ginza area. Very conveniently located. Near Ginza-Itchome train station so mobility around tokyo is easy. Price is on quite high compare to several hotels nearby but with a much bigger room. There is a nice japanese restaurant at the same building (ground floor) that sell sushi on rice such as chirashi sushi, etc with a great value.... overall a good stay in mercure Ginza.

Locating the hotel was relatively easy coming in from Haneda Airport and getting off at Tokyo Station. While there's a station (Ginza Itchome) right beneath the hotel, it wasn't on a convenient line as far as major tourist attractions are concerned. However, a short 10-minute walk away you will find the more accessible Higashiginza and Yurakucho stations. The hotel is a 12-15 minute walk away from Tsukuji Market and will be useful for those want to be there in time for the tuna auction.Check in and out was without stress. Room size was good when compared to most other hotels in Tokyo. Can't really say much about the view as we were looking out at the building next door (on the 4th floor).One complaint would be that a space right next to the hotel entrance doors have been designated as a smoking space (Ginza is generally a non-smoking area) so it's rather unpleasant for non-smokers when walking past this area to get to the hotel doors.The front desk staff were helpful and fluent in English.

If location was the main factor to judge a hotel, then i seems most people who wrote something about this hotel gave it an excellent rating. I question, however, if this is justified. Looking at the hotel without taking the location into consideration - it is really just an average if not below average hotel. The rooms are very small (maybe large per Japanese standards?), and the amenities/decorations in the hotel and rooms are not more than average as well. As far as location goes - when you are coming to Tokyo for business for a very short stay, is the location really that important? Although a big city, the transporation system of Tokyo is so good, you are probably within a half hour away from wherever you want to be. Then the question is - is the area of the hotel - being the Ginza area, really so great? Yes, there are a lot of very fancy brand shops very close by, but is that what one is looking for in the short free time one has. I believe there are even better areas in Tokyo for restaurants/night life in the vicinity. For this reason, I can not really give this hotel more than an average rating.
user_name:
Alan D
The Hague, The Netherlands

review_body: I arrived straight from the airport via the subway and got out at Tokyo station and straight into a taxi, but the hotel is nestled in a little side street and the driver did not know where it was, so what should have been a five minute ride turned into a bit of an ordeal. But once found, the room was bigger than average for Japan and my husband and I certainly had enough room. Staff were obliging, breakfast was adequate.

My friend and I stayed here for 6 nights when we visited Tokyo for the first time in April 2012. We stayed on the Ladies Floor which has an added level of security. The location of the hotel is great if you are planning on visiting Tsukiji Market (it's a short cab ride away) and we could connect to many other areas in Tokyo via the subway which links directly to the hotel. The room is very clean and bigger than I would have expected for a hotel in Japan. We previously stayed in a hotel in Osaka which involved lots of elbow-bumping in the toilet! (And mind you we are rather petite Asian girls so that says a lot...) Highly recommended!

Having stayed at a highly rated hotel in Kyoto we could hardly wait to get back to the Mercure .The room was a good size for us two , the front desk couldn't have been more helpful ,the food was very good ,the location was great ( though the taxi had a little trouble finding it , why we don't know ) .Close by there were excellent restaurants , for which the desk has a map , also were well-stocked convenient stores and there was a great little bar (" Nelson's" ) just around the corner . You're 10mins from Ginza Station and another one is under the hotel . We wouldn't stay anywhere else ( and it was a fair bit cheaper than the aforementioned Kyoto hotel, too ). Oh , and the glamourous main drag of Ginza is 5mins away .

Have stayed here three times now as it is such a good base in Tokyo. You can often get specials with 3 nights for the price of 2 but even without that it is a very reasonably priced room for Tokyo. Rooms aren't huge but they are modern and clean. The location is great, metro stations close by (ginza line better than Ginza Itchome), heaps of restaurants and amazing shopping.Room air conditioning can be a bit of a challenge to work out but if you follow the exact images on the instructions then you do get there eventually.

The room was not huge,none are in Tokyo, but it was very comfortable, clean and nicely decorated. We had a double business room. I think it would be fair to say it is a business style room and hotel. There is a bar and French restaurant but we did not eat there as we wanted to discover some Japanese cuisine.See http://www.iatr.com.au/?p=1292 for more of this review.

Very good location. 2 minutes’ walk from Ginza street and 5 minutes from Ginza subway station. Lots of restaurants , form very expensive to very cheap you find it all at 5 minutes from Hotel. Only problem is the Wifi available only in the lobby. In the rooms only the old fashion internet cables !!

Ideally situated for a short stay in Tokyo. The hotel is above one subway line and a short walk to a major subway station,Ginza.The reception staff were all excellent,very professional and extremely helpful. The rooms are on the small side but very clean and functional. The breakfast is quite good but area is small and can get very busy. The hotel has an estimated wait time depending on the hour. During a seven day stay we experienced only one wait.

Ginza is renown for its shopping and this hotel is only a few minute walk from the main street. Close to public transport - there is actually access to one of the subway stations in the basement of the hotel. Clean decent sized rooms with a nice bathroom. Free wired internet is available in the rooms and free wifi in the reception area.
user_name:
Nel U
Oakdale, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: Situated at ginza area, the rooms are rather small but all together a good hotel. They serve a good breakfast. The subway is also not far from the hotel.
Srrvice was very professional as an upper business class hotel. Clean and comfortable accommodation. The location cannot be better if you want to shop and brows in GInza. Good value for money.

We stayed at this hotel from May 16-19, 2012 and we felt like coming back again. Accessible from Metro Train station, high end shopping area and mostly very friendly and helpful staffs at the reception. One of the staff help us booked our full day Tokyo tour and he arranged everything for us. He also speaks English well. Our Limousine bus transfer was also arranged by them. Kudos to their front desk staff all of them are helpful.

We arrived at this hotel via the Yurakucho subway train line and found that there is an entrance to the hotel directly from Ginza Itchome station without going out to the street. An elevator takes you directly to the lobby. Check in was simple and assisted by friendly English-speaking reception staff. Our room was not as small as you come to expect in Tokyo and very nicely decorated. As usual in Japanese hotels, there was a small module-type bathroom. Internet access is free in the room via a wire provided in the desk drawer. There is also free wi-fi access in the lobby and a laptop available for guest use.We ate lunch and breakfast in the restaurant and both were good quality at reasonable prices, again the staff were multi-lingual and helpful.The department stores of Ginza ar only two minutes' walk away so easy to get back to the hotel with heavy bags.The hotel is mid price for Tokyo and good value.

I always stay here when I visit Tokyo. It's near my office, close to the shopping district, and next to a McDonalds (a lifesaver when you need a break from the marvelous japanese food). Walking distance to the imperial gardens and a good bookstore too. As is typical with the Japanese, the hospitality is perfect, the rooms are always perfect, although small and expensive.

Hotel Mercure Ginza is not a Ritz-Carlton but it is a perfectly adequate modest tourist-class hotel in the heart of Ginza. Located on a quiet but central and easy to find street provides all basic comforts most short-term visitors would need. Rooms are smallish but clean and functional. Our room had a safe and a free cable internet connection (Ethernet cable is available free of charge in each room). Wireless internet is available in the lobby. There is no street noise and the beds are comfortable. Tea and coffee are provided in the room along with the electric kettle. There are at least four subway stations within a ten minute walk from the hotel with one of them (I believe Ginza-Itchome) right outside the hotel. It takes fifteen minutes to walk to the hotel from Tokyo main railway station. Two inexpensive convenience stores are located at each end of the short street and there is a MacDonald’s restaurant within the same block .Reception staff speaks good English and there is a breakfast buffet available in the hotel restaurant. Free International Herald Tribune is available daily and your toilet seat is heated! Minor drawback was the air conditioning with controls labeled in Japanese characters. Despite basic English instructions that did come with it we could never set it up correctly. Consequently the room was uncomfortably warm at night and one couldn’t open the windows.

I recommend staying at this hotel. It is excellently located in Ginza, which is a very upmarket area of Tokyo. It is centrally located and therefore it is easy to get to any of the sights in Tokyo from here. There is a subway station in the basement, however this is not on a very convenient line. There are two other subway stations very close by, Ginza is the most convenient. It is so close that we actually walked there with our luggage when it came time to go home, and the information boards in Ginza Station tell you in English which exit you need to use to get to the hotel. All of this means that what ever sights you have decided you want to see in Tokyo, they are easy to get to from here. Just so you know here is some of what we visited and roughly how long it took from the hotel door, Disneyland - about 30 minutesSenso-Ji Temple - about 20 minutesShibyua - About 20 minutesso as you can see nowhere is really going to be more than about a 45 minute subway ride away. There are a couple of local 7/11 type shops near by which sell water and coke, sweets etc, which are cheaper than the mini bar, there is a Mcdonalds next door, and a few very good coffee shops/cafes in the street the hotel is in. In the next few streets are plenty of eating and drinking spots. The staff at the hotel recommended a sushi bar to us which was fantastic, it was called Bikkuri Sushi Ginza and I definitely recommend eating thee at least once.The room itself was very nice, it was clean and well appointed, not that big, but then you are in the centre of Tokyo so what do you expect. The bathroom was very clean and well appointed, the most advanced toilet I have ever seen!! It had a dial to change the temperature of the seat!There was free internet via a provided ethernet cable in the room and free wifi in the lobby. We didnt eat at the restaurant, breakfast or dinner, because there are so many other good spots to eat around, so I can't comment on the food. Just so you know who is submiting this reveiw, we are not backpackers, we do not stay at hostels, we like to stay at very nice private hotels. Yes this hotel isnt the ritz but it is affordable in the centre of Tokyo.Overall I would say: stay here, it is centrally located, easily walkable from Ginza subway station, and there are loads of facilities within walking distance.

The hotel is situated in ginza, the most exclusive part of tokyo, with convenience stores, fast food restaurants, inexpensive local food places and department stores just a few moments walk from the hotel. it is a very short taxi ride to tokyo main train station, it has an underground train station beneath it. the room was smallish but extremely confortable wth wonderful beds and every amenity, probably better than most mercure hotels i have stayed at in other locations. the internet lan in the room was free and fast. after a hard days touring and shopping it was a great place to come back to relax.Sightseeing Tip: Tokyo is full of amazing places to visit so be sure to buy your Japan Rail Pass before you leave your home country as it cannot be purchased in Japan, it is definitely worth it. When taking buses or the subway rail, you will need to pay separately but these prices are quite cheap. We found that most sightseeing places could be reached on the JR train lines. One of the best locations in Tokyo is Asakusa because it has a wonderful temple, great shopping and old houses.

The Mercure Tokyo Ginza hotel is a business, western style hotel in the upmarket Ginza neighbourhood in Tokyo. The Hotel is located in the main luxury shopping and dining district of the Japanese capital and is regarded as a high-end establishment, part of Accor, a French accomodation chain.If you have stayed at any Mercure hotel anywhere, you probably know that they are the standard for business 4* hotels. The Mercure Ginza is some 5 minutes away from Ginza Metro Station and around 25min walk to Tokyo Railway Station, making it quite handy. The rooms are big (huge for Japanese standards) and come equipped with most of the amenities you'd find in a Western 4-star hotel. The toilets are also huge and have a Japanese-style high tech toilet bowl with toilet seat heating and bidet.Keep in mind that standard rooms do not have wireless internet and only the superior ones do.I was lucky enough to get a free upgrade so I could use the internet.

This hotel is perfectly located in the heart of Ginza in a quiet street. Checkin was very nice, we asked for a room far from elevators and we got it without any problem. It was a simple room with queen sized bed, small room but normal for Japan standards and enough when you spend most of your day visiting Tokyo. We stayed 4 nights. (we even had the room before the official chekin time). We had breakfast at the hotel (21,000 yens) first day but decided the buffet was really not exceptional and too much food. nearby coffee shops around with nice pastries and much cheaper. you can book without breakfast and decide when you are on site, the cost is not different. We tested the bar: not very fun, but they offer happy hours...Free Wifi only in the lobby area. Some rooms (deluxe or whatever) have internet I think.all in one: nice and pleasant stay, very clean room, quiet. ideal for what we expected.

This hotel is located near the main shopping area in Ginza. It has a good selection of restaurants nearby and stores. The rooms are well equiped with good internet access, they are also quiet and the beds are comfortable. The staff on the front desk are very polite and are always there to help as best they can.The breakfast in the morning was excellent with a good selection from eggs, mushrooms to cereals.The restaurant in the evening was quite limited, so would recommend going out for a meal.For Business or Pleasure, this is a good hotel in the right area of Tokyo.

I booked at Mercure Tokyo Ginza Hotel based on other travellers' reviews and I wasn't dissapointed! Decent sized rooms and adequate amenities. Several restaurants and convenience stores located just outside the hotel premises. Very near the subway, bus and taxi stops. There's complimentary internet access, too. Definitely recommended!

We stayed at Mercure Ginza in March 2012 with my partner and 1.5 year old son.Mercure's stand out features are the size of the rooms and its location. It was easily the largest room of the 3 hotels we stayed at in Japan. It's location was a very short stroll from the main streets of Ginza and had many close by 7-11's, coffee shops and restaurants. A walk to the fish market or Tokyo Station / Imperial Palace is not a hard walk at all.I had ordered a sim card to be delivered to the hotel and this was handed over to me at check-in without asking.

I wasnt too sure what to expect on arrival. I was staying one night on business and this looked to be the least plush of the hotel's we'd stayed in so far. However I was pleasantly surprised by what the hotel offers. The hotel is slightly off the main road through Ginza and reception is on the second floor. The reception is very standard modern business hotel, nothing special, but staff are very friendly and speak fluent English. The room was a fair size for a Tokyo hotel - modern decor, well kept room which was clean, good ensuite with Japanese toilet, shower and bath, fully stocked. The bed was comfortable and provided a good night's sleep. There was enough size to position a case and bags, and unpack some of the contents. The hotel is located in the centre of Ginza in Central Tokyo near all the shops and Imperial Palace. It is also a 5 minutes walk from 2 metro stations which will take you anywhere in Tokyo. All in all I thought this hotel provided a great location and well sized room for the price and was one of the few business hotels I would return to for a leisure visit as well. Highly recommended for a stay.

Our group of four adults (Two rooms) stayed here late February and found the hotel rooms to adequate to our needs. Comfortable beds and large clean bathrooms. The only fault I could find would be the air-conditioning which was a real fiddle to operate. The hotels restaurant was like something out of Fawlty Towers with very little choice on offer, although we were there well before service ended. People who arrived for a meal five minutes before advertised closing, provided us with a scene from the Maitre'd banging cutlery and making a performance of annoyance. Most people think a Hotel restaurant would be used to people traveling and arriving hungry. We decided breakfast would be better outside the hotel based on what we'd wittnessed the night before.The other disappointment was the lack of concierge help for a broken zipper on my husbands jeans. I would have thought that in a city a large as Tokyo repair of a zipper could have been effected overnight. When we stayed at the Park Hyatt in Sydney without a pair of cuff-links for a dinner the concierge supplied some without fuss and allowed us to enjoy our stay.

Mercure Hotel's location is so convenient to all the meetings we had to squeeze in during our 2 day stay. We averaged 6 meetings and the hotel is just 10-minute cab ride from this hotel. It is that convenient especially during snowy winter. The rates were very reasonable as well.The rooms were a bit cramped, and there is no hotel lobby were guests could go for meetings. Thus, we were forced to go to other places.

SummaryFor high-priced Tokyo, Mercure Ginza offers good comfortable value in a great location. A small but well-appointed modern room (no 1021) which was very well laid out to offer maximum amenity in a small space which was a relief after the dreary hotel access and 1st floor reception.PlussesGreat location in Ginza with its high-end label shops all around; quick access to the excellent subway system. Comfortable bed and good pillow selectionGood air-conditioning systemIn room safeTea & coffee making facilities in roomIce machine down the corridorStocked minibarSpotlessly cleanTV with Japanese channels and 3 international channels including BBCFor foreigners – an innovative heated WC seat with electronic bidet etc!NegativesDreary entrance and reception area are off-putting – causing my wife to think we were staying somewhere (word edited!)This hotel is not serviced by the airport limousine bus service, but a 1160 yen taxi ride (on a traffic-free Sunday afternoon) to the T-Cat bus centre solves that problem – just ask reception to write the T Cat address on a card to show the taxi driver. Similarly upon arriving at the airport ask the Limo Bus desk to write the name of the hotel on a card as Mercure doesn’t translate automatically to Japanese!

I've stayed at the Mercure Ginza several times over the past couple of years and highly recommend it for it's top-notch location, ultra-clean rooms and friendly staff. This is the place to go if you cannot stand the cigarette smokey smell of the cheaper Japanese business hotels as most of the hotel is non-smoking. It's amazing to be in the heart of Ginza without having to pay an arm and a leg, and also within walking distance of the early-morning Tsukiji market. Looking forward to another visit next month!

We needed a place to stay for one night in between landing in Tokyo and boarding the shinkansen the following day. Mercure Ginza is well located in walking distance from Tokyo station (10-15 mins south along Sotobori Dori and then in to Ginza a few blocks), plus it's in the heart of Ginza surrounded by shops, restaurants coffee shops etc.Booking was made through expedia - room rate was good and no problems at all during check-in. Check-in staff were very friendly and spoke perfect English, which always helps after a long flight!Stayed in Superior Twin room. It was a "big" little room ... there was enough room for us to move about without stepping on each others toes- 2 large, comfortable single beds (could accommodate 6'3 partner) - large bathroom (by Tokyo standards) + good toiletries- tastefully decorated, - useful, 2 person desk (plus 2 chairs) so both of us could connect laptops and work if needed. - internet access worked perfectly, first time. - plently of space to laydown 2 suitcases, plus closet, coathangers etc.- tea & coffee facilities in room (no milk, but loads of convenience stores nearby). - good range of TV channels including bilingual movie channel.Good value for money. Would stay there again, and recommend to others.

The Mercure Ginza has a fantastic location, and that its key asset. It is also right on top of a metro station (which is handy but there are metro stations everywhere in Tokyo, its train system must be at the top of any scale). The hotel staff were helpful and spoke good English (which in Japan is not a given). You can walk to any of the many Ginza amenities and shops in no time at all. As Ginza is centrally located in Tokyo, this is a great place to use as your base.The rooms were not big. But this is Tokyo where space is at a significant premium. Despite their small size I found the rooms reasonably comfortable. The toilet seat is typical Japanese which is great. Everyone should have one at home. Bed quality and cleanliness were also good.Internet (ethernet, not wifi) is available at NO cost in the room. It is also of excellent quality. That is definitely a big plus. Wi-fi is available (also for no charge) at reception.I booked the Mercure online and got a very reasonable rate through one of the most popular booking websites.I would recommend the hotel to anyone going to Tokyo on holiday or business. It is not a corporate hotel but it is perfectly adequate on the things that matter: location, cleanliness, and fast and free internet access.

The Mercure is an average hotel centrally located in the shopping and business district of Ginza. At first I was not pleased by the receptionist's attitude, when on arriving around Sunday lunchtime after a gruelling 10 hour flight from Europe, heavily jetlagged into the bargain, she told me check-in was at 3pm, and to come back later! She offered to keep my luggage, but I told her there was no way I was going to go away and insisted that there must be at least one room ready for me. Five minutes later she handed me the keycard to a room, and I thought she might have checked room availability first before she told me to go away and come back later. Not what you want to hear after such a long transcontinental flight.Room rates are reasonable, around half of what you pay at the priciest locations in Ginza. Breakfast is not included in the price, but there are a number of good, clean cafes in the neighbourhood where you can eat well for Y 800-1000. The other main complaint with this hotel is that the reception is not on the ground floor as you enter, but you need to take a lift up to the second floor. The room I got had two beds in it, so had very little free space and the reception staff described this to me as a free upgrade, but I'd have preferred a room with only one bed and more space to open my luggage out in. There is a heated toilet seat in the bathroom which I found amusing to operate. Overall this hotel is not top luxury but it does the job at a sensible price.

I have stayed at this hotel a couple of times which by itself would be a recommendation. This hotel sits right in the middle of Ginza shopping and eating, everything less than a stone throw away.The rooms are very tight though; it is a miracle almost how they managed to squeeze all facilities in. To recommend these rooms as comfortable depends very much if you are traveling alone or together. I would think of these rooms as single person rooms no matter if there are double rooms in the offering; two pieces of luggage represent an issue because there is very limited storage capacity in the room and space around beds is very limited too.None of the rooms have a view, most of them are looking at the Tokyo race authorization building or its neighboring building, both not worth to have a look at at all.If plans are to hang out in the city all day this hotel is a very good choice of hotel because it sits on top of a subway station Ginza Ichome. Breakfast, dinner and coffee places all over. Tokyo central at the doorstep of the hotel, it's all right there as soon as you leave the ground floor entry.But when you are dependable of the hotel facilities my recommendation would be different; go and look further.Hotel staff is pleasant and helpful; breakfast is extended continental and sufficient but it does feel like you are in Paris instead of Tokyo. That is to be expected though from this chain of hotels. Some staff speaks French too, English language use is common for all.All in all, when you are looking for a luxury hotel with associated facilities do not go here. If you are looking for good international standards without frills and whistles, cleanliness, pleasant staff, perfect location to explore Tokyo (central) and a good price this hotel needs to be on your shortlist.
user_location: Capelle aan den IJssel, The Netherlands
user_name:
hans_hasselbach
Capelle aan den IJssel, The Netherlands

review_body: - no rain shower and poor bathroom - expensive- so so breakfast- no AI-club platinum recognition- poor bed linen quality- no gym room- no business center- average hotel although standard service and equipment for this categoryGood points: - free wifi internet in lobby and room.- central position in Ginza- kind female staff

This is really nice small business hotel just a few minutes walk away from the main shopping street in Ginza.Rooms are small but then you are in Tokyo, but beds are comfortable, shower powerful and very good toiletries supplied and replenished every day. Internet access (cable) in rooms and wireless in restarant is free, as is breakfast which is very good with a wide selection.The airport buses don't stop at this hotel but the Marriot is only 5 minutes away from Taxi so getting to and from via there is easy and they book you on for the return journey even though you are not staying there.You can walk from the subway directly to the hotel so very handy if that is your mode of transport, if not then get reception to call you a taxi or turn left or right when you come out of the hotel and you are on the main street where lots go by.Lots of restaurants within walking distance, Yakatori street is only a few minutes away and the food there is excellent as is Hajime, at which the food and ambience is truly amazing - high in the price stakes but worth every yen that it costs and more - the taxi stops at the front of the building so you walk past the parking lot turn left and walk down the stairs - booking in advance is a must as this is a secret jem so although open for long hours always busy.Back to the hotel, if you want a large corporate hotel then this is not for you, but if you want a smaller, clean, well appointed hotel in a good location with good access then it is perfect.Staff all speak English and are very helpful, restaurant menu if you do not want to go out is also very good, bar area great for relaxing in the evening or for afternoon meetings or catch-ups.

When my blind Priceline bid for a four-star hotel in Ginza produced the Mercure, I felt as if I'd drawn a Motel 6 on the Champs-Elysées or in Knightsbridge. Calling my reaction disappointment would be an understatement. (When I discovered that I was paying more than the rack rate on their website, I was further annoyed, but that has to do with my poor homework on Priceline prices, not the hotel itself.)As it happened, my disappointment was mitigated by a few things. If you're shopping or working in Ginza, the location is ideal and the price is considerably less than the average for such a posh neighborhood. The room, while not spacious, was a decent size, with an almost big bathroom. Staff was helpful, efficient and professional, was knowledgeable about the city and spoke English well (French seemed to be more of a challenge). Check in and out were quick. Tokyo and Shimbashi Stations are close on foot or by cab, metro and private line trains from Ginza station are even closer, and there is direct access to Ginza Itchome station from the basement level if that line in of use to you. But in the end, it was a standard-issue Mercure, not a luxurious Sofitel. I know that is stating the obvious, but I was hoping for something a little better, given the stars and the neighborhood. So while I have no particular complaints, there were no bells, no whistles, nothing to make the stay memorable, but nothing to complain about either.

This hotel is in an great area - ginza- a quiet , fashionable neighbourhood , where everyone looks smart. We visited other areas in Tokyo and we were really happy to have chosen this hotel. To Tokyo train station is a 10minute walk, there's a subway station under the hotel. The room was quite nice , modern and superclean . Breakfast was expensive ( as everything in tokyo) but it was a very nice buffet with a lot of variety. Free wi-fi in the lobby, we stayed on the 4th floor and although weak, sometimes we got Internet signal too. We arrived at 11am and straight away we were given a room , staff very nice and professional.

We stayed in this hotel for 7 nights, partially business, partially privat, the location for buusiness purpose was perfect, just a 5 minutes walk from the office, but also for leisure purpose the location was good, with a subway entrance just in front of the hotel and other entrances of other lines, in walking distance, also Tokyo station was close, also restaurants and shops were closly situated

Stay for 1 night for vacation.This mercure is a good choice with reasonable price in ginza area. It is not far from tokyo station, and the subway station is just under the hotel. The room is nice with everything you need. The size is typical Tokyo standard.Overall, we have a pleasant stay.

I booked the ginza mercure as I managed to get a great rate for a very central hotel in a very upmarket area.Coming from the airport, I took the JR line. It was abit of a walk with luggage and 2 kids in tow. We lost our way alittle and after 1/2 hour, cold and hungry, managed to find the hotel.Checkin was fast and efficient. Rooms were small and very cosy (but I guess by Japanese standards, the rooms would be considered sizable) and the 2 twin beds took up most of the room with just enough space under the counter worktop to put our luggage. The room was extremely clean and comfortable, with a LCD TV, a small (again) but very clean and nice bathroom with Japanese style bathrooms.The restaurant was under renovation when I was there in Dec so the dinner menu was extremely limited and we ended up having dinner at MacDonalds just 1 min walk away. The area is literally dotted with small eating places, ramen, bentos, 24 hours stores like lawsons, western style bakeries, and since this is the Ginza strip, very swanky shops and malls.During the evenings the area is closed to traffic and you can walk on the streets.The hotel is also close to 3 different subway lines, JR, Ginza line and the Ginza-itchome Station just below the hotel. It is a great base for exploring the Tokyo area.

You wouldn't expect to find a gem like this on a budget in the center of Tokyo (there's a subway station literally under the hotel - and no, you don't hear any of the trains...it's way underground), but here it is. For about $150 a night, you get a nice room, all the amenities you'd usually get in a Japanese hotel (toothbrush, razor, all kinds of facial products) as well as L'Occitane bath products. And yes, WiFi and breakfast (Japanese & European...highly recommend the Japanese, though) were included. Lots of shops, bars & restaurants nearby. You really can't go wrong.

This hotel is the perfect location to the best shopping area in Tokyo and so close to the subway. We stayed a couple of nights after skiing in Hakkuba and loved the variety to shops and restaurants both japanese and european in close vicinity. The chocolate shops are to die for. The reception staff were very helpful at all times and located our lost backpack left in a taxi within minutes. We had two rooms next to each other and they were suitable as we were out all day. We will definitely be back for the shopping.

I just stayed at the Mercure Ginza after twenty years of using The Imperial. Yes, The Imperial! Quite a difference you might think - and in cost terms yes. US$400 for the latter vs. an internet booking of $115 per night (plus taxes) for the Mercure. It's a great location for starters and right on the subway if that's helpful. The rooms are smallish; but the bathroom about the same size as a Tower room at The Imperial. The room was very clean and tidy, the bed comfortable. Effective and quiet (stress quiet) air-conditioning, and free wi-fi. The buffet breakfast at 1,900 Yen was rather pedestrian - so skip that and go to one of the many coffee shops in the area (and there a many in neighboring streets, including a 24 Hr McDonald's next door). Also close are small shops for supplies of bottled water (e.g. Lawsons). Reception were helpful and competent; and there were even copies of the International Herald Tribune on every floor in the morning (you only get that on the more expensive floors of The Imperial). This hotel is not on the Airport Limo bus route - but take the bus to TCAT and its about a $20/15 mins taxi ride from there. Though my taxi driver had to call the hotel for better directions (Note to hotel: Put the directions in JAPANESE also on your website for guests to print). On departure reception got a taxi to TCAT in nano-seconds. This, as far as I'm concerned is a great new find in a city of expensive and for the most part dreary 5 star hotels. I'll stay there again. One final note (again to the hotel or Accor as a whole). I'm a Platinum Member of A Club. But what benefit do I get from it? How about nothing! Never been upgraded; not even a free bottle of Evian - the loyalty plan needs a real re-think!

I have stayed here 4 times this year.Rooms are functional and clean, if a little small for my liking. Bathroom is adequate, shower works fine, but it's not separate, rather over the bath, something I don't personally like.Eat out, as the "French bistro" in the hotel is very limited choice, and the menu does not seem to change. Breakfast is enough for most peoples needs.Staff of the hotel are all helpful and friendly.
Very conveniently located in Ginza, near shopping and transport. Decent sized rooms too.

We got this hotel at $145 on priceline. it was a great deal for the very pricey are of Ginza. The rooms were beautiful and spacious. Everything was extremely comfortable. The location is good, close to shopping, eating and the imperial palace. The hotel is right above a subway station and about7 mins walk away from the JR station if you have a pass. Would certainly recommend this hotel.

The location is very central to shopping and restaurants in Ginza as well as walking distance to various Tokyo sights such as the fish markets. Tokyo train station is just around the corner from the hotel. We stayed there for our honeymoon and found it to be a perfect introduction to Tokyo. The rooms are small but clean and have everything you need. The staff had good english and were helpful and knowledgable about the area. The breakfast was fine with both western and asian cuisine available. The only downside was that it was VERY hard to find the hotel from the Tokyo train station (only for the first time only) using the hotel's very confusing walking directions so I would recommend taking a taxi for your first visit until you know the area.

This is a small hotel in a fantastic location in Ginza. It's in a quiet street & close to lots of eateries and just around the corner from the main shopping avenues of the elegant Ginza area. The staff are very pleasant and helpful and speak very good English. We found a good rate on the net, perhaps due to a drop off in tourism in the wake of the tsunami and Fukushima fallout, unfortunate for Japan but really Tokyo and Kyoto seem fine and things are normal. Back to the hotel - the rooms aren't particularly Japanese, except for the bathroom, rather more French inspired and they're very small but this is standard in Tokyo apparently. We could have paid more for a deluxe, larger room but figured the extra $80 a night (including breakfast) wasn't really worth it. The rooms are pleasant with a cosy feel, comfy chair, everything you need and in the right place. Free internet access was a real plus for me as I travel with my laptop. The bed was extremely comfortable and king size.We had the hotel breakfast one day which offered a pretty good variety of western and Japanese food. There's nothing glamorous or particularly interesting about the hotel's public areas, the foyer's on the 2nd floor & the dining room decor has a feel of a French provincial cafe. There are no areas to sit and hang out & I think the bar is part of the dining room/cafe. However, in such a great neighbourhood, who cares? We ate at a few local restaurants and all were great. I'd recommend EN, very close by, underneath Starbucks - for a wonderful Japanese eating experience.

1. HotelChoose accomodation central to places you intend to visit. Tokyo is a flat, good-pavement lined city but don't bother with fashion footwear. Ginza is a good option for shopping and restaurants, do expect to pay more for smaller room with fewer inclusions (no gym/pool/wifi/cable) but it doesn't matter if you spend little time there.2. ShoppingBrilliant with wide selection of local and international labels, remember to bring passport on person to enable tax-backs too. Salespersons are bilingual and very helpful,tax-free goods bonus for travellers. Best stores Isetan, Mitsukoshi, Matsuya, Barneys New York.3. Food is a major part of traveling for me, and I recommend eat mostly Japanese- style when you can. Sashimi wonderful, as is most Japanese cuisine. Tip for travellers: if on budget, buy prepackaged Japanese-style food from 24hr convenience stores; tasty, fresh, clean, wide variety, healthy and cheap. Fusion style offerings, even at high end restaurants don't really translate very well- best avoided.3. ToursBook in advance to get best rates, work out pickup points for tours to avoid confusion on day. Do visit many tourist hot spots like Mt Fuji and Hakone, choose weekday to avoid crowds.4. Tokyo is easy town to navigate on foot, and the metro-and rail lines are efficient and fast. Card machines in English, easy to top up. Best places to visit are Ueno Park for zoo, shrines and museums, Yoyogi Park for beautiful gardens and shrines, Akihabara for electronics, manga and games, Shibuya for shopping, Harajuku for fashion and people watching (recommend weekends) and Shinjuku for daytime shopping and nighttime bars, Pachinko and colorful nightlife.Tips for travellersTokyo very safe for foreigners, on streets and trains, but expect stares particulary at night on train if you're female. Have cash on you, most store purchases, even by locals are transacted in cash. Difficult to locate an ATM that actually took my card. Don't eat/drink when walking, or blow nose with tissue in public. My camera was stolen on my last day by a pickpocket on a train- in hindsight, put belongings away in a bag and secure/zip up bag at all times and be wary of fellow commuters who sit close/inadvertently bump into you. But don't let something like that ruin your holiday- Perfect holiday except for that one small mishap. Planning to go back again next year!!

Tokyo is known for their closet sized hotel rooms but I was rather surprised when I first walked into my Superior room and was actually able to turn around without hitting my head. The room was not large by any means but had everything a hotel room should have plus the space to move around. The hotel is very close to the Ginza metro station and in a walking distance from the Tokyo Central Station. However Taxis are affordable for short runs in Tokyo City. The Ginza area is also full of shopps that fulfill even the most demanding shoppers needs and at a reasonable price.

I stayed at The Mercure Ginza for 3 nights, and loved it. It was the first time I had been overseas since I was a child, and this hotel fulfilled all my expectations. Instead of catching a very expensive taxi from the airport, we caught the train and then a taxi from the station to the hotel (it was around the corner, but we were jet lagged and had no idea where we were going). The hotel let us check in at 11am, which was very nice of them, and our hotel room was fresh and cool (it was very hot outside already). It was spacious (especially for Tokyo) had free internet, and a small but very modern bathroom. The aircon works really well, you can't hear the sounds of the street from the rooms ( I think we were on level 8) and you need your key card to access the hotel floors in the elevator so it is very secure. There is convenience stores everywhere and vending machines directly across the road with cheap water, soft drink and juices. McDonalds is just down the street, as well as Starbucks, and there are restaurants just on the main road too, as well as the Apple Store, Chanel, Gucci etc. It has a subway underneath the hotel (it doesn't affect you with noise or anything) however it doesn't go to common stations, so the best station is just a few minutes walk away. All in all, a great hotel to stay in, I would stay here again.

This is a no frills hotel but is clean and quiet. We found it to be handy for us. You could take the lift to the basement and be straight into the MTR station. The hotel was an easy walk to the main shopping street and the Imperial Palace with it's beautiful gardens. We were here at the end of April and the blossom was still in bloom (although just coming to an end) and the Azaleas were looking spectacular.We were pleasantly surprised to find that Tokyo Disneyland had re-opened and we all had a fun day here. It was quite easy to get to using the MTR then JR line.There is free wi fi in the hotel but unfortunately it was not accessible from our room on the 11th floor so it meant going down to reception on the 2nd floor if we wanted to connect.We used the Airport Limousine bus to get to and from the Airport and found this very well organised and cheap. Unfortunately it doesn't go right to this hotel but it goes to the Mitsui Garden Hotel Ginza which is a 10 minute walk away. The Mitsui looked a much nicer hotel than ours and had a fabulous view from the top floor but I guess it is probably more expensive.There are plenty of restaurants both Japanese and Western close by (McDonalds just at the end of our street and a Pizza restaurant a few minutes walk much to the delight of our teenage daughter !!).

This is an unusual hotel, since it was built as an office building and retrofitted. There's no real lobby, and the layout is a bit like a filing cabinet. But other than that, they've done great job. The decor is pleasant, and the service is excellent, even by Japanese standards.The only negatives are the small rooms and the price. Small rooms are normal for Tokyo, and I can live with it. And if you've decided to stay in Ginza, you know you have to pay extra for it. I don't regret it!

If your after shopping this is the place for you, with many of the major brands at your doorstep. also only a short walk down to the fish markets. Rooms are small compared to Australian standards, but still comfortable a clean. Enjoy

Great location as it has many eateries and malls within walking distance from the hotel. MacDonalds is just right next door. The nearest train station takes just a 5 to 10 mins walk. Room size is relatively small but reasonable, by Japanese standard.
Nice, clean, reasonably priced hotel. It's perfectly located in Ginza and close to everything. Highly recommended...
Room is cosy and well-equipped but a bit small. Frontdesk service is very good.

I received very attentive and excellent service from Mercure Hotel. The staffs are very nice and can communicate well in English. They extended so much help to us during our stay. First and foremost, we appreciate their help in printing numerous maps for us to locate places of interest. They have also assisted us in sorting out a messy booking between Izu Onsen & Mercure Ginza.What really impressed me was my luggage numeric lock was jammed up for no reason. Mercure staffs were extremely helpful in contacting Samonite Japan on our behalf. Though the problem was not really resolved but the effort put in deserved a credit. You will enjoy your stay with them.
Recommend for single traveller, but not for the family
Nice room and convenient location. Would be more helpful if the access direction provided by the hotel website included travelling via subway (at Yurakucho station) instead of by taxi only.

Service staff very helpful and accomodating, rooms are comfortable and nice, the only problem is the location if one arrives from Ginza station, the walk is quite a distance esp when one has to pull along their luggage.
The hotel staff were very helpful in providing information and solving our problem. The rooms are clean and well maintained. We would definitely come back to stay at this hotel.
Hope to have more member promotion. Staff service is super excellent. Will visit Mercure Ginza again.
This hotel was quite good, service was fantastic on. When we arrived there Mr sasaki was helpful with directions around ginza and helped us book buses for Mt Fuji. Very impressed!

My first visit but will sure return! Hotel is easy to locate, even with change of train lines from Tokyo Station. Room size is very generous when compared to most Japanese hotels. Amenities in the bathroom was like close to a 5 star hotel and well presented. Housekeeping does a marvelous job in maintaining excellent cleanliness all over the hotel. Service was swift and efficient, a gentlemen at the Front Desk (speaks English with slight American accent) was very helpful with directions and general information of Tokyo. Overall, a most enjoyable stay!

We spent 2 nights at this hotel. The room is relatively small but well designed. The mattress is very comfortable. The room is well equipped with plenty of towels, slippers, pajamas/ kimonos, fridge, safety box, kettle but no wi-fi, only wired internet. AC system is central so it is very quiet. The lobby entrance is a bit low key as the reception is on the second floor, but the security seems OK as we need our door card to activate the elevator to the right floor.This hotel is well located, next to 3 subway stations, even sit on top of one of them, so the trip from Narita airport is quite simple. Take the Narita express train (NEX) to Tokyo station and switch to a subway line to go to Ginza.Restaurants around are a bit pricier than in other areas.We found our stay very pleasant and hope to return there on our next visit to Tokyo
location is perfect but the room size is very small.

This hotel is conveniently located. The vicinity is quiet and peaceful with 24hrs McDonalds and sundry stores nearby. The staff are very friendly and helpful. Service is good. I love the washroom. It has the best shower system, better than all the 5-star hotels I have stayed in. The bed is good, firm and comfortable. Can have a restful sleep. Room is big as compared to the rooms in other hotels in Japan.

Stayed for two nights, recieved early checkin (arrived at reception at 11am after a flight from Germany) at no cost, clean queen bed with working heating/cooling, mini bar, kettle. This is the second time we have stayed here and have done so because of the high standards. Staff speak excellent English, and it is near a Metro train stop. This doesn't help if you have the JR pass (which we did last time) but otherwise a 160Y fee one way to Yurachico (I think) is only one stop from the JR line. Very safe area (as is Japan in general). Resturant at the moment is undergoing renovations so the dinner menu was drastically culled to offer two options for entree, main and dessert. There are plenty of cheap feeds around including 24hour MacDonalds and various coffee houes and heaps of Lawsons/Family marts for food.Next trip to Japan I would stay here again. Mecure brand standards don't differ around the world and this is why we will continue to stay here.

Mercure Ginza hotel is very well located in the heart of Ginza district, within a short distance to 3 metro lines. Using the Ginza line, it is only a short ride from Tokyo main station, which is the place where the Narita express and Tokkaido Shinkansen (Kyoto line) arrive.The hotel's staff is very kind, they are ready at any time to give you helpful tips about Tokyo, and all that the city has to offer. The area nearby the hotel is full of cafes, convenience stores, and very good restaurants, Chuo-dori (Ginza street) is 2 minutes away and you can find all you can imagine. The room we've got was VERY small but convenient, we were not expecting something bigger in Tokyo and we've got this hotel through a Accor promotion so we were not at all disappointed. There was free internet in the room (by cable), and free wi-fi at the lobby.
Everything good -people , service ,location . breakfast , ,etc. Must be come back again.

very good hotel, well situated, nice rooms( a liitle bit small, but we are in japan). excellent breakfast, good service. Can only regret that there is no wifi in room, only cable ADSL.Nice place where to stay

we rated this hotel as the best bathroom cause of it's quality equipments in the bathroom, the shower always supplies smooth watering and temperatures. The room fullfill good necessary items for guest We are very happy while staying there.
we really enjoy the trip especially the location of the hotel and service, excellent...

My family and I stayed at the Mercure Hotel Ginza Tokyo and found it to be very clean, the room has everything you need. The service is amazing, the staff are attentive and very helpful with whatever you require. We were travelling with a large group of others and the bus did not stop outside the door, so the receptionist walked with us to show us the bus stop to catch the bus to the airport. Very impressed.

When booking for 2 adults and 1 child in room 1115 I would have expected 3 towels to be provided but was only given 2 towels - my son had to use 2 hand towels until I made the call to reception for another towel. I thought common-sense and the booking would indicate the need for 3 towels. This is the only minor thing I could criticise the Hotel for all the rest was perfect and clean. Well done!

Mecure Ginza hotel is perfectly located for an assault on designer clothing stores and upmarket shopping. Access to the subway is via the hotel basement. Numerous restaurants of all proce ranges are located within easy walking distances (even a McDonalds on the ground floor for those who desire a fix of grease and artificial food). The staff are fantastically helpful, fluent in english, and provided fantastic assistance to Tokyo novices. The only downsides were that the bistro choices seemed quite limited and the rates seemed quite expensive - although this is probably a function of the hotels location.I would have no hesitation in recommending this hotel to anyone.
Hotel staff were friendly and helpful. There was always someone at the front desk that spoke good english which always helps greatly. Rooms were clean.

Lucky to get "hot deal" rate and stayed 4-nights stay in Mercure Ginza.Friendly and Effecient Staff -- Our request to have our room next to our children triple room was promptly acknowledged before our trip and all arranged when we check-in. Kudo to the staff!The room is good-size, cozy with amenities, free WiFi and a 2mins walk from Metro Station. It is located very near to Mitsukoshi (三越) Departmental Store. Though it is not as big as Taipei store but it provide great convenience to shop with underground access from Hotel.However, it will be nice if they can change their breakfast variety after 3rd day and also reduce the breakfast price a bit.We certainly have a great stay there and I will definitely stay there again (if there is "hot deal" rate again :P )

We stayed here for four nights with my husband and daughter. Rooms are lovely although quite small but when you compare prices, who cares too much about this. Staff are helpful, location is terrific with the train station entry accessible from Hotel basement. Across the road is a terrific Tendon noodle / tempura restaurant that all of us could eat at for AUD 27.00 - great food and value. Starbucks (although not a favourite normally) has great coffee across the road as well.Would recommend this as the best value hotel in Tokyo - cannot think of any negatives except for expensive breakfast, but have found this is the norm in hotels across the world and the rooms were a little warmer than we would have liked.
Comfortable, clean and good size for Tokyo hotels. About 2 minute walk from Ginza subway with lots of eateries around.

We only had a short time to spend in Tokyo after a skiing trip. So we (a mate and me) wanted a central location to enable us to explore the city easily. The Mercure Hotel Ginza was ideal. A subway station assessable via the hotel lift and also right in the heart of the Ginza shopping district. The twin room we had was spacious, very clean and quiet and the service on the front desk was very helpful, friendly with very clear English being spoken. Would stay there again when travelling to Tokyo.

Hotel is not far from JR station (Yokucho) and subway is under hotel building that we can walk around 5 min (if you not have big suitcase I'm strongly recommended).If you are Accor member you will get some special service (ex.check out late until 3.00 pm).Reception are kinds and good welcome.

This hotel has the best location for shopping in Ginza, we shopped and dropped off our bags, took a break and headed out again. Cheap noodle shop is around the corner, there is also a very small seafood restaurant nearby that we promise ourselves that we'd return. Free wired internet in the room which is very handy, you also get free wifi in the reception area and the restaurant level. The room is small but completely functional, the beds are comfy and we had good night sleep. All the cleaning staffs we bumped into were very polite and always said hello. Check-in process is no frill, typical international chain hotel standard, the staff speaks good English and was very efficient, not over the top polite but completely good enough for me. It's a shame the hotel didn't offer any discount for house customers to dine in their restaurant. I love this hotel, and will return again for sure.
Great room for mercure but I think Ginza is less of normal store or restaurant, most of expensive food and high store, this area is not my favorite.

This was my second time staying at this hotel - and enjoyed it just as much. so close to the main shopping street in Ginza, plus great metro access. The staff were very helpful, they stored our snowboards at the hotel even prior to actual staying with them. Would definitely stay here again if in tokyo.

The rooms were trendy, clean and had modern decor but they were very small.... we stayed on the 12th floor in non smoking room, and also had other family members staying in other rooms on the floor, and a big issue for all of us was the fact that you could not open any windows in your room. Even to be able to open a slither would have been excellent but it is not possible and you can only try to freshen your air just by using the air conditioner. If your not bothered by not having access to fresh air then you wont find this a problem, but we all had food poisoning from eating oysters at Miyajima Island so really wanted it!! Also while it is in a nice area of Tokyo, the posh and expensive Ginza, no taxi drivers ever knew where or what the hotel was!! So this caused problems for us trying to get home from the our day trips to other areas of the city. But it is really handy to the train so if that is how you will travel then no problem. Overall I would stay somewhere else when I return to Tokyo.

Hotel mentioned that WIFI was available on the 2nd level only but unable to connnet to network with IPad. Reception staff are unable to help. Japan are suppose to be advanced in their IT technology but it is disappointed since the day I reach Japan and unable to use the network. Hotel is cleaned and well maintained.

Well, it's very nice to start staying in Tokyo at Mercure Ginza. We can easily go to anywhere we want; as we are very close to some subway & train station which can bring you anywhere you want.not to say the shopping and leisures you may find easily at short distance in a blink :)

Hotel location was great, right in the middle of Ginza! Very convenient & accessible to shops.Overall, a Great Stay at Mercure Ginza for the price range and great service from the attentive staff at the hotel.

Hotel was great. Room was clean and comfortable. Location was amazing with basement connected to subway station. Being in Ginza, only 5 minutes walking distance to main shopping centres or entertainment and food areas. Staffs was prompt, friendly and helpful. For its pricing, it is highly recommended,
Nice location in center of Ginza. Breakfast is also very nice both Japanese food & Western food.
Good location good service but the room is a bit small.
Good accessibility to Ginza Shopping and Tokyo Bay for Tokyo Disneyland.Metro station at basement and JR Yurakocho Station easily accessible.

The hotel is very well located, right in the heart of Ginza. Walking distance to some of the most famous brand name shops in the world. Ginza was love at first sight to my wife and she declined to go to disneyland so she can spend the entire day browsing and shopping in Ginza. One thing though, maybe the hotel can do a better write up on the hotel card as many taxi drivers still have a hard time finding the hotel, a few times we were taken to Monterrey hotel, on the next street. Otherwise, i have nothing but praises for Mercure Ginza!
sofa in the room makes no space to turn around although I can accept the room size.

Excellent location, right in the centre of Ginza area. Within walking distance to Tsukiji Fish Market. Direct basement access to an underground train station. Best is this line is directly to Disneyland / Sea.Am a repeat visitor and will recommend to anyone who wishes to visit Tokyo.

The hotel is in a good location which is rather near to the Ginza train station. Going to Disneyland from here is a breeze as the train station is just below the hotel where it only takes at most 30 mins or less. Hotel room is rather small but I think it is cozy and acceptable. There is a MacDonald's just below the hotel, which is great! It is also about 20 mins walk to the Tsukiji Fish Market.....very convenient!

some friends and i stayed at the Mercure Ginza on 20 Dec 2010. found the hotel very comforatble for the rate that we paid at that location. we were very happy with the service provided and would not hesitate to repeat our stay in the future.

Very good hotel in the heart of Ginza, Rooms are a bit small, but the price is reasonable for the location. Make sure you download the hotels location as some taxi drivers dont know the location that well.

The hotel is nice and clean, the rooms are spacious and conducive, there's also free cable connection in room (wifi only available @ lobby though). However, the service staff wasn't as helpful.One of our friends had viral infection and his foot was swollen. We requested for doctors to come over to check since he couldnt walk, without checking, the staffs immediately rejected and asked my friend to cab down to nearest clinic. After my friend got ready to go, and confirmed the location again, the reception informed him that clinic will be closed and he will not reach in time. They should have informed us the first time. Imagine if he went down all the way to realise it is closed?Other that that experience, it is a pretty comfortable hotel. Very far from the station though. Business district full of branded items nearby. For good shopping, have to take JR to elsewhere to shop.

With the members' benefit on the Accor Advantage, we chose Mecure Ginza Tokyo for a 3-day-2-night stay.The room was very spacious and the beds were comfortable.Hotel staff were also proficient in English which made it all the more convenient for non-Japanese speaking travellers.Situated in a accessible spot in town and is well-connected to the subway lines, our travelling in tokyo is made easy. The only nitpick we have is the shower and bathing ammenities were in bottles which were not easy to open.The

I like the location of the hotel as it is accessible to all forms of transportation, eateriesand shopping areas. The area is also safe for late evening outings. I would strongly recommend my clients/friends to stay with your hotel.
If hotel can arrange free shuttle service will be good
Friendly, clean, practical to move to anywhere, highly recommendable

The hotel was located at a very convenient location near to 3 Metro stations and is easily assessable to lot of tourist attraction. Although there isn't any limousine at the hotel to Haneda Airport, we can still take taxi to the nearest bus station at about USD15. They don't have grand lobby but their room won't disappoint your stay.

The hotel is located almost in the center of Ginza, Tokyo with easy access to Metro on basement. From here you can explore Ginza just a few minutes walk. The check-in process was also friendly and fast. The room is clean and comfortable.

I can't say enough about the excellent location of the hotel. Located in bustling Ginza yet walking to Tsukiji Market took only about 20mins on foot. The rooms are clean, not big but was very comfortable for the 2 of us. Really can't complain and will definitely stay here again the next time we are in Tokyo.
No complaints.The hotel rooms are large. Breakfast is delicious. Thourghly enjoyed our stay here.Very convenient.Close to shopping malls,cheap food and Metro station.

I would recommend that the hotel do provide some sort of room service for room guest. The staff have been very helpful, especially the front desk people. They really help me to sort for places that I wish to go and gave me good guides to move with great ease.
My 3 teenagers boy love the free internet access, from their room ! Room is clean and well kept :)
the hotel is a little difficult to find initially as it is not along the main road but it is in a very good location close to the subway and several shopping malls and convenient stores.

Was a little surprise after being 1 week in japan and having a great time and very welcoming stay in these places to arrive in mecure, ginza with somewhat rudeness. The management at reception were less than helpful for simple requests (accessing wifi and laundry matters). I have travelled 3 times to japan, in the last 3 years but this is the first time I have experienced such unpleasant service. This should not put you of visiting japan, nor staying in mecure, it is centrally located when informed of the correct subway to use. Hopefully high level management will read this and implement some changes.

This hotel is in Ginza which is the expensive shopping district but feels safe to walk around at night. Staff were very friendly on arrival and let us check into our room earlier than normal.The room was fairly small but had everything necessary and the bed was large and comfy. I don't think many hotel rooms are that spacious in Tokyo. The bathroom was good, great toilet, but the bath was three quarter size which was a little annoying. Breakfast was quite expensive and average. Within walking distance to public transport so convenient for sight seeing.I enjoyed my stay here very much, was very quiet and comfortable.

The grande Mercure is conveniently located close to the JR line, Ginza Street and a short cab ride from Tokyo Station. The staff are helpful, accomodating and the breakfast is superb. Take a longer stroll from this hotel in the morning to enjoy the Imperial Palce and its surrounding parklands. At night the local restaurants are pleasing to the palate and the lights of Ginza especially at Christmas are a brilliant scene that reminds you Tokyo is trully one of the great cites of the world. Got to love that location. Wandering around the streets at night near the hotel felt secure . A great base for a few days or a week in Tokyo.

We booked 2 rooms for our stay together with our 3 teenaged children for 3 days as part of our trip to tokyo.. From the funky red door to the stylish interior and crisp white comforter it was thumbs up all the wayl. The room size was fair, the bed was comfy the bathroom a good size considering Japanese standards and even the heated toilet seat was appreciated. The breakfast selection wasn't great but sufficient for us and the best part was that kids under 16 dined for free! The tea and coffee was a great and replenished daily. We brought home fond memories of our holiday in Japan!

Great Location with access to MTR under the Hotel opening up easy movement around TokyoRooms were comfortable and all necessary amenities available Value for Money Breakfast was basic but sufficient Would recommend Hotel

I like the free internet access in the room. Reception and housekeeping services were good. Location is good with easy access to the train stations and food outlets. We had a comfortable stay. The complimentary sachets of coffee was not to my taste, quite bitter. Maybe another blend with a lighter taste would be good. I would certainly recommend this hotel.

This hotel is very clean, nice, very comfortable to stay. The reception has been very helpful and will to help when call upon.Hotel in the Ginza area is very easily accessible from train and subway. There is alot to see and for people to move around easily.
The location is great. Right in the centre of Tokyo, with great accessibility to every place of Tokyo.
wish that they were located closer to the JR / metro stationsgood mix of shops around
We have stayed here many times and I have stayed on my own too. It is perfect for us - location, friendliness of staff, the quality of the rooms and everything else.
This is our 4th stay at the Mercure Hotel Ginza Tokyo.Mecure Hotel is strategically located, close to metro stations, shopping & restaurants.The instant coffee & green tea in the room taste great !
the only thing i dont really like about this hotel is their restaurant, not big enough for the size of the hotel, the food not good particularly good.
Ginza Mercure has the best location in Ginza. Near to the shopping, food and walking distance to Tsujiki. Train station convenient, just below the hotel.

We have stayed at this hotel a few times in the past couple of months and find it to be of exceptional quality. The staff are friendly, helpful and speaks good English. Being an Advantage Plus member we got a free room upgrade and late check out till 3pm. Good breakfast with 50% discount for member.They even provide free luggage deposit for a few days when we travelling out of tokyo.The location is good - walking distance to many shops, restaurant and Tokyo central station. Strongly recommended.

Slightly down market, but OK. Efficient check-in but somewhat small rooms, but OK bathroom (but still no independent shower). The room décor and furnishing are somewhat out dated, but functional. Free internet and a good working desk in the room.With the Ginza at your feet, who needs to eat in the hotel, but there is a small European style restaurant in the hotel.Fair value
Good Location and near to subway station, shopping centres, easy for reasonable healthy meals.

We visit Japan every year and this is 1 of the better hotels we have stayed.Rooms and bathrooms are Good sizeFree english newspapers.Good location with subway below though not the most convenient line for us.Would be better if there is free WiFiThere is a PC at lobby for access to internet but 1 is not enough especially when other guests use it beyond reasonable time
After travelling through Europe for 5 weeks, we would have prefered a nice Japanese restaurant in the hotel.Thankyou for wonderful service ! The staff are excellent ! We love the Japanese people !

This hotel met all my expectations. The location is great with train station just beside the hotel. There are also a lot of good eating outlet nearby and the price are not that expensive. Not fogetting lot & lot of shopping mall around the hotel.
Located in a heart of Ginza , easy access to metro cause it's connect to B2 floor of this hotel.
the room is spacious and clean. the staffs are polite and helpful. They can speak good english. Location is super. We really enjoy our stay there.
Not far from shopping center. Good location, you can access Subway at B1 floor.
Nice hotel, excellent location and surroundings. But the breakfast menu should be changed everyday.

Great location, just minutes from the Ginza shopping district which has all the high end stores and big depts. A few good restaurants within walking distance and noticeably a lot of Italian/Mediterranean influence which is interesting in the heart of Tokyo. Rooms are small but then isn't everything in Japan! We asked for a non-smoking room and I was disappointed to find on my first stay that the room was still very smoky and airless, but on the return trip found a much cleaner and nicer atmosphere although room type was no different, just different floor. The staff were helpful although their knowledge of local events such as a major Picasso visiting exhibition was very limited but they were willing to search. Everything is pricy in Japan so the hotel is no bargain but again its location more than compensated in its proximity to the train station and fast food restaurants should you need a caffeine fix. Beds were comfortable but typically hard Asian mattresses. Breakfasts were good and the time was generous on the weekends although the Japanese are sticklers for punctuality so no lingering over those croissants or noodles! It was also pleasing to see that Western and Asian tastes were adequately catered for. In spite of its downtown location it wasn't too noisy and I appreciated the fact that they could accomodate late check-out within reason and would mind your luggage and hail a cab for return to the station. A small hotel feel that is worth a look, even the manager introduced himself in the lift- a courtesy that did not go unnoticed.

This is our thrid times in Mercure hotel Ginza. The location is excellent. There are many restuarants around the hotel. The food center of Matsuya is a block away. Plus the Mitsukushi which is two block away just renovate and the food is so good. The front desk of the hotel are very helpful in giving you the direction to where ever you want to go. They also help you with the reservation of the restuarant for you.For asia-pacific people you can have a good deal by being a member of accor hotel group and refund your free night here which is much cheaper.

I have stayed at this hotel a few times in the past couple of months and find it to be of exceptional quality. The rates on the internet are reasonable given the generous room size (by Tokyo standard). I used to stay at Ryumeikan which is also good but it is usually full and the rates are higher. Mercure looks very new, staff is friendly and speaks good English. I have the added advantage of being an Advantage Plus member so I always get early check in (at 10am), free room upgrade and late check out (3pm), in addition to low member rates. I had asked for directions at the reception several times -for dinner, to go to fireworks, trains, etc and each time they have been more than helpful by printing out detail information for me. I have no problems at all with this hotel - the location is good - walking distance to many shops, restaurant and Tokyo central station. Strongly recommended.

I stayed at the Mercure Ginza in the Summer of '09 and it was one of if not the best hotel I've ever stayed at. The cost per night was somewhat high but it was certainly worth it.
