Although my room was quite small it had everything I needed and was very modern. However, the breakfast each morning was by far the best part of this hotel. I ate 3 or 4 plates of delicious bacon, eggs and fresh pastries each day and only needed a light snack later in the afternoon to tide me over saving myself hundreds of dollars in food costs. The hotel was in a great area of Ginza - close to subways and a lot of interesting sites. It would have been nice if the hotel had a pool because the temperatures were in the upper 30's each day, but, besides that I was very pleased with my stay and would recommend it highly.

If u are arriving from Ginza station, exit A13, walk towards the tiffany/bvlgari , turn right into the street at bvlgari is. Look out for Mecure when u see Starbucks. same building where Macdonald is.We stayed for 7 nights. Check in was a breeze. Free in-room LAN broadband. Front Desk spoke good english. Its nice to see that they have a dedicated room section for ladies only.shampoo/body wash are under the japanese brand KOSE. Location was good. on the street behind the main Ginza street. Going to disneyaland was easy, Hotel is linked to the subway at B1. Walking distance (Ard 15-20 mins) to tsukiji fish market. Luggage drop off/pick up was efficient. I believe they provide free luggage deposit for a few days if u are travelling out of tokyo for trips.No complaints about mecure ginza.

This was my first trip to Tokyo, so I didn't really know much about the Ginza neighborhood, particularly as it related to the tourist sites, but i was able to reserve the Mercure at a great price during an online sale through the Accor website so I took the chance. The hotel itself was very nice - clean (as is everything in Japan), friendly, all the employees I spoke with were fluent in English (i didn't realize just how rare this is prior to my visit), and in close proximity to a subway line (though one that never went where I was going), 2 Lawsons convenience stores and a McDonalds (all 24 hours). I did not spend much time in the hotel itself (other than to sleep), so I can't speak much of the services provided (restaurant, room service, fitness center, etc), except to say that I enjoyed the free in-room internet access (LAN not wifi).The hotel is convenient to Tokyo station, which is great if you are coming from Narita. It's about a 20 min walk (if you don't get lost!) so technically doable in good weather without luggage; alternatively, the cab ride cost me about 900Y. Based on another TA review, I contacted the hotel prior to arrival for directions that I was able to print and give to the cab driver - I highly recommend this to anyone staying here, as even with the map, the driver had to refer to it a couple times and circle the block once to find the hotel. It is also convenient to plenty of shopping and dining options, the Imperial Palace (walking distance), the Maranouchi line for traveling to Shinjuku (about 20 min), and the Ginza line for Shibuya/Harajuku (about 20 min) in one direction or Akihabara, Ueno, or Asakusa in the other (20 min or less). Despite all the above, I probably would not stay here on my next trip to Tokyo without a similar deal on price, but only because the location was not close to the sites I was most interested in, esp. the nightlife. Although I always felt very safe in Tokyo, as a solo female traveler, I prefer to have a hotel in the area where I will be at night (just to be clear, I'm not using the term "nightlife" to refer to all-night clubbing. The subways in Tokyo stop around midnight (the time varies slightly by line), and it always took me a few tries to find the right subway line and walk to the entrance (the stations are massive in Tokyo), so I would have to be headed to the subway no later than 11:30p, which sometimes made dinners feel rushed. The alternative would have been a 2,800Y cab ride back to Ginza). But if the Mercure were located in Shibuya, Harajuku or Shinjuku, I would be back here in a heartbeat!

A very good hotel, professional staff always attentive and polite, Free internet provided near reception or free wi fi in your room. The restaurant provided excellent meals at reasonable prices. Good spread of the usual breakfast products including a wide selection of japanese foods with breakfast buffet. The rooms were clean and spacious for Japanese standards. Your door key card was used to access your floor in the lift. The Tokyo Metro subway can be accessed via the B2 exit located on the basement level of the hotel. Close to Tsukiji fish market within 10 minutes walk and 2 minutes walk to the main shopping blocks on the Ginza. 15 minute stroll to the Imperial palace. Mcdonalds is open 24/7 and is located next door to the hotel on ground floor or there is a convenience store across the road.. You can find authentic japanese restaurants down the road at excellent prices. Overall a very good hotel....Idai na hoteru wa de, anata ni kansha taizai suru

I stayed at the Mercure GInza for 5 days. Tokyo is very expensive so and I got a reasonable rate (120 USD per night) at this hotel as I booked early. Here are the main problems:1. Hotel structure is ridiculously cheap - you can hear EVERYTHING that goes on on the rooms above and beside yours. I made several complaints to the staff and they did not do anything about it. This went of for 3 nights and seriously spoiled my stay as having a quiet full night sleep is impossible here.2. Staff is poorly trained, I don;t know what other guests that posted reviews here saw in this staff. They speak little English (and trust me, basic English is spoken everywhere in Tokyo, specially brand hotels) and have no power to help us in anything besides suggesting some average restaurants and saying hello and goodbye.3. Bar and restaurant are, to say the least. sad. Don't waste your time not even checking it out. I had received two courtesy drinks (which in Accor Hotels usually mean any drink) and as I was claiming the drink, I learned that I could have a soft drink or a beer. A courtesy drink is now a Coke?!?!?!?! Pitiful.Anyway.... there were so many other smaller problems that I think everyone should know that this hotel is not that great. Rooms are clean and location is OK (there are several good locations in Tokyo and this is by far not the coolest) but that is about it. If you pay a bit more, you can go for a 4/5 star hotel that will treat you right. Or just go to a simpler place and don't waste your money here.Besides that, enjoy Tokyo!

We had a little difficulty finding the hotel as we had to walk form the station Staff were very pleasant ;and helpful even though their English was not that good. The room had everything you could want except space. The main problem was that as we were there for a week we would have liked to unpack but the wardrobe was so tiny and there were absolutely no drawers or shelves. This resulted in a heap of clothes hanging on the chair and desk.Positives were free in room internet which was very handy as I had a macbook. There was also an internet site near the dining room. The bed was comfortable and there were a choice of pillows. The room was also extremely quite as there is not much activity outside the hotel.The Ginza is a fabulous place to stay even if it is hard to find a cheap meal There was so much happening there. There was a station right next door to the hotel but we didn't use it as it wasn't a JR line station but the other station was a short walk away.I thoroughly recommend getting a JR rail pass if you are going to go to Kyoto as you can use it on many of the lines around Tokyo and it is so easy

We stayed at this hotel for 4 nights. Its in a great location about 7 min walk to Yurakucho station. We stayed in a Deluxe quuen room which was very modern looking, the bathroom was clean & spacious. The room is more spacious than the superior room & for that amount of night i would definatly upgrade the room as the other one is way too small. We didnt have breakfast at the hotel as there are so many options outside the hotel to venture out & eat at. Not to mention there is a Macdonalds down stairs which helps for those occasions when you need a last min snack. Honestly the location of the hotel is unbeatable as you are right in the heat of Ginza. There are heaps of department stores with food courts to get your essentials from not to mention the Lawsons convenient stores (like a 7/11 store) where you get can get your water & snack.We were able to visit all the surroundings subburbs using the JR line with our JR passes so it was very convenient to get around.We also stumbled across a lovely tapas restaurant on our last night called Di Punto which is on the same st as the hotel right next door to the Canon Gallery.

We stayed 3 days in May in a twin bedroom:- The service from the reception was very good and helpful- The room was spacious and comfortable- The hotel location very good and convenient, in Ginza- Access to the Internet was freeHowever, the design of the breakfast lounge is out of date, and the breakfast products and service can breatly be improved.

I was not familiar with the size of rooms in Japan, but became aquainted real quick. The room we were in was about 1/3 size less than the eqivalent in the US. So it was cozy. But for the price, it was worth it and got the job done. It's located in the heart of the Ginza district, so there's a lot of stores and restaurants in the area. In fact, we were right around the corner from a Starbucks, if you need that fix. The staff was courteous, spoke English and overall, we had a good experience.

Just stayed here for 5 nights and would highly recommend this hotel. We locked in a great rate on expedia and was very surprised at the quality. Extremely clean and in a highly central location in Ginza. Staff were friendly and mostly spoke English extremely well. We asked the staff to book us into particular restaurants and mail a package home for us with no problem. I didn't find the rooms too small - compact yes but not overly small. They change the sheets, towels and kimonos everyday unless asked otherwise (e.g. to be more environmentally friendly). The only minor downside is that the hotel is not located on the Yamanote line and it involves a 10 mins walk to the nearest Yamanote line station (Yurakucho). Our room also had free internet connection.

One of the few hotels I found in Japan that allowed one child in up to 16 to stay free. We booked a Superior 2 single beds. I was a little concern, since our daughter is a tall 13 years old, but to our suprise the beds were more like a full size bed and the two of us could share one bed comfortably. The room was big enough for the three of us and our luggage. Bathroom was spacious for Japan standards. It took a little getting use to the step up into the bathroom. Lots of neat features through out the room for example, you have to place your key card in a holder near the door to active the lights, so when you leave and take your card out all the lights go off! The rest you can explore when you are in the room.Service was great. Room was immaculate. Bedding was very comforatble. They were very responsive when I emailed them questions prior to our arrival.Direct access to Ginzaitchōme Station Exit No. 11 on the Metro Yurakucho Line . You need your key card to access your floor in the elevator, so it's very secure. Only a block or two away from all the department stores. Tsukiji was walking distance maybe a leisure 20 minutes, It's a great way to walk up an appetite for sushi breakfast! We just took a chance with one of the resturants and it was great! Sorry can't give you the name or directions, it's a maze in there.We took the Narita Express to Tokyo Station and then Taxi to the hotel. (Make sure you get directions in Japanese from hotel.) We got the N'EX and SUICA package at the Travel Center at the Narita Airport Terminal 1 Level B1F(Go down one level after you exit customs). That was the best thing we did. With the SUICA card you don't have to worry about buying tickets for the complicated transit systems. You can charge it (add more money) at any of the fare machines, some even have English.

Nightlife in Ginza isn't much but if you like a quiet, central place to stay, this is it. There is a subway station - Ginza ichome metro station underneath, four (that we found) convenient stores on adjacent blocks to the hotel, 24hr MacDonalds right next door - pretty handy we thought. The location of the hotel is only about 1.5km from the Imperial Palace (great for runners like us who want to run the 6km circuit around the moat) and about the same to the fish markets. Two upmarket department stores are only a few hundred metres away and you're only about 100-200m away for the main glitzy street of GinzaThe room was small (as you would expect in Tokyo) and not much of a view out of the window but very clean. Internet was free though not wireless. The bed was firm and comfortable. We had x5 16hr days back-to-back and each night we had no problem getting to sleep. The service was outstanding as I had sent emails regarding how to get to the place earlier. Replies were thorough and sent promptly with maps and instructions to give to the taxi driver. They have staff that speak English and Chinese (I believe). We would certainly stay there again.

Stayed for 1 night. Didn't expect much. Maybe that made my review better....Its room, we had twin room (2 beds). Beds are wider than average single size. Mattress is very comfortable. Hotel seems very new. Bathroom has bathtub (although it was kinda small, it is fine as Japanese business hotel) Shower had great water pressure, had basic amenities, like shampoo and conditioner, body shampoo, soap, toothbrush and paste, hair dryer, and sleeping gown, Yukata Japanese style bathrobe. Room had kettle, tea, coffee(free), minibar, fridge space that you can put your own stuff. Ice machine on each floor It is located in GINZA, one of the busiest area of Tokyo. You can find most of the stuff you might think of within short walking distance. There are few 24 hr open convenience stores within a block. Major shopping street is just 1 min away. Metro station closest to the hotel is Ginza 1chome on Yurakucho line but you can walk easily from Yurakucho (JR or metro) station, or Ginza metro station. Only thing is it might not have lift of escalator access all the way to ground level. So if you have heavy big suitcase, you might just want to follow what hotel website suggest, take taxi from Tokyo station. (although I even walked to Tokyo station) There are so many restaurant and pubs and bars and everything near the hotel. Hotel staff speak excellent English and saw more non-Japanese guests at this hotel while I was there.

I stayed in the Mercure Ginza twice during our trip to Japan. Overall it was a great choice. You can tell it was cozy no-frills style accommodation, yet it has everything you need with great service. ROOMSI booked a queen bed room which had no view (unless looking into the office building windows next door counts as a view). The bed was comfy, small but adequete storage space and desk area, which was a real surprise considering the amount of luggage I had (skis and ski boots). The bathroom amenities provided were more than enough. The only thing that needed getting used to were the lighting system and how to use the hot and cold taps in the shower. Luckily commonsense prevailed within a few hours of checking in!PUBLIC AREASDon't expect someone to help you with your bags and ensure you dont leave anything behind as the reception desk is on the 2nd floor. The second time I stayed, the staff offered to carry our bags downstairs- I wasn't sure why as they never bothered the first time round. All staff have good English and were very helpful with Limosuine bus transfers and taxi pick ups etc. They were also helpful in letting us store some of our luggage while we went to other parts of Japan till our return. There is one computer that has free Wi-fi access just outside the only restaurant in the hotel. I didn't use the restaurant as there was a Maccas (and the rest of Tokyo for that matter) under the building and the menu looked a little pricey. LOCATIONThe hotel is under the train subway- all you need is a Suica Card which you can obtain at the Tokyo airport and you're set to go anywhere you want within the city. As mentioned before, there is a McDonalds under the hotel as well as a Lawson's convenience store, Starbucks and several vending machines. The hotel itself does not stand out as it's a grey high rise tucked away in the back street. I always used landmarks such as Chanel, Louis Vuitton, Maccas and the Bvlgari signs to guide us back home! TIPS- Always have the address of the hotel writen down preferably in japanese as cab drivers aren't known for being bi-lingual- Learn a few phrases in japanese to help out the cab drivers- Front Tokyo station it is less than 1000 yen to the hotel. - have your itinerary handy in case there are any disputes. I personally had no problems but there would be nothing more frustrating than arguing to someone in a foreign country over who's right and who's wrong!- be prepared for 'service charges' added at the end of a bill in japan in general. its normally 5% but still be aware in case someone tries to rip you off

Excellent location with Yurakucho subway access on Floor B1. You can also walk underground all the way to Ginza Station which is nice when it is raining. Staff was friendly and spoke good English. They also have a couple of in-house guides to three popular areas of Tokyo; Imperial Palace, Asakusa, and Ueno. They give step by step instructions on how to get there including which subway tickets to buy. My wife and I found these especially useful being unexpected first-time visitors. Room was standard size in Japan and the hotel provides many bathroom amenities, basically everything you need except deodorant. Breakfast is buffet style and cost 2000 yen per person.

The Mercure Ginza is located in one of the most expensive areas in the world, and yet we were able to stay there for a very reasonable rate by booking through their loyalty program. We took the taxi from Tokyo station as we had just flown in with several bags and a 6 month old baby and didn't think negotiating the subway system was the best plan. The trip came in the for the minimum fare so worked out only marginally more than the subway would have been. The staff at reception were excellent. Very helpful with a good command of English. Our room and all of the public spaces were very clean and elegant. The room was small, but that is to be expected at a hotel of this level in Japan. The bed was very comfortable and the bathroom was quite spacious. I would probably have preferred a smaller bathroom and more room in the living space.There was free internet access in the lobby near the restaurant although it was quite slow with an outdated browser and only one machine.We ate at the French restaurant on the lobby floor on our first night and enjoyed impeccable service. The food was quite rich, but we both had our fill and were able to relax.The hotel is less than 2 minutes from Matsuya - one of the main department stores in Ginza - and is surrounded by both Japanese and Western food vendors including two Starbucks within a block, McDonalds in the same building, a tempura restaurant, soba restaurant and donburi restaurant all within a block and an excellent bar serving a wide range of sake about 1.5 blocks away. We got disoriented for the first couple of days, as the hotel is in the midst of a highrise jungle.

Stayed 4 nights - 4 adults + a 2YO. Rooms very small. Staff were very helpful with very good spoken English. Buffet breakfast was satisfactory. Again need the hotel address in Japanese to have any chance that the taxi driver will find the hotel. The location is exscellent with easy access to everything the Ginza can offer. Many restaurants nearby as well as McDonalds and Starbucks. We purchased a suica card and caught the Narita Express into Tokyo Station and a taxi to the hotel. We left from Haneda airport to travel to Sapporo. There is a metro (Higashi Ginza) just around the corner from the hotel that travels direct to Haneda airport.

For the price we paid (about US$100/night), it's really worth it. The hotel is very small and basic, with only 1 restaurant, no bell hops. The room is reasonably good for a Ginza small hotel stay, slightly bigger than most japanese hotels I've stayed in. At least I can move around, even in the bathroom! The basement is connected to GINZA ITCHOME-11, and it's only 5 mins walk to Ginza station, 5-10 mins to Kabuki Za Theater. It's not within walking distance of Tokyo station, but a 5-10 min taxi ride that is not considered costly if you have 4 persons with lots of luggages. Various cafes and a McDonald's are located nearby, with a Lawson supermarket just round the corner. Very convenient.For shopping, the whole of Ginza is there. Louis Vuitton and Bulgari are only a block away.

My family of 3 adults and a 16 year old stayed in 2 adjacent rooms on the 9th floor of the Ginza Mercure this week. We found the rooms to be a reasonable size for Tokyo, fitting two suitcases each with room to spare. The beds were comfortable, rooms very clean and quiet and bathrooms well sized. The restaurant is basic but provided an adequate breakfast. Free broadband using provided ethernet cable was excelent. We would recommend this hotel to you! We travelled into Tokyo via the Narita Express. Purchased "Green" reserved seats and a Suica pass each through the JR office which is easy to find. The unreserved seats would be fine to purchase but as we had flown from Sydney the larger more comfortable seats of the Green reserved carriage were preferred. JR have an excellent website. Print off the map to make your way around the terminal easier.From Tokyo station we caught 2 taxis (4 people + 4 suitacses and hand luggage would not fit into one taxi) to the hotel. I had the name and address printed off in Japanese for the drivers as they do not speak english. The fare was about YEN800 for ne of us and YEN950 for the other! When we left Tokyo ecaught the TCAT bus to the terminal which was really straight forward and easy. The hotel booked us 4 seats which we paid for at the hotel and were given vouchers. We caught 2 taxis to the TCAT terminal and traded the vouchers for tickets. At our departure time there were plenty of seats on the bus and the trip took about an hour straight to Terminal 2. We had a Tokyo Free Guide on the first day of our stay which was marvellous! Having a guide helped us orientate ourselves and we learnt how to use the subway system so that on day 2 we were able to get around ourselves. Look up their website and book early.

As per the other recent reviews I agree with everything. We did have a couple of hassles and they were nothing to do with the hotel. First one was we caught the airport express train into Tokyo station and bought a coke on the train and it cost A$10, we knew it was expensive in Tokyo but that was rediculous but soon realised it was just on the train as the thousands of vending machines where only about A$2. The only other problem was we found the taxi rank after a little searching at Tokyo station and no one knew where the Mecure was, I had printed out the name etc of the website but I think because it was in english he didnt understand and then he asked his supervisor and it took about 15mins before we got going and then got to Ginza and he just kept driving around until my mother saw the sign and we found it, so suggest you check the exact address & phone number to show the driver. Otherwise great trip, We did hire a private guide for just the 2 of us for the day and that was great, we saw so much and really covered a lot of area in a short amount of time. Only suggest a couple of days in Tokyo then get out into the real Japan.

We stayed for 4 nights in this hotel November 2009. 5 minutes by cab from the Tokyo Shinkansen (Y710) or 15 mins on foot. There is a 24-hour Mcdonald's at the ground floor of the hotel and a 24-hour convenience store across the street. the main shopping street of Ginza is 100 meters from the perimeter of the hotel. There is subway line at the basement of the hotel, 3 subway lines 5 minutes walk and the JR Yamanote line 8 mins walk. Deluxe rooms have a width of 4 meters and Superior rooms have a width of 3 meters. Overall a good value hotel given the location and price.

Well located at the Ginza Ichome station. Main Chuo Street where all the big department stores like mitsukoshi and the retail stores are just steps away. there's a Macdonald's downstairs, coffee places just across the street, convenience stores and restaurants and little boutiques surrounding the hotel. Main ginza station is an easy 5-7 min walk. another plus is accessibility to Disneyland as cited by others 4-5 stops away although you need to make one swithch. Tsukiji market is a very easy 10-12 min walk with many little shops and cafes along the way as is the kabuki theatre is that's what you are interested in. Would recommend taking a bus to JCAT terminal and taking a taxi directly to the hotel. From Tokyo station a bit of a nightmare...even finding exit to taxi stand. Notably very no-frills. no porter and reception is on 2nd floor. If w. family, would recommend the upgrade to deluxe rooms...as you can add an extra bed.
Good Location. If u wanna go Disney.....take a lift to B1 for the subway! Nice room of decent size!

This is not a full service hotel, as this is rare in Japan. You will not have someone to carry bags or wait on you hand and foot in your room. This can be had in Tokyo, but at an extreme price, certainly far above what the very reasonable Mercure charges.That said, this business/leisure hotel is in one of the most expensive shopping areas of Tokyo (without the usual corresponding prices for the rooms) and you can expect a beautifuly quiet night's sleep here without traffic or train noise interrupting. The Subway is at the end of the street (50 meters) or you can jump the JR line with another 2 minutes walk. Ginza Dori is only 2 short blocks away for a little shopping. Tokyo station (take the Narita Express in from the airport to here) is only 700 yen by taxi, door to door.The rooms are small, but not by Japanese standards. They are welll fitted out and pleasant on the eye, not to mention, spotlessly clean of course. Free internet in the rooms is standard (are you listening Paris!!!), as are the local English newspapers.The staff were fantastic - all spoke good English, knew the area well and were only too happy to recommend restaurants, nightlife and touring spots. They also helped on the phone talking to the taxi driver so he could find the place from Tokyo station! Good food is available all around the area and you need only walk 10 paces before another Izakaya or food store comes into view from the hotel's front door. A comprehensive gaijin styled breakfast is available at the 2nd floor restaurant for a reasonable price each morning, if you get sick of rice and uncooked eggs.A great central base to explore the whole of Tokyo.

We stayed here for 5 nights and enjoyed the location for shopping and being centrally located for sighseeing and near the metro. The hotel's reception is on the second floor and there are no amenities to speak of. the staff are helpful but don't expect help with your luggage or the extra touches which you might receive elsewhere. Initially we were given a very small room (2 adults and one child aged 2yrs) and so requested to be moved and luckily there were larger rooms available so we were moved. This area is not for those wanting nightlife but we tended to explore other areas of Tokyo as well as Ginza and find a restaurant for dinner on the way back and retire earlyish with a toddler ! If we were to visit Tokyo again we would stay in Shinjuku/Shibuya area as this is more buzzy/trendy with more restaurants etc

On a business trip to Japan stayed with my wife in Mercure ginza the heart of Tokyo its surrounded by fantastics malls and shopping cenre and 20 metres away was a very good Indian resturent called Old Delhi on the 4 the floor public transport and train stations only few steps from the hotel the rooms though small are well equipped all amenties and good courteuos staff

We had a pleasure of staying at this hotel. Very good location in the heart of Ginza. The Ginza-itchome subway access (Yurakucho line) was just underneath the hotel. Perfect for exploring the whole of Tokyo with convenient access to Disney. The room size is ok for us w/ free internet (you can rent a laptop too). Staffs speak good english. Service was fast when we requested for extra pillows & blankets. Across the street were 2 convenience stores Lawson & Am/Pm - perfect for hungry night owls and quick refreshments. Few meters away is McDonalds. And of course the upscale shopping district of Ginza where you will find all the high-end fashion brands.

The hotel had a great location, easilly accessible by rail. The room was clean as was the bed and bathroom. I stayed in a room with a double bed which was enough for me, but others may consider the room small. The view from the room was into the side street, but if you are the type of traveller like me that only spends time in their room to shower, sleep and store your bags, then the room size is fine.

Location was perfect (around 2 blocks from the main Ginza shopping district). There were restaurants and convenience stores everywhere. The staff were very pleasant and courteous. Hotel was very modern. The only down side of this hotel was that rooms were so small we could barely open a medium sized luggage. They say this is what you usually get for a GInza hotel.

Stayed for 3 nights in early April for sakura season. If you are coming for serious shopping in Tokyo, this is the hotel for you. Well-located for shopping and people-watching in Ginza. Lot of small restaurants and cafes around the area. Ours was double room so a little on small side. Do ask for a twin room for more space. Room was very clean though and the bed and pillows comfortable. Breakfast was adequate but the waiters could have been more friendly.All-in-all, an above average stay.

This hotel has it all.1. Price - I'm an Accor Advantage Plus member and I booked the room on their prepaid plan (no refunds) and paid less than 11,000 Yen per night (including tax). Best thing is that because it was prepaid, my credit card was charged about 6 months ago - when the Yen was much lower, compared to my Singaporean dollar. Altogether it costed about SGD160 per night. Oh yeah, I used my free night's stay for the 2nd night. Weird thing is that they have different rates for different nights.2. Location - Ginza Itchome subway station is linked to the hotel by an underpass. Very convenient for me. But note, the walk from the actual subway gate is about 3-4 minutes, and there are about 3 flights of stairs in all - not wheelchair accessible. McDonalds is just next door. They're having a promotion - 100 Yen each for the pork burger (yeah you heard right), hamburger (sometimes known as junior burger), chicken cutlet, small milkshake and coffee / soft drinks.Just around the corner (5 minutes' walk) is the street with all the big department stoes (Matsuya Ginza).For Disneyland visitors, you take the train from the Ginza Itchome station 5 stops up, change line and go one more stop. Takes only about 20 minutes in all.3. Staff - all speak English.4. Room - size is smallish, but not that bad. Bigger than what I've seen in Hong Kong. Comfortable. But the bed's hard and the pillow's a bit high. Toilet / washlet / bidet system is cool!!!! I can't get enough of this!!!5. Amenities - Toiletries include - hairbrush, shaving kit, toothbrush kit (2), cotton buds and facial pads, body gel, shampoo, conditioner (al by kose), soap, tissue paper.tea and coffee making facilities are included. 6. Restaurant - breakfast is 2100 Yen per person. I used my Accor card for a 50% discount for 2 people.Breakfast includes a "Continental breakfast" section of bread, pastries, cereal, yoghurt, fruit and salad, an "American breakfast" section (steamed broccoli and cauliflower, sausages and bacon), and a "Japanese breakfast" section (miso soup, rice with sachets of flavoring, Japanese style omelette, pickles, some kind of fish, not sure if it's cured or raw or ..., cold Japanese meatballs, and other unidentified Japanese items). Drinks include tea, coffee, hot chocolate, green tea and juices. Very comprehensive guide, like I just ate it... OH YEAH I DID!!! Lol... I'm writing from the hotel!!!!!7. FREE INTERNET!!!! All rooms come with free internet now!!! Woo hoo!!! Read that they charged for it just recently, Must have had too many complains. Good for me!!!How's that for the details? Lonely Planet should give me a job...
Very small rooms but they are very clean and cozy. Not far from Ginza str., destination - super.

After a slight hiccup (were given wrong grade of room) everything was great. Hotel has recently been renovated. Beds very comfortable (essential) and pillows a cross between Japanese/European OK. Very conveniently placed near the Ginza. Many small restaurants adjacent to hotel (also 7/11s). Considering Tokyo prices this hotel represents very good value. Don't be put off by street access it is much better above. Hotel has access to the subway system by internal lift. Highly recommended.

Mercure Ginza has a good location, of course not on main road, but not too dificult to find...stayed few days, and good stay, room is not too big but size still ok, we are in japan.... breakfast is good, mixed with japanese and french style breakfast, bread is excellent....try the dinner, the food is excellent as well, overall stay very good, just only one negative point is about the bar, no bar really in this hotel.....staff is helpul and speak english very well, as well french....

This is our second time staying in this hotel. It is very conveniently located, the basement has direct access to a metro station and is walking distance from JR Yurakucho Station, which is excellent for people using the Rail Pass. Mercure is also located centrally in Ginza area. The room might seem small to some people but it is a standard hotel room size in Japan. So is normal and the place is very clean and comfortable.

We stayed there for 4 nights with our 5 year old. Loved the place, it's clean, staff are very professional, conveniently located. Walking around the area, you will find lots of local eateries at reasonable prices. Famous American fast food chain located just below the hotel, which was convenient as my son loved having the breakfast there. A few 24 hour type shops located nearby to get snacks or drinks. Getting there wasn't too much of a problem if you follow the instructions provided by the hotel but I suggest getting the Japanese name to give to the cab driver. We took the train from the airport to TOkyo station and then took a short taxi ride from the station to the hotel.
Clean, have all the basic necessities that I need.Good location in ginza area.

Have just returned from a week long stay with colleagues at the Mercure Ginza and in the main found it to be a pleasant stay and would recommend this hotel for anyone looking for a central base in Ginza. The hotel is located in a side a side street and after getting into a cab at Tokyo station it was soon clear that our cab driver (and another one he asked for directions) didn’t know where the hotel was. I suppose it didn’t help that the taxi driver was not just unable to understand the map, he was in fact drunk, but that’s another story. If you are getting a cab then see if you can get the address of the hotel in Japanese. After the first day it was clear that the best option was the metro and the hotel has a basement entrance from the station.My room was of a decent standard, clean and functional. It was fine for me on a weeks visit however had I brought more luggage or had my wife with me then things would have been a bit cramped and storage would have been a problem, however from reading reviews on other hotels space seems to be an issue at most of the reasonably priced hotels. Plenty of complimentary toiletries were supplied along with adequate tea, coffee and a morning newspaper. The air conditioning system was easy to operate, responsive and most of all quiet. Because of the hotels location it is very quiet at night and unless you are on the top floors not much of a view from the windows. I only had breakfast once at the hotel and it was fine but there are so many decent coffee shops around the hotel (Starbucks and a local chain Dotour) it’s cheaper to eat out. The reception staff were fine and my wife had no problems at all getting through when calling from the UK. I had some laundry done during my stay and that wasn’t as expensive as I thought but there is a huge hike in the price for Sundays and public holidays.Some points to note. If you want an early check in confirm with the hotel first, I did and still had to wait until exactly (and I mean exactly) 2pm before being given my pass card. There are also a number of smoking rooms so book ahead to avoid these. There is only one laptop with internet access for general use and although free there did tend to always be a wait and it wasn’t private as you would have people waiting behind you whilst you read your e mails.On the whole a good stay with no problems in a great central location.

We paid $180 / night, and our room was really nice, if a little small. Our room was really clean and cute. The place is a little hard to find, it's basically near really high-end stores, so if you've got a girlfriend with an expensive taste, beware because she could get stuck in Tiffany's or Gucci's when walking to and from the hotel.Great location. If I come back to Japan, I'd definitely book here again.
The Mercure hotel in Ginza is a great place to stay. The hotel was clean, the rooms were large and the location was great! Would stay here again

We have stayed here about 4-5 times over the past few years. We choose it for it's location. If we are needing to be in the Ginza area or on the east side of Tokyo it is very handy to everywhere. The rooms have everything you need and are very clean and tidy. The view is city view, the room size is small, compact really. Internet connection great. Comfy beds. Good for a short stay.Check in and check out is smooth and the reception is on the 2nd floor, take the lift. Limited parking is available but there is a size restriction. Lots of cafes nearby so have never gotten around to trying out the restaurant, on the same floor as the lobby.

I enjoyed my stay in this hotel. The hotel is well located and has the added convenience of a subway entrance in the basement of the hotel. The station is the Ginza Ichome station on the Yurakucho line. Getting to the actual subway still requires a few minutes of walking underground, however. The hotel is located near restaurants and shops and there is a convenience store right outside.I had a room with a double bed and it was comfortable and much larger than I expected. The room had a safe and the bathroom was immaculate. The staff spoke fluent English and were very courteous. The breakfast at the restaurant is good, but pricey. The only disappointment was having to pay for wired internet. I walked to the hotel after arriving at Tokyo Station. The walk took about 15-20 minutes with my bags. Exit the station on Sotobori-Dori and walk south until you see a Wendy’s on your left. Take a left at the Wendys and walk past the Ginza Itchome subway station. You will find the hotel on your right. The hotel is located near the Tokyo Station, but you have to change trains to get between them. Take one of the trains (not the subway) to Yurakucho Station and then change to the Yurakucho line subway for one stop Ginza Itchome. By the time you make the changes, you aren’t saving much walking, however.In summary, a comfortable well located hotel with convenient access to the subway. I wouldn’t hesitate to stay in this hotel again.

We stayed in Mercure Ginza for 5 nights and could not be happier with their services. All the staff speak good english and offered useful tips for locations & other enquiries.The location is gd, central and very good if you want to go to Tokyo disney, you do not need to go through the busy & often confusing Tokyo station. We went to Nikko & Kinugawa & is convenient as there is a direct line to Tobu Asakusa station.On top of that, there is free internet access & ICE machine!! Which is very helpful during the height of summer.In all, although some might find it a bit dead at night, I personally like the quietness & peace after a long day of sightseeing & walking.

This hotel is located in the central Ginza district of Tokyo. The rooms are small, the bathroom is small, storage space is minimal and the step up into the bathroom in some rooms is about 50cm (not good for the elderly). The area is nice, with interesting food halls a however the shopping is expensive and mainly includes western or European brands. Also, language can be a real problem with many menus and signs written only in Hiragana or Kanji. Language is a positive for the hotel, as they have a number of English-speaking staff on hand. The view from many hotel rooms is non-existent. Also, the room I stayed in was poorly laid out with a chair blocking access to part of the room. The breakfast was ok, but did not have a huge variety when it came to choice. The hotel also did not have any leisure facilities like a pool or a gym, which was a shame.Overall, I would say the Mercure Ginza hotel is reasonable, but don't go there expecting too much.

Good central location in Ginza shopping district area. I used Metro to get to Hotel either of the Ginza stations are very close by. Taxi from Tokyo station is also a short ride away. I think this hotel is above the normal standard of a Mercure with nice extras in the room such as Japanese bath robe and slippers. Rooms are also nicely decorated and larger than the Mercure hotel at Narita. I thought the room was actually spacious by other standard of Japanese similar star rating hotels. Helpful full English speaking staff. Facility for secure left luggage is available. Hotel area is busy by day but a bit dead by night when the shops close but a very very safe area even late at night. There are many local restaurants around but some are very pricey so do check before.If you want to stay in Ginza at a reasonable price for the area then this hotel is perfect. However the area is a bit characterless compaired to other more busy areas especially by night and more pricey.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel on a business trip to Tokyo. Our clients booked the room for us, based on their knowledge of the area. We agree with the other reviews -- the Mercure is very nice and in a great location. Getting to check-in can be a bit of a challenge. We found that the best approach for the money is to take the Limousine Bus service from the airport to Tokyo Station. The bus service handled all of our bags for us, without our having to negotiate stairs or escalators; then we put our bags directly on a taxi at Tokyo Station. The taxi from Tokyo bus/train station to the hotel was quick and inexpensive. Hotel Reception is on the second floor, so managing the bags into the elevator was cumbersome. A luggage trolly is available in reception, and hotel staff will convey your luggage for you. Internet connection was $9 per day via ethernet. However, there is a McDonalds next door that must have WiiFi because we were often able to access a public wireless line at no charge.We had a "deluxe" room, which was quite small but adequate. Closet space was minimal.

My husband and I visited the Mercure Ginaz in Tokyo for 5 days, it was a superb location, walkable to nearly everything and a great station nearby Ginza Line. Staff at hotel were fabolous,all spoke v ery good english and could not be more helpful with maps, stations and booking airport transfersRoom was smallish but beautifully clean, we had clean kimonos, slippers and towels every day.Breakfast was not included but loads of breakfast shops around, with set breakfasts for all tastes.Will definately stay again with the Mercure group, I have been recommended to join the Accor Group as the discounts in all their hotels are good.Restaurants on top of department stores were fab, the freshest sushi ever at Tsunki Fish Market, everywhere we went was perfection,

We stayed 5 nights at the beginning of April. Our plan from the airport was to buy a Narita Express + Suica card package at the JR Office at Narita Station. The N'Ex ticket got us to Tokyo Main Station plus a transfer to Yurakucho Station. We then planned to use our Suica cards to get the subway to Ginza Ichome right under the hotel. Unfortunately the escalators ran out at Yurakucho, and we had to lug cases down stairways. At that point we took a taxi. In retrospect, taking a taxi from Tokyo Main Station would have been straightforward and no more expensive, as it is not far from the Mercure.The Mercure has a small but functional reception area and a good breakfasting restaurant. The rooms have pretty much all you need, Nicely furnished, flat screen telly, electric toilet. However our room was so narrow, and had one very small wardrobe and virtually no drawers. My wife used the wardrobe, and I pretty much lived out of my case. However hotels, like most things in life, are a compromise. You can put up with a lot for the location in the heart of Ginza, with department stores, restaurants and coffee shops all around.The Imperial Palace Gardens are a pleasant stroll away, and with the subway station under the hotel you can get most places quickly.We booked a coach trip to Fuji from hotel reception, and were picked up the next morning. As well as visiting Hakone, this trip took us up to the second level of Fuji, from where we had wonderful views of the mountain, plus a snowball fight!

i am a frequent travler spending close to 200 days on the road each year primarily for business in asia. i like 3/4 star hotels that focus on businessmen and i had stayed in the mercure in shanghai which was a great experience. even though i go to tokyo at least once each year, i booked this hotel for the first time because my meetings were at pccw near tokyo train station. the location is great because one is close to the interesting part of the ginza. it was also a 10 minute walk to pccw building.negatives: rooms were incredibly small. because i was travelling with my wife to tokyo who was also working there, we felt that the standard rooms were too claustraphobic and we had to upgrade just to get a bit more space. our original room had maybe 3 feet between the end of the bed and the wall; only one very small window. upgrading resulted in increasing our room rate by nearly 50%.by changing rooms, we also ended up in a smoking rather than non-smoking room. no wireless connection in the room and one needed to use a lan cable to hook up to the internet. the daily internet rate was reasonable, but we ended getting charged twice each day because they charge based on number of computers logging onto the system. when i asked them to deduct one internet charge, they were rude and refused to make the change eventhough my upgrade was $100 per day.because of this behavior at checkout, i will not stay here again.

Great location if you are taking metro, but can be a bit tiring for female travelers to walk from Yurakucho, the nearest railway station, with a heavy suitcase. Catching a taxi can be a solution but avoid rush hours! Rooms are small but can't complain considering the location and the price. Like most of the Japanese hotels, amenities are fairly good. The bathroom is quite spacious and the bed wide enough which are probably the reasons why I've came back here several times despite the unfriendly staff! I don't recommend the French restaurant, overpriced for the quality. But still you have many options to dine out anyways. . . Enjoy your stay!

A great hotel, in a fantastic location in an amazing city!!! Reception is on the 2nd floor, so the ground level is nothing special. The 2nd floor is accessed by stairs or lift. The only downside of the hotel is the size of the rooms - rather small, but perfecty formed! The bathroom was snug but immaculate, with clean kimonos and slippers every day. There is a safety deposit box in the room which is free, and a small fridge. Plasma tv on the wall opposite the bed, and a radio alarm clock. Even the toilet was electronic! This hotel is less then 2 minutes from the main street through Ginza, and about 5 minute walk to the subway station. Please use the subway - it's straight forward when you get the hang of it, and very clean and safe. The subway map on the wall inside of the station has numbers in place of the station names - this number is the price you have to pay for your journey. If you decide to travel further there is a 'fare adjustment' machine at each station so you can top up your fare accordingly to enable you to leave the station through the electronic gates. Breakfast in the hotel is good - a little over priced but sets you up for the day in a city where they don't do 'breakfast food' like we do! The city felt very safe at night time, and the road between the hotel and the main Ginza street is well lit and with plenty of people about. I'd stay here again without a doubt. Enjoy Tokyo!

Upscale hotel w/ english speaking staff.Great location in the Ginza district. You can goout and walk to all the major shopping areas. Close to rail transportation. I even went for an jog around the Imperial Palace, about 45 min run.Its got the push button spray toilet which I had never seen before.

We were only staying for one night in Tokyo, we had large amounts of luggage, and this was our first trip to Asia. So we needed something easy.Which is pretty much what we got - having missed the instructions for the hotel buses leaving from narita airport, we caught the train into the central Tokyo. From there we went one stop on the tube (subway) to Ginza. You can go to Ginza Itchome which is directly under the hotel, but for ease, the hotel is still walking distance from Ginza. Once in Ginza station, make a note of how the blocks are numbered on the maps outside the turnstiles. I think on the same map there it also shows where the Mercure Ginza is located. Exit out of A13 which is about a 5 minute walk from where you come out of the turnstiles.As for the hotel itself, the staff were friendly and helpful. The rooms were clean and the bathroom quite spacious. It contains all of the mod-cons (including those famous Japanese toilets with bidet etc on it). Bathrobes and slippers are also provided. The international paper written in English dropped outside our room was a nice touch - at least the staff pay attention. All in all, this is a simple hotel - good for a place to lay your head. We found it relatively easy to get to Haneda airport from there as well.

We stayed at this hotel three times when we were in Japan because we had our flight to Tokyo, then we were in the North, then Tokyo, then Kyoto and Hiroshima and at last back to Tokyo. The staff were great. Always smiling and very helpful. When we arrived, jet-lagged, didn't know if we were eating breakfast, lunch or dinner, we went to the restaurant to eat. I ate salmon. It was the best fish-dinner I have ever had! The breakfast was in the same restaurant. It was buffet-style and there were choices between Japanese or Western breakfast.The hotel is in the middle of the shopping-district. FANTASTIC!When we went to Kyoto and Hiroshima the staff were very kind to collect one of our suitcases.I can not recommend this hotel highly enough!
Mit diesem Hotel kann nichts schiefgehen. Wir waren so angenehm überrascht vom boutiqueartigen Ambiente, den schönen, stilvollen Zimmern und den überraschend geräumigen Badezimmern.

I enjoyed my stay at this hotel, the room were clean, service were excellent, the staff were polite and could speak excellent English. The hotel provided a shared computer for internet access. The breakfast buffet was good - quite a lot to eat. The hotel is located a street behind the main shopping area in Ginza. However, if your purpose to Tokyo is mainly for shopping, I would recommend staying in Shinjuku rather than Ginza. There is not much to see in Ginza after 8pm, also the restaurants are comparatively more expensive than anywhere else in Tokyo. Another downside about this hotel is that it is not easily accessible from Narita Airport as the airport coaches does not drop you off directly at the hotel, the nearest drop off point was Tokyo Station, u then had to take a taxi to the hotel. Another problem is that the taxi driver had no idea where this hotel was as they said that this hotel is not very well known in Ginza area. You must print a map of the hotel to show the driver. All in all, I enjoyed my stay at this hotel. But if I could choose again, I would prefer to stay in Shinjuku as most aiport coaches stop in most of the hotel around that area.

This hotel was a great find. Room was a good size, as was bathroom. Great value. Location was fantastic (although a little hard to find) in the great area of Ginza - all the shops on your doorstep. We loved the furnishings, and the reception staff were very friendly and efficient. Would stay here again.

This is a good and not too pricey hotel at Ginza area. The staff is very efficient and can speak good English. The room is consider big in Japanese standard. I stayed at the Superior Twin Room. The bed is bigger than the normal single bed, each bed can take up to 2 person (of asian size). The location is close to 2 Metro lines and also the JR line. All within walking distance. Very convenient. There is a 24hr Macdonald just next to the hotel, and ample cafes, resturants and eateries at the area.The only complaint that I had is the transfer from the Narita Airport to the hotel. Must change at the Tokyo Station or Ueno Station to Ginza. Nevertheless, I will definitely stay there again.

For a hotel in the heart of Ginza, it is quite tastefully done. Aside from the French motif in the hallway red wallpaper, B&W framed photos of Paris scenes, and the random young cynical French male national serving in the dining room, you will not feel schizophrenic about where you are in the world. The rooms are clean, small, yet extra-efficient. Paying just a bit more for the next size up (a few square feet more and still small) was certainly worthwhile, and we only had one suitcase. There is not much of a view, but the almost perfect location more than compensates for that. Just a hop (by foot or cab ride) to the Tokyo JR Yamanote line station and hops to 2 or 3 subway stations with access to the rest of the city (Ginza station was invariably the most useful). The single most important aspect of this hotel’s location though is the walking distance proximity to the Tsukiji fish market—best visited at 5:00am, the perfect antidote to jet lag for the American or European visitor!The breakfast is not fantastic but still OK and convenient to have readily available before heading out on a long day. And, certainly good coffee is on offer—what else would you expect from the French. As an alternative, Starbucks is around the corner, if you happen to be that type. The best culinary “secret” though is the food court in the basement of the next-door department stores, Takashiyama, Mitsukoshi, Matsuzakaya. Reasonably priced with a large variety of Japanese fair. No place to sit though—so takeaway is the deal! The service at the hotel is excellent. The staff is young and ready to give you reliable advice on getting around or anything else you might want to learn about. All-in-all, a perfect hotel, especially if you are visiting Tokyo for the first time and want to feel close to “everything”.

The hotel is located in Ginza, close to department stores and offices nearby. A subway exit (Ginza I-chome, exit 11) is lcoated at the basement which opens from 7:00-22:00. It is also walkable from Tokyo train station (20-30 minutes walk) which connects to the Narita Airport in less than an hour. The room is reasonably large in size according to Tokyo standard and the service is ok. However, the breakfast offers very limited choices and there is no other public facilities (gym, business centre etc.) at the hotel, though one notebook computer (with Internet access) is available for use next to the restaurant.

We stayed at the Mercure Ginza for four nights. I have to say I expected a hotel of a better class after having read the reviews here. Mercure is your basic tourist class hotel, nothing more. The location is excellent, however.

The Mercure Ginza was quite hard to find in the Ginza area of Tokyo as all the streets do not run in numerical order, however, once found it was more than adequate. The rooms were small but had everything you need, including the all singing, all dancing japanese tiolet that even had heating! A great feature was that you did not have to go through the lobby everytime you went out, as the lobby was situated on the 2nd floor. Security was good as you had to put your room key into a slot to go higher in the lift to your room. The breakfast was buffet style and had everything from rice to muffins. Only objection I would point out would be the area the hotel is in - Ginza is very westernised and has mostly department stores and big grand names such as Cartier, so if you're looking for a 'japanese experience' this wouldn't suit. In saying that, the way the bathrooms are set up in your room is very japanese - sliding doors made from glass in panels and they provide the traditional japanese robes. The rooms were clean and had tea making equipment, tv etc. The bed was very comfortable. The views were of other office/shop skyscrapers.All in all, I probably would use this hotel again.

Immaculately kept, modern hotel in great location right in the heart of Ginza. We stayed in a double room with 2 queen sized beds and though not large, the room was perfectly adequate and cleaned everyday to perfection. Trendy loo and excellent power shower over the bath, freebies in room and mini-bar with enough room for your own water and food. Very cheap local calls from the room phone was re-assuring when I got the bill. Very varied Eastern and Western buffet breakfast from 6.30- at least 10am is good for the jet-lag and was included in our room-rate. Didn't eat in the hotel otherwise - just so many other places to choose from. All the staff are bi-lingual and very friendly. This was our first trip to Japan and I will stay at the hotel again.Ginza is rather like the Bond Street area - smart shops and boutiques but not very cutting edge. Hotel within 15 min walk of Tokyo Station or short taxi ride. Ask hotel to give you directions back to hotel in Japanese ( even print a map to the hotel before you leave) and print out maps in Japanese as taxi drivers rarely speak any English and certainly don't read it and they don't map-read very well - even with Japanese maps but v. friendly. We took JR Line train from Narita Airport which was superb, v.efficient -just under 1 hr from Airport terminal. Hope you enjoy your trip as much as us.

This hotel is in the perfect location....in the nice shopping and restaurant area of Ginza and walkable to the Tokyo Train Station. Tokyo can be so expensive and so this reasonably priced hotel in such a great location is a jewel. The rooms are not huge but are definitely large enough so you don't feel like you are in a closet. We stayed 2 nights and then went to Kyoto for one night and returned to this hotel for our last night in Tokyo. When we returned for the last night, the check-in person upgraded our room to a larger room which was a nice surprise. There is a computer next to the restaurant for free internet access. Lots of coffee shops nearby for breakfast. Would definitely recommend this to our friends.

My first trip to Tokyo during one of the hotest Augusts on record. Rooms are smaller than US standards but well thought out. Rooms include refrigerator and safe. Bidet toilet, deep tub shower. In addition to normal soap shampoo, conditioner and shower cap, the hotel also provides tooth brushes, razors and kimono style robes and slippers.It took me a few minutes to figure out how to turn on the lights. You place your door key card in a slot near the entry. The A/C was slient and cooled the room down quicktly. This hotel is probably the quietest hotel room I have ever experienced. The staff was very gracious and extremely helpful. The hotel location is 2 blocks off the main Ginza boulevard. Great location because the hotel is on a small narrow side streed I think it contributes to the quiet of the neighborhood. The breakfast buffett is both Western, with eggs sausage, bacon, yogurt, cereal and Asian with miso soup, rice, fish, and tofu. Green Tea or coffee and a variety of juices. The restaurant also offers a lunch and dinner menu and has a bar in the evenings.The easiest way to get to the Narita airport to this hotel is to take the Narita Express to Yurakucho station. The hotel it is about a 10 minute walk or a quick taxi ride away from the station.There is a Starbucks on the corner as well as a McDonalds close by. I skipped them both as I can that in the US but some of my traveling mates enjoyed getting their latte fix in the morning.I would stay at this hotel again.

We arrived at tokyo narita airport and found the aiport bus to tokyo the best way to travel......however, the bus didnt drop-off at our hotel but we thought, we can easily walk to our hotel from the last drop-off.........little did we know that the address in tokyo are prob the most unorganised, difficult address's to find in the world! we walked and walked and walked (with our large suitcases) down the most busy shopping street in ginza and found a starbucks - who didnt speak any english but managed to use hand gestures to help us find our hotel.....across the road! so eventually when we arrived, the hotel was modern and high rise (as all the buildings in tokyo) and the staff were friendly and helpful. We got an upgrade to a suite as it was our honeymoon so we had a separate bedroom with double bed and average furniture and coffee and tea facilities. The bathroom was modern and spacious and the toilet was fab......seat warmer, water spray etc. this is the norm in toliets throughout tokyo - public toilets and pub toilets are so clean and pleasent compared to the typical english pub toliet!!!!We were room only so having starbucks and new yorkers cafe around the corner was a great, a coffee and a douhnut is def a holiday breakfast in my eyes and a great start to the sight-seeing day! The hotel had a french themed restaruant, which looked lovely and served breakfast, lunch and dinner but we didnt go in coz there were just so much to do away from the hotel it was just a bed and a base for us really. The hotel as got to be one of the best locations in tokyo, in the heart of ginza and the shopping heaven! very much like the heart of new york, the same atmosphere and busy-ness and great to experience the day to day life of a japanese business-person. There were lots of tourists but mostly japanese rather than wetsern and after a few hours in tokyo you can see why........everything is in japanese........doh.....i feel abit nieve now we have been and come back to think everything else really, we english are guilty of expecting everything to be in the home-tongue and english but not in toyko. And on reflection is its apeal and charm but when its nearly midnight and you are struggling to find something to eat for dinner it can get you down! So my advice is to learn at least conversation japanese or to be able to read a menu in japanese to meet them halfway.After that slight drawback we still saw and experienced everything we wanted to and had the best honeymoon! A few bits and bobs about the city......go to tokyo bay, a beach and cafe's and boat trips are ace. The imperial palace is great, takes you away from the city and gives you a cultural insight to the city too. We also went to Ueno Park, which was lovely but much more touristy - the zoo was good and seeing the temple and pergoda was lovely. We got around on the metro everyday - and night - which was great, easy to use and from the hotel you have three different stations and about 6 different metro lines to choose from so you can get anywhere you want! A night at reponggi hills complex is also worth a visit - modern, gorg restaruants and bars. I would love to go back to tokyo but i will def learn some japanese before i go!

Our family ( me, my husband and our 3 kids) stayed at this hotel in July 2006 and again in February 2007 as part of our visit to the Sapporo Snow Festival in Hokkaido. The hotel is in a great location where we can walk about 10 mins from the nearest JR station where we got off the Narita express. The underground metro station is just at the corner of the hotel. Although, the underground metro is a bit more expensive than the JR, we found that it's more convenient for our family which have 3 small kids (age 9, 6 and 4) as it's station is less crowded than the JR's. From the hotel, it is also a short walk to the other underground station which we took the train to Haneda airport for a flight to Hokkaido.We booked connecting rooms. Rooms are nice, clean and very small. Anyway, we understand that this is Ginza (the most expensive area of Tokyo). The most impressing thing about the hotel is its staffs. Before my trip started, I had booked a hotel in Hokkaido with one of the Japanese website which I used for the first time. I was not sure about the booking so I emailed Mercure Ginza asking for some suggestions. Without my request, one of the staff had called the hotel in Hokkaido and confirmed everything for us. This is really impressed me. I plan to go to Japan again next year for Tateyama - Japan Alps and will definetly stay at the Mercure Ginza Hotel again as part of the trip.

We stayed at the Mercure Ginza July 12-18, 2007. This great little hotel is tucked away behind the Matsuya Department Store just off the main Ginza St. Rooms are compact, yet highly functional and comfortable. We were on the 8th floor, and it was very quiet. Easy to walk to all great Ginza shopping, and to the Tokyo Station. Great rates, and their breakfast is filling and has lots of choices, Western or Japanese! Can't go wrong here.

Booked this place via the accor.com web site which, in my opinion, provides the best web deals. Good location right in Ginza - not the most happening part of Tokyo, that's for sure, but it was very convenient for subway and train access, plus the local department stores all have basement food courts with incredibe food at good value. Good coffee places nearby for your morning fix. I liked the local restaurants in the area - we tried everything from noodle places to sushi to teppanyaki and if Tokyo is supposed to be super-expensive on food these places certainly were not. The rooms were huge and I loved the heated toilet seats and the mirror that was always clear no matter how much steam was in the room. It's those little things that make Japan so great!

Excellent hotel in the middle of Ginza. Great location easy to find your way around. Very helpful and very friendly staff. Standard rooms are rather small and therefore it is advisable to reserve a deluxe room. Rooms on the 12th floor are very quiet.

Only half of the taxi drivers will find it without mistake, but it is right there in the centre of Ginza, one block from Ginza dori. . A reasonably priced 4 star hotel , directly behind Matsuya department store and with underground access to the Yurakucho line. Expect perfect French service with that special Japanese smile added to. Europeans, used to the portfolio of Accor chain, feel at home from the first minute. As a welcome gift we received French biscuits from a top brand French pastry shop nearby.Small reception and lobby on 2nd floor (use the elevator !). Use the free internet desk and (like many French expatriates) have a lunch in their French restaurant before strolling over to Luis Vuitton (just around the corner) or Printemps department store. Many French companies having their offices around this place, hold their business meetings there.The rooms are European size, the furniture is new, pictures and decoration deliver some mixed Tokyo/Paris-atmosphere. Very comfortable bathroom (incl. Electronic WC). French luxury stores as well as 24 h shops, coffeeshops and fast food chains around.Most of Ginza offices (e.g. Renault Nissan) in walking distance. 5 min. by taxi to Tokyo station. From there you can take the airport bus or train to Narita or stay overnight at Mercure Narita hotel for an early morning flight.Highly recommendable !

Excellent location for the price, walk straight out to Ginza shopping district. Expect Ginza to be like any shopping highstreet - as close to paris or London in shopping choice, not as nice as Michigan Av Chicargo IL. Very Spectacular when lit at night.Hotel staff very polite helpful, room upgrade given as we had large luggage and a stroller, however extra £20 added to have a bed for little one - despite having booked this - advised no way H&S would allow extra bed in first room. Bathrooms clean lots of towels/toiletries. Small - but more space than we were expecting for the money. Hotel restuarant was OK not great - very strange take on French Food (not really remotely french)Use the coach service to the airport terminal in the centre of Tokyo to get out to the airport - cheap regular and runs ontime.

Our stay at the Mercure was excellent. The rooms are a good size for Tokyo and spotlessly clean. The staff was courteous and spoke excellent English. As for the location, it is literally a 2 minute walk from Ginza dori, the main street in Ginza, a very posh district in Tokyo full of designer shops, eateries and neon lights at night. Recommended!

Our family with 3 adults and 3 kids (Age7,6 and 4) stay in 2 cconnecting rooms. The room was very clean and the decoration are in good condition. However if you have big suitcases beware of the tiny room (which are all the same in tokyo). The location of the hotel are excelllent. There is starbuck around the corner and Mcdonald is on the ground floor of the hotel. The big deparment store (Matsugaya) is 2 blocks away.We came from Narita by airport limusine, get off at Tokyo station and take a taxi ( one taxi is enough for our group!!!!) It cost about 700 yen only. I do recommend every one to stay at this hotel but don't carry large suitecase.

We were very happy with this hotel. Number one on our list of reasons was the service. Everyone at the desk was so helpful and friendly. They all spoke English quite well. Our luggage was delayed, and the staff went out of their way to help us, even arranging for our luggage to be transfered when it was delivered by the airlines to the wrong hotel. They were also great about helping us map out directions to various sights etc. We liked the location of the hotel. It was 5 minutes taxi ride from Tokyo station, making access eay from the hotel to the Narita Express and other trains for trips outside of Tokyo. The Ginza area was fun, with lots of stores, galleries, places to eat. The hotel was close to 3 subway lines. The room, while not huge, was a decent size. We didn't like the step up to the bathroom, which seems to be the design in Japanese hotels. We also found this in our hotel in Kyoto, but the ste up at the Mercure was steeper. We had breakfast at the hotel, which weas quite anice buffet. We were able to get a discounted rate on the room and breakfast by contacting the reservation desk atby e-mail at the hotel directly. Anyhow, we would definately stay there again-wish we were going back soon! P.S. We had a non-smoking room and did not encounter any problems as outlined in one of the posts we read here.

Hotel central for the shopping district of Ginza and the local attractions.Located in nice quiet street and you can gain access to hotel from subway direct to hotel reception.Free internet access as internet cafes quite scarse.Good room size but no drawers for clothing.Bathroom very good size and modern.Room had beautiful decor,very quite hotel never heard any neighbours in other rooms.

I really enjoyed my stay at the Mercure Ginza. This is a quiet hotel just off the main Ginza-dori, quite a charming area with small boutiques, coffee shops and a fruit stand on the block. Subway station accessible from the basement level. The staff were courteous, my room was very clean and a decent size by Tokyo standards. Very comfortable mattress. Good breakfast buffet. I have stayed at more expensive hotels in Tokyo, but prefer the Mercure Ginza.

We had a very enjoyable stay. The room was a good size, clean and tastefully decorated. Good location for shopping within the Ginza district of Tokyo. Very convenient to travel elsewhere with easy access to the trains. We would recommend it.

I booked this hotel room as part of a package. I read the reviews on this site and thought it was a good bet. When I booked it I strongly requested a non-smoking room.When we checked in I asked whether this had been honoured and the woman on the front desk assured me we were in a nonsmoking room on a non-smoking floor.We went to the room (on the 3rd floor) and everything was good. Clean, comfy bed, nice bathroom. The room is very small but adequate for 3 star. The next day however, things started to go bad. They only give you the bare minimum, one towel each, they don't replace the used shampoo and I had to ask for it. The TV has only 1 English channel (CNN). I am not there for the TV by any means but it is nice to watch a bit before going to sleep of a night. The worst however was that when we got back into the room on the second night it reeked of smoke! So much that went we both walked in we started coughing. We had been given a room that had a door into the next room. This was locked but I think the smoke was getting underneath the door or coming through the air-conditioning system, I am not sure.I rang up reception very confused as we had been told it was a nonsmoking floor and they said that no, I was in a smoking room on a smoking floor. When I said that obviously I had been told a lie then, they refused to acknowledge this or apologize. I requested another room and they said this was not possible. I asked for compensation of some kind and they said that was not possible either. In the end they gave me 1 hour later checkout. Not much good as far as I am concerned. We went out for dinner and they said they would come in and air out the room. When we came back it was a bit better, but could still smell the smoke. We were woken up though at about 6 am the next morning from the really strong smell of smoke. Obviously someone had got up pretty early in the room next to us. Now I understand that sometimes it is not possible to give everyone a non-smoking room, but if you are going to put non smokers into a smoking room you have to at least make sure that they are able to stay in there comfortably. It was so bad I developed a sore throat and had to leave the room.I will never be going back to this place and would not recommend it to anyone.
The location is just amazing when we were ready to finish shopping at the end of our trip. The room is new and clean ... what can we ask for?
user_name:
pollyanywhere
New York City, New York

review_body: Lots of other comments tell you about the high standard of the rooms. I just want to repeat how wonderfully situated this hotel is. Just around the corner and you are on the main department store strip in Tokyo - their equivalent of Midtown Manhattan. Three metro stations to choose from (I don't think we ever used the one in the basement) plus a stop on the JR Yamanote line about five minutes walk away. Ten minutes walk to the Tsukiji Fish market. We only tried the buffet breakfast once as it was quite expensive - you need to be very hungry for it to be worthwhile; it's more like a brunch. However on our other seven days there we had coffee and croissants or Danish in a different café every day. Do note that taxi drivers don't know this hotel and even their little Japanese map on the website doesn't help much. I ended up giving the driver instructions when we arrived the first day. I used to ask them to bring us to the Matsuya dept store and we would walk the rest of the way (two blocks, and Ginza blocks are much, much narrower than NY ones). So I would thoroughly recommend this hotel.

I loved this hotel! The staff was warm and friendly and spoke excellent English. The food in the restaurant was excellent. The room was adorable and the bed absolutely comfortable. There's a mini-bar with a good assortment of drinks and some snacks. A tea/coffee maker and lovely tea set/service. A writing desk. Flat screen tv. LAN connection $5 U.S. per day. Excellent location right above a metro line and around the corner from a department store with a killer basement food shop. AM/PM market and a couple other local 7-11 type stores very nearby. Quiet rooms. I would gladly stay here again and pay even more to do so!

This is a really nice hotel for its price, and had a large amount of non-smoking rooms available. The management and staff were extremely courteous. They answered all of our email and phone inquiries immediately in fluent English, and were very accommodating when it came to our requests.The rooms were immaculate and stocked with a mini-bar and tiny refrigerator, a hot-tea pot with cups and tea, and all the bathroom amenities you could need (including toothbrush/paste, slippers, hairbrush, yukata, etc.). The beds we had were very firm, and the rooms are a bit small, compared to US hotels, but that's normal for Japan.We didn't eat in their on-site French restaurant, but they provided coupons for guests of the hotel to eat breakfast there.There is a subway station directly beneath the hotel, which makes travel extremely convenient. For other lines, subway stations are within 2-3 blocks.The Ginza department stores and other fancy shops and restaurants are 2-3 short blocks away, as well.We will definitely stay here again!

This was our first time in Tokyo and we picked our hotel well!! We had a free upgrade (we were on our honeymoon) and had a nice big, tastefully decorated room with a big bed, big telly and well equiped bathroom. The staff were all very friendly and completely unobtrusive. The only small gripe is that we found it quite hard to find and the hotels website didn't really make this much easier (no Japanese address for example, so we couldn't really jump into a cab). For reference, if you get to the area and go into Ginza Itchome (I think its called that) metro station and head for exit 11, you'll be right next to/under it. We had vouchers for money off breakfast which we only used once as it was still quite expensive. There are lots of combinis and starbucks nearby so brakfast won't be a problem. So all in all a very positve experience, so much so that when we had a bad hotel experience in Nikko, we got online and bookd ourselves a room here again. Would definately stay here again.
