This is a nice hotel in a good location in central Tokyo. It's clearly a "Western" chain hotel, but staff are still helpful and the rooms a good size. The rooms have a rather modern decor that is unusual in Japan and, while maybe not to my taste, a nice change from the typical business hotel. I paid 16100 for a single room including breakfast, which is a reasonable deal for central Tokyo. The breakfast was not the best I had in Japan, but acceptable. High-speed in-room internet is an extra 500 yen per day.I walked to the hotel in about 15 minutes from Tokyo JR station (although this might not be the best idea with a lot of luggage). There's also several metro stops right nearby, but it seemed to me a lot of trouble for such a short distance.The area is a very good base for exploring Tokyo, walking distance to many of the sights and, as mentioned, within easy reach of both the metro and the trains.

it was our first time in tokyo and what a brilliant choice this hotel was! we had a free up-grade on arrival and the staff were absolutely wonderful. the rooms were clean, tidy and a great bathroom with a hyper-modern Japanese toilet. located right above an underground station and a mc donald's (for those late night burgers) and in the heart of ginza it was a winner. quiet rooms enabled a good night's sleep. i am returning to tokyo later on this year and guess where i'll be staying?! mercure ginza.

we would recommend the mercure ginza at any time to business and leisure travellers alike. don't bother looking any further: just enjoy your stay at the mercure ginza! (i have not been paid by them to write this review, btw... ;-) )anyway, here the review comes - we were very impressed by our room at the mercure ginza hotel:- pretty big room (>20 sq. meters)- huge bed- space toilet- heated bathroom mirror (great feature when steam builds up)- very quiet- supplies provided (shaving kit, slippers, kimono, etc.)- big flat screen tv- (really) easy to use alarm clock- high speed internet (LAN, no WiFi, Y500/day)- free daily english newspaper (int'l herald tribune)as it was our first trip to japan we were especially keen on easy accessibility of the hotel. took the keisei limited express from narita to ueno, then changed to the ginza line, stepped off at ginza station (exit #13), first right, second left, a mere 3 minute walk. have not used the metro line that runs through the basement of the hotel, though. ginza is a very posh, clean neighbourhood, we felt very safe, even late at night. for those who can't help it there are the golden arches and starby nearby. very convenient: a 24h convenience store is just round the corner as is a huge array of soda machines.sightseeing from the mercure ginza is a piece of cake. tsukiji fish market is a mere 15 minute walk away (go early, very early, e.g. 4am), akihabara, shibuya, roppongi, emperor's palace, asakusa and many more are also within easy reach. (btw. have you ever considered walking tokyo instead of taking the metro all the time? it's a great way to soak up all the action.)

Mercure Ginza is a good hotel in an excellent location. It is walking distance from the JR rail line at Yurakucho and has access to the metro through the hotel basement level to Ginza Itchome station. The rooms are smallish but clean and comfortable. They also supply free internet access near reception which is always good to let people back home know you are still alive. Breakfast at the hotel was reasonably priced using the 500 yen discount vouchers provided at check-in. The staff spoke good English and were always polite and helpful whenever we needed assistance. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a well priced hotel in central Tokyo.

While I never used the subway line in the basement, you are only a few steps from the Ginza line and a short cab ride to Tokyo Station. Plenty of big shopping centres with food courts in their basements. Starbucks and McDonald's a stone's throw away for those who cannot cope. Very quiet area and a quiet hotel with a special women's floor. Rooms are big. Bathrooms are nice - super deluxe Japanese toilets with heated seats are not too shabby either.

We were pleasantly surprised at the modern decor of the hotel lobby and the room we were staying in. The staff attended to us at the reception spoke perfect English (surprise surprise!) and the check in was swift. Internet service is complimentary. The room is very clean, new, modern and very comfortable. Coffee and tea is provided free of charge. The bed is large (despite the impression given by some reviewers about hotels in Japan that beds are usually short). Kimono like bath robes are provided. The best is the automatic toilet bowl that provides bidet and shower for your bottom after your visit to the toilet and automatically warms up the seat when you sit on it. The warming feature is useful as it was cold during winter when we visited Japan.We have travelled to many places and we both agree that this hotel is almost perfect for us - clean, efficient, good service, central location (lots of shopping and food around hotel) and quiet.

Wonderful little boutique hotel. Excellent location near several subway stops. Right off of Tokyo's equivalent of NYC's Fifth Avenue. Helpful staff. Clean, largish rooms with flat-screen, plasma tvs. No views to speak of. Check for discount rates. Would stay there again.
